<html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Battleship</i> (film)</h1>
<p><i><b>Battleship</b></i> is a 2012 American <a href="/wiki/Military_science_fiction" title="Military science fiction">military science fiction</a> <a href="/wiki/Action_film" title="Action film">action</a> <a href="/wiki/War" title="War">war</a> <a href="/wiki/Film" title="Film">film</a> loosely inspired by <a href="/wiki/Battleship_(game)" title="Battleship (game)">the classic board game</a>. The film was directed by <a href="/wiki/Peter_Berg" title="Peter Berg">Peter Berg</a> and released by <a href="/wiki/Universal_Studios" title="Universal Studios">Universal Pictures</a>. It was also the only <a href="/wiki/Hasbro" title="Hasbro">Hasbro</a> property to be produced in association with <a href="/wiki/Dentsu" title="Dentsu">Dentsu Inc.</a>, which left <a href="/wiki/NBCUniversal_Entertainment_Japan" title="NBCUniversal Entertainment Japan">NBCUniversal Entertainment Japan</a> before being spun off as a separate company in February 17, 2014. The film stars <a href="/wiki/Taylor_Kitsch" title="Taylor Kitsch">Taylor Kitsch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liam_Neeson" title="Liam Neeson">Liam Neeson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Skarsg%C3%A5rd" title="Alexander Skarsgrd">Alexander Skarsgrd</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rihanna" title="Rihanna">Rihanna</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Tui" title="John Tui">John Tui</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Decker" title="Brooklyn Decker">Brooklyn Decker</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tadanobu_Asano" title="Tadanobu Asano">Tadanobu Asano</a>.</p>
<p>The film was originally planned to be released in 2011, but was rescheduled to April 11, 2012, in the United Kingdom and May 18, 2012, in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> The film's world premiere was in Tokyo, Japan, on April 3, 2012.</p>
<p>It received negative reviews, but did well at the box office grossing over 300 million</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>In 2005, scientists discover an extrasolar planet, which they name Planet G, believed to have <a href="/wiki/Habitable_zone" title="Habitable zone" class="mw-redirect">conditions nearly identical to Earth</a>. In 2006, <a href="/wiki/NASA" title="NASA">NASA</a> built a transmission device in <a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">Hawaii</a> that is five times more powerful than any before it, and a program to contact the planet began; it was known as "The Beacon Project". Meanwhile, slacker Alex Hopper gets arrested while attempting to impress Sam Shane, daughter of <a href="/wiki/Commander,_U.S._Pacific_Fleet" title="Commander, U.S. Pacific Fleet">U.S. Pacific Fleet commander</a> <a href="/wiki/Admiral_(United_States)" title="Admiral (United States)">Admiral</a> Terrance Shane. Infuriated at Alex's lack of motivation, Stone Hopper, Alex's older brother and a naval officer, forces him to also sign up for the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Navy" title="U.S. Navy" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Navy</a>.</p>
<p>In 2012, Alex is a hothead and disrespectful <a href="/wiki/Lieutenant_(navy)" title="Lieutenant (navy)">lieutenant</a> and Tactical Action Officer aboard the <a href="/wiki/Arleigh_Burke-class_destroyer" title="Arleigh Burke-class destroyer"><i>Arleigh Burke</i>-class destroyer</a> <a href="/wiki/USS_John_Paul_Jones_(DDG-53)" title="USS John Paul Jones (DDG-53)">USS<i>John Paul Jones</i></a>, while Stone is a <a href="/wiki/Commander_(United_States)" title="Commander (United States)">commander</a> and the Commanding Officer of <a href="/wiki/USS_Sampson_(DDG-102)" title="USS Sampson (DDG-102)">USS<i>Sampson</i></a>. Alex is in a relationship with Sam and is in danger of being <a href="/wiki/Military_discharge" title="Military discharge">discharged</a> from the Navy. Their ships join the <a href="/wiki/Exercise_RIMPAC#RIMPAC_2012" title="Exercise RIMPAC">2012 Rim of the Pacific Exercise (RIMPAC)</a> in Hawaii.</p>
<p>During the exercises, five alien spacecraft arrive in response to the NASA signal. One of their ships (a communications ship) collides with a satellite and crashes in <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a>, causing heavy casualties and damages while the other four (a Mothership and three warships with red, green and blue sidelights) land in the water near Hawaii. <i>Sampson</i>, <i>John Paul Jones</i>, and the <a href="/wiki/Japan_Maritime_Self-Defense_Force" title="Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force">JMSDF</a> <a href="/wiki/Kong%C5%8D-class_destroyer" title="Kong-class destroyer"><i>Kong</i>-class destroyer</a> <i><a href="/wiki/JDS_My%C5%8Dk%C5%8D" title="JDS Myk">Myk</a></i> are ordered to investigate. Upon arrival at the indicated location, they discover a massive floating structure. Alex and two crew members, Raikes and Beast, are sent to approach the structure in an armed <a href="/wiki/Zodiac_Marine_%26_Pool" title="Zodiac Marine &amp; Pool" class="mw-redirect">Zodiac</a>.</p>
<p>When Alex touches the structure, it knocks him away, and generates a massive <a href="/wiki/Force_shield" title="Force shield" class="mw-redirect">force field</a> that encloses the Hawaiian islands, all the alien warships and separates the three ships from the RIMPAC fleet. The three alien warships appear from underwater and face the three Navy ships in a defensive posture. <i>Sampson</i> issues a blast from its fog horn, but the alien warships answer it with a damaging sonic blast, shattering all the glass on the ship's bridge. After a warning shot from <i>John Paul Jones</i>, the alien warship monitors reevaluates the Earth ships' <a href="/wiki/Identification_friend_or_foe" title="Identification friend or foe">friend or foe</a> status, changing the color for the Navy ships from green to red and respond with shots of their own. In the ensuing engagement, both the <i>Sampson</i> and the <i>Myk</i> are sunk, and the <i>John Paul Jones</i> is damaged with both Commanding and Executive Officers killed.</p>
<p>Alex sees his brother die in the explosion in <i>Sampson</i> and returns to his ship. Being the most senior officer left on the ship, he is forced to take command, to the disbelief of the crew. Alex orders an attack, but Beast manages to calm him down. They recover the survivors from <i>Myk</i>, including Captain Nagata with whom Alex is in a rivalry. The alien warships remain in a defensive posture but do not engage the <i>John Paul Jones</i> in a battle. The Mothership launches three shredder-drones towards Hawaii. These drones attack and destroy military and civilian infrastructure installations on the island of <a href="/wiki/Oahu" title="Oahu">Oahu</a>, killing some civilians along the way.</p>
<p>In Oahu, Sam, a <a href="/wiki/Physical_therapist" title="Physical therapist" class="mw-redirect">physical therapist</a>, is accompanying retired <a href="/wiki/U.S._Army" title="U.S. Army" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Army</a> veteran and double amputee Mick Canales, on a mountain hike to help him adapt to his prosthetic legs. Sam and Mick run into some police officers who order them to off the mountain. The officers head up the mountain, but they are ambushed and killed by aliens. Later, Sam and Mick run into scientist Cal Zapata, who works at the communications array and informs them that the aliens had killed his grad student and took over the communications array, and then they realize that the aliens are modifying it to reestablish communications with their home planet.</p>
<p>On the <i>John Paul Jones</i>, naval personnel capture an unconscious alien from the communications ship. The alien awakens, attacks Alex and forms a brief telepathic link with him. He learns how the aliens have successfully attacked and conquered other planets. Other aliens arrive to rescue their captured comrade. One alien stays onboard, and Alex kills it by tricking it into the firing line of a <a href="/wiki/5%22/54_caliber_Mark_45_gun" title='5"/54 caliber Mark 45 gun'>5"/54 caliber Mark 45 gun</a>. Investigating the captured alien's helmet, Ordy is able to determine that the aliens are sensitive to sunlight.</p>
<p>Ashore, Zapata steals a spectrum analyzer from the aliens, and though he is caught by an alien, successfully escapes. Using it, Sam and Mick to contact the <i>John Paul Jones</i> crews and inform them that in four hours, the aliens will be able to contact their planet.</p>
<p>The <i>John Paul Jones</i> prepare to retaliate. As the force field has disabled their radar functions, Nagata suggests using <a href="/wiki/National_Oceanic_and_Atmospheric_Administration" title="National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration">NOAA</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Tsunami_warning_system" title="Tsunami warning system">tsunami warning buoys</a> around Hawaii to track the alien warships. Using this strategy, the <i>John Paul Jones</i> destroys and sinks two of the three alien warships. At dawn, they manage to make the third warship face East, where Alex and Nagata shoot out its bridge windows. Blinded by sunlight, the warship's crew is disorganized. Seizing the chance, the <i>John Paul Jones</i> successfully destroy it, but the Mothership retaliates with shredder-drones. The crew abandons the <i>John Paul Jones</i>, which is rapidly destroyed by shredder-drones and sunk.</p>
<p>Alex, along with the survivors of the <i>John Paul Jones</i> and <i>Myk</i> return to Pearl Harbor and commandeer the <a href="/wiki/USS_Missouri_(BB-63)" title="USS Missouri (BB-63)">USS<i>Missouri</i></a>, a decommissioned <a href="/wiki/Battleship" title="Battleship">battleship</a> turned into a <a href="/wiki/Museum_ship" title="Museum ship">museum ship</a>. They reactivate the battleship with the aid of the retired veterans preserving her, and confront the massive floating structure, which is revealed to be part of the submerged Mothership. In the ensuing battle, the <i>Missouri'</i>s <a href="/wiki/16%22/50_caliber_Mark_7_gun" title='16"/50 caliber Mark 7 gun'>16-inch main guns</a> severely damage the Mothership, disabling the force field in the process. Meanwhile, Mick, Sam and Zapata distract the aliens near the communications array to buy the <i>Missouri</i> more time. The Mothership reactivates and prepares to launch shredder-drones against the <i>Missouri</i>. Instead of shooting the Mothership, Alex uses the last shell to destroy the communications array on the island, cutting the aliens' contact with their home planet. Before the <i>Missouri</i> is destroyed by the shredder-drones, <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australian</a> <a href="/wiki/F/A-18" title="F/A-18" class="mw-redirect">F/A-18</a> fighters from the RIMPAC fleet arrive, destroying the shredder-drones and the Mothership, eliminating the alien threat.</p>
<p>A ceremony is held to honor the Navy personnel, where Alex is promoted to <a href="/wiki/Lieutenant_commander_(United_States)" title="Lieutenant commander (United States)">lieutenant commander</a>. He is presented with a <a href="/wiki/Silver_Star" title="Silver Star">Silver Star</a> and his brother's posthumous <a href="/wiki/Navy_Cross_(United_States)" title="Navy Cross (United States)" class="mw-redirect">Navy Cross</a>. After the ceremony, Alex is given an offer to become a <a href="/wiki/Navy_SEAL" title="Navy SEAL" class="mw-redirect">Navy SEAL</a>, and then asks Admiral Shane for his daughter's hand in marriage. The Admiral initially refuses but invites Alex to lunch to discuss the matter, referencing how Alex and Sam met.</p>
<p>In a <a href="/wiki/Post-credits_scene" title="Post-credits scene">post-credits scene</a>, three teenagers and a <a href="/wiki/Handyman" title="Handyman">handyman</a> in <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a> discover a crashed alien pod. When they open it, an alien hand reaches out, and they run off in terror.</p>
<p><i>Battleship</i> was to begin filming in <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Gold_Coast,_Queensland" title="Gold Coast, Queensland">Gold Coast</a> in 2010, but the production company changed location due to a lack of Australian government tax incentives and a high estimated budget of $209 million.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Filming took place in the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">Hawaiian</a> islands of <a href="/wiki/Maui" title="Maui">Maui</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oahu" title="Oahu">Oahu</a>, as well as in <a href="/wiki/Sherman_Oaks,_California" title="Sherman Oaks, California" class="mw-redirect">Sherman Oaks, California</a> to do a few apartment scenes and in <a href="/wiki/Playa_del_Rey,_California" title="Playa del Rey, California" class="mw-redirect">Playa del Rey, California</a> where they filmed a driving scene along with a shootout.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> Further filming was also done on the <a href="/wiki/USS_Missouri_(BB-63)" title="USS Missouri (BB-63)">USS Missouri</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> Some scenes were also filmed in <a href="/wiki/Baton_Rouge,_Louisiana" title="Baton Rouge, Louisiana">Baton Rouge</a>, <a href="/wiki/Louisiana" title="Louisiana">Louisiana</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Science_%26_Entertainment_Exchange" title="Science &amp; Entertainment Exchange">Science &amp; Entertainment Exchange</a> provided science consultation for the film.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>A <a href="/wiki/Kong%C5%8D-class_destroyer" title="Kong-class destroyer"><i>Kong</i>-class destroyer</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Japan_Maritime_Self-Defense_Force" title="Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force">Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force</a> also appeared in the film.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Jeremy_Renner" title="Jeremy Renner">Jeremy Renner</a> was originally considered for the role of Hopper, but the actor chose to star in a <a href="/wiki/Paul_Thomas_Anderson" title="Paul Thomas Anderson">Paul Thomas Anderson</a> drama filming at roughly the same time.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-THR_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-THR-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup> In April 2010, it was reported that Taylor Kitsch had been cast as Alex Hopper,<sup id="cite_ref-THR_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-THR-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup> Alexander Skarsgrd played his brother Stone Hopper, Brooklyn Decker stars as Sam, Hopper's fiancee and Liam Neeson as Admiral Shane, Sam's father and Hopper's superior officer.<sup id="cite_ref-comingsoon_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-comingsoon-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup> Barbadian R&amp;B singer Rihanna makes her acting debut in the film, as a sailor.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup> In an interview with <i><a href="/wiki/GQ" title="GQ">GQ</a></i>, Berg explained how he came up with the idea to cast her. He realized she could act after seeing her 2009 interview about the Chris Brown assault on <i><a href="/wiki/Good_Morning_America" title="Good Morning America">Good Morning America</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Diane_Sawyer" title="Diane Sawyer">Diane Sawyer</a> during which he found her "intelligent and articulate", and her appearance on <i><a href="/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live" title="Saturday Night Live">Saturday Night Live</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup> She accepted the role because she wanted "to do something badass" and also because it wasn't a role too big for her to play.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tadanobu_Asano" title="Tadanobu Asano">Tadanobu Asano</a> also has a role in the film as the commander of a Japanese <i>Kong</i>-class destroyer. Double amputee U.S. Army <a href="/wiki/Colonel" title="Colonel">Colonel</a> <a href="/wiki/Gregory_D._Gadson" title="Gregory D. Gadson">Gregory Gadson</a>, who had never acted before, plays <a href="/wiki/Lieutenant_colonel" title="Lieutenant colonel">LTC</a> Mick Canales.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> He was cast after Berg saw a picture of him in the <i><a href="/wiki/National_Geographic_(magazine)" title="National Geographic (magazine)">National Geographic Magazine</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film marks the reunion between former co-stars Kitsch and Jesse Plemons, who previously worked together on Berg's TV series <i><a href="/wiki/Friday_Night_Lights_(TV_series)" title="Friday Night Lights (TV series)">Friday Night Lights</a></i>. Berg said he loves working with friends and explained he knew how comfortable Kitsch was with Plemons, "I know that hes really good for Taylor and he makes Taylor better. So, I wrote that whole part for Jesse." He added, "I never thought of it as a <i>Friday Night Lights</i> reunion. I thought of it as protection, bringing a trusted family member in."<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>U.S. Navy sailors were used as extras in various parts of this film. Sailors from assorted commands in Navy Region Hawaii assisted with line handling to take <a href="/wiki/USS_Missouri_(BB-63)" title="USS Missouri (BB-63)"><i>Missouri</i></a> in and out of port for a day of shooting in mid 2010. A few months later, the production team put out a casting call for sailors stationed at various sea commands at Naval Station Mayport, Florida to serve as extras.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup> Sailors were also taken from various ships stationed at <a href="/wiki/Naval_Station_Mayport" title="Naval Station Mayport">Naval Station Mayport</a>, Jacksonville, Florida: <a href="/wiki/USS_Hu%C3%A9_City_(CG-66)" title="USS Hu City (CG-66)">USS<i>Hu City</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/USS_Carney_(DDG-64)" title="USS Carney (DDG-64)">USS<i>Carney</i></a> and USS <a href="/wiki/USS_Vicksburg_(CG-69)" title="USS Vicksburg (CG-69)"><i>Vicksburg</i></a> were some of the ships that provided sailors.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><span id="Soundtrack"></span><span id="Score"></span></p>
<p>Due to his success with the <i><a href="/wiki/Transformers_(film_series)" title="Transformers (film series)">Transformers</a></i> franchise, composer <a href="/wiki/Steve_Jablonsky" title="Steve Jablonsky">Steve Jablonsky</a> was chosen to score the official soundtrack. The soundtrack features original compositions from Jablonsky and features rock guitarist <a href="/wiki/Tom_Morello" title="Tom Morello">Tom Morello</a> from <a href="/wiki/Rage_Against_The_Machine" title="Rage Against The Machine" class="mw-redirect">Rage Against The Machine</a>. Director Peter Berg stated:</p>
<p>"Working with composers often is a really frustrating experience because you speak a different language and, oftentimes, they take two or three jobs, at the same time. They're difficult and pretentious and they're tormented artists. I'm not going to name names, but most of them are. One guy who isn't is <a href="/wiki/Hans_Zimmer" title="Hans Zimmer">Hans Zimmer</a>, who taught Steve Jablonsky. We had a couple of meetings and I came up with this idea. The day I met with him, I had had an <a href="/wiki/Magnetic_resonance_imaging" title="Magnetic resonance imaging">MRI</a> for my neck, and they make that really scary sound. I was like, "I just had this MRI, and when I was in there, I was thinking about the aliens, and it was really scary." And he was like, "Oh, that's awesome!" He went and recorded MRIs and made music out of MRIs, and that's the theme of the aliens in our film. He is no drama, and just goes and gets it done. The score is big and awesome and scary and driving. At times, it's very simple and acoustic and touching and emotional. He's the best I've ever worked with."<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>All songs written and composed by Steve Jablonsky except where noted.</p>
<p>The film's world premiere took place in Tokyo on April 3, 2012. The event was attended by director <a href="/wiki/Peter_Berg" title="Peter Berg">Peter Berg</a>, actors <a href="/wiki/Taylor_Kitsch" title="Taylor Kitsch">Taylor Kitsch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Decker" title="Brooklyn Decker">Brooklyn Decker</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Skarsg%C3%A5rd" title="Alexander Skarsgrd">Alexander Skarsgrd</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rihanna" title="Rihanna">Rihanna</a>. Later on they initiated a Press Tour visiting Madrid, London and Cartagena de Indias to promote the film.</p>
<p>The film earned $303,025,485, of which $65,422,625 was in North America.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film opened outside North America on Wednesday, April 11, 2012, more than five weeks before its North America release, earning $7.4 million.<sup id="cite_ref-ddln-opening_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ddln-opening-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup> Through Friday, April 13, the film had earned a 3-day total of $25 million.<sup id="cite_ref-THR-opening_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-THR-opening-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup> By the end of its opening weekend, it earned $55.2 million from 26 markets, ranking second behind the 3D re-release of <i><a href="/wiki/Titanic_(1997_film)#3D_Theatrical_Re-release" title="Titanic (1997 film)">Titanic</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>However, on its second weekend, it topped the box office outside North America, with $60 million.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup> In South Korea, it achieved the highest-grossing opening day for a non-sequel and the third-highest overall ($2.8 million).<sup id="cite_ref-THR-opening_27-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-THR-opening-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup> In comparison to other <a href="/wiki/Hasbro" title="Hasbro">Hasbro</a> films, <i>Battleship</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'s</span> opening in the UK (3.76 million) was behind the first <i><a href="/wiki/Transformers_(film)" title="Transformers (film)">Transformers</a></i> (8.72 million), but did better than <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_The_Rise_of_Cobra" title="G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra">G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra</a></i> (1.71 million).<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30"><span>[</span>30<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In North America, <i>Battleship</i> grossed $8.8 million on its opening day (Friday, May 18, 2012), with $420,000 originating from midnight showings,<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup> and finished the weekend with $25.5 million. It settled in second place for its opening day and opening weekend behind <i><a href="/wiki/Marvel%27s_The_Avengers" title="Marvel's The Avengers" class="mw-redirect">Marvel's The Avengers</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34"><span>[</span>34<span>]</span></a></sup> Its opening weekend grosses were well below the anticipated $35$40 million range that Universal and director <a href="/wiki/Peter_Berg" title="Peter Berg">Peter Berg</a> were hoping for.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35"><span>[</span>35<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film has received mixed to negative reviews from critics. <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a> has given the film an average score of 41 out of 100 based on 39 reviews.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> gives the film a score of 34% based on reviews from 209 critics, with a rating average of 4.6 out of 10. The site's consensus reads: "It may offer energetic escapism for less demanding filmgoers, but Battleship is too loud, poorly written, and formulaic to justify its expense -- and a lot less fun than its source material."<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Megan Lehmann of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter" title="The Hollywood Reporter">The Hollywood Reporter</a></i> thought that the "impressive visual effects and director <a href="/wiki/Peter_Berg" title="Peter Berg">Peter Berg</a>'s epic set pieces fight against an armada of cinematic clichs and some truly awful dialogue."<sup id="cite_ref-Lehmann_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lehmann-38"><span>[</span>38<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Empire_(film_magazine)" title="Empire (film magazine)"><i>Empire</i> magazine</a>'s Nick de Semlyen felt there was a lack of character development and memorable action shots, and sums up his review of the movie in one word: "Miss."<sup id="cite_ref-deSemlyen_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-deSemlyen-39"><span>[</span>39<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Many reviews panned the "based on a board game" concept driving the film, although some, such as Jason Di Rosso from the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Broadcasting_Corporation" title="Australian Broadcasting Corporation">Australian Broadcasting Corporation</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Radio_National" title="Radio National">Radio National</a>, claimed the ridiculousness of the setup is "either sheer joy or pure hell  depending on how seriously you take it", while de Semlyen "had to admire [the film's creators] jumping through hoops to engineer a sequence that replicates the board game."<sup id="cite_ref-deSemlyen_39-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-deSemlyen-39"><span>[</span>39<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hardie_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hardie-40"><span>[</span>40<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span>[</span>41<span>]</span></a></sup> Several compared the film to <a href="/wiki/Michael_Bay" title="Michael Bay">Michael Bay</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Transformers_(film)" title="Transformers (film)">Transformers</a></i> film series in terms of quality and cinematic style, with Giles Hardie of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Sydney_Morning_Herald" title="The Sydney Morning Herald">The Sydney Morning Herald</a></i> claiming that the movie "finds the same balance between action-packed imagination and not taking the premise seriously that made Michael Bay's original <i>Transformers</i> such a joyride."<sup id="cite_ref-Lehmann_38-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lehmann-38"><span>[</span>38<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hardie_40-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hardie-40"><span>[</span>40<span>]</span></a></sup> Andrew Harrison of <i><a href="/wiki/Q_(magazine)" title="Q (magazine)">Q</a></i> magazine called the film "crushingly stupid".<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span>[</span>42<span>]</span></a></sup> Film critic Kenneth Turan, in a review written for the <i>Los Angeles Times</i>, also expressed disappointment, criticizing the film's "humanoid aliens", stating that they are "as ungainly as the movie itself, clunking around in awkward, protective suits." He called the content "all very earnest", but added "it's not a whole lot of fun".<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span>[</span>43<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Other critics were less harsh for <i>Battleship</i>: Writing for <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i>, Steven James Snyder was somewhat positive because he had low expectations of the film. He wrote, "The creative team behind this ocean-bound thriller decided to fill the narrative black hole with a few ingredients all but absent from todays summer tent poles  namely mystery, nostalgia and a healthy dose of humility" and described it as "an unlikely mix of <i><a href="/wiki/Independence_Day_(1996_film)" title="Independence Day (1996 film)">Independence Day</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Pearl_Harbor_(film)" title="Pearl Harbor (film)">Pearl Harbor</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Jurassic_Park_(film)" title="Jurassic Park (film)">Jurassic Park</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hunt_for_Red_October_(film)" title="The Hunt for Red October (film)">The Hunt for Red October</a></i>".<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44"><span>[</span>44<span>]</span></a></sup> Giving it a B+ grade, Lisa Schwarzbaum of <i><a href="/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly" title="Entertainment Weekly">Entertainment Weekly</a></i> said, "For every line of howler dialogue that should have been sunk, there's a nice little scene in which humans have to make a difficult decision. For every stretch of generic sci-fi-via-CGI moviemaking, there's a welcome bit of wit."<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45"><span>[</span>45<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Post" title="The Washington Post">The Washington Post</a></i> gave the film a three-star rating out of four commenting it is "an invigorating blast of cinematic adrenaline".<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46"><span>[</span>46<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Roger_Ebert" title="Roger Ebert">Roger Ebert</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Chicago_Sun-Times" title="Chicago Sun-Times">Chicago Sun-Times</a></i> gave the film 2 stars out of 4, praising the climax as "an honest-to-God third act, instead of just settling for nonstop fireballs and explosions, as Bay likes to do. I don't want to spoil it for you. Let's say the Greatest Generation still has the right stuff and leave it at that."<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span>[</span>47<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Battleship</i> was released on <a href="/wiki/DVD" title="DVD">DVD</a> and <a href="/wiki/Blu-ray_disc" title="Blu-ray disc" class="mw-redirect">Blu-ray disc</a> on August 20, 2012 in the United Kingdom,<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span>[</span>56<span>]</span></a></sup> and on August 28 in the United States and Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57"><span>[</span>57<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>A video game based on the film, titled <i><a href="/wiki/Battleship_(2012_video_game)" title="Battleship (2012 video game)">Battleship: The Video Game</a></i>, was released on May 15, 2012 to coincide with the film's international release. The game was published by <a href="/wiki/Activision" title="Activision">Activision</a> and developed by <a href="/wiki/Double_Helix_Games" title="Double Helix Games">Double Helix Games</a> for <a href="/wiki/PlayStation_3" title="PlayStation 3">PlayStation 3</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wii" title="Wii">Wii</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Xbox_360" title="Xbox 360">Xbox 360</a>, and developed by Magic Pockets for <a href="/wiki/Nintendo_3DS" title="Nintendo 3DS">Nintendo 3DS</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nintendo_DS" title="Nintendo DS">Nintendo DS</a>.</p>
<p>Hasbro released several new editions of the classic board game, including an update to the regular fleet-vs.-fleet game and a "movie edition", featuring the alien vessels and a card-based play mode.</p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Goodbye Mr. Loser</i></h1>
<p><i><b>Goodbye Mr. Loser</b></i> (<a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a>: <span lang="zh"></span>; <a href="/wiki/Pinyin" title="Pinyin">pinyin</a>: <i><span lang="zh-Latn-pinyin">Xi Lu T Fnno</span></i>) is a 2015 Chinese <a href="/wiki/Comedy_film" title="Comedy film">comedy film</a> directed by Yan Fei and Peng Damo, and starring <a href="/wiki/Shen_Teng" title="Shen Teng">Shen Teng</a>, Ma Li, Yin Zheng, Ai Lun, Wang Zhi, Tian Yu, Song Yang, Chang Yuan and Li Ping.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> The film is based on a play of the same name.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> It was released on September 30, 2015. Critics claim the film to be inspired from a 1986 American film <i><a href="/wiki/Peggy_Sue_Got_Married" title="Peggy Sue Got Married">Peggy Sue Got Married</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>Unemployed amateur musician Xia Luo (, Shen Teng) attends the wedding of Qiu Ya (, Wang Zhi), his high school crush. He overdrinks, makes an inebriated declaration of love to Qiu Ya, and angers his wife Ma Dongmei (, Ma Li), who publicly shames him for being a poor provider and husband.</p>
<p>After causing chaos as his wife pursues him through the wedding hall, Xia Luo locks himself into a bathroom at the wedding venue, flies into a rage of self-hatred and passes out, waking up in his teenage body in his middle-school classroom in 1997. After impulsively beating up his teacher, setting fire to the classroom, and kissing Qiu Ya, he jumps out a window to end the dream, but after waking up in hospital still in 1997, is forced to make the best of things.</p>
<p>Although Xia Luo appears his normal teenage self to everyone else in 1997, he retains all his memories of adult life, including around twenty years of as yet unwritten pop music - which he decides to present as his own work, to gain fame and to win the heart of Qiu Ya. Over the next twenty years he becomes a pop megastar in China, taking the place of other superstar singers from the original 1990s to 2000s timeline, including 'ghostwriting' famous TV themes for pop radio and duetting with <a href="/wiki/Sarah_Brightman" title="Sarah Brightman">Sarah Brightman</a> at the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">2008 Beijing Olympic</a> opening ceremony in place of <a href="/wiki/Liu_Huan" title="Liu Huan">Liu Huan</a>.</p>
<p>Having achieved all of his ambitions including marrying Qiu Ya, Xia Luo gradually realizes that he was destined to be with Ma Dongmei - after he abandoned her in middle school in the new timeline, she nevertheless defended him from bullies and troublemakers and was forced into a simple life in a small apartment, marrying one of Xia Luo's kindly but slow-witted classmates from 1997.</p>
<p>Xia Luo makes a proposal to Ma Dongmei's husband to trade away all he owns in exchange for his wife, but the frustrated husband punches him into unconsciousness and he wakes up in a hospital bed, where it is discovered he is dying from AIDS. Ma Dongmei sings a final purloined song to him in his hospital bed, revealing that it was always her favourite (even though he was serenading Qiu Ya with it in the classroom at the time).</p>
<p>At the moment of his death, Xia Luo is thrown back into the original timeline in the wedding venue bathroom where he realizes that Ma Dongmei is the true love of his life. He runs back into the room and embraces her, which he continues to do as they are both arrested and taken to the local police station. He resumes his normal life much as before but with a new devotion to Ma Dongmei.</p>
<p>The film contains many references to Chinese popular culture in the late 1990s and early 2000s, including cameo appearances and depictions of well-known pop stars of that era. Some celebrities appear as themselves (including <a href="/wiki/Jay_Chou" title="Jay Chou">Jay Chou</a> as a talent show contestant who performed a song Xia Luo had allegedly written, in reality one that Xia Luo had plagiarized from him), whilst others are depicted through stand-ins (for instance, <a href="/wiki/Na_Ying" title="Na Ying">Miss Na</a>, who talent-spots Xia Luo in the new 1997 timeline).</p>
<p>The directors of <i>Goodbye Mr. Loser</i>, Yan Fei and Peng Damo, revealed that their film is inspired by a post on the Chinese Internet forum <a href="/wiki/Tianya_Club" title="Tianya Club">Tianya</a> in 2010, which inspired the a theater play by <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.mahuawang.cn">Mahua FunAge</a> with the same name and subsequently the directors adapted it, featuring a loser in his middle age, who magically traveled back to his school days and developed romance with his first love again.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film has grossed <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$226.6 million</span> in China and <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$228.5 million</span> worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-thenumbers_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thenumbers-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Hanna</i> (film)</h1>
<p><i><b>Hanna</b></i> is a 2011 <a href="/wiki/Action_film" title="Action film">action</a> <a href="/wiki/Thriller_(genre)" title="Thriller (genre)">thriller film</a> that contains prominent <a href="/wiki/Fairy_tale" title="Fairy tale">fairy tale</a> elements, directed by <a href="/wiki/Joe_Wright" title="Joe Wright">Joe Wright</a>. The film stars <a href="/wiki/Saoirse_Ronan" title="Saoirse Ronan">Saoirse Ronan</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Title_character" title="Title character" class="mw-redirect">title character</a>, a girl raised in the wilderness of northern Finland by her father, an ex-CIA operative (<a href="/wiki/Eric_Bana" title="Eric Bana">Eric Bana</a>), who trains her as an assassin. <a href="/wiki/Cate_Blanchett" title="Cate Blanchett">Cate Blanchett</a> is a senior CIA agent who tries to track down and eliminate the girl and her father. The soundtrack was written by <a href="/wiki/The_Chemical_Brothers" title="The Chemical Brothers">The Chemical Brothers</a>.</p>
<p><i>Hanna</i> was released in North America in April 2011 and in Europe in May 2011. The film received a positive response from critics, with reviewers praising the performances of Ronan and Blanchett as well as the action sequences and themes. The film was a commercial success, earning $63.7 million at the international box-office, against its budget of $30 million.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>Hanna Heller (<a href="/wiki/Saoirse_Ronan" title="Saoirse Ronan">Saoirse Ronan</a>) is a 15-year-old girl<sup id="cite_ref-Goundry20110512_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Goundry20110512-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup> who lives with her father, Erik Heller (<a href="/wiki/Eric_Bana" title="Eric Bana">Eric Bana</a>) in rural northern <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">Finland</a>, near <a href="/wiki/Kuusamo" title="Kuusamo">Kuusamo</a>. The film opens with her <a href="/wiki/Hunting" title="Hunting">hunting</a> and killing a <a href="/wiki/Reindeer" title="Reindeer">reindeer</a>, first by shooting it with an <a href="/wiki/Arrow" title="Arrow">arrow</a> that just misses its <a href="/wiki/Heart" title="Heart">heart</a>, and then killing it with a <a href="/wiki/Handgun" title="Handgun">handgun</a>.</p>
<p>Since the age of two, Hanna has been trained by Erik, an ex-<a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">CIA</a> operative from <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a>, to be a skilled <a href="/wiki/Assassin" title="Assassin" class="mw-redirect">assassin</a>. He teaches her hand-to-hand combat and drills her in target shooting. He left the agency, going incognito into the Arctic. Erik knows a secret that cannot become public, and is being sought by Marissa Wiegler (<a href="/wiki/Cate_Blanchett" title="Cate Blanchett">Cate Blanchett</a>), a senior CIA officer, who wants to eliminate him. Erik has trained Hanna with the intent that she will kill Marissa. Hanna reads a bloodstained <a href="/wiki/Grimms%27_Fairy_Tales" title="Grimms' Fairy Tales">Grimms' Fairy Tales</a> book frequently, has a great deal of encyclopedic knowledge, and is fluent in several languages. Due to her training away from civilization, she has never come into contact with modern <a href="/wiki/Technology" title="Technology">technology</a> or <a href="/wiki/Culture" title="Culture">culture</a>, and is unfamiliar with <a href="/wiki/Music" title="Music">music</a> or <a href="/wiki/Electricity" title="Electricity">electricity</a>. She has memorized a series of fake <a href="/wiki/Back-story" title="Back-story" class="mw-redirect">back-stories</a> for herself to be used "when the time comes".</p>
<p>One night, Hanna tells Erik that she is "ready" to face their enemies. Erik digs up a <a href="/wiki/Distress_radio_beacon" title="Distress radio beacon" class="mw-redirect">radio beacon</a> that will alert the outside world to their presence. Warning Hanna that if Marissa ever finds her, she "won't stop until you're dead. Or she is", he reluctantly allows Hanna the freedom to make her decision. After some consideration, Hanna flips the switch. Erik leaves, instructing her to meet him in <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a>. Hanna kills two of the special forces team when they enter the cabin and then waits for the rest, knowing that they will assume her father to have killed the pair before escaping.</p>
<p>Hanna is taken to an underground CIA complex. Marissa is suspicious of Hanna's request to talk to her, and sends in a body double (<a href="/wiki/Michelle_Dockery" title="Michelle Dockery">Michelle Dockery</a>) instead. Hanna asks the body double where she met her father. The double, who is being fed answers through an <a href="/wiki/Earpiece" title="Earpiece" class="mw-redirect">earpiece</a> by Marissa, answers the questions correctly, and Hanna starts to cry and crawls sobbing into the lap of the double, which makes the officials uneasy. They send soldiers and a doctor to her cell to sedate her. As they enter the cell, Hanna kills the double, and several others (stealing a handgun from one), breaks free through the <a href="/wiki/HVAC" title="HVAC">ventilation</a> system and escapes.</p>
<p>In a flashback, Marissa is seen firing at a car that is carrying Johanna Zadek, Hanna's mother; two-year-old Hanna; and Erik. The car crashes but the trio flee. Marissa follows, shooting Johanna as she lies on the ground. But Erik escapes with Hanna into the woods.</p>
<p>Hanna finds herself on the run in the <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Moroccan</a><sup id="cite_ref-Goundry20110512_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Goundry20110512-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> desert, where she meets Sebastian (<a href="/wiki/Jason_Flemyng" title="Jason Flemyng">Jason Flemyng</a>) and Rachel (<a href="/wiki/Olivia_Williams" title="Olivia Williams">Olivia Williams</a>), a bohemian <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">British</a> couple on a camper-van holiday with their teenage daughter, Sophie (<a href="/wiki/Jessica_Barden" title="Jessica Barden">Jessica Barden</a>), and their younger son, Miles (Aldo Maland). She sneaks into the family's camper-van and hitches a ferry ride to <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> with the goal of reaching <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a>. The family is nice to her, and she and Sophie become friends, and spend some time together, even sharing a kiss.</p>
<p>Marissa hires Isaacs (<a href="/wiki/Tom_Hollander" title="Tom Hollander">Tom Hollander</a>), a former agent, to capture Hanna. Hanna travels with the family as they drive north. Isaacs and two <a href="/wiki/Skinhead" title="Skinhead">skinheads</a> trail them and eventually corner Hanna and the family in <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>, but she manages to escape, killing one of the men. Marissa arrives and interrogates the British family, finding out that Hanna is heading to Berlin, her place of birth.</p>
<p>Arriving at the address her father had told her, Hanna meets with Knepfler (<a href="/wiki/Martin_Wuttke" title="Martin Wuttke">Martin Wuttke</a>), an eccentric old magician and a friend of Erik's, who lives in a <a href="/wiki/Grimms%27_Fairy_Tales" title="Grimms' Fairy Tales">Grimms' Fairy Tales</a>-themed house in an abandoned <a href="/wiki/Amusement_park" title="Amusement park">amusement park</a>. It is Hanna's 16th birthday and Knepfler makes her <a href="/wiki/Breakfast" title="Breakfast">breakfast</a>. Hanna plans a rendezvous with her father. However, Marissa and Isaacs arrive. Hanna escapes, but not before she overhears comments that suggest Erik is not her biological father.</p>
<p>Later, Hanna meets her father at her German grandmother's apartment, whom Marissa had already shot in a previous scene. Hanna demands he tell her the truth, and he admits that he is not her biological father. Erik once recruited pregnant women into a program where their children's <a href="/wiki/DNA" title="DNA">DNA</a> was enhanced in order to create <a href="/wiki/Super-soldier" title="Super-soldier" class="mw-redirect">super-soldiers</a>. The project was shut down, with almost all of its subjects eliminated.</p>
<p>Marissa and Isaacs arrive, intent on killing them; Erik acts as a distraction to allow Hanna to escape. Erik kills Isaacs in a brutal fight, but is shot by Marissa, who returns to the Grimm house. Hanna is there, having just discovered Knepfler dead. After a chase, Hanna and Marissa confront one another. Hanna pleads for the killing to end, saying she does not want to hurt anyone else. Marissa says she just wants to talk, but when Hanna starts walking away, she shoots her. Hanna responds by shooting her with an arrow she had pulled from Knepfler's body. Hanna falls to the ground, but gets up, regains her bearings and follows Marissa into a tunnel. She sees a deer, then spots Marissa fleeing up a water slide. The unarmed Hanna chases Marissa to the top of the slide's stairs, as Marissa shoots at her. Near the top, it becomes clear that Hanna's arrow did serious damage, and just as she is about to shoot Hanna, a disoriented Marissa falls and slides down the water flume, dropping her handgun. Hanna follows, picks up the dropped gun, and shoots her in the heart. This <a href="/wiki/Framing_device" title="Framing device" class="mw-redirect">bookend scene</a> mirrors the opening of the film in which Hanna hunts and kills the reindeer.</p>
<p>The film's story and script were written by <a href="/wiki/Seth_Lochhead" title="Seth Lochhead">Seth Lochhead</a> while a student at <a href="/wiki/Vancouver_Film_School" title="Vancouver Film School">Vancouver Film School</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> He wrote the original story and script <a href="/wiki/Spec_script" title="Spec script">on spec</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup> and finalized the script in 2006, with <a href="/wiki/David_Farr_(theatre_director)" title="David Farr (theatre director)">David Farr</a> providing later changes.<sup id="cite_ref-Focus_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Focus-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Danny_Boyle" title="Danny Boyle">Danny Boyle</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alfonso_Cuar%C3%B3n" title="Alfonso Cuarn">Alfonso Cuarn</a> were previously attached to direct the film, before it was confirmed that Joe Wright would direct,<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup> after Ronan prompted the producers to consider him.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film was co-produced by the US Holleran Company and German <a href="/wiki/Studio_Babelsberg" title="Studio Babelsberg" class="mw-redirect">Studio Babelsberg</a>, with financial support from various German film funds and the main distributor, <a href="/wiki/Focus_Features" title="Focus Features">Focus Features</a>, which holds the copyright to the film.<sup id="cite_ref-BFI_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BFI-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Most of the filming was done at Studio Babelsberg in <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a>, but locations also included Lake Kitka in <a href="/wiki/Kuusamo" title="Kuusamo">Kuusamo, Finland</a>, several German locations (including <a href="/wiki/Bad_T%C3%B6lz" title="Bad Tlz">Bad Tlz</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Magdeburg_Water_Bridge" title="Magdeburg Water Bridge">water bridge at Magdeburg</a>, <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6hlbrandbr%C3%BCcke" title="Khlbrandbrcke" class="mw-redirect">Khlbrandbrcke</a> and <a href="/wiki/Reeperbahn" title="Reeperbahn">Reeperbahn</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hamburg" title="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>, and various sites in Berlin, such as <a href="/wiki/Kottbusser_Tor" title="Kottbusser Tor" class="mw-redirect">Kottbusser Tor</a>, <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6rlitzer_Bahnhof_(Berlin_U-Bahn)" title="Grlitzer Bahnhof (Berlin U-Bahn)">Grlitzer Bahnhof</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spreepark" title="Spreepark">Spreepark</a><sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup>), as well as <a href="/wiki/Ouarzazate" title="Ouarzazate">Ouarzazate</a> and <a href="/wiki/Essaouira" title="Essaouira">Essaouira</a> in <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-tfs21511_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tfs21511-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup> Temperatures during the Finland shoot sometimes fell as low as 33C (27F), but Ronan said "Finland did bring out the <a href="/wiki/Fairy_tale" title="Fairy tale">fairy tale</a> aspects of the story. We were shooting on a frozen lake, surrounded by pine trees covered in snow".<sup id="cite_ref-tfs21511_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tfs21511-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Reviewers remarked that the <a href="/wiki/Setting_(fiction)" title="Setting (fiction)" class="mw-redirect">setting</a> and <a href="/wiki/Style_(fiction)" title="Style (fiction)" class="mw-redirect">style</a> of <i>Hanna</i> significantly depart from a typical action movie.<sup id="cite_ref-TTRS20110411_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TTRS20110411-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-TYT_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TYT-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup> According to the official <a href="/wiki/Website" title="Website">website</a>, the film has "elements of dark <a href="/wiki/Fairy_tale" title="Fairy tale">fairy tales</a>" woven into an "adventure <a href="/wiki/Thriller_(genre)" title="Thriller (genre)">thriller</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-Focus_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Focus-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Joe_Wright" title="Joe Wright">Joe Wright</a>, the director, has said that the movie's <a href="/wiki/Theme_(literature)" title="Theme (literature)" class="mw-redirect">theme</a> is a "fantasy" about "overcoming the dark side" during the "rites of passage" of adolescent maturation when a child transforms and "has to go into the world".<sup id="cite_ref-Hiscock_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hiscock-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> He said that he was influenced by personal exposure every day as he grew up to "violent, dark, cautionary fairy tales" that "prepare children for the future obstacles in the wider world", as well as his "deep love for the mystical qualities of <a href="/wiki/David_Lynch" title="David Lynch">David Lynch</a> movies", by the patterns of narrative that he prefers because of his <a href="/wiki/Dyslexia" title="Dyslexia">dyslexia</a>, and by working as a child in his parents' <a href="/wiki/Puppetry" title="Puppetry">puppetry</a> company.<sup id="cite_ref-Hiscock_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hiscock-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In an interview with <a href="/wiki/Film_School_Rejects" title="Film School Rejects">Film School Rejects</a>, Wright acknowledged <a href="/wiki/David_Lynch" title="David Lynch">David Lynch</a> as a major influence on <i>Hanna</i><sup id="cite_ref-FSR_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FSR-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup> and also pointed to <a href="/wiki/The_Chemical_Brothers" title="The Chemical Brothers">The Chemical Brothers</a>' score: "You can expect an extraordinarily loud, thumping, deeply <a href="/wiki/Funk" title="Funk">funky</a> score that will not disappoint".<sup id="cite_ref-FSR_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FSR-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup> The music, including <i>The Devil Is In The Beats</i><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup> and <i>The Devil Is In The Details</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup> underscores the movie's style,<sup id="cite_ref-Hiscock_19-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hiscock-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> recalling <a href="/wiki/Stanley_Kubrick" title="Stanley Kubrick">Stanley Kubrick</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/A_Clockwork_Orange_(film)" title="A Clockwork Orange (film)">A Clockwork Orange</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-Jurgensen_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jurgensen-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> with musical motifs consistent with Wright's "fairy tale theme"<sup id="cite_ref-Jurgensen_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jurgensen-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> of childhood innocence confronting the modern "synthetic" world.<sup id="cite_ref-Jurgensen_24-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jurgensen-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> Several reviewers have commented that the movie has a hyper-stylized <a href="/wiki/Stanley_Kubrick" title="Stanley Kubrick">Kubrickian</a> tone, reminiscent of <i>A Clockwork Orange</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup> The "Kubrick-esque" style<sup id="cite_ref-campo_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-campo-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup> includes Isaac's "gleeful sadism... at times darkly comedic,"<sup id="cite_ref-Bernardelli_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bernardelli-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup> a whistling villain reminiscent of <a href="/wiki/Alex_(A_Clockwork_Orange)" title="Alex (A Clockwork Orange)">Alex DeLarge</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-campo_27-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-campo-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup> Joe Wright's "love of fairy tales and David Lynch movies"<sup id="cite_ref-Hiscock_19-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hiscock-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> was seen as blending <i>A Clockwork Orange</i> <sup id="cite_ref-Bernardelli_28-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bernardelli-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup> and the work of the <a href="/wiki/Brothers_Grimm" title="Brothers Grimm">Brothers Grimm</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Bernardelli_28-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bernardelli-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ebert_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ebert-30"><span>[</span>30<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Richard_Roeper" title="Richard Roeper">Richard Roeper</a> judged it to be a "surreal fairy tale" with "omnipresent symbolism".<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup> Matt Goldberg said it was "an effective and surreal dark fairy tale"... ..."with a dreamlike sensibility... ...Everything in the picture is slightly askew and provides immediacy to Hannas offbeat coming-of-age tale... ...a film that refuses to exist solely in the realm of reality or fairy tale... ...'gritty' realism simply isnt worthy of the story hes trying to tell."<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup> Fairy tale motifs are strewn through the film.<sup id="cite_ref-Ebert_30-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ebert-30"><span>[</span>30<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-McCarthy_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McCarthy-33"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Mottram_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mottram-34"><span>[</span>34<span>]</span></a></sup> In the "tightly-edited patchwork of visual iconography, allusion and symbolism"<sup id="cite_ref-Outlaw_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Outlaw-35"><span>[</span>35<span>]</span></a></sup> Wiegler is equated with the <a href="/wiki/Big_Bad_Wolf" title="Big Bad Wolf">Big Bad Wolf</a><sup id="cite_ref-Bernardelli_28-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bernardelli-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-McCarthy_33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McCarthy-33"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Mottram_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mottram-34"><span>[</span>34<span>]</span></a></sup> or the queen in <i><a href="/wiki/Snow_White" title="Snow White">Snow White</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Dargis_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dargis-36"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup> "Classic fairy tale movie <a href="/wiki/Trope_(literature)" title="Trope (literature)">tropes</a> abound;"<sup id="cite_ref-Outlaw_35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Outlaw-35"><span>[</span>35<span>]</span></a></sup> for example, the camera spins in obvious circles as Hanna makes her escape from the underground government facility early in the film, "just as the young heroines world is spinning out of control."<sup id="cite_ref-Outlaw_35-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Outlaw-35"><span>[</span>35<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Peter_Bradshaw" title="Peter Bradshaw">Peter Bradshaw</a> found the fairy tale mythology "unsubtle".<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup> Conversely, some reviewers did not comment on the fairy tale elements,<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span>[</span>38<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39"><span>[</span>39<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span>[</span>40<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span>[</span>41<span>]</span></a></sup> and others did so with expressive reservation.<sup id="cite_ref-Dargis_36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dargis-36"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span>[</span>42<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Kyle Munkittrick of <i>Discover</i> magazine notes that Hanna is a "<a href="/wiki/Transhumanism" title="Transhumanism">transhumanist</a> hero". Despite being <a href="/wiki/Genetically_engineered" title="Genetically engineered" class="mw-redirect">genetically engineered</a> to have "high intelligence, muscle mass, and no pity", she is still a good-natured person. He says Hanna, "symbolizes the contest between genetics and environment", or, "perhaps more familiarly, nature versus nurture".<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span>[</span>43<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Hanna</i> received mostly positive reviews; it holds a 72% favorable rating on <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> based on 203 reviews with the consensus stating "Fantastic acting and crisply choreographed action sequences propel this unique, cool take on the revenge thriller".<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44"><span>[</span>44<span>]</span></a></sup> Justin Chang of <i><a href="/wiki/Variety_(magazine)" title="Variety (magazine)">Variety</a></i> states that "Joe Wright's 'Hanna' is an exuberantly crafted chase thriller that pulses with energy from its adrenaline-pumping first minutes to its muted bang of a finish".<sup id="cite_ref-Variety_4-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Variety-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Roger_Ebert" title="Roger Ebert">Roger Ebert</a> gave the film three and a half stars out of four, commenting "Wright combines his two genres into a stylish exercise that perversely includes some sentiment and insight".<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45"><span>[</span>45<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Peter_Bradshaw" title="Peter Bradshaw">Peter Bradshaw</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a>,</i> on the other hand, gave the film two stars out of five, stating "With its wicked-witch performance from <a href="/wiki/Cate_Blanchett" title="Cate Blanchett">Cate Blanchett</a>, its derivative premise, its bland Europudding location work and some frankly outrageous boredom, this will test everyone's patience."<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46"><span>[</span>46<span>]</span></a></sup> Kenneth Turan, of the <i>Los Angeles Times</i>, states that the film "starts off like a house afire but soon burns itself out". He states that even though the film is "[b]lessed with considerable virtues, including a clever concept, crackling filmmaking and a charismatic star, it ultimately squanders all of them, undone by an unfortunate lack of subtlety and restraint".<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span>[</span>47<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>According to <i><a href="/wiki/Hollywood_Reporter" title="Hollywood Reporter" class="mw-redirect">Hollywood Reporter</a></i>, <i>Hanna</i> came in second place at the U.S. box office in its first weekend behind <i><a href="/wiki/Hop_(film)" title="Hop (film)">Hop</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48"><span>[</span>48<span>]</span></a></sup> When the film closed on 7 July 2011, it had grossed $40,259,119 in the domestic box office, with a worldwide total of $63,782,078; based on a $30 million budget, the film is considered a financial success.<sup id="cite_ref-BOM_5-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BOM-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The soundtrack album features a score composed by the British <a href="/wiki/Big_beat" title="Big beat">big beat</a> duo, <a href="/wiki/The_Chemical_Brothers" title="The Chemical Brothers">The Chemical Brothers</a>.</p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Mad Max: Fury Road</i></h1>
<p><i><b>Mad Max: Fury Road</b></i> is a 2015 <a href="/wiki/Action_film" title="Action film">action film</a> directed and produced by <a href="/wiki/George_Miller_(director)" title="George Miller (director)">George Miller</a>, and written by Miller, <a href="/wiki/Brendan_McCarthy" title="Brendan McCarthy">Brendan McCarthy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nico_Lathouris" title="Nico Lathouris">Nico Lathouris</a>. The fourth instalment in the <a href="/wiki/Mad_Max_(franchise)" title="Mad Max (franchise)"><i>Mad Max</i> franchise</a>, it is an Australian and American<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> venture produced by <a href="/wiki/Kennedy_Miller_Mitchell" title="Kennedy Miller Mitchell">Kennedy Miller Mitchell</a>, <a href="/wiki/RatPac-Dune_Entertainment" title="RatPac-Dune Entertainment">RatPac-Dune Entertainment</a> and <a href="/wiki/Village_Roadshow_Pictures" title="Village Roadshow Pictures">Village Roadshow Pictures</a>. It is set in a future desert wasteland where gasoline and water are scarce commodities. It follows <a href="/wiki/Max_Rockatansky" title="Max Rockatansky">Max Rockatansky</a> (<a href="/wiki/Tom_Hardy" title="Tom Hardy">Tom Hardy</a>), who joins forces with <a href="/wiki/Imperator_Furiosa" title="Imperator Furiosa">Imperator Furiosa</a> (<a href="/wiki/Charlize_Theron" title="Charlize Theron">Charlize Theron</a>) to flee from cult leader Immortan Joe (<a href="/wiki/Hugh_Keays-Byrne" title="Hugh Keays-Byrne">Hugh Keays-Byrne</a>) and his army in an armoured tanker truck, which leads to a lengthy road battle. The film also features <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_Hoult" title="Nicholas Hoult">Nicholas Hoult</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rosie_Huntington-Whiteley" title="Rosie Huntington-Whiteley">Rosie Huntington-Whiteley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Riley_Keough" title="Riley Keough">Riley Keough</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zo%C3%AB_Kravitz" title="Zo Kravitz">Zo Kravitz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abbey_Lee" title="Abbey Lee" class="mw-redirect">Abbey Lee</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Courtney_Eaton" title="Courtney Eaton">Courtney Eaton</a>.</p>
<p><i>Fury Road</i> was in "<a href="/wiki/Development_hell" title="Development hell">development hell</a>" for many years, with pre-production starting as early as 1997. Attempts were made to shoot the film in 2001 and 2003, but were delayed due to the <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11 attacks</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">Iraq War</a>. In 2007, after focusing on <i><a href="/wiki/Happy_Feet" title="Happy Feet">Happy Feet</a></i>, Miller decided to pursue producing the film again. He briefly considered producing it as a computer-animated film but abandoned it in favor of live-action. In 2009, Miller announced that filming would begin in early 2011. Hardy was cast as Max in June 2010, with production planned to begin that November. Principal photography was delayed several more times before beginning in July 2012. The film <a href="/wiki/Wrap_(filmmaking)" title="Wrap (filmmaking)">wrapped</a> in December 2012, although additional footage was shot in November 2013.</p>
<p>The film had its world premiere on 7 May 2015 at the <a href="/wiki/Grauman%27s_Chinese_Theatre" title="Grauman's Chinese Theatre">TCL Chinese Theatre</a>. It began a worldwide theatrical release on 14 May 2015, including an out-of-competition screening at the <a href="/wiki/2015_Cannes_Film_Festival" title="2015 Cannes Film Festival">68th Cannes Film Festival</a>, in 2D, <a href="/wiki/3D_film" title="3D film">3D</a>, <a href="/wiki/IMAX_3D" title="IMAX 3D" class="mw-redirect">IMAX 3D</a> and <a href="/wiki/4DX" title="4DX">4DX</a>. It has grossed over $376 million worldwide, making it the highest grossing film in the <i>Mad Max</i> franchise. The film was widely acclaimed for its acting, direction, screenplay, art direction, score, practical effects, stunts and action sequences, and is considered one of the best films of 2015 by many critics and publications<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> as well as <a href="/wiki/List_of_films_considered_the_best#Action" title="List of films considered the best">one of the greatest action films of all time</a>. The film won many critical and guild awards, as well as receiving ten <a href="/wiki/Academy_Awards" title="Academy Awards">Academy Award</a> nominations including <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Best Picture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Director" title="Academy Award for Best Director">Best Director</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup> It is the first film of the <i>Mad Max</i> franchise to receive <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award" title="Academy Award" class="mw-redirect">Academy Award</a> recognition, and the second most-nominated film of the <a href="/wiki/88th_Academy_Awards" title="88th Academy Awards">88th Academy Awards</a> after <i><a href="/wiki/The_Revenant_(2015_film)" title="The Revenant (2015 film)">The Revenant</a></i>, also starring Hardy.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>Following a <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_holocaust" title="Nuclear holocaust">nuclear holocaust</a>, the world has become a desert wasteland and civilization has collapsed. <a href="/wiki/Max_Rockatansky" title="Max Rockatansky">Max Rockatansky</a>, a survivor, is captured by the War Boys, the army of the tyrannical Immortan Joe, and taken to Joe's Citadel. Designated a <a href="/wiki/Universal_blood_donor" title="Universal blood donor" class="mw-redirect">universal blood donor</a>, Max is imprisoned and used as a "blood bag" for a sick War Boy called Nux. Meanwhile, <a href="/wiki/Imperator_Furiosa" title="Imperator Furiosa">Imperator Furiosa</a>, one of Joe's lieutenants, is sent in her armored semi-truck, the "War Rig", to collect gasoline. When she drives off-route, Joe realises that his five wiveswomen selected for breedingare missing. Joe leads his entire army in pursuit of Furiosa, calling on the aid of nearby Gas Town and the Bullet Farm.</p>
<p>Nux joins the pursuit with Max strapped to his car to continue supplying blood. A battle ensues between the War Rig and Joe's forces. Furiosa drives into a <a href="/wiki/Sand_storm" title="Sand storm" class="mw-redirect">sand storm</a>, evading her pursuers, except Nux, who attempts to sacrifice himself to destroy the Rig. Max escapes and restrains Nux, but the car is destroyed. After the storm, Max sees Furiosa repairing the Rig, accompanied by the Wives: Capable, Cheedo, Toast, the Dag and Angharad, who is heavily pregnant with Joe's child. Max steals the Rig, but its <a href="/wiki/Kill_switch" title="Kill switch">kill switch</a> disables it. Max reluctantly agrees to let Furiosa and the Wives accompany him; Nux, left behind, is picked up by Joe's army.</p>
<p>Furiosa drives through a biker gang-controlled <a href="/wiki/Canyon" title="Canyon">canyon</a> to barter a deal for safe passage; however, with Joe's forces pursuing, the gang turns on her, forcing her and the group to flee while the bikers detonate the canyon walls to block Joe. Max and Furiosa fight pursuing bikers as Joe's car, with Nux now on board, surmounts the blockade and eventually attacks the War Rig, allowing Nux to board. However, as the Rig escapes, Angharad falls off in an attempt to protect Max and is run over by Joe's car, killing her and her child.</p>
<p>Furiosa explains to Max that they are escaping to the "Green Place," an idyllic land she remembers from her childhood. Capable finds Nux hiding in the Rig, distraught over his failure, and consoles him. That night, the Rig gets stuck in mud. Furiosa and Max slow Joe's forces with mines, but Joe's ally, the Bullet Farmer, continues pursuing them. Nux helps Max free the Rig while Furiosa shoots and blinds the Bullet Farmer. Max walks into the dark to confront the Bullet Farmer and his men, returning with guns and ammunition.</p>
<p>They drive the War Rig overnight through swampland and desert, coming across a naked woman the next day. Max suspects a trap, but Furiosa approaches the woman and states her history and clan affiliation. The naked woman summons her clan, the Vuvalini, who recognise Furiosa as one of their own who was kidnapped as a child. Furiosa is devastated to learn that the swampland they passed was indeed the Green Place, now uninhabitable. The group then plans to ride motorbikes across immense <a href="/wiki/Salt_pan_(geology)" title="Salt pan (geology)">salt flats</a> in the hope of finding a new home. Max chooses to stay behind, but after seeing visions of a child he failed to save, he convinces them to return to the undefended Citadel, which has ample water and greenery that Joe keeps for himself, and trap Joe and his army in the bikers' canyon.</p>
<p>The group heads back to the Citadel, but they are attacked en route by Joe's forces, and Furiosa is seriously wounded. Joe positions his car in front of the War Rig to slow it, while Max fights Joe's giant son, Rictus Erectus. Joe captures Toast, but she distracts him long enough for Furiosa to rip off his breathing mask, killing him. Nux sacrifices himself by wrecking the Rig, killing Rictus and blocking the canyon, allowing Max, Furiosa, the wives, and the Vuvalini to successfully escape in Joe's car, where Max transfuses his blood to Furiosa to help her survive her injuries.</p>
<p>At the Citadel, the impoverished citizens are overjoyed at the sight of Joe's corpse. Furiosa, the wives, and the Vuvalini are cheered by the people and welcomed by the remaining War Boys, but Max walks away, sharing a glance with Furiosa before disappearing into the crowd.</p>
<p>Hugh Keays-Byrne played the main motorcycle villain Toecutter in the original <i><a href="/wiki/Mad_Max" title="Mad Max">Mad Max</a></i> film. Joy Smithers was offered the role of Max Rockatansky's wife in the original 1979 film (a character killed by Toecutter), but was forced to decline after her parents would not let the 15-year-old travel to <a href="/wiki/Adelaide" title="Adelaide">Adelaide</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The primary theme of <i>Mad Max: Fury Road</i> is survival.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup> As the underlying goal for Max,<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup> the theme of staying alive has been carried over from the previous instalments of the series that also highlight issues such as <a href="/wiki/Ecological_collapse" title="Ecological collapse">ecological collapse</a> and moral decadence.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup> "Survival is key", explained Miller. "I think it's a reason why the <a href="/wiki/Epic_Western" title="Epic Western" class="mw-redirect">American Western</a> was such a staple for the better part of a century in <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_the_United_States" title="Cinema of the United States">American cinema</a>. They were allegorical tales with figures in the landscape working these things out".<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Further themes pointed out by critics have included vengeance, solidarity, home, and redemption. In his review of <i>Mad Max: Fury Road</i>, film critic <a href="/wiki/A._O._Scott" title="A. O. Scott">A. O. Scott</a> wrote: "The themes of vengeance and solidarity, the wide-open spaces and the kinetic, ground-level movement mark <i>Fury Road</i> as a western, and the filmmakers pay tribute to such masters of the genre as <a href="/wiki/John_Ford" title="John Ford">John Ford</a>, <a href="/wiki/Budd_Boetticher" title="Budd Boetticher">Budd Boetticher</a> and, not least, <a href="/wiki/Chuck_Jones" title="Chuck Jones">Chuck Jones</a>, whose <a href="/wiki/Wile_E._Coyote_and_The_Road_Runner" title="Wile E. Coyote and The Road Runner">Road Runner</a> cartoons are models of ingenuity and rigor."<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup> Similar to the previous <i>Mad Max</i> films, home has been regarded as a central theme in <i>Mad Max: Fury Road</i> as it dominates the motivations of Max, Furiosa, and the Five Wives: his home was destroyed, she was taken from her home, and the wives are in search of a new home to raise their children.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup> The unity of these characters also harnesses a concern for family, a common theme within Miller's filmography.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup> The Biblical theme of redemption has been described by critics, especially Nux's constant aspiration to be taken to <a href="/wiki/Valhalla" title="Valhalla">Valhalla</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> It also carries the theme of <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_empowerment" title="Women's empowerment">female empowerment</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Plans for a fourth film in the <i>Mad Max</i> series hit financial difficulties and the project spent several years in "<a href="/wiki/Development_hell" title="Development hell">development hell</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup> In 1995, George Miller re-acquired the rights to future <i>Mad Max</i> films from Warner Bros.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup> The idea for a fourth instalment occurred to Miller in August 1998 when he was walking in an intersection in <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NYP_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYP-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup> About a year later, while travelling from Los Angeles to <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a>, the idea coalesced.
