Miller conceived a story where "violent marauders were fighting, not for oil or for material goods, but for human beings."<sup id="cite_ref-NYP_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYP-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup> The film was set to shoot in 2001 through <a href="/wiki/20th_Century_Fox" title="20th Century Fox">20th Century Fox</a>, but was postponed because of the <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11 attacks</a> that same year.<sup id="cite_ref-Filming1_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Filming1-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> "The American dollar collapsed against the Australian dollar, and our budget ballooned", Miller said, adding that he "had to move on to <i><a href="/wiki/Happy_Feet" title="Happy Feet">Happy Feet</a></i> because there was a small window when that was ready". <a href="/wiki/Mel_Gibson" title="Mel Gibson">Mel Gibson</a>, who starred in the original three previous films, would not return to his role as the lead character. Miller ended up re-casting the role because of controversies surrounding Gibson and because he wanted Max to remain at a younger age, as the "same contemporary warrior".<sup id="cite_ref-NYP_23-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYP-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup> Miller announced in 2003 that a script had been written for a fourth film, and that pre-production was in the early stages.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup> Although the project was given the green light for a US$100 million budget to begin filming in Australia in May 2003, <i>Mad Max 4</i> entered hiatus because of security concerns related to trying to film in <a href="/wiki/Namibia" title="Namibia">Namibia</a> because the United States and many other countries had tightened travel and shipping restrictions.<sup id="cite_ref-screenrant1_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-screenrant1-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup> With the outbreak of the <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">Iraq War</a>, <i>Mad Max 4</i> was abandoned as it was considered a potentially politically sensitive film.<sup id="cite_ref-screenrant1_26-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-screenrant1-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In November 2006, Miller stated that he intended to make <i>Fury Road</i> and that the film was never going to involve Gibson: "There's a real hope. The last thing I wanted to do is another <i>Mad Max</i>, but this script came along, and I'm completely carried away with it."<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup> The film's screenplay was co-written with cult British comic creator <a href="/wiki/Brendan_McCarthy" title="Brendan McCarthy">Brendan McCarthy</a>, who also designed many of the new characters and vehicles.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup> Miller again confirmed his intention to make another <i>Mad Max</i> at the 2007 Aurora film maker initiative. However, he stated that he thought Gibson would not be interested in the film because of his age.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30"><span>[</span>30<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Heath_Ledger" title="Heath Ledger">Heath Ledger</a> was reportedly considered for the lead before his death in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-NYP_23-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYP-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup> On 5 March 2009, it was announced that an <a href="/wiki/Motion_Picture_Association_of_America_film_rating_system#MPAA_film_ratings" title="Motion Picture Association of America film rating system">R-rated</a> <a href="/wiki/3D_film" title="3D film">3D</a> animated feature film was in pre-production and would be taking much of the plot from <i>Fury Road</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup> although Gibson would not be in the film and Miller was looking for a "different route", a "renaissance" of the franchise.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_32-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup> Miller cited director <a href="/wiki/Akira_Kurosawa" title="Akira Kurosawa">Akira Kurosawa</a> as an inspiration for what he wanted to do with the franchise. Miller was also developing an action-adventure <a href="/wiki/Tie-in" title="Tie-in">tie-in</a> video game based on the fourth film, along with <i><a href="/wiki/God_of_War_II" title="God of War II">God of War II</a></i> video game designer <a href="/wiki/Cory_Barlog" title="Cory Barlog">Cory Barlog</a>. Both projects were expected to take two to two-and-a-half years, according to Miller, with a release date of either 2011 or 2012. <i>Fury Road</i> was going to be produced at <a href="/wiki/Dr._D_Studios" title="Dr. D Studios" class="mw-redirect">Dr. D Studios</a>, a digital art studios founded in 2008 by Miller and Doug Mitchell.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_32-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On 18 May 2009, it was reported that location scouting was underway for <i>Mad Max 4</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-firstshowing1_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-firstshowing1-33"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup> After exploring the possibility of an animated 3D film, Miller decided instead to shoot a 3D live action film.<sup id="cite_ref-firstshowing1_33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-firstshowing1-33"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup> By this time, production had moved to <a href="/wiki/Warner_Bros." title="Warner Bros.">Warner Bros.</a><sup id="cite_ref-Filming1_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Filming1-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> In October 2009, Miller announced that principal photography on <i>Fury Road</i> would commence at <a href="/wiki/Broken_Hill,_New_South_Wales" title="Broken Hill, New South Wales">Broken Hill, New South Wales</a> in early 2011, ending years of speculation.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34"><span>[</span>34<span>]</span></a></sup> This announcement attracted widespread media attention in Australia, with speculation on whether Gibson would return as Max.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35"><span>[</span>35<span>]</span></a></sup> That same month, British actor <a href="/wiki/Tom_Hardy" title="Tom Hardy">Tom Hardy</a> was in negotiations to take the lead role of Max, while it was also announced that <a href="/wiki/Charlize_Theron" title="Charlize Theron">Charlize Theron</a> would play a major role in the film.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup> In June 2010, Hardy (who was just six weeks old when the original <i><a href="/wiki/Mad_Max" title="Mad Max">Mad Max</a></i> began shooting) announced on <i><a href="/wiki/Friday_Night_with_Jonathan_Ross" title="Friday Night with Jonathan Ross">Friday Night with Jonathan Ross</a></i> that he would play the title role.<sup id="cite_ref-NYP_23-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYP-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup> In July 2010, Miller announced plans to shoot two <i>Mad Max</i> films back-to-back, entitled <i>Mad Max: Fury Road</i> and <i>Mad Max: Furiosa</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span>[</span>38<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Weta_Digital" title="Weta Digital">Weta Digital</a> was originally involved with the film when it was scheduled for a 2012 release.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39"><span>[</span>39<span>]</span></a></sup> The company was to be handling visual effects, conceptual designs, specialty make-up effects, and costume designs until production was postponed from its November 2010 start date.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span>[</span>40<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In November 2011, filming was moved from Broken Hill back to Namibia, after unexpected heavy rains caused wildflowers to grow in the desert, inappropriate for the look of the film.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span>[</span>41<span>]</span></a></sup> Other potential locations scouted included the <a href="/wiki/Atacama_Desert" title="Atacama Desert">Atacama Desert</a> in Chile, <a href="/wiki/Chott_el_Djerid" title="Chott el Djerid">Chott el Djerid</a> in Tunisia, and <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span>[</span>42<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In a July 2014 interview at <a href="/wiki/San_Diego_Comic-Con_International" title="San Diego Comic-Con International">San Diego Comic-Con International</a>, Miller said he designed the film in <a href="/wiki/Storyboard" title="Storyboard">storyboard</a> form before writing the screenplay, working with five storyboard artists. It came out as about 3,500 panels, almost the same number of shots as in the finished film. He wanted the film to be almost a continuous chase, with relatively little dialogue, and to have the visuals come first.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span>[</span>43<span>]</span></a></sup> Paraphrasing <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock" title="Alfred Hitchcock">Alfred Hitchcock</a>, Miller said that he wanted the film to be understood in Japan without the use of subtitles.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44"><span>[</span>44<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Principal_photography" title="Principal photography">Principal photography</a> began on 26 June 2012 in <a href="/wiki/Namibia" title="Namibia">Namibia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45"><span>[</span>45<span>]</span></a></sup> Filming also took place at <a href="/wiki/Potts_Hill,_New_South_Wales" title="Potts Hill, New South Wales">Potts Hill</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cranebrook,_New_South_Wales#Penrith_Lakes" title="Cranebrook, New South Wales">Penrith Lakes</a> in <a href="/wiki/Western_Sydney" title="Western Sydney">Western Sydney</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46"><span>[</span>46<span>]</span></a></sup> In October 2012, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter" title="The Hollywood Reporter">The Hollywood Reporter</a></i> reported that <a href="/wiki/Warner_Bros." title="Warner Bros.">Warner Bros.</a> sent an executive to keep the production on track.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span>[</span>47<span>]</span></a></sup> Filming wrapped on 17 December 2012<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48"><span>[</span>48<span>]</span></a></sup> and lasted for 120 days.<sup id="cite_ref-Filming1_24-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Filming1-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> In February 2013, a leaked draft from the <a href="/wiki/Namibian_Coast_Conservation_and_Management_group" title="Namibian Coast Conservation and Management group" class="mw-redirect">Namibian Coast Conservation and Management group</a> accused the producers of damaging parts of the <a href="/wiki/Namib_Desert" title="Namib Desert">Namib Desert</a>, endangering a number of plant and animal species.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49"><span>[</span>49<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50"><span>[</span>50<span>]</span></a></sup> However, the Namibia Film Commission said it had "no reservations" after visiting the set during production. It disputed claims reported in the media, calling the accusations "unjust rhetoric".<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span>[</span>51<span>]</span></a></sup> In September 2013, it was announced that the film would undergo reshoots in November 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52"><span>[</span>52<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Miller said that he did not feel he had to top himself in terms of production design compared to the previous films in the series. Instead, he wanted the production design to both hearken back to the earlier films and reflect the changes of the past 30 years. <a href="/wiki/Colin_Gibson_(production_designer)" title="Colin Gibson (production designer)">Colin Gibson</a>, the production designer, said that they developed an internally consistent history to explain the film's look and justify its use of <a href="/wiki/Hot_rods" title="Hot rods" class="mw-redirect">hot rods</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53"><span>[</span>53<span>]</span></a></sup> Gibson designed the film's vehicles, all of which are fully functional.<sup id="cite_ref-vehicles_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vehicles-54"><span>[</span>54<span>]</span></a></sup> Construction of some of the vehicles began as early as 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55"><span>[</span>55<span>]</span></a></sup> The cars were designed to show characterisation and detail in the world, including the characters' feelings of guilt, loss, and their attempts to recycle the remains of civilization.<sup id="cite_ref-vehicles_54-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vehicles-54"><span>[</span>54<span>]</span></a></sup> Both the Doof Wagon and the Doof Warrior's guitar are fully functional  none of his scenes were rendered in <a href="/wiki/Computer-generated_imagery" title="Computer-generated imagery">CGI</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span>[</span>56<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Cinematographer <a href="/wiki/John_Seale" title="John Seale">John Seale</a> came out of retirement to shoot <i>Fury Road</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Collider_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Collider-57"><span>[</span>57<span>]</span></a></sup> He replaced <a href="/wiki/Dean_Semler" title="Dean Semler">Dean Semler</a>, the cinematographer of the previous two films, after Semler left.<sup id="cite_ref-seale-variety_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-seale-variety-58"><span>[</span>58<span>]</span></a></sup> Seale outfitted his camera crew with six <a href="/wiki/Arri_Alexa" title="Arri Alexa">Arri Alexa</a> Pluses and four Alexa Ms, as well as a number of <a href="/wiki/Canon_EOS_5D" title="Canon EOS 5D">Canon EOS 5Ds</a> and <a href="/wiki/Olympus_PEN_E-P5" title="Olympus PEN E-P5">Olympus PEN E-P5s</a> that were used as crash cams for the action sequences.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span>[</span>59<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60"><span>[</span>60<span>]</span></a></sup> It was the first time Seale shot with digital cameras.<sup id="cite_ref-seale-variety_58-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-seale-variety-58"><span>[</span>58<span>]</span></a></sup> Because of the fast nature required for edits, Miller asked Seale to keep the focus of the shot centered for each scene, thus allowing the audience to quickly orient towards it.<sup id="cite_ref-Hitflixlurred_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hitflixlurred-61"><span>[</span>61<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In July 2014, director George Miller described the film as "a very simple allegory, almost a western on wheels".<sup id="cite_ref-guardian_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guardian-62"><span>[</span>62<span>]</span></a></sup> Miller said that 90% of the effects were <a href="/wiki/Practical_effect" title="Practical effect">practical</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63"><span>[</span>63<span>]</span></a></sup> Second unit director and supervising stunt coordinator Guy Norris was in charge of over 150 stunt performers, which included <a href="/wiki/Cirque_du_Soleil" title="Cirque du Soleil">Cirque du Soleil</a> performers and <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympic</a> athletes.<sup id="cite_ref-Collider_57-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Collider-57"><span>[</span>57<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64"><span>[</span>64<span>]</span></a></sup> Miller invited playwright <a href="/wiki/Eve_Ensler" title="Eve Ensler">Eve Ensler</a> to act as an on-set adviser. Impressed with the script's depth and what she saw as feminist themes, she spent a week in Namibia, where she spoke to the actors about issues of <a href="/wiki/Violence_against_women" title="Violence against women">violence against women</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65"><span>[</span>65<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Mad Max: Fury Road</i> contains 2,000 <a href="/wiki/Visual_effects" title="Visual effects">visual effects</a> shots.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66"><span>[</span>66<span>]</span></a></sup> The lead effects company was Iloura, who delivered more than 1,500 effects shots for the film.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67"><span>[</span>67<span>]</span></a></sup> Additional visual effects studios that worked on the film include <a href="/wiki/Method_Studios" title="Method Studios">Method Studios</a>, Stereo D, 4DMax, BlackGinger, The Third Floor, and <a href="/wiki/Dr._D_Studios" title="Dr. D Studios" class="mw-redirect">Dr. D Studios</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68"><span>[</span>68<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69"><span>[</span>69<span>]</span></a></sup> Miller recruited his wife, Margaret Sixel, to edit the film, as he felt she could make it stand out from other action films.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70"><span>[</span>70<span>]</span></a></sup> Sixel had 480 hours of footage to edit; watching it took three months.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71"><span>[</span>71<span>]</span></a></sup> The film contains about 2,700 cuts of its entire running length, which is equivalent to 22.5 cuts per minute compared to <i>The Road Warrior</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s 1,200 cuts of its 90-minute running time equivalent to 13.33 cuts per minute.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72"><span>[</span>72<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Frame_rate" title="Frame rate">frame rate</a> was also manipulated. "Something like 50 or 60 percent of the film is not running at 24 frames a second, which is the traditional frame rate," said Seale. "It'll be running below 24 frames because George, if he couldn't understand what was happening in the shot, he slowed it down until you could. Or if it was too well understood, he'd shorten it or he'd speed it up back towards 24. His manipulation of every shot in that movie is intense."<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73"><span>[</span>73<span>]</span></a></sup> The Washington Post would later note that the changing frame rate gave the film an "almost cartoonishly jerky" look.<sup id="cite_ref-starwarswp_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-starwarswp-74"><span>[</span>74<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The extensive effects work included altering lighting and time of day, weather effects, terrain replacement and plate composition.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75"><span>[</span>75<span>]</span></a></sup> Night scenes were <a href="/wiki/Day_for_night" title="Day for night">filmed in bright daylight</a>, deliberately overexposed and colour-manipulated. In many shots, the sky was digitally replaced with more detailed or interesting skies. Charlize Theron wore a green cover over her left arm to aid effects artists in digitally removing her arm from her scenes.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<p>Sound designer Mark Mangini stated that he viewed the War Rig as an allegory for <a href="/wiki/Moby-Dick" title="Moby-Dick">Moby-Dick</a> with Immortan Joe playing the role of <a href="/wiki/Captain_Ahab" title="Captain Ahab">Captain Ahab</a>. As such, the mechanical truck sounds were layered with whale calls to provide a more animal-like quality to the truck. When the tank is pierced with harpoons and milk sprays out, the sound of whale blow-holes were used. For the final destruction of the War Rig, the only sounds used were slowed down bear growls to symbolize the death of the truck as a living creature.<sup id="cite_ref-moby_dick_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-moby_dick-76"><span>[</span>76<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Both a PG-13 and R-rated version had been shown separately in different test screenings. The R-rated version was better received by test audiences, leading Warner Brothers to release it.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77"><span>[</span>77<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Film_score" title="Film score">musical score</a> for <i>Mad Max: Fury Road</i> was written by the Dutch composer <a href="/wiki/Junkie_XL" title="Junkie XL">Junkie XL</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78"><span>[</span>78<span>]</span></a></sup> Prior to Junkie XL's involvement, <a href="/wiki/Hans_Zimmer" title="Hans Zimmer">Hans Zimmer</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Powell_(film_composer)" title="John Powell (film composer)">John Powell</a> and <a href="/wiki/Marco_Beltrami" title="Marco Beltrami">Marco Beltrami</a> were attached at separate times to score the film.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79"><span>[</span>79<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80"><span>[</span>80<span>]</span></a></sup> After hearing Junkie XL's score for <i><a href="/wiki/300:_Rise_of_an_Empire" title="300: Rise of an Empire">300: Rise of an Empire</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81"><span>[</span>81<span>]</span></a></sup> Miller met with the composer in Sydney. "I got very inspired and started writing pieces of music for scenes," said Junkie XL. "The initial main themes were written in the four weeks after that first meeting and those themes never changed."<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82"><span>[</span>82<span>]</span></a></sup> A soundtrack album was released by <a href="/wiki/WaterTower_Music" title="WaterTower Music">WaterTower Music</a> on 12 May 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83"><span>[</span>83<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>A deluxe edition hardcover collection of art titled <i>Mad Max: Fury Road - Inspired Artists Deluxe Edition</i> inspired by the film was released on 6 May 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-THR_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-THR-84"><span>[</span>84<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ComicAll_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ComicAll-85"><span>[</span>85<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>Mad Max: Fury Road</i> had its world premiere on 7 May 2015 at the <a href="/wiki/Grauman%27s_Chinese_Theatre" title="Grauman's Chinese Theatre">TCL Chinese Theatre</a> in <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86"><span>[</span>86<span>]</span></a></sup> On 14 May 2015, it screened out-of-competition at the <a href="/wiki/2015_Cannes_Film_Festival" title="2015 Cannes Film Festival">68th Cannes Film Festival</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87"><span>[</span>87<span>]</span></a></sup> and then was released in theaters on 15 May 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88"><span>[</span>88<span>]</span></a></sup> Leading up its release, the film was digitally re-mastered into the <a href="/wiki/IMAX_3D" title="IMAX 3D" class="mw-redirect">IMAX 3D</a> format. It was released into IMAX theaters in select international territories on 13 May 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89"><span>[</span>89<span>]</span></a></sup> It also received a one-week only IMAX 3D re-release in America starting 11 September 2015. Warner Bros. spent a total of $43.7 million on advertisement for the film.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90"><span>[</span>90<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In May 2015, <a href="/wiki/Vertigo_(DC_Comics)" title="Vertigo (DC Comics)">Vertigo</a> began publishing a comic book prequel <a href="/wiki/Limited_series" title="Limited series" class="mw-redirect">limited series</a>. Each issue focuses on the backstory of one or two of the film's characters. The first issue, titled <i>Mad Max: Fury Road - Nux and Immortan Joe #1</i>, was released on 20 May. The second, <i>Mad Max: Fury Road - Furiosa #1</i>, was released on 17 June. The third, <i>Mad Max: Fury Road - Mad Max #1</i>, was released on 8 July. The final issue, <i>Mad Max: Fury Road - Mad Max #2</i>, was released on 5 August.<sup id="cite_ref-THR_84-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-THR-84"><span>[</span>84<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ComicAll_85-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ComicAll-85"><span>[</span>85<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91"><span>[</span>91<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92"><span>[</span>92<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93"><span>[</span>93<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94"><span>[</span>94<span>]</span></a></sup> A single-volume collection containing the stories of all four issues was released on 26 August.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95"><span>[</span>95<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Miller stated that the <a href="/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc" title="Blu-ray Disc" class="mw-redirect">Blu-ray Disc</a> release would include <a href="/wiki/Black-and-white" title="Black-and-white" class="mw-redirect">black-and-white</a> and <a href="/wiki/Silent_film" title="Silent film">silent</a> versions of the film, with the latter accompanied by the musical score. Miller described the black-and-white cut as the best version of the film.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96"><span>[</span>96<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97"><span>[</span>97<span>]</span></a></sup> However, when details for both the United Kingdom and United States releases of the Blu-ray were announced, the alternate cuts were absent.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98"><span>[</span>98<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99"><span>[</span>99<span>]</span></a></sup> Producer Doug Mitchell in December 2015 confirmed that the black and white version existed and could potentially see a future theatrical release.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100"><span>[</span>100<span>]</span></a></sup> In January 2016, Miller announced the black-and-white versions would appear on an another DVD release.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101"><span>[</span>101<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film was released on Blu-ray and DVD in the United Kingdom on 5 October 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102"><span>[</span>102<span>]</span></a></sup> In the United States, the film was released digitally on 11 August 2015, and physically on 1 September. In addition to the stand-alone release, a box set containing all four films and a documentary about the series titled "Madness of Max" was released the same day.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103"><span>[</span>103<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Mad Max: Fury Road</i> became a moderate hit at the box office. It definitely emerged as a successful film, albeit when comparing the final theatrical gross to its $200 million budget (including production, marketing and distribution costs), it is an average hit with <i><a href="/wiki/Forbes" title="Forbes">Forbes</a></i> camparing the figures of the film to <i><a href="/wiki/Edge_of_Tomorrow_(film)" title="Edge of Tomorrow (film)" class="mw-redirect">Edge of Tomorrow</a></i> calling it "too expensive, but not really <a href="/wiki/Box_office_bomb" title="Box office bomb">a flop</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-FFF_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FFF-104"><span>[</span>104<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105"><span>[</span>105<span>]</span></a></sup> One of the reason why the film emerged rather unsuccessful according to <i>Forbes</i> was its cancelled release in China, which could have aided the film in at least passing $400 million had the film found success there.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106"><span>[</span>106<span>]</span></a></sup> It grossed $153.6 million in North America and $222.2 million in other territories for a worldwide total of $375.8 million.<sup id="cite_ref-BOM_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BOM-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> It had a worldwide opening weekend total of $109 million,<sup id="cite_ref-FFF_104-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FFF-104"><span>[</span>104<span>]</span></a></sup> and went on to become the second highest-grossing Warner Bros. film of 2015 (behind <i><a href="/wiki/San_Andreas_(film)" title="San Andreas (film)">San Andreas</a></i>),<sup id="cite_ref-2015WG_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2015WG-107"><span>[</span>107<span>]</span></a></sup> and the nineteenth highest-grossing film of 2015 worldwide overall.<sup id="cite_ref-2015WG_107-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2015WG-107"><span>[</span>107<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In the United States and Canada, <i>Mad Max: Fury Road</i> opened simultaneously with <i><a href="/wiki/Pitch_Perfect_2" title="Pitch Perfect 2">Pitch Perfect 2</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-MM4_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MM4-108"><span>[</span>108<span>]</span></a></sup> It opened Friday, 15 May 2015, across 3,702 theaters, and earned $16.77 million on its opening day.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109"><span>[</span>109<span>]</span></a></sup> This included $3.7 million it made from Thursday night run from 3,000 theaters.<sup id="cite_ref-TN_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TN-110"><span>[</span>110<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111"><span>[</span>111<span>]</span></a></sup> In its opening weekend, the film grossed $45.4 million, finishing in second at the box office behind <i>Pitch Perfect 2</i> ($69.2 million).<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112"><span>[</span>112<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Outside North America, it opened on 14 May on 12,000 screens in 48 countries, earning $10.4 million.<sup id="cite_ref-overseasday1_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-overseasday1-113"><span>[</span>113<span>]</span></a></sup> It opened in 20 more countries on 15 May, earning $14.2 million from 16,700 screens in 68 countries, for a two-day total of $24.6 million.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114"><span>[</span>114<span>]</span></a></sup> Through Sunday, 17 May, it had an opening weekend total of $65 million from over 9.1 million admissions on nearly 16,900 screens across 68 countries, debuting at second place behind <i><a href="/wiki/Avengers:_Age_of_Ultron" title="Avengers: Age of Ultron">Avengers: Age of Ultron</a></i>. It went number one in 40 countries. Its highest openings were recorded in the UK ($7 million), South Korea ($6.6 million), France ($6.1 million), Russia and the CIS ($6 million) and Australia ($4.9 million).<sup id="cite_ref-MM_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MM-115"><span>[</span>115<span>]</span></a></sup> It opened in its last market, Japan, on June 20, earning $2.2 million from 175,000 admissions in its opening weekend debuting at No. 2 behind local film <i>Love Live! The School Idol Movie</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116"><span>[</span>116<span>]</span></a></sup> In total earnings, its three largest markets outside of the U.S. and Canada are South Korea ($29.7 million), followed by the UK ($26.9 million) and France ($18.1 million).<sup id="cite_ref-China_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-China-117"><span>[</span>117<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-SWO_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SWO-118"><span>[</span>118<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Review_aggregator" title="Review aggregator">Review aggregator</a> website <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> gives <i>Mad Max: Fury Road</i> a 97% approval rating and <a href="/wiki/Rating_average" title="Rating average" class="mw-redirect">rating average</a> score of 8.6 out of 10 based on 335 reviews. The site's consensus reads, "With exhilarating action and a surprising amount of narrative heft, <i>Mad Max: Fury Road</i> brings George Miller's post-apocalyptic franchise roaring vigorously back to life."<sup id="cite_ref-RTFuryMain_119-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RTFuryMain-119"><span>[</span>119<span>]</span></a></sup> On <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>, which assigns a normalised rating, the film has a score of 89 out of 100 based on 47 critics, indicating "universal acclaim".<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120"><span>[</span>120<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/CinemaScore" title="CinemaScore">CinemaScore</a> polls reported that the average grade cinema audiences gave the film was a "B+" on an A+ to F scale.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121"><span>[</span>121<span>]</span></a></sup> Some critics have named <i>Mad Max: Fury Road</i> <a href="/wiki/List_of_films_considered_the_best#Action" title="List of films considered the best">one of the greatest action films ever made</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122"><span>[</span>122<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123"><span>[</span>123<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Robbie_Collin" title="Robbie Collin">Robbie Collin</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph" title="The Daily Telegraph">The Daily Telegraph</a></i> gave the film a full five stars and praised the film for its acting, screenplay, choreography, stunts, humor, and direction calling the film a "spiritual sequel" and an "eruption of craziness."<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124"><span>[</span>124<span>]</span></a></sup> Writing for <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i> and awarding the film four stars out of five, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Bradshaw" title="Peter Bradshaw">Peter Bradshaw</a> wrote, "Extravagantly deranged, ear-splittingly cacophonous, and entirely over the top, George Miller has revived his <i>Mad Max</i> punk-western franchise as a bizarre convoy chase action-thriller in the post-apocalyptic desert."<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125"><span>[</span>125<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> wrote, "Miller has reminded us that blockbusters have the potential to not only be art, but radically visionary  even the fourth in a series. What a lovely day, indeed."<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126"><span>[</span>126<span>]</span></a></sup> Scott Mendelson of <i><a href="/wiki/Forbes" title="Forbes">Forbes</a></i> gave the film 10 out of 10 stars and wrote, "<i>Mad Max: Fury Road</i> is a remarkable and glorious motion picture, not just one of the great action movies of our time but also a great and timely film, period."<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127"><span>[</span>127<span>]</span></a></sup> Alonso Duralde of <a href="/wiki/TheWrap" title="TheWrap">TheWrap</a> wrote, "In the same way that the original 1979 <i>Mad Max</i> was the <i><a href="/wiki/Citizen_Kane" title="Citizen Kane">Citizen Kane</a></i> of gut-bucket <a href="/wiki/Ozploitation" title="Ozploitation">Australian exploitation cinema</a>, <i>Mad Max: Fury Road</i> may well be the <i><a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6tterd%C3%A4mmerung" title="Gtterdmmerung">Gtterdmmerung</a></i> of drive-in movies. It has its roots in the Western and the post-apocalyptic road-rage action saga [...], where Miller dares anyone else to follow in his tire treads."<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128"><span>[</span>128<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/IGN" title="IGN">IGN</a> reviewer Scott Collura gave the film 9.2 out of 10, saying: "The over-the-top stunts and eccentric characters and designs are all hugely important to <i>Fury Road</i>, ... but it's the overriding sense of the film's uniqueness, its striving to be something more than just another action movie, that is most impressive."<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129"><span>[</span>129<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film has also been praised by feminist critics<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130"><span>[</span>130<span>]</span></a></sup> on several fronts, including the dominant role taken by Furiosa and the range of atypical female roles including the wives and the gun-toting Vuvalini.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131"><span>[</span>131<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Mad Max: Fury Road</i> was named one of the best films of 2015 by numerous critics and publications and was ranked first on <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a>'s best scored film of 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132"><span>[</span>132<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133"><span>[</span>133<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134"><span>[</span>134<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135"><span>[</span>135<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136"><span>[</span>136<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In 2011, Miller and McCarthy found during the writing process for <i>Fury Road</i> that they had enough story material for two additional scripts. One of these, entitled <i>Mad Max: Furiosa</i>, had already been completed, and Miller hoped to film it after the release of <i>Fury Road</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137"><span>[</span>137<span>]</span></a></sup> In March 2015, during an interview with <i><a href="/wiki/Esquire_(magazine)" title="Esquire (magazine)">Esquire</a></i>, Hardy revealed that he was attached to star in four more <i>Mad Max</i> films following <i>Fury Road</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138"><span>[</span>138<span>]</span></a></sup> In May 2015, Miller told <i><a href="/wiki/Wired_(magazine)" title="Wired (magazine)">Wired</a></i>: "Should <i>Fury Road</i> be successful, I've got two other stories to tell."<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139"><span>[</span>139<span>]</span></a></sup> Later in May, Miller revealed that plans for the sequel had changed and the next instalment will instead be titled <i>Mad Max: The Wasteland</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140"><span>[</span>140<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141"><span>[</span>141<span>]</span></a></sup> In October 2015, Miller revealed in an interview with <a href="/wiki/Top_Gear_(2002_TV_series)" title="Top Gear (2002 TV series)">TopGear.com</a> that they had two scripts for sequels which they ended up with during the writing process.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142"><span>[</span>142<span>]</span></a></sup> Later in October in an interview with <a href="/wiki/Digital_Spy" title="Digital Spy">Digital Spy</a>, he revealed that Furiosa won't appear in the sequel and clarified that <i>Mad Max: The Wasteland</i> is just a <a href="/wiki/Working_title" title="Working title">working title</a> for the sequel.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143"><span>[</span>143<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144"><span>[</span>144<span>]</span></a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:TOPIC" title="Wikipedia:TOPIC" class="mw-redirect"><span title="The material near this tag may contain the information irrelevant to the article's main topic. (November 2015)">relevant?</span></a> <span class="metadata"> <a href="/wiki/Talk:Mad_Max:_Fury_Road#Future_plans_for_Furiosa" title="Talk:Mad Max: Fury Road">discuss</a></span></i>]</sup> Miller reaffirmed his intent to continue the franchise after reports to the contrary surfaced following an interview in January 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145"><span>[</span>145<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>The Lives of Others</i></h1>
<p><i><b>The Lives of Others</b></i> (German: <span lang="de"><i>Das Leben der Anderen</i></span>) is a 2006 <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Germany" title="Cinema of Germany">German</a> drama film, marking the feature film debut of filmmaker <a href="/wiki/Florian_Henckel_von_Donnersmarck" title="Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck">Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck</a>, about the monitoring of <a href="/wiki/East_Berlin" title="East Berlin">East Berlin</a> residents by agents of the <a href="/wiki/Stasi" title="Stasi">Stasi</a>, the <a href="/wiki/East_Germany" title="East Germany">GDR</a>'s secret police. It stars <a href="/wiki/Ulrich_M%C3%BChe" title="Ulrich Mhe">Ulrich Mhe</a> (who died within a year of the film's release) as Stasi Captain Gerd Wiesler, <a href="/wiki/Ulrich_Tukur" title="Ulrich Tukur">Ulrich Tukur</a> as his superior Anton Grubitz, <a href="/wiki/Sebastian_Koch" title="Sebastian Koch">Sebastian Koch</a> as the playwright Georg Dreyman, and <a href="/wiki/Martina_Gedeck" title="Martina Gedeck">Martina Gedeck</a> as Dreyman's lover, a prominent actress named Christa-Maria Sieland.</p>
<p>The film was released in Germany on 23 March 2006. At the same time, the screenplay was published by <a href="/wiki/Suhrkamp_Verlag" title="Suhrkamp Verlag">Suhrkamp Verlag</a>. <i>The Lives of Others</i> won the <a href="/wiki/79th_Academy_Awards" title="79th Academy Awards">2006 Academy Award</a> for <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Foreign_Language_Film" title="Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film">Best Foreign Language Film</a>. The film had earlier won seven <a href="/wiki/Deutscher_Filmpreis" title="Deutscher Filmpreis">Deutscher Filmpreis</a> awardsincluding those for best film, best director, best screenplay, best actor, and best supporting actorafter setting a new record with 11 nominations. It was nominated for Best Foreign Language Film at the <a href="/wiki/64th_Golden_Globe_Awards" title="64th Golden Globe Awards">64th Golden Globe Awards</a>. <i>The Lives of Others</i> cost US$2 million<sup id="cite_ref-arnyt_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-arnyt-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> and grossed more than US$77 million worldwide as of November 2007<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_Lives_of_Others&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Released 17 years after the fall of the <a href="/wiki/Berlin_Wall" title="Berlin Wall">Berlin Wall</a> marking the end of the East German socialist state, it was the first noticeable drama film about the subject after a series of comedies such as <i><a href="/wiki/Goodbye,_Lenin!" title="Goodbye, Lenin!" class="mw-redirect">Goodbye, Lenin!</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Sonnenallee" title="Sonnenallee">Sonnenallee</a></i>. This approach was widely applauded in Germany even as some criticized the humanization of Wiesler's character. Many former East Germans were stunned by the factual accuracy of the film's set and atmosphere, accurately portraying <a href="/wiki/German_reunification" title="German reunification">a state which merged</a> with <a href="/wiki/West_Germany" title="West Germany">West Germany</a> and ceased to exist 16 years prior to the release. The film's authenticity was considered notable, given that the director grew up outside of East Germany and was only sixteen when the Berlin Wall fell.<sup id="cite_ref-nybooks_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nybooks-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>In 1984 <a href="/wiki/East_Germany" title="East Germany">East Germany</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stasi" title="Stasi">Stasi</a> Hauptmann Gerd Wiesler (<a href="/wiki/Ulrich_M%C3%BChe" title="Ulrich Mhe">Ulrich Mhe</a>), code name HGW XX/7, suggests to his superiors that he begin to spy on the playwright Georg Dreyman (<a href="/wiki/Sebastian_Koch" title="Sebastian Koch">Sebastian Koch</a>). Wiesler and his team bug the apartment, set up surveillance equipment in an attic, and begin reporting Dreyman's activities. Dreyman, who escaped state scrutiny due to his pro-Communist views and international recognition, soon learns the real reason behind the surveillance: Minister of Culture Bruno Hempf (<a href="/wiki/Thomas_Thieme" title="Thomas Thieme">Thomas Thieme</a>) covets Dreyman's girlfriend, actress Christa-Maria Sieland (<a href="/wiki/Martina_Gedeck" title="Martina Gedeck">Martina Gedeck</a>), and is trying to eliminate Dreyman as a romantic rival. While Wiesler's superior, Lt. Col. Anton Grubitz (<a href="/wiki/Ulrich_Tukur" title="Ulrich Tukur">Ulrich Tukur</a>), sees an opportunity for advancement, the idealist Wiesler asks Grubitz, "Is this why we joined?" Minister Hempf coerces Sieland into having sex with him by exploiting her vulnerability as an insecure actress. After discovering Sieland's relationship with Hempf, Dreyman implores her not to meet him again. Sieland flees to a nearby bar where Wiesler, posing as a fan, urges her to be true to herself. She returns home and reconciles with Dreyman, rejecting Hempf.</p>
<p>Though a communist and supporter of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_the_GDR" title="Council of Ministers of the GDR">regime</a>, Dreyman becomes disillusioned with the treatment of his colleagues by the state. At his birthday party, his friend Albert Jerska (a <a href="/wiki/Blacklist_(employment)" title="Blacklist (employment)">blacklisted</a> theatrical director) gives him <a href="/wiki/Sheet_music" title="Sheet music">sheet music</a> for <i>Sonate vom Guten Menschen</i> (<i>Sonata for a Good Man</i>). Shortly afterwards, Jerska hangs himself. Dreyman decides to publish an anonymous article on the East German suicide rate in <i><a href="/wiki/Der_Spiegel" title="Der Spiegel">Der Spiegel</a></i>, a prominent West German newsweekly. Dreyman's article accuses the state of callously ignoring those who commit suicide. Since all East German <a href="/wiki/Typewriter" title="Typewriter">typewriters</a> are registered, an editor of <i>Der Spiegel</i> smuggles Dreyman a miniature typewriter with a red ribbon. Dreyman hides the typewriter in the floor of his apartment, but is seen one afternoon by Sieland hiding it there as she returns to the apartment. Meanwhile, a disillusioned Wiesler has a change of heart about his own role in protecting the regime.</p>
<p>When Dreyman and his friends check whether his flat is bugged, Wiesler, who has become sympathetic to Dreyman, does not alert the border guards, and the conspirators believe they are safe. After learning that it was Dreyman who actually wrote the article, Wiesler races to Colonel Grubitz's office intending to notify his boss of the breakthrough; but as soon as he hears Grubitz talk about how to silence dissident artists like Dreyman, Wiesler changes his mind and asks for the surveillance to be scaled back.</p>
<p>A few days later, Dreyman's article is published, angering the East German authorities. The Stasi obtains a copy of the suicide article, typewritten in red ink, but they are unable to link it to any typewriter legally registered in the GDR. Livid at being jilted by Sieland and her abuse of prescription medication, Hempf orders Grubitz to arrest her. She is blackmailed into revealing Dreyman's authorship of the article and becoming an informant. When the Stasi search his apartment, however, they cannot find the typewriter. Dreyman and his friends conclude that Sieland could not have informed because she would have given away the location of the hidden typewriter. Grubitz, suspicious that Wiesler has mentioned nothing unusual in his daily reports of the monitoring, gives Wiesler "one more chance" and orders him to do the follow-up interrogation of Sieland. Wiesler resumes his role as Stasi interrogator and forces Sieland to tell him exactly where the typewriter is hidden.</p>
<p>Grubitz and the Stasi return to Dreyman's apartment. Sieland panics when she realizes that Dreyman will know she betrayed him and flees the apartment. When Grubitz removes the floor, however, the typewriter is goneWiesler having removed the hidden evidence. Unaware that the typewriter was removed, Sieland runs to the street and commits suicide by stepping into the path of an oncoming truck. Grubitz offers a perfunctory claim of sympathy and informs Dreyman that the investigation is over. Wiesler drives Grubitz back to the Stasi and is told that his career is over, and that his remaining 20 years with the agency will be in Department M, a dead-end position for disgraced agents. As he leaves, Grubitz discards a newspaper announcing <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev" title="Mikhail Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a> as the new leader of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>.</p>
<p>On November 9, 1989, Wiesler is steaming open letters in the cramped, windowless office of Department M when a co-worker tells him about the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Berlin_Wall" title="Fall of the Berlin Wall" class="mw-redirect">fall of the Berlin Wall</a>. Realizing that this will mean the end of the GDR and the Stasi, Wiesler silently stands and leaves the office, inspiring his co-workers to do the same. Two years later, Hempf and Dreyman have a chance encounter while both are attending a new performance of Dreyman's play. Dreyman asks the former government minister why he had never been monitored. Much to his surprise, Hempf tells him that he had, in fact, been under full surveillance and to "look behind the light switches" for the listening devices that had been installed in 1984.</p>
<p>At the <a href="/wiki/Stasi_Records_Agency" title="Stasi Records Agency">Stasi Records Agency</a>, Dreyman reviews the files the Stasi kept while he was under surveillance. He reads that Sieland was released just before the second search, and could not have removed the typewriter. As he goes through his files, he is at first confused by the false and contradicting information that has been written about his activities, but when he reaches the final typewritten report, he sees a fingerprint in red ink just under the signature. Dreyman finally realizes that it was the writerStasi agent HGWXX/7who had knowingly concealed his illegal activities, including his authorship of the suicide article, and that he had been the one who had removed the typewriter from its hidden location. Dreyman searches for Wiesler, who has a job as a postman, and finds him on his rounds. Unsure of what to say to him, however, he decides not to approach him.</p>
<p>Two years later, Wiesler still has the same job and, whilst on his round, passes a bookstore window display promoting Dreyman's new novel, <i>Sonate vom Guten Menschen</i>. He goes inside and opens a copy of the book, discovering it is dedicated "To HGW XX/7, with gratitude". Deeply moved, Wiesler buys the book. When the sales clerk asks if he wants it gift-wrapped, he responds, "No. It's for me."</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Florian_Henckel_von_Donnersmarck" title="Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck">Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck</a>'s parents were both from East Germany (originally they were from <a href="/wiki/Former_eastern_territories_of_Germany" title="Former eastern territories of Germany">further east</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Von_Donnersmarck" title="Von Donnersmarck" class="mw-redirect">von Donnersmarcks</a> belonged to <a href="/wiki/Silesia" title="Silesia">Silesian</a> nobility but the region was transferred to Poland from Germany after World War II). He has said that, on visits there as a child before the <a href="/wiki/Berlin_Wall" title="Berlin Wall">Berlin Wall</a> fell, he could sense the fear they had as subjects of the state.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>He said the idea for the film came to him when he was trying to come up with a scenario for a film class. He was listening to music and recalled <a href="/wiki/Maxim_Gorky" title="Maxim Gorky">Maxim Gorky</a>'s saying that <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Lenin</a>'s favorite piece of music was <a href="/wiki/Ludwig_van_Beethoven" title="Ludwig van Beethoven">Beethoven</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Piano_Sonata_No._23_(Beethoven)" title="Piano Sonata No. 23 (Beethoven)">Appassionata</a></i>. Gorky recounted a discussion with Lenin:</p>
<p>And screwing up his eyes and chuckling, [Lenin] added without mirth:</p>
<p>But I can't listen to music often, it affects my nerves, it makes me want to say sweet nothings and pat the heads of people who, living in a filthy hell, can create such beauty. But today we mustn't pat anyone on the head or we'll get our hand bitten off; we've got to hit them on the heads, hit them without mercy, though in the ideal we are against doing any violence to people. Hm-hmit's a hellishly difficult office!</p>
<p>Donnersmarck told a <i>New York Times</i> reporter: "I suddenly had this image in my mind of a person sitting in a depressing room with earphones on his head and listening in to what he supposes is the enemy of the state and the enemy of his ideas, and what he is really hearing is beautiful music that touches him. I sat down and in a couple of hours had written the <a href="/wiki/Film_treatment" title="Film treatment">treatment</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-arnyt_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-arnyt-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> The screenplay was written during an extended visit to his uncle's monastery, <a href="/wiki/Heiligenkreuz_Abbey" title="Heiligenkreuz Abbey">Heiligenkreuz Abbey</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Although the opening scene is set in <a href="/wiki/Berlin-Hohensch%C3%B6nhausen_Memorial" title="Berlin-Hohenschnhausen Memorial">Hohenschnhausen prison</a> (which is now the site of a memorial dedicated to the victims of Stasi oppression), the film could not be shot there because <a href="/wiki/Hubertus_Knabe" title="Hubertus Knabe">Hubertus Knabe</a>, the director of the memorial, refused to give Donnersmarck permission. Knabe objected to "making the Stasi man into a hero" and tried to persuade Donnersmarck to change the film. Donnersmarck cited <i><a href="/wiki/Schindler%27s_List" title="Schindler's List">Schindler's List</a></i> as an example of such a plot development being possible. Knabe's answer: "But that is exactly the difference. There was a <a href="/wiki/Oskar_Schindler" title="Oskar Schindler">Schindler</a>. There was no Wiesler."<sup id="cite_ref-af_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-af-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film was received with widespread acclaim. Film <a href="/wiki/Review_aggregator" title="Review aggregator">aggregate</a> site <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> reports a 93% "Fresh" rating, based on 142 positive reviews out of 152.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> A review in <i>Daily Variety</i> by Derek Elley noted the "slightly stylized look" of the movie created by "playing up grays and dour greens, even when using actual locations like the Stasi's onetime HQ in Normannenstrasse."<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i> magazine's <a href="/wiki/Richard_Corliss" title="Richard Corliss">Richard Corliss</a> named the film one of the Top 10 Movies of 2007, ranking it at #2. Corliss praised the film as a "poignant, unsettling thriller."<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Film critic <a href="/wiki/Roger_Ebert" title="Roger Ebert">Roger Ebert</a> gave the film four stars, describing it as "a powerful but quiet film, constructed of hidden thoughts and secret desires."<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup> A. O. Scott, reviewing the film in <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i>, wrote that <i>Lives</i> is well-plotted, and added, "The suspense comes not only from the structure and pacing of the scenes, but also, more deeply, from the sense that even in an oppressive society, individuals are burdened with free will. You never know, from one moment to the next, what course any of the characters will choose."<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times" title="Los Angeles Times">Los Angeles Times</a></i> movie critic Kenneth Turan agreed that the dramatic tension of the film comes from being "meticulously plotted", and that "it places its key characters in high-stakes predicaments where what they are forced to wager is their talent, their very lives, even their souls." The movie "convincingly demonstrates that when done right, moral and political quandaries can be the most intensely dramatic dilemmas of all."<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>American commentator <a href="/wiki/John_Podhoretz" title="John Podhoretz">John Podhoretz</a> called the film "one of the greatest movies ever made, and certainly the best film of this decade."<sup id="cite_ref-jp_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jp-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/William_F._Buckley,_Jr." title="William F. Buckley, Jr.">William F. Buckley, Jr.</a> wrote in his syndicated column that after the film was over, "I turned to my companion and said, 'I think that is the best movie I ever saw.'"<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/John_J._Miller" title="John J. Miller">John J. Miller</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/National_Review" title="National Review">National Review Online</a></i> named it #1 in his list of 'The Best Conservative Movies' of the last 25 years.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Several critics pointed to the film's subtle building up of details as one of its prime strengths. The film is built "on layers of emotional texture", wrote Stephanie Zacharek in <i>Salon</i> online magazine.<sup id="cite_ref-zach_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zach-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> Josh Rosenblatt, writing in the <i>Austin Chronicle</i> called the film "a triumph of muted grandeur."<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup> Lisa Schwarzbaum, writing in <i><a href="/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly" title="Entertainment Weekly">Entertainment Weekly</a></i>, pointed out that some of the subtlety in the film is due to the fact that "one of the movie's tensest moments take place with the most minimal of action" but that the director still "conveys everything he wants us to know about choice, fear, doubt, cowardice, and heroism."<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup> An article in <i><a href="/wiki/First_Things" title="First Things">First Things</a></i> makes a philosophical argument in defense of Wiesler's transformation.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup> The East German dissident songwriter <a href="/wiki/Wolf_Biermann" title="Wolf Biermann">Wolf Biermann</a> was guardedly enthusiastic about the film, writing in a March 2006 article in <i>Die Welt</i>: "The political tone is authentic, I was moved by the plot. But why? Perhaps I was just won over sentimentally, because of the seductive mass of details which look like they were lifted from my own past between the total ban of my work in 1965 and denaturalisation in 1976."<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Slavoj_%C5%BDi%C5%BEek" title="Slavoj iek">Slavoj iek</a>, reviewing the film for <i><a href="/wiki/In_These_Times" title="In These Times">In These Times</a></i>, criticized the film's perceived <a href="/wiki/Soft_pedal#Metaphorical_usage" title="Soft pedal">softpedaling</a> of the oppressiveness of the <a href="/wiki/German_Democratic_Republic" title="German Democratic Republic" class="mw-redirect">German Democratic Republic</a>, as well as structure of the playwright's character, which he thought was not very likely under a hard communist regime.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Anna_Funder" title="Anna Funder">Anna Funder</a>, the author of the book <i><a href="/wiki/Stasiland" title="Stasiland">Stasiland</a></i>, in a review for <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i> called <i>The Lives of Others</i> a "superb film" despite not being true to reality. She claims that it was not possible for a Stasi operative to have hidden information from superiors because Stasi employees themselves were watched and almost always operated in teams.<sup id="cite_ref-af_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-af-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film and its principals have won numerous awards. Among the most prestigious are:</p>
<p><i>The Lives of Others</i> also appeared on many critics' lists of the ten best films of 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Europe_List&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Europe List (page does not exist)">The Europe List</a>, the largest survey on European culture established that the top three films in European culture are</p>
<p>Belgium, Denmark, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Netherlands and Sweden had the film at number 1.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In September 2014, 43 members of the Israeli elite clandestine <a href="/wiki/Unit_8200" title="Unit 8200">Unit 8200</a> wrote a letter to Israels prime minister and army chief, refusing further service and claiming Israel made no distinction between Palestinians who are and are not involved in violence and that information collected harms innocent people. One of these people named a viewing of <i>The Lives of Others</i> as "the transformational moment".<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30"><span>[</span>30<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>The Lives of Others</i> has been referenced in political protests following the <a href="/wiki/2013_mass_surveillance_disclosures" title="2013 mass surveillance disclosures" class="mw-redirect">2013 mass surveillance disclosures</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Ellsberg" title="Daniel Ellsberg">Daniel Ellsberg</a> in an interview with <a href="/wiki/Brad_Friedman" title="Brad Friedman">Brad Friedman</a> on <a href="/wiki/Pacifica_Radio" title="Pacifica Radio">KPFK/Pacifica Radio</a> republished on <a href="/wiki/Salon.com" title="Salon.com" class="mw-redirect">salon.com</a> stressed the importance of <i>The Lives of Others</i> in light of <a href="/wiki/Edward_Snowden" title="Edward Snowden">Edward Snowden's</a> revelations:<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Film critic and historian <a href="/wiki/Carrie_Rickey" title="Carrie Rickey">Carrie Rickey</a> believes that <i>The Lives of Others</i> was one of two movies that influenced Snowden's actions, the other being the 1974 <a href="/wiki/Francis_Ford_Coppola" title="Francis Ford Coppola">Francis Ford Coppola</a> film <i><a href="/wiki/The_Conversation" title="The Conversation">The Conversation</a></i>, both being about wiretappers troubled by guilt.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On 25 June 2013, after revelations of collaboration between <a href="/wiki/NSA" title="NSA" class="mw-redirect">NSA</a> and <a href="/wiki/GCHQ" title="GCHQ" class="mw-redirect">GCHQ</a>, British journalist and documentary maker <a href="/wiki/Sarfraz_Manzoor" title="Sarfraz Manzoor">Sarfraz Manzoor</a> tweeted that "Now would be a good time to pitch a British remake of The Lives of Others."<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34"><span>[</span>34<span>]</span></a></sup> On 16 July 2013, American novelist and frequent cable news commentator Brad Thor stated "At what point did the Obama administration acquire the rights to reenact <i>The Lives of Others</i>?" <sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35"><span>[</span>35<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>French President <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_Sarkozy" title="Nicholas Sarkozy" class="mw-redirect">Nicholas Sarkozy</a> gave an interview in <a href="/wiki/Le_Figaro" title="Le Figaro">Le Figaro</a> expressing his outrage over being the victim of surveillance himself. He drew a direct comparison to Henckel von Donnersmarck's film: "This is not a scene from that marvellous film The Lives of Others, about East Germany and the activities of the Stasi. It is not the case of some dictator acting against his political opponents. This is France."<sup id="cite_ref-newyorker.com_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newyorker.com-36"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup> Because this interview, sales of <a href="/wiki/Le_Figaro" title="Le Figaro">Le Figaro</a> more than doubled.<sup id="cite_ref-newyorker.com_36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newyorker.com-36"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Donnersmarck and Ulrich Mhe were successfully sued for libel for an interview in which Mhe asserted that his second wife, Jenny Grllmann, informed on him while they were East German citizens<sup id="cite_ref-arnyt_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-arnyt-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> through the six years of their marriage.<sup id="cite_ref-globe_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-globe-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup> Mhe's former wife denied the claims, although 254 pages' worth of government records detailed her activities.<sup id="cite_ref-zach_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zach-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> However, Jenny Grllmann's real-life controller later claimed he had made up many of the details in the file and that the actress had been unaware that she was speaking to a Stasi agent.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span>[</span>38<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><b>Notes</b></p>
<p><b>Bibliography</b></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Inside Out</i> (2015 film)</h1>
<p><i><b>Inside Out</b></i> is a 2015 American <a href="/wiki/3D_film" title="3D film">3D</a> <a href="/wiki/Computer_animation" title="Computer animation">computer-animated</a> <a href="/wiki/Comedy-drama" title="Comedy-drama">comedy-drama</a> <a href="/wiki/Adventure_film" title="Adventure film">adventure film</a><sup id="cite_ref-RogerEbert.com_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RogerEbert.com-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> produced by <a href="/wiki/Pixar" title="Pixar">Pixar Animation Studios</a> and released by <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_Pictures" title="Walt Disney Pictures">Walt Disney Pictures</a>. The film was directed and co-written by <a href="/wiki/Pete_Docter" title="Pete Docter">Pete Docter</a>, co-directed and co-written by <a href="/wiki/Ronnie_del_Carmen" title="Ronnie del Carmen">Ronnie del Carmen</a> and produced by <a href="/wiki/Jonas_Rivera" title="Jonas Rivera">Jonas Rivera</a>, with music composed by <a href="/wiki/Michael_Giacchino" title="Michael Giacchino">Michael Giacchino</a>. The film is set in the mind of a young girl named Riley Andersen (Kaitlyn Dias), where <a href="/wiki/Emotion#Classification" title="Emotion">five personified emotions</a>Joy (<a href="/wiki/Amy_Poehler" title="Amy Poehler">Amy Poehler</a>), Sadness (<a href="/wiki/Phyllis_Smith" title="Phyllis Smith">Phyllis Smith</a>), Fear (<a href="/wiki/Bill_Hader" title="Bill Hader">Bill Hader</a>), Anger (<a href="/wiki/Lewis_Black" title="Lewis Black">Lewis Black</a>), and Disgust (<a href="/wiki/Mindy_Kaling" title="Mindy Kaling">Mindy Kaling</a>)try to lead her through life as her parents (<a href="/wiki/Diane_Lane" title="Diane Lane">Diane Lane</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kyle_MacLachlan" title="Kyle MacLachlan">Kyle MacLachlan</a>) <a href="/wiki/Relocation_(personal)" title="Relocation (personal)">move</a> the family from <a href="/wiki/Minnesota" title="Minnesota">Minnesota</a> to <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco" title="San Francisco">San Francisco</a> and she has to adjust to her new life.</p>
<p>Docter first began developing <i>Inside Out</i> in 2009 after noticing changes in his daughter's personality as she grew older. The film's producers consulted numerous <a href="/wiki/Psychologist" title="Psychologist">psychologists</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Dacher_Keltner" title="Dacher Keltner">Dacher Keltner</a> from the <a href="/wiki/University_of_California,_Berkeley" title="University of California, Berkeley">University of California, Berkeley</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-DKeltner2015_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DKeltner2015-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> who helped revise the story by emphasizing the <a href="/wiki/Neuropsychology" title="Neuropsychology">neuropsychological</a> findings that human emotions affect <a href="/wiki/Interpersonal_relationship" title="Interpersonal relationship">interpersonal relationships</a> and can be significantly moderated by them.<sup id="cite_ref-science_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-science-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>After premiering at the <a href="/wiki/2015_Cannes_Film_Festival" title="2015 Cannes Film Festival">68th Cannes Film Festival</a> in May, <i>Inside Out</i> was released in North America on June 19, 2015, accompanied by the short film <i><a href="/wiki/Lava_(2014_film)" title="Lava (2014 film)">Lava</a></i> directed by <a href="/wiki/James_Ford_Murphy" title="James Ford Murphy">James Ford Murphy</a>. Critics praised the film's concept, poignant subject matter, musical score, and the vocal performancesparticularly for Poehler, Smith, and <a href="/wiki/Richard_Kind" title="Richard Kind">Richard Kind</a>. The film grossed $90.4 million in its first weekendthe highest opening for an original title;<sup id="cite_ref-EWBiggestOriginal_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EWBiggestOriginal-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> it has accumulated over $856 million in worldwide box office revenue.<sup id="cite_ref-BOM_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BOM-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>Inside Out</i> has received several awards, including the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Animated_Feature_Film" title="Golden Globe Award for Best Animated Feature Film">Golden Globe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Critics%27_Choice_Movie_Award_for_Best_Animated_Feature" title="Critics' Choice Movie Award for Best Animated Feature">Critics' Choice Award</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Annie_Award_for_Best_Animated_Feature" title="Annie Award for Best Animated Feature">Annie Award</a> for Best Animated Feature, and has also been nominated at the <a href="/wiki/88th_Academy_Awards" title="88th Academy Awards">88th Academy Awards</a> for <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Animated_Feature" title="Academy Award for Best Animated Feature">Best Animated Feature</a> and <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Screenplay" title="Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay">Best Original Screenplay</a>.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>A girl named Riley Andersen is born in <a href="/wiki/Minnesota" title="Minnesota">Minnesota</a> and within her mind, five personifications of her <a href="/wiki/Emotion#Basic_emotions" title="Emotion">basic emotions</a> - Joy, Sadness, Fear, Disgust, and Anger - gradually come to life. As Riley grows up, her emotions influence her actions via a control console in her mind's Headquarters. Her memories are stored in colored orbs, which are sent into <a href="/wiki/Long-term_memory" title="Long-term memory">long-term memory</a> each night via a suction tube. The most important "core memories" are housed in a hub and power five "islands", each reflecting a different aspect of her personality. Joy's purpose is to keep Riley happy, Fear protects her from danger, Disgust guards her health and social status, and Anger ensures that she is treated fairly. Since no one understands Sadness's purpose (even Sadness herself), Joy tries to steer her away from the console.</p>
<p>When Riley is 11 years old, she and her parents move to <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco" title="San Francisco">San Francisco</a>. She is disappointed by their new home and other difficulties: the moving van with all their belongings gets lost, and her father is under stress due to his struggling business. When Sadness begins touching Riley's happy memories, turning them sad, Joy tries to guard them by keeping her isolated. On Riley's first day at her new school, Sadness causes her to cry in front of her class, creating a sad core memory. Joy tries to dispose of it before it reaches the hub, but instead knocks the other core memories loose during a struggle with Sadness, depowering the personality islands and rendering them unstable. Joy and Sadness are sucked into the memory tube and taken to the maze-like storage area of long-term memory, taking the core memories with them.</p>
<p>With Joy and Sadness gone, Anger, Fear, and Disgust try to maintain Riley's emotional state, but only end up unintentionally distancing her from her parents, friends and hobbies, making her personality islands gradually crumble and fall, one by one, into the "Memory Dump", an abyss where memories are forgotten. Finally, Anger inserts an idea into the console, prompting Riley to <a href="/wiki/Runaway_(dependent)" title="Runaway (dependent)">run away</a>, believing the only way she can be happy again is to go back to Minnesota.</p>
<p>Meanwhile, Joy and Sadness encounter Bing Bong, Riley's childhood <a href="/wiki/Imaginary_friend" title="Imaginary friend">imaginary friend</a>. He tells them they can get to Headquarters by riding the <a href="/wiki/Train_of_thought" title="Train of thought">train of thought</a>. After chasing the train through Riley's mind, the three eventually catch the train, but it is derailed when one of the personality islands collapses when Riley steals a credit card from her mother's purse, leaving Joy and Sadness distraught.</p>
<p>In desperation, Joy abandons Sadness and attempts to ride a "<a href="/wiki/Recall_(memory)" title="Recall (memory)">recall tube</a>" back to Headquarters, but a piece of a personality island collapses, breaking the tube and plunging Joy and Bing Bong into the Memory Dump. While despairingly looking through fading memories, Joy discovers a sad memory of a hockey game that becomes happy when Riley's parents and friends comfort her, causing her to finally realize Sadness' purpose: to alert others when Riley is emotionally overwhelmed and needs help.</p>
<p>Joy and Bing Bong try to use Bing Bong's old wagon rocket to escape the Memory Dump, but after several tries, Bing Bong realizes their combined weight is too much and jumps out on the third attempt, sacrificing himself and fading away to enable Joy to escape. Joy then uses various tools from around Riley's mind to propel herself and a despondent and unwilling Sadness through the air to Headquarters, to discover that Anger's idea has disabled the console, rendering Riley <a href="/wiki/Depression_(mood)" title="Depression (mood)">depressed</a> and <a href="/wiki/Apathy" title="Apathy">apathetic</a>. To the surprise of the others, Sadness (at Joy's insistence) takes control and extracts the idea, reactivating the console and prompting Riley to return home.</p>
<p>As Sadness reinstalls the core memories, Riley arrives home and bursts into tears, confessing to her parents that she misses her old life. As her parents reassure and comfort her, Joy and Sadness work the console together, creating a new core memory that combines their emotions, which restores one of the collapsed personality islands in a new and better form.
