One year later, Riley has fully adapted to her new home, made new friends, returned to her old hobbies, and adopted a few new ones (fueled by new, more nuanced core memories). On the inside, her emotions take their place at a new, larger console that allows them to work together, enabling Riley, now 12 years old, to lead a more emotionally complex life.</p>
<p>Several of the film's creators also contributed some voice acting, including director <a href="/wiki/Pete_Docter" title="Pete Docter">Pete Docter</a> as Father's Anger,<sup id="cite_ref-SKCastCameos_16-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SKCastCameos-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup> and co-director <a href="/wiki/Ronnie_del_Carmen" title="Ronnie del Carmen">Ronnie del Carmen</a>, who provided additional voices.<sup id="cite_ref-SKCastCameos_16-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SKCastCameos-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>As a child, director Pete Docter relocated with his family to <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a> when his father moved to study the music of <a href="/wiki/Carl_Nielsen" title="Carl Nielsen">Carl Nielsen</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nyt_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> While his sisters had an easy time adjusting to the new surroundings, Docter felt he was judged constantly by peers.<sup id="cite_ref-iw1_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iw1-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup> While other kids were interested in sports, Docter sat alone drawing, a hobby that eventually led him to animation.<sup id="cite_ref-iw_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iw-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup> His social anxiety ended by high school.<sup id="cite_ref-nyt_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In late 2009, Docter noticed his pre-teen daughter, Elie, exhibiting similar shyness.<sup id="cite_ref-v1_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-v1-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup> "She started getting more quiet and reserved, and that, frankly, triggered a lot of my own insecurities and fears," he said.<sup id="cite_ref-nyt_19-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> He imagined what happens in the human mind when emotions set in. The idea to depict it through animation excited Docter, who felt it the ideal form to portray "strong, opinionated, caricatured personalities."<sup id="cite_ref-npr_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-npr-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup> He began researching information about the mind, alongside Jonas Rivera, a producer, and Ronnie del Carmen, a secondary director. They consulted <a href="/wiki/Paul_Ekman" title="Paul Ekman">Paul Ekman</a>, a well-known psychologist who studies emotions, and <a href="/wiki/Dacher_Keltner" title="Dacher Keltner">Dacher Keltner</a>, a professor of psychology at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_California,_Berkeley" title="University of California, Berkeley">University of California, Berkeley</a>. Ekman had early in his career identified six core emotionsanger, fear, sadness, disgust, joy, and <a href="/wiki/Surprise_(emotion)" title="Surprise (emotion)">surprise</a>. Docter found surprise and fear to be too similar, which left him with five emotions to build characters around.<sup id="cite_ref-npr_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-npr-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup> Keltner focused on sadness being an emotion that strengthens relationships.<sup id="cite_ref-npr_23-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-npr-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup> Both emphasized how emotions organize social lives and the structuring of interpersonal interactions.<sup id="cite_ref-science_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-science-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The smash success of Docter's 2009 film <a href="/wiki/Up_(2009_film)" title="Up (2009 film)"><i>Up</i></a> encouraged those at Pixar to allow Docter to create another film with a more sophisticated story.<sup id="cite_ref-nyt_19-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>Inside Out</i> is the first Pixar film without input from co-founder and former <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc." title="Apple Inc.">Apple</a> CEO <a href="/wiki/Steve_Jobs" title="Steve Jobs">Steve Jobs</a>, who died in 2011. It also lacked extensive input from <a href="/wiki/John_Lasseter" title="John Lasseter">John Lasseter</a>, who was more focused on restructuring <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_Animation_Studios" title="Walt Disney Animation Studios">Walt Disney Animation Studios</a> in <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a> at the time of its production.<sup id="cite_ref-nyt_19-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> Executives at Disney and Pixar were positive at the proposal of making <i>Inside Out</i>, but acknowledged it would be difficult to market.<sup id="cite_ref-lat_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lat-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Docter recruited a story crew to help develop the film's plot line. Although animation as an industry had been dominated by men, half of the story crew were women, in an attempt to have more diverse input. The choice to focus the film on a girl came from research that claimed that females age 11 to 17 are more attuned to expressions and emotions than others. The idea to have Riley play hockey came from Del Carmen, who observed that the sport is very popular in Minnesota. They tried to stray away from stereotypically feminine interests, such as the color pink or dresses.<sup id="cite_ref-iw_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iw-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup> Initial ideas for the film found the main character, Riley, falling into a deep depression: Docter later felt they were inappropriate and scrapped them, although in the final film Riley does sink into a depression.<sup id="cite_ref-nyt_19-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film was first storyboarded over a period of two to three years, all the while undergoing screenings for Pixar's "Brain Trust", a small group of creative leaders at Pixar who oversee development on all films. After multiple screenings and suggestions from other filmmakers, the picture was put into production. It was again evaluated three months into that process. Kevin Nolting, editor of the film, estimated there were seven versions of <i>Inside Out</i> created before it even went into production.<sup id="cite_ref-hr_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hr-25"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup> The story team attempted to create as much contrast with characters as possible.<sup id="cite_ref-iw_21-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iw-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup> They found Joy the most complex character to write for, as she illustrates a broad range of "happy feelings".<sup id="cite_ref-vul_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vul-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup> The earliest idea present in the final film is that Joy holds onto youth too long, setting about a "social storm" for Riley.<sup id="cite_ref-mf_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mf-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup> It was not until several screenings later that they came upon the concept of moving to a new place, which created an external conflict that made the story easier to write. Initially, this crisis was to be set at a <a href="/wiki/Thanksgiving_Day" title="Thanksgiving Day" class="mw-redirect">Thanksgiving Day</a> pageant, in which Riley was hoping to be cast as its lead role, the turkey. Docter later deemed this idea too "bizarre" and it was replaced.<sup id="cite_ref-sf_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sf-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Docter estimated it took four years of development for the film to achieve success in marrying the architecture of Riley's mind and her personal troubles. The concept of "personality islands" helped develop the film's emotional stakes, as they directly affect events inside her mind and in her life. In one draft, the characters fell into "Idea Fields", where they would "cultivate new ideas", much like a farmer would cultivate crop.<sup id="cite_ref-sf_28-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sf-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup> The character of Bing Bonga discarded old imaginary friendcame about in one draft of the film as part of a refugee camp inside Riley's mind. It was difficult to achieve the correct tone for the film; for example, viewers could not be distracted by Joy's nature or feel negative about the mess she helps steer Riley into. Rivera credited the casting of Amy Poehler, in addition to the idea of moving, with helping the film find the right tone.<sup id="cite_ref-mf_27-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mf-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>An early version of the film focused on Joy and Fear getting lost together, as it seemed to be the most humorous choice. By July 2012, the project was set for an evaluation screening with other Pixar filmmakers. Docter gradually began to feel that the story was not working, which led to fears that he might be fired. He took a long walk at his home one Sunday, in which he began to consider himself a failure, his previous successes "flukes", and a general sense that he should resign from the film.<sup id="cite_ref-npr_23-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-npr-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup> While pondering what he would miss about Pixar, he concluded that he would miss his coworkers and friends most of all. He soon reached a breakthrough: that emotions are meant to connect people together, and that relationships are the most important things in life.<sup id="cite_ref-lat_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lat-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> He decided to replace Fear with Sadness, which he felt is crucial to renewal. He met with Rivera and Del Carmen that night to explain his change of plans, and to his surprise, they reacted positively to it. At the screening, he informed his superiors that new plans for the film were in order. Although a "scary moment", the film remained in production.<sup id="cite_ref-nyt_19-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Screenwriter <a href="/wiki/Michael_Arndt" title="Michael Arndt">Michael Arndt</a> worked for a year on the film's script, calling it "both a brilliantly creative idea but also incredibly challenging," but left the project in early 2011, adding that "knowing the Pixar process, there may not be a single word [I wrote] that remains in the final script! They've had writers work on it since then."<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film's voice cast of emotions, <a href="/wiki/Amy_Poehler" title="Amy Poehler">Amy Poehler</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lewis_Black" title="Lewis Black">Lewis Black</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mindy_Kaling" title="Mindy Kaling">Mindy Kaling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bill_Hader" title="Bill Hader">Bill Hader</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Phyllis_Smith" title="Phyllis Smith">Phyllis Smith</a>, were first announced in August 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-EWD232013_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EWD232013-30"><span>[</span>30<span>]</span></a></sup> With the release of the film's trailer in December 2014, it was revealed that <a href="/wiki/Diane_Lane" title="Diane Lane">Diane Lane</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kyle_MacLachlan" title="Kyle MacLachlan">Kyle MacLachlan</a> were cast in the film as Riley's parents.<sup id="cite_ref-USAT-Parents_15-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USAT-Parents-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Hader, who had previously cameoed in <i><a href="/wiki/Monsters_University" title="Monsters University">Monsters University</a></i>, was cast to voice Fear, a role that he felt he "weaseled" his way into by being a "huge fan" of Pixar's filmography.<sup id="cite_ref-ppl_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ppl-31"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup> Hader toured the studio over a week, and also "helped out" in the story room.<sup id="cite_ref-wp_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wp-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup> He was invited to play Fear by the end of his stay there, but was also asked to contact fellow <i><a href="/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live" title="Saturday Night Live">Saturday Night Live</a></i> (<i>SNL</i>) veteran Amy Poehler, which the team viewed as perfect for the character of Joy. "They said: 'Would you mind calling Amy? We don't want to call her and have her think we're some weirdo,'" he recalled. He phoned Poehler and explained the story to her, noting that her role would be the driving force in the film.<sup id="cite_ref-wp_32-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wp-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup> When the story was pitched to Kaling, she broke down in tears, explaining "I just think it's really beautiful that you guys are making a story that tells kids that it's difficult to grow up and it's OK to be sad about it."<sup id="cite_ref-npr_23-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-npr-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Smith was chosen by Rivera while he was watching <i><a href="/wiki/Bad_Teacher" title="Bad Teacher">Bad Teacher</a></i> and saw her in a lunch scene. He called Docter and said "I think we found our Sadness."<sup id="cite_ref-MashableSadness_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MashableSadness-33"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup> As the film contains several veterans of <i>SNL</i>, the film's team spent a week at that program for research on a live television sequence.<sup id="cite_ref-ppl_31-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ppl-31"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Richard_Kind" title="Richard Kind">Richard Kind</a>, who had previously starred in <i><a href="/wiki/A_Bug%27s_Life" title="A Bug's Life">A Bug's Life</a></i>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Cars_(franchise)" title="Cars (franchise)">Cars</a></i> series, and <i><a href="/wiki/Toy_Story_3" title="Toy Story 3">Toy Story 3</a></i>, portrayed Bing Bong. Kind tried to convey the same "sort of innocence" of his previous Pixar roles, and wound up not taking part in pre-release promotion as the producers decided to keep the character a secret.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34"><span>[</span>34<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film's art design is intended to reflect 1950s <a href="/wiki/Broadway_musical" title="Broadway musical" class="mw-redirect">Broadway musicals</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nyt_19-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> Docter imagined that with emotions for characters, they could "push the level of caricature both in the design and in the style of movement to degrees [they'd] never done before." To this end, they emulated animators <a href="/wiki/Tex_Avery" title="Tex Avery">Tex Avery</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chuck_Jones" title="Chuck Jones">Chuck Jones</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sf_28-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sf-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup> Docter informed supervising animators Shawn Krause and Victor Navone to push the graphic caricature of each character rather than sticking to the rigid behavior of each <a href="/wiki/RenderMan_(software)" title="RenderMan (software)">RenderMan</a> model. This required an artist to draw over characters in the film during <a href="/wiki/Dailies" title="Dailies">dailies</a>, using a <a href="/wiki/Wacom_Cintiq" title="Wacom Cintiq" class="mw-redirect">Wacom Cintiq</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-iwjun5_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iwjun5-35"><span>[</span>35<span>]</span></a></sup> One of the first scenes the team worked on was the dinnertime scene, in which viewers rapidly switch between the real world and Headquarters inside the family's minds.<sup id="cite_ref-hr_25-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hr-25"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In envisaging how the mind's interior would be depicted, the filmmakers concentrated on the word <i>electrochemical</i>; <a href="/wiki/Ralph_Eggleston" title="Ralph Eggleston">Ralph Eggleston</a>, the film's production designer, explained, "It meant thinking of things as energy or energy-based, excitable."<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup> Each emotion has a glowing, "effervescent quality" to them (particularly Joy), which was difficult to animate as it could be viewed as distracting.<sup id="cite_ref-BI_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BI-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup> "The characters are created with this energy because we are trying to represent what emotions would look like. They are made up of particles that actually move. Instead of being skin and solid, it is a massive collection of energy," Docter remarked.<sup id="cite_ref-HollywoodReporter_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HollywoodReporter-38"><span>[</span>38<span>]</span></a></sup> The team worked for eight months on Joy's "sparkly" aura, but was prepared to delete it, as it would affect the film's budget. However, Lasseter requested that it be applied for each emotion. "You could hear the core technical staff just hitting the ground, the budget falling through the roof," recalled Eggleston.<sup id="cite_ref-BI_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BI-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film is localized to accommodate international audiences: In the Japanese version, for example, Riley is disgusted by green <a href="/wiki/Bell_pepper" title="Bell pepper">bell peppers</a>, rather than by broccoli (the only topping offered by the local pizzeria), to reflect the fact that broccoli is generally less undesirable to Japanese children.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39"><span>[</span>39<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Michael Giacchino composed the film's score; this was his fifth collaboration with Pixar and his second collaboration with Pete Docter after <i>Up</i>. The producers first met with Giacchino to explain the film's concept and screen it for him. In response, he composed an eight-minute suite of music, unconnected to the film, based on his emotions viewing it.<sup id="cite_ref-sf_28-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sf-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup> Rivera noted that while both Giacchino and Docter were musicians, they discussed the film in terms of story and character.<sup id="cite_ref-sf_28-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sf-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><span id="Music"></span><span id="Score"></span><span id="Soundtrack"></span></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_Records" title="Walt Disney Records">Walt Disney Records</a> released the soundtrack on June 16, 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-FMRInsideSoundtrack_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FMRInsideSoundtrack-40"><span>[</span>40<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>All music composed by <a href="/wiki/Michael_Giacchino" title="Michael Giacchino">Michael Giacchino</a>.</p>
<p><i>Inside Out</i> was first announced in August 2011 at the <a href="/wiki/D23_Expo" title="D23 Expo" class="mw-redirect">D23 Expo</a>. In December 2012, Bleeding Cool reported the title of the film would be <i>The Inside Out</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span>[</span>41<span>]</span></a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/ComingSoon.net" title="ComingSoon.net" class="mw-redirect">ComingSoon.net</a> reported it would be <i>Inside Out</i> the following February.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span>[</span>42<span>]</span></a></sup> In April 2013, <a href="/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company" title="The Walt Disney Company">Disney</a> officially announced the title on <a href="/wiki/Twitter" title="Twitter">Twitter</a> as <i>Inside Out</i>, during <a href="/wiki/National_Association_of_Theatre_Owners#CinemaCon_.28formerly_ShoWest.29" title="National Association of Theatre Owners">CinemaCon</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span>[</span>43<span>]</span></a></sup> Prior to its release, the film underwent a test screening for children, due to concerns from executives that it would be too complex for younger audiencesa fear quelled when the audience reacted positively to the picture.<sup id="cite_ref-vul_26-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vul-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film premiered on May 18, 2015, at the <a href="/wiki/2015_Cannes_Film_Festival" title="2015 Cannes Film Festival">68th Cannes Film Festival</a>, in an out-of-competition screening.<sup id="cite_ref-LATCannes2015_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LATCannes2015-44"><span>[</span>44<span>]</span></a></sup> In the United States, it premiered on June 8, 2015, at the <a href="/wiki/El_Capitan_Theatre" title="El Capitan Theatre">El Capitan Theatre</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hollywood" title="Hollywood">Hollywood</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-VarietyPremiere_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VarietyPremiere-45"><span>[</span>45<span>]</span></a></sup> and received a wide theatrical release starting on June 19, 2015, in 2D, 3D, and select <a href="/wiki/IMAX_3D" title="IMAX 3D" class="mw-redirect">IMAX 3D</a> theatres.<sup id="cite_ref-AWNTitle2015_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AWNTitle2015-46"><span>[</span>46<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span>[</span>47<span>]</span></a></sup> It was the first animated movie to be released in <a href="/wiki/Dolby_Laboratories" title="Dolby Laboratories">Dolby Vision</a> format in <a href="/wiki/Dolby_Cinema" title="Dolby Cinema">Dolby Cinema</a> and the second for Disney following <i><a href="/wiki/Tomorrowland_(film)" title="Tomorrowland (film)">Tomorrowland</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48"><span>[</span>48<span>]</span></a></sup> Also notable was the fact that it was one of two animated movies (the other being <i>The Good Dinosaur</i>) released by Pixar in the same calendar year, a first for the company.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49"><span>[</span>49<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>A short animated film, titled <i><a href="/wiki/Lava_(2014_film)" title="Lava (2014 film)">Lava</a></i>, accompanied <i>Inside Out</i> during its theatrical release. The musical love story was directed by <a href="/wiki/James_Ford_Murphy" title="James Ford Murphy">James Ford Murphy</a> and produced by Andrea Warren. The story was inspired by the isolated beauty of tropical islands and the explosive allure of ocean volcanoes, and takes place over millions of years.<sup id="cite_ref-THRLavaAnnounced_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-THRLavaAnnounced-50"><span>[</span>50<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On June 18, 2015, <a href="/wiki/Skype" title="Skype">Skype</a> added faces of the five "emotions" of the film as <a href="/wiki/Emoticons" title="Emoticons" class="mw-redirect">emoticons</a> available for use in its IM service for the next three months.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span>[</span>51<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Inside Out</i> was released by <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_Studios_Home_Entertainment" title="Walt Disney Studios Home Entertainment">Walt Disney Studios Home Entertainment</a> on <a href="/wiki/Blu-ray" title="Blu-ray">Blu-ray</a> (2D and 3D) and DVD on November 3, 2015,<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52"><span>[</span>52<span>]</span></a></sup> while a <a href="/wiki/Digital_distribution" title="Digital distribution">digital release</a> was released on October 13, 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53"><span>[</span>53<span>]</span></a></sup> A short film set in the world of <i>Inside Out</i>, titled <i><a href="/wiki/Riley%27s_First_Date%3F" title="Riley's First Date?">Riley's First Date?</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-ZavviInsideOut3D_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ZavviInsideOut3D-54"><span>[</span>54<span>]</span></a></sup> and directed by <a href="/wiki/Josh_Cooley" title="Josh Cooley">Josh Cooley</a>, the head of story on the film,<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55"><span>[</span>55<span>]</span></a></sup> was included, along with Pixar's theatrical short, <i><a href="/wiki/Lava_(2014_film)" title="Lava (2014 film)">Lava</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-ZavviInsideOut3D_54-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ZavviInsideOut3D-54"><span>[</span>54<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>An <i>Inside Out</i> play set featuring all five emotions as playable characters was made available for <i><a href="/wiki/Disney_Infinity_3.0" title="Disney Infinity 3.0">Disney Infinity 3.0</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span>[</span>56<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>A mobile game, <i>Inside Out: Thought Bubbles</i>, was released on June 18, 2015 by Disney Mobile Games on <a href="/wiki/App_Store_(iOS)" title="App Store (iOS)">Apple App Store</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google_Play" title="Google Play">Google Play</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amazon_Appstore" title="Amazon Appstore">Amazon Appstore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Windows_Store" title="Windows Store">Windows Store</a> and <a href="/wiki/Windows_Phone_Store" title="Windows Phone Store">Windows Phone Store</a>. Playing as Riley's emotions, players have to match and sort memory bubbles through 270 levels inspired by the film's locations.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57"><span>[</span>57<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Inside Out</i> grossed $356.5 million in North America and $500.3 million in other territories for a worldwide total of $856.8 million, against a budget of $175 million.<sup id="cite_ref-BOM_5-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BOM-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> It is the second highest-grossing 2015 animated film, the <a href="/wiki/2015_in_film" title="2015 in film">seventh highest-grossing film of 2015</a>, the third highest-grossing Pixar film, the ninth highest-grossing film released by <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_Studios_Motion_Pictures" title="Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures">Disney</a>, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_animated_films" title="List of highest-grossing animated films">tenth highest-grossing animated film of all time</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_films" title="List of highest-grossing films">45th highest-grossing film</a> overall (with the latter four rankings not <a href="/wiki/Real_versus_nominal_value_(economics)" title="Real versus nominal value (economics)">adjusted for inflation</a>).</p>
<p><i>Inside Out</i> opened across 3,946 theaters in the United States and Canada, of which 3,100 showed the film in <a href="/wiki/3D_film" title="3D film">3D</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58"><span>[</span>58<span>]</span></a></sup> It grossed $3.7 million during its Thursday-night showings. This was a record among Pixar films that had Thursday-night showings, but behind <i><a href="/wiki/Toy_Story_3" title="Toy Story 3">Toy Story 3</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s $4 million midnight showing.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span>[</span>59<span>]</span></a></sup> The film then earned $34.2 million on its opening day, which is the second-largest opening day for a Pixar film behind <i>Toy Story 3</i> ($41.1 million).<sup id="cite_ref-CS_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CS-60"><span>[</span>60<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-OP_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OP-61"><span>[</span>61<span>]</span></a></sup> It ended its opening weekend in second place with $90.4 million, behind the second-weekend gross of dinosaur thriller <i><a href="/wiki/Jurassic_World" title="Jurassic World">Jurassic World</a></i> ($106.6 million).<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62"><span>[</span>62<span>]</span></a></sup> Although it was Pixar's first film not to debut at #1, its opening weekend gross was still the biggest for a Pixar original film (breaking <i><a href="/wiki/The_Incredibles" title="The Incredibles">The Incredibles</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span> record), the studio's second-biggest of all time (behind <i>Toy Story 3</i>), the biggest weekend debut for a film that did not debut at #1 (breaking <i><a href="/wiki/The_Day_After_Tomorrow" title="The Day After Tomorrow">The Day After Tomorrow</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s record),<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63"><span>[</span>63<span>]</span></a></sup> and the top opening for any original film, live-action or otherwise, not based on sourced material, eclipsing the $77 million debut of <i><a href="/wiki/Avatar_(2009_film)" title="Avatar (2009 film)">Avatar</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-EWBiggestOriginal_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EWBiggestOriginal-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-OPW_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OPW-64"><span>[</span>64<span>]</span></a></sup> The film's successful opening has been attributed to its Cannes premiere, <a href="/wiki/CinemaCon" title="CinemaCon" class="mw-redirect">CinemaCon</a> press screening, its 98% <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> score, good <a href="/wiki/Word-of-mouth" title="Word-of-mouth" class="mw-redirect">word-of-mouth</a>, <a href="/wiki/Father%27s_Day" title="Father's Day">Father's Day</a> weekend and a successful Tuesday night Fathom screening.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65"><span>[</span>65<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66"><span>[</span>66<span>]</span></a></sup> In its <a href="/wiki/Second_weekend_in_box_office_performance" title="Second weekend in box office performance">second weekend</a>, the film fell by 42% to $52.3 million and still held the second spot behind <i>Jurassic World</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67"><span>[</span>67<span>]</span></a></sup> The rest of the week saw it slightly ahead of the latter.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68"><span>[</span>68<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>Inside Out</i> reached the #1 spot at the box office on its third weekend with $29.8 million.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69"><span>[</span>69<span>]</span></a></sup> Overall, IMAX contributed 10% or $36 million (as of September 4, 2015) of its total North American revenue.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70"><span>[</span>70<span>]</span></a></sup> It ended up grossing a total of $356.5 million and became the second highest-grossing Pixar film (behind <i>Toy Story 3</i>),<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71"><span>[</span>71<span>]</span></a></sup> the fourth highest-grossing film of 2015,<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72"><span>[</span>72<span>]</span></a></sup> the seventh highest-grossing animated film of all time,<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73"><span>[</span>73<span>]</span></a></sup> the highest of 2015, and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_films_in_Canada_and_the_United_States" title="List of highest-grossing films in Canada and the United States">thirtieth highest-grossing films in Canada and the United States</a> (not adjusted for inflation).<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74"><span>[</span>74<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Outside North America, the film earned an estimated $40.3 million on its opening weekend from 37 countries, which is 42% of the entire international market.<sup id="cite_ref-SWO_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SWO-75"><span>[</span>75<span>]</span></a></sup> Its largest openings were recorded in China ($11.7 million), the UK, Ireland and Malta ($11.4 million), Mexico ($8.6 million), Russia and the CIS ($7.6 million), Italy ($7.4 million), Germany ($7.1 million) and South Korea ($5.1 million).<sup id="cite_ref-SWO_75-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SWO-75"><span>[</span>75<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76"><span>[</span>76<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77"><span>[</span>77<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Intl_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Intl-78"><span>[</span>78<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79"><span>[</span>79<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Overseas8thOpening_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Overseas8thOpening-80"><span>[</span>80<span>]</span></a></sup> In total earnings, its largest markets outside the U.S. and Canada are the United Kingdom ($58.1 million), South Korea ($31.7 million) and Mexico ($31 million).<sup id="cite_ref-Overseas2ndOpening_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Overseas2ndOpening-81"><span>[</span>81<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Overseas3rdOpening_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Overseas3rdOpening-82"><span>[</span>82<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6thOverseasOpening_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6thOverseasOpening-83"><span>[</span>83<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84"><span>[</span>84<span>]</span></a></sup> It became the highest-grossing Disney or Pixar animated film of all time in Mexico (ahead of <i><a href="/wiki/Frozen_(2013_film)" title="Frozen (2013 film)">Frozen</a></i>), the Philippines (ahead of <i><a href="/wiki/Big_Hero_6_(film)" title="Big Hero 6 (film)">Big Hero 6</a></i>),<sup id="cite_ref-ph-open_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ph-open-85"><span>[</span>85<span>]</span></a></sup> India and Ukraine, and in Russia, it is the second highest-grossing Disney or Pixar film and the first Pixar film to exceed one billion rubles.<sup id="cite_ref-Intl_78-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Intl-78"><span>[</span>78<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Review_aggregator" title="Review aggregator">review aggregator</a> website Rotten Tomatoes gives the film a rating of 98%, based on 301 reviews, with a <a href="/wiki/Weighted_arithmetic_mean" title="Weighted arithmetic mean">rating average</a> of 9/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "Inventive, gorgeously animated, and powerfully moving, <i>Inside Out</i> is another outstanding addition to the Pixar library of modern animated classics".<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86"><span>[</span>86<span>]</span></a></sup> The film also topped the site's Top 100 Animation Movies list<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87"><span>[</span>87<span>]</span></a></sup> and attains the highest position of a film released in the 21st century on the Top 100 Movies of All Time list at number 13.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88"><span>[</span>88<span>]</span></a></sup> On <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>, which assigns a normalized rating, the film has a score of 94 out of 100, based on 48 critics, indicating "universal acclaim".<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89"><span>[</span>89<span>]</span></a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/CinemaScore" title="CinemaScore">CinemaScore</a> polls, cinema audiences gave <i>Inside Out</i> an average score of "A" on an A+ to F scale.<sup id="cite_ref-CS_60-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CS-60"><span>[</span>60<span>]</span></a></sup> Amy Poehler, Phyllis Smith<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90"><span>[</span>90<span>]</span></a></sup> and Richard Kind have received praise for their vocal performances in the film.</p>
<p>Prior to its release, there was concern among the general public that Pixar films were declining in quality, with an over-reliance on sequels.<sup id="cite_ref-ATLANTIC_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ATLANTIC-91"><span>[</span>91<span>]</span></a></sup> Likewise, <a href="/wiki/DreamWorks_Animation" title="DreamWorks Animation">DreamWorks Animation</a> was beginning to flounder in the early 2010s as several films performed below expectations at the box office, leading to speculation that the "genre" of <a href="/wiki/Computer_animation" title="Computer animation">computer animation</a> was "in a funk".<sup id="cite_ref-nyt_19-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>Inside Out</i> has been hailed as a return to form by numerous film critics.<sup id="cite_ref-ct_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ct-92"><span>[</span>92<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93"><span>[</span>93<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nyt15_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt15-94"><span>[</span>94<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-atl15_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-atl15-95"><span>[</span>95<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-reel_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reel-96"><span>[</span>96<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Following an advance screening at CinemaCon on April 22, 2015, the film was well received by audiences. Praise was aimed for its smart storyline, although some wondered whether the concept was too complicated for young audiences and to attract family crowds.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97"><span>[</span>97<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98"><span>[</span>98<span>]</span></a></sup> After premiering at the 2015 Cannes Film Festival, the film attracted praise from film critics. Peter Debruge of <i><a href="/wiki/Variety_(magazine)" title="Variety (magazine)">Variety</a></i> was effusive, calling it the studio's "greatest idea" and "a stunningly original concept that [...] promises to forever change the way people think about the way people think".<sup id="cite_ref-v_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-v-99"><span>[</span>99<span>]</span></a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Chicago_Tribune" title="Chicago Tribune">Chicago Tribune</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s <a href="/wiki/Michael_Phillips_(critic)" title="Michael Phillips (critic)">Michael Phillips</a> called it the studio's best since <i>Up</i> (also directed by Docter), a "consistently inventive and a heartening corrective to recent, stockholder-driven inferiorities".<sup id="cite_ref-ct_92-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ct-92"><span>[</span>92<span>]</span></a></sup> Todd McCarthy of <i>The Hollywood Reporter</i> deemed it an "audacious concept" that stands among the most "conceptually trippy films" for family audiences.<sup id="cite_ref-THRReview_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-THRReview-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> "With its quite literally cerebral bent, I think <i>Inside Out</i> might have some trouble fully connecting with younger kids, but grown-ups are likely to shed more than a few tears", remarked Richard Lawson of <i><a href="/wiki/Vanity_Fair_(magazine)" title="Vanity Fair (magazine)">Vanity Fair</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-vf_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vf-100"><span>[</span>100<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s <a href="/wiki/Peter_Bradshaw" title="Peter Bradshaw">Peter Bradshaw</a> felt it "buoyant and sweet-natured," though slightly inferior to Pixar's best.<sup id="cite_ref-tg_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tg-101"><span>[</span>101<span>]</span></a></sup> Ignatiy Vishnevetsky of <i><a href="/wiki/The_A.V._Club" title="The A.V. Club">The A.V. Club</a></i>, while overall positive on the film, said it "trades the wordless gracefulness and sense of discovery of the animation studio's best work for explanatory voice-over and nonstop exposition", also arguing that the Pixar animators could have been more visually adventurous to match the conceptual ambition.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102"><span>[</span>102<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>As the film went into wide release, it continued to attract acclaim. Aside from naming it the best film of 2015, Kristopher Tapley of <i><a href="/wiki/HitFix" title="HitFix">HitFix</a></i> called it as "one of the best films of the 21st century."<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103"><span>[</span>103<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104"><span>[</span>104<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/A._O._Scott" title="A. O. Scott">A. O. Scott</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> deemed the film "an absolute delight", reserving particular praise for its "defense of sorrow, an argument for the necessity of melancholy dressed in the bright colors of entertainment".<sup id="cite_ref-nyt15_94-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt15-94"><span>[</span>94<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Post" title="The Washington Post">The Washington Post</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s Ann Hornaday considered it "that rare movie that transcends its role as pure entertainment to become something genuinely cathartic, even therapeutic, giving children a symbolic language with which to manage their unruliest emotions".<sup id="cite_ref-wp15_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wp15-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Richard_Roeper" title="Richard Roeper">Richard Roeper</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Chicago_Sun-Times" title="Chicago Sun-Times">Chicago Sun-Times</a></i> found it "bold, gorgeous, sweet, funny, [and] sometimes heartbreakingly sad", deeming it one of the best films of the year.<sup id="cite_ref-cst15_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cst15-105"><span>[</span>105<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly" title="Entertainment Weekly">Entertainment Weekly</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s Chris Nashawathy extolled it as "transcendent and touching [...] so smart and psychologically clever".<sup id="cite_ref-ew15_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ew15-106"><span>[</span>106<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s Mary Pols felt it a "nearly hallucinogenic, entirely beautiful" work that "defies the conventions of family movies".<sup id="cite_ref-t15_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-t15-107"><span>[</span>107<span>]</span></a></sup> Christopher Orr of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Atlantic" title="The Atlantic">The Atlantic</a></i> urged readers to view the picture, calling it "Pixar once again at the top of its game, telling the kind of thoughtful, moving meta-story it's hard to imagine being produced anywhere else".<sup id="cite_ref-atl15_95-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-atl15-95"><span>[</span>95<span>]</span></a></sup> Wai Chee Dimock in the <i><a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Review_of_Books" title="Los Angeles Review of Books">Los Angeles Review of Books</a></i> compared the film to the work of neuroscientists <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Damasio" title="Antonio Damasio">Antonio Damasio</a>, Dacher Keltner, and <a href="/wiki/Oliver_Sacks" title="Oliver Sacks">Oliver Sacks</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108"><span>[</span>108<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Inside Out</i> has received dozens of industry and critics awards. The film received 15 Best Picture, 21 Best Original Screenplay and 40 Best Animated Feature nominations from over 50 different organizations and associations.<sup id="cite_ref-mcawardsnoms_109-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mcawardsnoms-109"><span>[</span>109<span>]</span></a></sup> The film is nominated for the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Animated_Feature" title="Academy Award for Best Animated Feature">Academy Award for Best Animated Feature</a> and <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Screenplay" title="Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay">Best Original Screenplay</a> at the <a href="/wiki/88th_Academy_Awards" title="88th Academy Awards">88th Academy Awards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110"><span>[</span>110<span>]</span></a></sup> It received ten out of 14 <a href="/wiki/Annie_Awards" title="Annie Awards" class="mw-redirect">Annie Awards</a> at the <a href="/wiki/43rd_Annie_Awards" title="43rd Annie Awards">43rd Annie Awards</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Annie_Award_for_Directing_in_a_Feature_Production" title="Annie Award for Directing in a Feature Production">Outstanding Achievement in Directing in an Animated Feature Production</a> for Docter, <a href="/wiki/Annie_Award_for_Voice_Acting_in_a_Feature_Production" title="Annie Award for Voice Acting in a Feature Production">Outstanding Achievement in Voice Acting in an Animated Feature Production</a> for Smith and <a href="/wiki/Annie_Award_for_Best_Animated_Feature" title="Annie Award for Best Animated Feature">Best Animated Feature</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111"><span>[</span>111<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112"><span>[</span>112<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/American_Film_Institute" title="American Film Institute">American Film Institute</a> selected <i>Inside Out</i> as one of the <a href="/wiki/American_Film_Institute#Top_10_Films" title="American Film Institute">Top Ten Films of the year</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-AFI_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AFI-113"><span>[</span>113<span>]</span></a></sup> The film received the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Animated_Feature_Film" title="Golden Globe Award for Best Animated Feature Film">Golden Globe Award for Best Animated Feature Film</a> at the <a href="/wiki/73rd_Golden_Globe_Awards" title="73rd Golden Globe Awards">73rd Golden Globe Awards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114"><span>[</span>114<span>]</span></a></sup> It received three <a href="/wiki/Critics%27_Choice_Movie_Award" title="Critics' Choice Movie Award" class="mw-redirect">Critics' Choice Movie Award</a> nominations including <a href="/wiki/Critics%27_Choice_Movie_Award_for_Best_Animated_Feature" title="Critics' Choice Movie Award for Best Animated Feature">Best Animated Feature</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115"><span>[</span>115<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/New_York_Film_Critics_Circle" title="New York Film Critics Circle">New York Film Critics Circle</a> awarded <i>Inside Out</i> <a href="/wiki/New_York_Film_Critics_Circle_Award_for_Best_Animated_Film" title="New York Film Critics Circle Award for Best Animated Film">Best Animated Film</a><sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116"><span>[</span>116<span>]</span></a></sup> and it was named <a href="/wiki/National_Board_of_Review:_Top_Ten_Films" title="National Board of Review: Top Ten Films">Film of the Year</a> by <a href="/wiki/National_Board_of_Review" title="National Board of Review">National Board of Review</a> with also winning <a href="/wiki/National_Board_of_Review_Award_for_Best_Animated_Film" title="National Board of Review Award for Best Animated Film">Best Animated Film</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117"><span>[</span>117<span>]</span></a></sup> The film was runner-up for <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Film_Critics_Association_Award_for_Best_Animated_Film" title="Los Angeles Film Critics Association Award for Best Animated Film">Best Animated Film</a> at <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Film_Critics_Association_Awards" title="Los Angeles Film Critics Association Awards" class="mw-redirect">Los Angeles Film Critics Association Awards</a><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118"><span>[</span>118<span>]</span></a></sup> and at <a href="/wiki/San_Diego_Film_Critics_Society_Awards" title="San Diego Film Critics Society Awards" class="mw-redirect">San Diego Film Critics Society Awards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119"><span>[</span>119<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120"><span>[</span>120<span>]</span></a></sup> It received four nominations from <a href="/wiki/Satellite_Awards" title="Satellite Awards">Satellite Awards</a> including <a href="/wiki/Satellite_Award_for_Best_Original_Screenplay" title="Satellite Award for Best Original Screenplay">Best Screenplay - Original</a>, <a href="/wiki/Satellite_Award_for_Best_Animated_or_Mixed_Media_Feature" title="Satellite Award for Best Animated or Mixed Media Feature">Best Animated or Mixed Media Feature</a> and <a href="/wiki/Satellite_Award_for_Best_Original_Score" title="Satellite Award for Best Original Score">Best Original Score</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121"><span>[</span>121<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Inside Out</i> was named one of the best films of 2015 by numerous critics and publications and was ranked second on <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> and fourth on <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>'s best scored film of 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122"><span>[</span>122<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123"><span>[</span>123<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124"><span>[</span>124<span>]</span></a></sup> According to CriticsTop10, the film appeared in 340 critics' lists, with 27 of them giving the film the number one spot. It is among the most acclaimed films of 2015 alongside <i><a href="/wiki/Mad_Max:_Fury_Road" title="Mad Max: Fury Road">Mad Max: Fury Road</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Carol_(film)" title="Carol (film)">Carol</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Spotlight_(film)" title="Spotlight (film)">Spotlight</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Room_(2015_film)" title="Room (2015 film)">Room</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_(film)" title="Brooklyn (film)">Brooklyn</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125"><span>[</span>125<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On June 24, 2015, when asked about if there are plans for a possible sequel, Pete Docter explained that he had no current plans to create a sequel, stating, "Theres no sequel idea from me at this point", but he also said, "Never say never".<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127"><span>[</span>127<span>]</span></a></sup> On January 14, 2016, in an interview with <i><a href="/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly" title="Entertainment Weekly">Entertainment Weekly</a></i>, Docter stated that a sequel is possible, and that he and Pixar will explore ideas for a sequel, saying: "We'll see if anything turns up. To me it's not as simple as: 'We liked it, so let's make another one.' What happens is you design these characters not so much looks-wise but as they are as character and people for a story. So we'll explore it and see what happens."<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128"><span>[</span>128<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Fury</i> (2014 film)</h1>
<p><i><b>Fury</b></i> is a 2014 American-British <a href="/wiki/War_film" title="War film">war film</a> written and directed by <a href="/wiki/David_Ayer" title="David Ayer">David Ayer</a>. The film stars <a href="/wiki/Brad_Pitt" title="Brad Pitt">Brad Pitt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shia_LaBeouf" title="Shia LaBeouf">Shia LaBeouf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Logan_Lerman" title="Logan Lerman">Logan Lerman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michael_Pe%C3%B1a" title="Michael Pea">Michael Pea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jon_Bernthal" title="Jon Bernthal">Jon Bernthal</a>. The film portrays US tank crews in <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a> during the final days of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>. Ayer was influenced by the service of veterans in his family and by reading books, such as Belton Y. Cooper's <i>Death Traps</i>, about American armored warfare in World War II. Ayer aimed for a greater degree of realism in the film than in other World War II dramas.<sup id="cite_ref-nytimes.com_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes.com-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Rehearsal began in early September 2013 in <a href="/wiki/Hertfordshire" title="Hertfordshire">Hertfordshire</a>, <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a> followed by <a href="/wiki/Principal_photography" title="Principal photography">principal photography</a> on September 30, 2013, in <a href="/wiki/Oxfordshire" title="Oxfordshire">Oxfordshire</a>. Filming continued for a month and a half at different locations, which included the city of <a href="/wiki/Oxford" title="Oxford">Oxford</a>, and concluded on November 13. <i>Fury</i> was released on October 17, 2014. The film received positive reviews from critics and proved to be successful at the box office.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>Don "Wardaddy" Collier, a battle-hardened <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army" title="United States Army">U.S. Army</a> <a href="/wiki/Staff_sergeant#U.S._Army" title="Staff sergeant">staff sergeant</a> in the <a href="/wiki/2nd_Armored_Division_(United_States)" title="2nd Armored Division (United States)">2nd Armored Division</a>, commands an <a href="/wiki/M4_Sherman" title="M4 Sherman">M4 Sherman</a> "Easy Eight" tank named <i>Fury</i> and its five-man, all-veteran crew: gunner Boyd "Bible" Swan; loader Grady "Coon-Ass" Travis; and driver Trini "Gordo" Garcia (all who have been together since the <a href="/wiki/North_African_Campaign" title="North African Campaign">North African Campaign</a>), as the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allies</a> make their final push into <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>. When the tank's original assistant driver/bow gunner, "Red", is <a href="/wiki/Killed_in_action" title="Killed in action">killed in action</a>, Norman Ellison, a fresh recruit trained only as a <a href="/wiki/Clerk" title="Clerk">clerk typist</a>, is assigned as a reluctant replacement.</p>
<p>As the Fury and its tank platoon moves deeper into Germany, Norman's inexperience becomes dangerous: first when he fails to shoot several <a href="/wiki/Hitler_Youth" title="Hitler Youth">Hitler Youth</a> scouts  who ambush the commanding officer's tank with a <a href="/wiki/Panzerfaust" title="Panzerfaust">Panzerfaust</a>, killing him and his crew; then later during a battle with German anti-tank guns, where he hesitates under fire. Wardaddy is angered at his incompetence, and after the latter incident, he orders Norman to execute a captive German soldier. When Norman refuses, Wardaddy wrestles a pistol into his hand and forces him to pull the trigger, killing the prisoner and traumatizing Norman. Wardaddy then leads the tanks to capture a small German town, where Norman earns his first confirmed kills. While searching an apartment, Wardaddy and Norman encounter a German woman, Irma, and her younger cousin, Emma. Norman and Emma go into the bedroom together, and fall in love. The four then have breakfast, but the rest of Fury's crew barges in, harassing the women and angering Wardaddy and Norman. The men soon leave, and then a German artillery bombardment strikes the town; Norman finds Emma among the dead, traumatizing him once more.</p>
<p>Wardaddy and his platoon are then ordered to hold some vital <a href="/wiki/Crossroads_(junction)" title="Crossroads (junction)" class="mw-redirect">crossroads</a> to prevent the enemy from attacking the Allies' vulnerable rear lines. They head to their objective, only to be ambushed by a German <a href="/wiki/Tiger_I" title="Tiger I">Tiger I</a>. Wardaddy leads the Shermans in a counter-attack; their shells fail to penetrate the Tiger's thick frontal armor, and its heavier cannon obliterates most of the platoon. The Fury eventually destroys the Tiger by outmaneuvering it and firing into its thinner rear armor, but with the radio damaged the Fury is forced to continue the mission alone. Just as it reaches the crossroads, the tank is immobilized by a <a href="/wiki/Landmine" title="Landmine" class="mw-redirect">landmine</a>. Norman is ordered to scout a nearby hill and he spots a battalion of <a href="/wiki/Waffen-SS" title="Waffen-SS">Waffen-SS</a> heading their way. The crew initially wants to abandon the tank and escape on foot, but Wardaddy refuses to leave, obligating the men to stay and fight.</p>
<p>The crew disguises the Fury so that it would appear knocked-out, and then waits for the approaching Germans inside. Wardaddy breaks out a bottle of whiskey and shares it with the others, and Norman is finally accepted by the crew and given his nickname: "Machine". When the Germans arrive, the Fury reactivates and ambushes them: outnumbered and surrounded, Wardaddy and his men nevertheless inflict heavy losses on the Germans using both the tank's and their own personal weapons. As ammunition runs out and the battle turns desperate, Grady is killed by a Panzerfaust round penetrating the turret; Gordo is wounded and then sacrifices himself by covering one of his dropped grenades; then a sniper kills Bible and badly wounds Wardaddy. Wardaddy and Norman take refuge inside the tank and share their last words. Wardaddy then orders Norman to escape through an emergency hatch in the floor as the Germans drop grenades into the Fury; Norman slips out just as they explode, killing Wardaddy. Norman tries to hide as the Germans move on, but is quickly discovered by a young SS trooper; the trooper hesitates and then leaves, deciding not to report him.</p>
<p>The next morning, Norman awakens and crawls back into the tank; he covers Wardaddy's corpse with his coat and takes his revolver as he hears movement outside. Norman awaits his fate, only to discover he is being rescued by U.S. soldiers, who tell him that he's a hero. As Norman is transported to safety, he looks back at the carnage behind him: countless dead Germans, surrounding the battered and broken Fury.</p>
<p>On April 3, 2013, Sony started to assemble the cast for the film when <a href="/wiki/Brad_Pitt" title="Brad Pitt">Brad Pitt</a>, who previously starred in 2009's WWII-set <i><a href="/wiki/Inglourious_Basterds" title="Inglourious Basterds">Inglourious Basterds</a></i>, entered final talks to take the lead role of Wardaddy.<sup id="cite_ref-Brad_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brad-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> On April 23, <a href="/wiki/Shia_LaBeouf" title="Shia LaBeouf">Shia LaBeouf</a> joined the cast.<sup id="cite_ref-Shia_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Shia-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> On May 1 it was announced that <a href="/wiki/Logan_Lerman" title="Logan Lerman">Logan Lerman</a> had also joined <i>Fury</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s cast, playing Pitt's crew member Norman Ellison.<sup id="cite_ref-Logan_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Logan-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup> On May 14, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter" title="The Hollywood Reporter">The Hollywood Reporter</a></i> announced that <a href="/wiki/Michael_Pe%C3%B1a" title="Michael Pea">Michael Pea</a> was in negotiations to play a member of Pitt's tank crew.<sup id="cite_ref-Michael_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Michael-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> On May 17, <a href="/wiki/Jon_Bernthal" title="Jon Bernthal">Jon Bernthal</a> joined the cast as Grady Travis, a cunning, vicious and world-wise Arkansas native.<sup id="cite_ref-Jon_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jon-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> On August 26, <a href="/wiki/Scott_Eastwood" title="Scott Eastwood">Scott Eastwood</a> also joined the cast, playing Sergeant Miles.<sup id="cite_ref-Scott_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Scott-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup> On September 19, <a href="/wiki/Brad_William_Henke" title="Brad William Henke">Brad William Henke</a> joined as Sergeant Roy Davis, commander of another tank, <i>Lucy Sue.</i> (The second Sherman destroyed by the Tiger).<sup id="cite_ref-Henke_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Henke-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jason_Isaacs" title="Jason Isaacs">Jason Isaacs</a> was cast on October 7, 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-Jason_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jason-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup> Other cast members include <a href="/wiki/Xavier_Samuel" title="Xavier Samuel">Xavier Samuel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jim_Parrack" title="Jim Parrack">Jim Parrack</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eugenia_Kuzmina" title="Eugenia Kuzmina">Eugenia Kuzmina</a>, Kevin Vance, and <a href="/wiki/Branko_Tomovi%C4%87" title="Branko Tomovi">Branko Tomovi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Branko_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Branko-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Prior to filming, Ayer required the actors to undergo a four-month preparation process. This included a week-long boot camp run by <a href="/wiki/United_States_Navy_SEALs" title="United States Navy SEALs">Navy SEALs</a>. Pitt stated, "It was set up to break us down, to keep us cold, to keep us exhausted, to make us miserable, to keep us wet, make us eat cold food. And if our stuff wasn't together we had to pay for it with physical forfeits. We're up at five in the morning, we're doing night watches on the hour."</p>
<p>Ayer also pushed the cast to physically spar each other, leading to many black eyes and bloody noses. They insulted each other with personal attacks as well. On top of that, the actors were forced to live in the tank together for an extended period of time where they ate, slept, and defecated.</p>
<p>In regard to his choices, Ayer defended himself, saying, "I am ruthless as a director. I will do whatever I think is necessary to get what I want.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film's crews were rehearsing the film scenes in <a href="/wiki/Hertfordshire" title="Hertfordshire">Hertfordshire</a>, <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a>, in September 2013. The crew were also sighted filming in various locations in the North West of England. Brad Pitt was spotted in preparations for <i>Fury</i> driving a tank on September 3 in the English countryside.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Principal_photography" title="Principal photography">Principal photography</a> began on September 30, 2013, in the <a href="/wiki/Oxfordshire" title="Oxfordshire">Oxfordshire</a> countryside.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pinewood_Studios" title="Pinewood Studios">Pinewood Studios</a> sent warning letters to the villagers of <a href="/wiki/Shirburn" title="Shirburn">Shirburn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pyrton" title="Pyrton">Pyrton</a> and <a href="/wiki/Watlington,_Oxfordshire" title="Watlington, Oxfordshire">Watlington</a> that there would be sounds of gunfire and explosions during the filming of <i>Fury</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On October 15, 2013, a stuntman was accidentally stabbed in the shoulder by a <a href="/wiki/Bayonet" title="Bayonet">bayonet</a> while rehearsing at the set in Pyrton. He was taken to <a href="/wiki/John_Radcliffe_Hospital" title="John Radcliffe Hospital">John Radcliffe Hospital</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oxford" title="Oxford">Oxford</a> by an air ambulance. Police confirmed that they were treating it as an accident.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup> In November 2013, the film caused controversy by shooting a scene on <a href="/wiki/Remembrance_Day" title="Remembrance Day">Remembrance Day</a> in which extras wore <a href="/wiki/Wehrmacht" title="Wehrmacht">Wehrmacht</a> and <a href="/wiki/Waffen-SS" title="Waffen-SS">Waffen-SS</a> uniforms. Ayer apologized for the incident, and Sony also made an apology.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> Filming was wrapped-up on November 15, 2013 in Oxfordshire.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On November 19, 2013, composer <a href="/wiki/Steven_Price_(composer)" title="Steven Price (composer)">Steven Price</a> signed on to score the film.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Steven_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Steven-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Var%C3%A8se_Sarabande" title="Varse Sarabande">Varse Sarabande</a> released the original soundtrack album for the film on October 14, 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Fury</i> is a fictional film about a tank crew during the final days of the war in Europe. Ayer was influenced by the service of veterans in his family and by reading books such as Belton Y. Cooper's <i>Death Traps</i> about American armored warfare in World War II. Ayer went to considerable lengths to seek authentic uniforms and weapons appropriate to the period of the final months of the war in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-nytimes.com_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes.com-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> The film was shot in England in large part due to the availability of working World War II-era tanks. The film featured <a href="/wiki/Tiger_131" title="Tiger 131">Tiger 131</a>, the last surviving operational <a href="/wiki/Tiger_I" title="Tiger I">Tiger I</a>. The tank belongs to <a href="/wiki/The_Tank_Museum" title="The Tank Museum">The Tank Museum</a> at <a href="/wiki/Bovington" title="Bovington" class="mw-redirect">Bovington</a>, England. It is the first time since the 1946 film <i><a href="/wiki/Theirs_Is_the_Glory" title="Theirs Is the Glory">Theirs Is the Glory</a></i> that a real Tiger tank  and not a prop version  has been used on a film set.<sup id="cite_ref-.27Last.27_WW2_Tiger_tank_to_be_used_in_Brad_Pitt_film_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-.27Last.27_WW2_Tiger_tank_to_be_used_in_Brad_Pitt_film-29"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup> Tiger 131 is a very early model Tiger I tank; externally it has some significant differences from later Tiger I models, most noticeably the outermost row of road wheels (of the trio per axle, used in the <i>Schachtellaufwerk</i> overlapping and interleaved arrangement characteristic of the Tiger I) which are also rimmed in rubber, as well as the dustbin shaped cupola.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30"><span>[</span>30<span>]</span></a></sup> In the last weeks of the war a number of these early model Tigers were used in last ditch defense efforts; one of Germany's last Tigers to be lost at the <a href="/wiki/Brandenburg_Gate" title="Brandenburg Gate">Brandenburg Gate</a> in <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a> was of a similar vintage.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Ten working <a href="/wiki/M4_Sherman" title="M4 Sherman">M4 Sherman</a> tanks were used. The Sherman tank <i>Fury</i> was played by an M4A2E8 Sherman tank named <i>RON/HARRY</i> (T224875), also lent by The Tank Museum.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup> Ayer's attention to detail also extended to the maps used in the film. A 1943 wartime map of Hannover, Germany held in McMaster Universitys <a href="/wiki/McMaster_University_Library#Collections" title="McMaster University Library">Lloyd Reeds Map Collection</a> was used to demonstrate the types of resources relied on by Allied forces.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>While the plot of the film is fictional, the depiction of the tank <i>Fury</i> and its commander Wardaddy parallels the experience of several real <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allied</a> tankers, such as the American tank commander <a href="/wiki/Staff_Sergeant" title="Staff Sergeant" class="mw-redirect">Staff Sergeant</a> <a href="/wiki/Lafayette_G._Pool" title="Lafayette G. Pool">Lafayette G. "War Daddy" Pool</a> who landed just after D-Day and destroyed 258 enemy vehicles before his tank was knocked out in Germany in late 1944,<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34"><span>[</span>34<span>]</span></a></sup> and the small number of Sherman tanks to survive from the landing at D-Day to the end of the war, such as <a href="/wiki/Bomb_(tank)" title="Bomb (tank)"><i>Bomb</i></a>, a Sherman tank that landed at D-Day and survived into the bitter fighting in Germany at the war's end, the only <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canadian</a> Sherman tank to survive the fighting from D-Day to <a href="/wiki/VE_Day" title="VE Day" class="mw-redirect">VE Day</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35"><span>[</span>35<span>]</span></a></sup> The plot also has some similarities to the battle of <a href="/wiki/Crailsheim" title="Crailsheim">Crailsheim</a>, fought in Germany in 1945.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The last stand of the crew of the disabled <i>Fury</i> appears to be based on an anecdote from <i>Death Traps</i>, where a lone tanker was "in his tank on a road junction" when a "German infantry unit approached, apparently not spotting the tank in the darkness." This unnamed tanker is described to have ricocheted shells into the enemy forces, fired all of his machine gun ammunition and thrown grenades to kill German soldiers climbing onto the tank. Cooper concluded: "When our infantry arrived the next day, they found the brave young tanker still alive in his tank. The entire surrounding area was littered with German dead and wounded." <sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup> The battle bears some resemblance to that of <a href="/wiki/Medal_of_Honor" title="Medal of Honor">Medal of Honor</a> recipient <a href="/wiki/Audie_Murphy" title="Audie Murphy">Audie Murphy</a> aboard a burning <a href="/wiki/M10_tank_destroyer" title="M10 tank destroyer">M10 tank destroyer</a> outside <a href="/wiki/Holtzwihr" title="Holtzwihr">Holtzwihr</a> in <a href="/wiki/Alsace-Lorraine" title="Alsace-Lorraine">Alsace-Lorraine</a> on <a href="/wiki/Military_career_of_Audie_Murphy#Colmar_Pocket" title="Military career of Audie Murphy">January 26, 1945</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup> The fighting in the film also bears similarity to the 1943 film <i><a href="/wiki/Sahara_(1943_film)" title="Sahara (1943 film)">Sahara</a></i> starring <a href="/wiki/Humphrey_Bogart" title="Humphrey Bogart">Humphrey Bogart</a> in which the crew of an <a href="/wiki/M3_Lee" title="M3 Lee">M3 Lee</a> named "Lulu Belle" and a contingent of stranded British soldiers, defend a remote well in <a href="/wiki/Libya" title="Libya">Libya</a> against a larger German force of the elite <a href="/wiki/Afrika_Korps" title="Afrika Korps">Afrika Korps</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span>[</span>38<span>]</span></a></sup> to the demise of most of the Allies.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39"><span>[</span>39<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Sony_Pictures" title="Sony Pictures" class="mw-redirect">Sony Pictures</a> had previously set November 14, 2014 as the American release date for <i>Fury</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span>[</span>40<span>]</span></a></sup> On August 12, 2014, the date was moved up to October 17.<sup id="cite_ref-date_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-date-41"><span>[</span>41<span>]</span></a></sup> The film was released in the United Kingdom on October 22, 2014.</p>
<p><i>Fury</i> had its world premiere at <a href="/wiki/Newseum" title="Newseum">Newseum</a> in <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> on October 15, 2014,<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span>[</span>42<span>]</span></a></sup> followed by a wide release across 3,173 theaters in North America on October 17.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span>[</span>43<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film was released on DVD and <a href="/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc" title="Blu-ray Disc" class="mw-redirect">Blu-ray Disc</a> in the United States on January 27, 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44"><span>[</span>44<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film additionally had a partnership with the popular online video game <i><a href="/wiki/World_of_Tanks" title="World of Tanks">World of Tanks</a></i>, where the main tank from the film, <i>Fury</i>, was available for purchase in-game using real currency for a limited time after the film's release. The tank also served as the centerpiece in themed events in the vein of the film following its release.<sup id="cite_ref-Fury_WoT1_.28NewsArticle.29_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fury_WoT1_.28NewsArticle.29-45"><span>[</span>45<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Fury_WoT2_.28NewsArticle.29_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fury_WoT2_.28NewsArticle.29-46"><span>[</span>46<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Fury_WoT3_.28GamePage.29_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fury_WoT3_.28GamePage.29-47"><span>[</span>47<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>As part of the UK DVD release, the game also hid 300,000 codes inside copies of the film, which gave in-game rewards and bonuses.<sup id="cite_ref-SPREAD_THE_WORD_CONTEST.28GamePage.29_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SPREAD_THE_WORD_CONTEST.28GamePage.29-48"><span>[</span>48<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film was <a href="/wiki/Internet_leak" title="Internet leak">leaked</a> onto peer-to-peer file sharing websites as part of the <a href="/wiki/Sony_Pictures_Entertainment_hack" title="Sony Pictures Entertainment hack">Sony Pictures Entertainment hack</a> by the hacker group "Guardians of Peace" on November 27, 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-hack_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hack-49"><span>[</span>49<span>]</span></a></sup> Along with it came four unreleased <a href="/wiki/Sony_Pictures" title="Sony Pictures" class="mw-redirect">Sony Pictures</a> films (<i><a href="/wiki/Annie_(2014_film)" title="Annie (2014 film)">Annie</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Mr._Turner_(film)" title="Mr. Turner (film)" class="mw-redirect">Mr. Turner</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Still_Alice" title="Still Alice">Still Alice</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/To_Write_Love_on_Her_Arms_(film)" title="To Write Love on Her Arms (film)">To Write Love on Her Arms</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-hack_49-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hack-49"><span>[</span>49<span>]</span></a></sup> Within three days of the initial leak, <i>Fury</i> had been downloaded an estimated 1.2 million times.<sup id="cite_ref-hack_49-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hack-49"><span>[</span>49<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Fury</i> was a box office success. The film grossed $85.8 million in North America and $126 million in other territories for a worldwide total of $211.8 million, against a budget of $68 million.<sup id="cite_ref-mojo_4-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mojo-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Fury</i> was released on October 17, 2014, in North America across 3,173 theaters.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50"><span>[</span>50<span>]</span></a></sup> It earned $1.2 million from Thursday late night showings from 2,489 theaters.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span>[</span>51<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52"><span>[</span>52<span>]</span></a></sup> On its opening day, the film grossed $8.8 million.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53"><span>[</span>53<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54"><span>[</span>54<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55"><span>[</span>55<span>]</span></a></sup> The film topped the box office on its opening weekend earning $23,500,000 at an average of $7,406 per theater.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span>[</span>56<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57"><span>[</span>57<span>]</span></a></sup> The film's opening weekend gross is David Ayer's biggest hit of his (now five-film) directorial career, surpassing the $13.1 million debut of <i><a href="/wiki/End_of_Watch" title="End of Watch">End of Watch</a></i> and his third-biggest opening as a writer behind <i><a href="/wiki/The_Fast_and_the_Furious" title="The Fast and the Furious">The Fast and the Furious</a></i> ($40 million) and <i><a href="/wiki/S.W.A.T._(film)" title="S.W.A.T.
