(film)">S.W.A.T.</a></i> ($37 million).<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58"><span>[</span>58<span>]</span></a></sup> In its second weekend the film earned $13 million (-45%).<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span>[</span>59<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Fury</i> was released a week following its North American debut and earned $11.2 million from 1,975 screens in 15 markets. The film went number one in <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a> ($2.2 million) and number five in <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a> ($2.1 million).<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60"><span>[</span>60<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61"><span>[</span>61<span>]</span></a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/UK" title="UK" class="mw-redirect">UK</a>, the film topped the box office in its opening weekend with 2.69 million ($4.2 million) knocking off <i><a href="/wiki/Teenage_Mutant_Ninja_Turtles_(2014_film)" title="Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (2014 film)">Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles</a></i> which earned 1.92 million ($3.1 million) from the top spot.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62"><span>[</span>62<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63"><span>[</span>63<span>]</span></a></sup> In its second weekend the film added $14.6 million in 44 markets, bringing the overseas cumulative audience [cume] to $37.8 million. It went number one in <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">Finland</a> ($410,000) and in <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> ($160,000).<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64"><span>[</span>64<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Fury</i> received positive reviews from critics, who praised the portrayal of war, as well as Ayer's direction, Price's score and the work of its main cast members; with the performances of Brad Pitt, Logan Lerman, and Shia LaBeouf singled out for praise. On <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a>, the film has a "Certified Fresh" rating of 77%, based on 221 reviews, with an average rating of 6.9/10. The site's consensus reads, "Overall, <i>Fury</i> is a well-acted, suitably raw depiction of the horrors of war that offers visceral battle scenes but doesn't quite live up to its larger ambitions."<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65"><span>[</span>65<span>]</span></a></sup> On <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>, the film has a score of 64 out of 100, based on 47 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66"><span>[</span>66<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/The_Boston_Globe" title="The Boston Globe">The Boston Globe</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s <a href="/wiki/Ty_Burr" title="Ty Burr">Ty Burr</a> gave 2.5 out of 4 stars and talked about Pitt's character Sergeant Don "Wardaddy" Collier, commenting on Wardaddy's portrayal as "the battle-scarred leader of a tank crew pushing through Germany toward Berlin, Brad Pitt creates a warrior who is terse, sometimes noble, more often brutal." Another critic, Burr, explained that Ayer portrayed in the character of Wardaddy "a figure both monstrous and upstanding. In one scene, he shoots a captured enemy officer in the back. A few scenes later, he's protecting two German women from being assaulted by his own men." Burr further stated that, "<i>Fury</i> gives us terrible glimpses: tank treads rolling over a body pancaked into the mud, an elderly woman cutting meat off a dead horse, a woman in a wedding dress among a crowd of refugees. <i>Fury</i> wants to lead us to a fresh consideration of 'the good war' while simultaneously celebrating the old bromides and clichs. No wonder it shoots itself in the tank."<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67"><span>[</span>67<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/Newsday" title="Newsday">Newsday</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s Rafer Guzman admired director Ayer, who "does a good job of putting us inside the tank <i>Fury</i>"; with "all the extra blood and brutality, this is still a macho and romanticized war movie", and he singled out Pitt, who he said "serves honorably in the <a href="/wiki/John_Wayne" title="John Wayne">John Wayne</a> role".<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68"><span>[</span>68<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Deadline_Hollywood" title="Deadline Hollywood" class="mw-redirect">Deadline Hollywood</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s Pete Hammond praised Lerman's performance saying, "It is a great performance, very Oscar-worthy in part of Logan Lerman. Those scenes between Brad Pitt and Logan Lerman trying to teach him the trips of war and how to man up is remarkable."<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69"><span>[</span>69<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>It never scales the cinematic heights or reaches the same groundbreaking level as <i><a href="/wiki/Saving_Private_Ryan" title="Saving Private Ryan">Saving Private Ryan</a></i>, but it's intensely ferocious and relentlessly rough on the senses. You'll know you've been to war, and not on the Hollywood front.</p>
<p>Film critic <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Orr_(film_critic)" title="Christopher Orr (film critic)">Christopher Orr</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Atlantic" title="The Atlantic">The Atlantic</a></i> magazine said that the film "is too technically refined to be a truly bad movie, but too narratively and thematically stunted to be a good one. In a sense, it succeeds too well in conjuring its own subject matter: heavy, mechanical, claustrophobic, and unrelenting."<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71"><span>[</span>71<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Philadelphia_Inquirer" title="The Philadelphia Inquirer">The Philadelphia Inquirer</a>'s</i> <a href="/wiki/Steven_Rea" title="Steven Rea">Steven Rea</a> gave the film 3 out of 4 stars and praised, "<i>Fury</i> presents an unrelentingly violent, visceral depiction of war, which is perhaps as it should be. Bayonets in the eye, bullets in the back, limbs blown apart, corpses of humans and horses splayed across muddy, incinerated terrain. Ayer brought a similar you-are-there intensity to his 2012 cops-on-patrol drama, <i>End of Watch</i> (also with Pea)." But on the opposite side of Rea's admiration, he thinks, "It wouldn't be right to call <i>Fury</i> entertaining, and in its narrow focus (as narrow as the view from the tank's periscope), the film doesn't offer a broader take on the horrors of war - other than to put those horrors right in front of us, in plain view."<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72"><span>[</span>72<span>]</span></a></sup> Chris Vognar wrote the review for <i><a href="/wiki/The_Dallas_Morning_News" title="The Dallas Morning News">The Dallas Morning News</a></i> giving the film "B+" grade, in which he writes about "War" which he thinks is, "hell," and also "relentless, unsparing, unsentimental and violent to the mind, body and soul. <i>Fury</i> conveys these truths with brute force and lean, precise drama."<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73"><span>[</span>73<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kenneth_Turan" title="Kenneth Turan">Kenneth Turan</a> for the <i><a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times" title="Los Angeles Times">Los Angeles Times</a></i> praised the film highly, writing: "Best job I ever had" sentence "is one of the catchphrases the men in this killing machine use with each other, and the ghastly thing is they half believe it's true."<sup id="cite_ref-KennethTuranTimesLA_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KennethTuranTimesLA-74"><span>[</span>74<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Todd_McCarthy" title="Todd McCarthy">Todd McCarthy</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter" title="The Hollywood Reporter">The Hollywood Reporter</a></i> simply said, "<i>Fury</i> is a good, solid World War II movie, nothing more and nothing less. Rugged, macho, violent and with a story sufficiently unusual to grab and hold interest, it's a modern version of the sort of movie Hollywood turned out practically every week back in the 1940s and 1950s."<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75"><span>[</span>75<span>]</span></a></sup> Peter Debruge wrote for the magazine <i><a href="/wiki/Variety_(magazine)" title="Variety (magazine)">Variety</a></i> in which he praised Pitt, "Brad Pitt plays a watered-down version of his 'Inglourious Basterds' character in this disappointingly bland look at a World War II tank crew."<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76"><span>[</span>76<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wrap" title="The Wrap" class="mw-redirect">The Wrap</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s James Rocchi gave 4 out 5 ratings and expressed a warm approval of the film which is "unflinching, unsentimental and never unconsidered, "<i>Fury</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s rumbling, metal-clad exterior has real humanity, fragile and frightened, captured and caged deep within it."<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77"><span>[</span>77<span>]</span></a></sup> Randy Myers of the <i><a href="/wiki/San_Jose_Mercury_News" title="San Jose Mercury News">San Jose Mercury News</a></i> rated the film 3 out of 4 and talked about LaBeouf "who's most impressive, inhabiting the soul of a scripture-quoting soldier who seeks guidance from the Word in hopes of remaining on a moral path. While much has been made about the reportedly extreme lengths he took to prep for the role, the fact remains it is one of his best performances."<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78"><span>[</span>78<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mick_LaSalle" title="Mick LaSalle">Mick LaSalle</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Chronicle" title="San Francisco Chronicle">San Francisco Chronicle</a></i> gave a 4 out of 4 rating and wrote completely in the favor of the film: "A great movie lets you know you're in safe hands from the beginning."<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79"><span>[</span>79<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/James_Berardinelli" title="James Berardinelli">James Berardinelli</a> also gave the film a positive review saying: "This is a memorable motion picture, accurately depicting the horrors of war without reveling in the depravity of man (like Platoon). Equally, it shows instances of humanity without resorting to the rah-rah, sanitized perspective that infiltrated many war films of the 1950s and 1960s. It's as good a World War II film as I've seen in recent years, and contains perhaps the most draining battlefield sequences since <i><a href="/wiki/Saving_Private_Ryan" title="Saving Private Ryan">Saving Private Ryan</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80"><span>[</span>80<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span> critic <a href="/wiki/A._O._Scott" title="A. O. Scott">A. O. Scott</a> well praised the film and Pitt's character, "Within this gore-spattered, superficially nihilistic carapace is an old-fashioned platoon picture, a sensitive and superbly acted tale of male bonding under duress."<sup id="cite_ref-AOScottTimesNY_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AOScottTimesNY-81"><span>[</span>81<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rex_Reed" title="Rex Reed">Rex Reed</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Observer" title="The New York Observer">The New York Observer</a></i> said, "The actors are all good, Mr. Pitt moves even closer to iconic stardom, and young Mr. Lerman steals the picture as the camera lens through whose eyes and veins we share every dehumanizing experience. Purists may squabble, but if you're a history buff or a pushover for the sight of a man engulfed in flames who shoots himself through the head before he burns to death, you'll go away from <i>Fury</i> sated."<sup id="cite_ref-RexReedObserver_70-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RexReedObserver-70"><span>[</span>70<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Arizona_Republic" title="The Arizona Republic">The Arizona Republic</a>'s</i> critic Bill Goodykoontz said, "In terms of story, structure and look (with the exception of the gore), this movie could have been made at any time in the past 70 years."<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82"><span>[</span>82<span>]</span></a></sup> To Goodykoontz review, Claudia Puig of <i><a href="/wiki/USA_Today" title="USA Today">USA Today</a></i> gave the reply, "Given how many World War II films have emerged in the last 70 years, it requires a thoroughly fresh angle to make one seem distinctive." Puig also said, "Flesh-and-blood soldiers play second fiddle to the authentic-looking artillery in <i>Fury</i>, rendering the film tough and harrowing, but less emotionally compelling than it could have been."<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83"><span>[</span>83<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_A.V._Club" title="The A.V. Club">The A.V. Club</a>'s</i> <a href="/wiki/Ignatiy_Vishnevetsky" title="Ignatiy Vishnevetsky">Ignatiy Vishnevetsky</a> gave the film a "C+" grade and said, "It's all very Peckinpah-or at least it could be, if Ayer had any sense of poetry."<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84"><span>[</span>84<span>]</span></a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Chicago_Tribune" title="Chicago Tribune">Chicago Tribune</a>'s</i> <a href="/wiki/Michael_Phillips_(critic)" title="Michael Phillips (critic)">Michael Phillips</a> wrote a negative review, saying "At its weakest, <i>Fury</i> contributes a frustrating percentage of tin to go with the iron and steel."<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85"><span>[</span>85<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/The_Miami_Herald" title="The Miami Herald" class="mw-redirect">The Miami Herald</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'s</span> Rene Rodriguez gave the film 2 out of 4 stars said, "War is hell. That's entertainment, folks."<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86"><span>[</span>86<span>]</span></a></sup> Amy Nicholson of <i><a href="/wiki/LA_Weekly" title="LA Weekly">LA Weekly</a></i> said, "This is an ugly part of an ugly war, and Ayer wallows in it. Instead of flags and patriotism, <i>Fury</i> is about filth: the basins of blood, the smears on the soldiers' exhausted faces, the bodies pushed around by bulldozers, a decomposing corpse that's melted into the mud."<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87"><span>[</span>87<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Peter_Travers" title="Peter Travers">Peter Travers</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone" title="Rolling Stone">Rolling Stone</a></i> gave 3 out of 4 stars and said, "Written and directed with exacting skill and aching heart by David Ayer, <i>Fury</i> captures the buried feelings of men in combat with piercing immediacy."<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88"><span>[</span>88<span>]</span></a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_Post" title="New York Post">New York Post</a>'s</i> <a href="/wiki/Kyle_Smith" title="Kyle Smith">Kyle Smith</a> said that he "couldn't help suspecting that there's a pornographic leer to it all, a savage glee."<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89"><span>[</span>89<span>]</span></a></sup> Tom Long wrote for <i><a href="/wiki/The_Detroit_News" title="The Detroit News">The Detroit News</a></i> and gave the film negative reviews, "<i>Fury</i> is a brutal film that too easily celebrates rage and bloodshed to no clear end beyond ugly spectacle."<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90"><span>[</span>90<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Globe_and_Mail" title="The Globe and Mail">The Globe and Mail</a></i> wrote: "<i>Fury</i>...is a war movie with balls of steel and marbles for brains."<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91"><span>[</span>91<span>]</span></a></sup> Chris Klimek of <i><a href="/wiki/NPR" title="NPR">NPR</a></i> praised the film and actors, "<i>Fury</i> is a big step up in sophistication. Where it elevates itself from being merely a believably grimy, well-acted war drama is in its long and surprising middle act."<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92"><span>[</span>92<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_(magazine)" title="New York (magazine)">New York</a></i> magazine<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s <a href="/wiki/David_Edelstein" title="David Edelstein">David Edelstein</a> admired the film in his own words, "Though much of <i>Fury</i> crumbles in the mind, the power of its best moments lingers: the writhing of Ellison as he's forced to kill; the frightening vibe of the scene with German women; the meanness on some soldiers' faces and soul-sickness on others'."<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93"><span>[</span>93<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Crash</i> (2004 film)</h1>
<p><i><b>Crash</b></i> is a 2004 <a href="/wiki/Ensemble_cast" title="Ensemble cast">ensemble</a> <a href="/wiki/Drama_film" title="Drama film" class="mw-redirect">drama film</a> co-written, produced, and directed by <a href="/wiki/Paul_Haggis" title="Paul Haggis">Paul Haggis</a>. The film is about <a href="/wiki/Racism" title="Racism">racial</a> and <a href="/wiki/Classism" title="Classism" class="mw-redirect">social</a> tensions in <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a>, <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>. A self-described "passion piece" for Haggis, <i>Crash</i> was inspired by a real-life incident, in which his <a href="/wiki/Porsche" title="Porsche">Porsche</a> was <a href="/wiki/Carjacking" title="Carjacking">carjacked</a> outside a video store on <a href="/wiki/Wilshire_Boulevard" title="Wilshire Boulevard">Wilshire Boulevard</a> in 1991.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Several characters' stories interweave during two days in Los Angeles: a <a href="/wiki/African_American" title="African American" class="mw-redirect">black</a> <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Police_Department" title="Los Angeles Police Department">detective</a> estranged from his mother; his criminal younger brother and gang associate; the <a href="/wiki/White_American" title="White American" class="mw-redirect">white</a> <a href="/wiki/District_attorney" title="District attorney">district attorney</a> and his irritated, pampered wife; a racist white police officer who disgusts his more idealistic younger partner; an <a href="/wiki/African_American" title="African American" class="mw-redirect">African American</a> <a href="/wiki/Hollywood" title="Hollywood">Hollywood</a> director and his wife who must deal with the officer; a <a href="/wiki/Iranian_citizens_abroad" title="Iranian citizens abroad" class="mw-redirect">Persian</a>-immigrant father who is wary of others; and a hard-working <a href="/wiki/Hispanic" title="Hispanic">Hispanic</a> family man, a locksmith. The film differs from many other films about racism in its rather impartial approach to the issue. Rather than separating the characters into victims and offenders, victims of racism are often shown to be prejudiced themselves in different contexts and situations. Also, racist remarks and actions are often shown to stem from ignorance and misconception rather than a malicious personality.</p>
<p>The film stars <a href="/wiki/Sandra_Bullock" title="Sandra Bullock">Sandra Bullock</a>, <a href="/wiki/Don_Cheadle" title="Don Cheadle">Don Cheadle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Matt_Dillon" title="Matt Dillon">Matt Dillon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jennifer_Esposito" title="Jennifer Esposito">Jennifer Esposito</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brendan_Fraser" title="Brendan Fraser">Brendan Fraser</a>, <a href="/wiki/Terrence_Howard" title="Terrence Howard">Terrence Howard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ludacris" title="Ludacris">Chris "Ludacris" Bridges</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thandie_Newton" title="Thandie Newton">Thandie Newton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michael_Pe%C3%B1a" title="Michael Pea">Michael Pea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ryan_Phillippe" title="Ryan Phillippe">Ryan Phillippe</a>. Matt Dillon was particularly praised for his performance and received Academy Award, BAFTA, Golden Globe and Screen Actors Guild Award nominations for Best Supporting Actor. Additionally, the cast won the <a href="/wiki/Screen_Actors_Guild_Award_for_Outstanding_Performance_by_a_Cast_in_a_Motion_Picture" title="Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture">Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture</a>. The film received six <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award" title="Academy Award" class="mw-redirect">Academy Award</a> nominations, including Best Picture and Best Director for Paul Haggis, and won three for <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Best Picture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Screenplay" title="Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay">Best Original Screenplay</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Film_Editing" title="Academy Award for Best Film Editing">Best Film Editing</a> at the <a href="/wiki/78th_Academy_Awards" title="78th Academy Awards">78th Academy Awards</a>. It was also nominated for nine BAFTA awards, and won two, for Best Original Screenplay and <a href="/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Actress_in_a_Supporting_Role" title="BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role">Best Supporting Actress</a> for Thandie Newton.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p><b>Today</b><br>
The film begins with commentary by passenger Detective Graham Waters (<a href="/wiki/Don_Cheadle" title="Don Cheadle">Don Cheadle</a>) having suffered a car accident with his partner Ria (<a href="/wiki/Jennifer_Esposito" title="Jennifer Esposito">Jennifer Esposito</a>). He mentions that the denizens of <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a> have lost their "sense of touch." Ria and the driver of the other car, Kim Lee, exchange racially charged insults. When Waters exits the car, he arrives at a <a href="/wiki/Police" title="Police">police</a> investigation <a href="/wiki/Crime_scene" title="Crime scene">crime scene</a> concerning the discovery of "a dead kid."</p>
<p><b>Yesterday</b><br>
While purchasing a revolver at a gun store, Farhad (<a href="/wiki/Shaun_Toub" title="Shaun Toub">Shaun Toub</a>), a Persian shop owner, and his daughter Dorri (<a href="/wiki/Bahar_Soomekh" title="Bahar Soomekh">Bahar Soomekh</a>), argue in <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a> over what box of bullets they should buy. The gun store owner grows impatient and degrades the two of them by referring to Farhad as "<a href="/wiki/Osama_bin_Laden" title="Osama bin Laden">Osama</a>". Farhad clarifies that he is an American citizen but the store owner continues exchanging racially stereotypical insults at Farhad and has the security guard escort him out the store. Dorri demands the store owner to give her the gun or give her back the money. After the store owner gives the gun to Dorri, she asks for "the ones in the red box". The store owner asks why, but Dorri does not answer and insists on buying that particular box. In another part of town, two black men, Anthony (<a href="/wiki/Ludacris" title="Ludacris">Ludacris</a>) and Peter (<a href="/wiki/Larenz_Tate" title="Larenz Tate">Larenz Tate</a>), argue over racial stereotyping of African Americans after Jean Cabot (<a href="/wiki/Sandra_Bullock" title="Sandra Bullock">Sandra Bullock</a>), the wife of the local <a href="/wiki/District_attorney" title="District attorney">district attorney</a> Rick Cabot (<a href="/wiki/Brendan_Fraser" title="Brendan Fraser">Brendan Fraser</a>), walks in another direction whilst fearfully staring at them.</p>
<p>Anthony and Peter carjack the married couple as they are about to enter their <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Navigator" title="Lincoln Navigator">Lincoln Navigator</a>. Later, at the Cabot house, Hispanic locksmith Daniel Ruiz (<a href="/wiki/Michael_Pe%C3%B1a" title="Michael Pea">Michael Pea</a>) is changing their locks when Jean notices his tattoos. She loudly complains to Rick about having been carjacked and now having to endure a Hispanic man changing their locks, feeling he will give copies of the keys to "his gang banger friends". Having overheard this, Daniel leaves the keys on Jean's kitchen counter. Detectives Waters and Ria arrive at the scene of a shooting between two drivers. The surviving shooter is a white male, identified as an undercover police officer. The dead shooter, a black male, is revealed also to be an undercover police officer. There is a large amount of cash found in the black officer's trunk. This is the third time the white officer has shot and killed a black man.</p>
<p>LAPD officer John Ryan (<a href="/wiki/Matt_Dillon" title="Matt Dillon">Matt Dillon</a>) calls an <a href="/wiki/HMO" title="HMO" class="mw-redirect">HMO</a> on behalf of his father and has an argument with a representative named Shaniqua Johnson (<a href="/wiki/Loretta_Devine" title="Loretta Devine">Loretta Devine</a>). He then gets into the squad car with his partner Tom Hansen (<a href="/wiki/Ryan_Philippe" title="Ryan Philippe" class="mw-redirect">Ryan Philippe</a>) and sees a car passenger performing fellatio on the driver of a moving vehicle. They pull over the Navigator similar to the one carjacked earlier, despite discrepancies in the descriptions. They order the couple, television director Cameron Thayer (<a href="/wiki/Terrence_Howard" title="Terrence Howard">Terrence Howard</a>) and his wife Christine (<a href="/wiki/Thandie_Newton" title="Thandie Newton">Thandie Newton</a>), to exit. Cameron is cooperative, but Christine is argumentative. This annoys Ryan, who manually molests Christine under the pretense of administering a pat-down. Intimidated, Cameron says nothing. The couple is released without a citation. Once home, Christine becomes enraged that Cameron did nothing while she was being violated. Cameron insists that what he did was correct and storms out.</p>
<p>Arriving home from work long after dark, Daniel finds his young daughter, Lara (<a href="/wiki/Ashlyn_Sanchez" title="Ashlyn Sanchez">Ashlyn Sanchez</a>), hiding under her bed after hearing a gunshot outside. To comfort her, Daniel gives her an "invisible impenetrable cloak", which makes her feel safe enough to fall asleep in her bed. In the carjacked SUV, Anthony and Peter, arguing and distracted, hit a Korean man while passing a parked white van. They argue about what to do with him, finally dumping him in front of a hospital and driving away. Due to the blood in the vehicle, they are unable to receive payment for the carjacking. The next day, at the Los Angeles Police Department station, Hansen talks to his superior, Lt. Dixon (<a href="/wiki/Keith_David" title="Keith David">Keith David</a>), about switching partners. Dixon, a black man, claims that Hansen's charge of Ryan as a racist could cost both Hansen and Dixon their jobs. Dixon suggests a transfer to a one-man car and mockingly tells Hansen that he should justify it by claiming to have uncontrollable flatulence.</p>
<p>Ryan visits Shaniqua and apologizes for the argument. He explains that his father was previously diagnosed with a bladder infection, but he fears it may be <a href="/wiki/Prostate_cancer" title="Prostate cancer">prostate cancer</a>. Shaniqua nearly calls security to escort Ryan out of her office when he proceeds to insult Shaniqua by calling her an affirmative action hire. When Ryan asks for his father to see a different doctor, Shaniqua denies the request and he storms out of her office in anger. Meanwhile, Daniel is seen replacing a lock at Farhad's shop and tries to explain to him that the door frame needs to be replaced. Farhad, whose English is limited, misunderstands and accuses Daniel of cheating him, which causes Daniel to leave.</p>
<p><b>Today</b><br>
The next morning, Farhad discovers the store has been wrecked and defaced with graffiti. His insurance company does not cover the damage, calling it a case of negligence due to the defective door. When Farhad is told that his shop will be closing down, he vows revenge on Daniel. Detective Waters visits his mother (<a href="/wiki/Beverly_Todd" title="Beverly Todd">Beverly Todd</a>), a hard drug abuser. She asks him to find his missing younger brother. He promises and takes notice that there is almost no food in the apartment as he is leaving. When he tries to present evidence in the shooting between undercover police officers, his superiors tell him not to reveal the cash in the black officer's trunk, saying that their work in crafting a non-racist image for the department will be undone.</p>
<p>Jean comes home and sees dishes in the dishwasher. She accosts her Hispanic maid Maria for not putting them in the cupboards. Ryan comes across a car accident and as he crawls into the overturned vehicle, he finds Christine trapped. Upon recognizing Ryan, Christine becomes hysterical, but gasoline is leaking from the tank and running downhill towards another wreck, which has already caught fire. He calms her down, and with the assistance of his partner and spectators, Ryan pulls Christine out just as her car bursts into flames. Anthony and Peter approach another Navigator which happens to be Cameron's. They only see Cameron driving after they open the door and are shocked to see that the driver is black. Cameron is tired of being pushed around and resists. Anthony tells Peter to shoot Cameron, but Peter does not.</p>
<p>As police officers arrive, Cameron and Anthony both race for the car and jump in. Cameron drives away, with Anthony continuing to point a gun at him. A car chase ensues. Hansen is one of the police officers who has responded and recognizes Cameron's vehicle. Cameron drives into a dead end, puts Anthony's gun into his pocket, and gets out of the car, all the while yelling insults at the officers. Just before he pulls out the gun, Hansen convinces him to stop aggravating the situation and to go home. Hansen vouches for Cameron, fending off the other officers, and promising to give him a "harsh" warning. Later, Cameron tells Anthony that as a black man he is embarrassed for him and drops Anthony off at a bus stop.</p>
<p>Farhad locates Daniel's house and waits in ambush. Just as Daniel's daughter Lara jumps into his arms, attempting to protect him with the "invisible cloak", Daniel's wife Elizabeth (<a href="/wiki/Karina_Arroyave" title="Karina Arroyave">Karina Arroyave</a>) runs out the front door and watches in horror as Farhad shoots Lara. It takes the grief-stricken parents and Farhad a moment to realize that Lara is miraculously unharmed. The box of ammunition that Dorri had selected contained <a href="/wiki/Blank_(cartridge)" title="Blank (cartridge)">blanks</a>. Farhad later tells his daughter that he believes the little girl was his guardian angel, preventing him from committing a terrible crime. Jean is complaining to someone she knows over the phone that she wakes up angry every day and does not know why. Immediately afterwards, she slips and falls down a flight of stairs, spraining her ankle. Jean phones Rick, telling him of her accident. Whilst resting in her bed, Jean hugs Maria, saying she is the only true friend she has ever had and apologizes.</p>
<p>Peter, who is hitchhiking, is picked up by Hansen. Peter sees that Hansen has a small statuette of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Christopher" title="Saint Christopher">Saint Christopher</a> like his own. He begins to laugh as he realizes that they have so much in common, but Hansen thinks that he is being laughed at. Hansen pulls over and tells Peter to get out if he wants to be "funny". Peter moves to pull the statuette out of his pocket in explanation, but Hansen believes he is pulling out a gun and mistakenly shoots and kills Peter. Hansen dumps the body in the bush beside a road and then torches his own car. Peter is revealed to be Waters' missing brother. Waters and his mother meet at the morgue, where Dorri is revealed to be a coroner and Waters promises to find who is responsible. Mrs. Waters blames her surviving son for his brother's death, claiming he was always too busy to look for Peter.</p>
<p>Anthony returns to the white van owned by the Korean man whom they had run over the night before. Finding the keys still hanging from the door lock, he drives the van away. The Korean man's wife Kim Lee arrives at the previously mentioned hospital looking for her husband, the man who was run over, named Choi Jin Gui. Conscious and coherent, he tells her to go and immediately cash a check that he has in his wallet. Anthony has driven the white van to a chop shop he frequents, and as they inspect the van, a number of Cambodian immigrants are discovered locked in the back of the van, revealing that Choi was involved in <a href="/wiki/Human_trafficking" title="Human trafficking">human trafficking</a>. Anthony is offered $500 for each person in the van but refuses out of disgust. Anthony drives to <a href="/wiki/Chinatown,_Los_Angeles" title="Chinatown, Los Angeles">Chinatown</a> and sets the Cambodian people free. As Anthony drives away, he passes a car crash, which turns out to involve Shaniqua. Shaniqua and the other driver get out and begin to exchange racial slurs.</p>
<p><i>Crash</i> opened in <a href="/wiki/Wide_release" title="Wide release">wide release</a> on May 6, 2005, and was a box office success in the late spring of 2005. The film had a budget of $6.5 million (plus $1 million in financing).<sup id="cite_ref-BOM_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BOM-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> Because of the financial constraints, director Haggis filmed in his own house, borrowed a set from the TV show <i><a href="/wiki/Monk_(TV_series)" title="Monk (TV series)">Monk</a></i>, used his car in parts of the film, and even used cars from other staff members.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2012)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The film grossed $53.4 million domestically, making back more than seven times its budget.<sup id="cite_ref-BOM_2-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BOM-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> Despite its success in relation to its cost, <i>Crash</i> was the lowest grossing film at the domestic box office to win <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Best Picture</a> since <i><a href="/wiki/The_Last_Emperor" title="The Last Emperor">The Last Emperor</a></i> in 1987.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2012)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<p>The film received mostly positive reviews. Review aggregator website <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> reports that 170 out of the 227 reviews they tallied were positive, for a score of 75% positive reviews and a certification of "fresh", with an average score of 7.3 out of 10,<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> and the critical consensus "A raw and unsettling morality piece on modern angst and urban disconnect, <i>Crash</i> examines the dangers of bigotry and xenophobia in the lives of interconnected Angelenos", while <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a> tallied an average score of 69 out of 100 for <i>Crash</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'s</span> critical consensus.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Roger_Ebert" title="Roger Ebert">Roger Ebert</a> gave the film four-out-of-four stars and described it as "a movie of intense fascination",<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> listing it as the best film of 2005. The film also ranks at #460 in <i><a href="/wiki/Empire_(film_magazine)" title="Empire (film magazine)">Empire</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s 2008 poll of the "500 Greatest Films of All Time".<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Some later reviews of Crash have been less favorable. Cultural critic <a href="/wiki/Ta-Nehisi_Coates" title="Ta-Nehisi Coates">Ta-Nehisi Coates</a> criticized the film as shallow and "unthinking," naming Crash "the worst film of the decade."<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup> The film has been critiqued for depicting the Persian shopkeeper as a "deranged, paranoid individual who is only redeemed by what he believes is a mystical act of God."<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> The film has also been criticized for using multicultural and sentimentalist imagery to cover over material and "historically sedimented inequalities" that continue to affect different racial groups in Los Angeles.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Crash</i> won the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Best Picture</a> Oscar at the <a href="/wiki/78th_Academy_Awards" title="78th Academy Awards">78th Academy Awards</a>, controversially beating the critically favored <i><a href="/wiki/Brokeback_Mountain" title="Brokeback Mountain">Brokeback Mountain</a></i> and making it only the second film ever (the other being <i><a href="/wiki/The_Sting" title="The Sting">The Sting</a></i>) to win the Academy Award for Best Picture without having been nominated for any of the three Golden Globe Awards for Best Motion Picture (Best Drama, Best Comedy/Musical and Best Foreign Film).</p>
<p>The film's use of moral quandary as a storytelling medium was widely reported as ironic, since many saw it as the "safe" choice to <i>Brokeback Mountain</i>. Critic <a href="/wiki/Kenneth_Turan" title="Kenneth Turan">Kenneth Turan</a> suggested that <i>Crash</i> benefited from anti-homosexual discomfort among Academy members,<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup> while critic <a href="/wiki/Roger_Ebert" title="Roger Ebert">Roger Ebert</a> was of a different opinion, arguing that the better film won that year. Ebert placed <i>Crash</i> on his best ten list as #1 best film of 2005,.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/Film_Comment" title="Film Comment">Film Comment</a></i> magazine placed <i>Crash</i> first on their list of "Worst Winners of Best Picture Oscars", followed by <i><a href="/wiki/Slumdog_Millionaire" title="Slumdog Millionaire">Slumdog Millionaire</a></i> at #2, and <i><a href="/wiki/Chicago_(2002_film)" title="Chicago (2002 film)">Chicago</a></i> at #3.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In a 2015 re-polling of Academy members, Brokeback Mountain was voted Best Picture over Crash and the other 2006 nominees.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Crash</i> was nominated for six awards at the <a href="/wiki/78th_Academy_Awards" title="78th Academy Awards">78th Academy Awards</a> and won three, including the win for <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Best Picture</a>. It was nominated for two <a href="/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award" title="Golden Globe Award">Golden Globe Awards</a>, one for <a href="/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actor_%E2%80%93_Motion_Picture" title="Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor  Motion Picture">Best Supporting Actor</a> (<a href="/wiki/Matt_Dillon" title="Matt Dillon">Matt Dillon</a>) and the other for <a href="/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Screenplay" title="Golden Globe Award for Best Screenplay">Best Screenplay</a> (<a href="/wiki/Paul_Haggis" title="Paul Haggis">Paul Haggis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Robert_Moresco" title="Robert Moresco">Robert Moresco</a>).</p>
<p>Other awards include Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture at the <a href="/wiki/2005_Screen_Actors_Guild_Awards" title="2005 Screen Actors Guild Awards" class="mw-redirect">2005 Screen Actors Guild Awards</a>; Best Original Screenplay at the <a href="/wiki/Writers_Guild_of_America_Awards_2005" title="Writers Guild of America Awards 2005">Writers Guild of America Awards 2005</a>; Best Original Screenplay and Best Supporting Actress (Newton) at the <a href="/wiki/59th_British_Academy_Film_Awards" title="59th British Academy Film Awards">59th British Academy Film Awards</a>; Best Writer at the <a href="/wiki/Critics%27_Choice_Awards" title="Critics' Choice Awards" class="mw-redirect">Critics' Choice Awards</a>; Outstanding Motion Picture and Outstanding Actor in a Leading Role (Howard) at the Black Movie Awards; Best First Feature and Best Supporting Male (Dillon) at the <a href="/wiki/Independent_Spirit_Awards" title="Independent Spirit Awards" class="mw-redirect">Independent Spirit Awards</a>; Best Cast and Best Writer at the <a href="/wiki/Broadcast_Film_Critics_Association_Awards" title="Broadcast Film Critics Association Awards" class="mw-redirect">Broadcast Film Critics Association Awards</a>; and Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Motion Picture (Howard) and Outstanding Motion Picture at the <a href="/wiki/NAACP_Image_Award" title="NAACP Image Award">NAACP Image Awards</a>.</p>
<p><i>Crash</i> was one of the 400 nominated movies for the <a href="/wiki/American_Film_Institute" title="American Film Institute">American Film Institute</a>'s 2007 list <a href="/wiki/AFI%27s_100_Years...100_Movies_(10th_Anniversary_Edition)" title="AFI's 100 Years...100 Movies (10th Anniversary Edition)">AFI's 100 Years...100 Movies (10th Anniversary Edition)</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>All songs were written and composed by <a href="/wiki/Mark_Isham" title="Mark Isham">Mark Isham</a>, except where noted. The original score was released through labels Gut and Colosseum in 2005. The iTunes release is the complete score released through Yari Music Group, and has the cues isolated and in film order (unlike the commercial score CD which is edited, incomplete, in a different order, and in suite form).<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The soundtrack's title is <i>Crash: Music from and Inspired by the Film</i>.</p>
<p><small style="font-size:85%;">Note: The country song playing during the carjacking scene is "Whiskey Town" by <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.mootdavis.com">Moot Davis</a>.</small></p>
<p><i>Crash</i> was released on <a href="/wiki/DVD" title="DVD">DVD</a> on September 6, 2005, in widescreen and fullscreen one-disc versions, with a number of bonus features, including a music video by <a href="/wiki/KansasCali" title="KansasCali">KansasCali</a> (now known as <a href="/wiki/The_Rocturnals" title="The Rocturnals">The Rocturnals</a>) for the song "If I..." from the soundtrack. The <a href="/wiki/Director%27s_cut" title="Director's cut">director's cut</a> of the film was released in a two-disc special edition DVD on April 4, 2006, with more bonus content than the one-disc set. The director's cut is three minutes longer than the theatrical cut. The scene where Daniel is talking with his daughter under her bed is extended and a new scene is added with officer Hansen in the police station locker room.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2012)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<p>The film also was released in a limited edition <a href="/wiki/VHS" title="VHS">VHS</a> version. It was the last Academy Award for Best Picture-winning film to be released in VHS format.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2009)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> It was also the first Best Picture winner to be released on <a href="/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc" title="Blu-ray Disc" class="mw-redirect">Blu-ray Disc</a> in the US, on June 27, 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>A 13-episode series premiered on the <a href="/wiki/Starz_(TV_channel)" title="Starz (TV channel)" class="mw-redirect">Starz</a> network on October 17, 2008. The series features <a href="/wiki/Dennis_Hopper" title="Dennis Hopper">Dennis Hopper</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Record_producer" title="Record producer">record producer</a> in <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a>, <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>, and how his life is connected to other characters in the city, including a police officer (<a href="/wiki/Ross_McCall" title="Ross McCall">Ross McCall</a>) and his partner, actress-turned-police officer, <a href="/wiki/Arlene_Tur" title="Arlene Tur">Arlene Tur</a>. The cast consists of a Brentwood mother (<a href="/wiki/Clare_Carey" title="Clare Carey">Clare Carey</a>), her real-estate developer husband (<a href="/wiki/D._B._Sweeney" title="D. B. Sweeney">D. B. Sweeney</a>), a former <a href="/wiki/Gang" title="Gang">gang</a> member-turned-EMT (<a href="/wiki/Brian_Tee" title="Brian Tee">Brian Tee</a>), a street-smart driver (<a href="/wiki/Jocko_Sims" title="Jocko Sims">Jocko Sims</a>), an undocumented <a href="/wiki/Guatemala" title="Guatemala">Guatemalan</a> <a href="/wiki/Immigrant" title="Immigrant" class="mw-redirect">immigrant</a> (Luis Chavez), and a detective (Nick Tarabay).<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><br></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Pacific Rim</i> (film)</h1>
<p><i><b>Pacific Rim</b></i> is a 2013 <a href="/wiki/Science_fiction_film" title="Science fiction film">science fiction film</a> directed by <a href="/wiki/Guillermo_del_Toro" title="Guillermo del Toro">Guillermo del Toro</a>, and starring <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Hunnam" title="Charlie Hunnam">Charlie Hunnam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Idris_Elba" title="Idris Elba">Idris Elba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rinko_Kikuchi" title="Rinko Kikuchi">Rinko Kikuchi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Day" title="Charlie Day">Charlie Day</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Kazinsky" title="Robert Kazinsky">Robert Kazinsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Max_Martini" title="Max Martini">Max Martini</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ron_Perlman" title="Ron Perlman">Ron Perlman</a>. The screenplay is by <a href="/wiki/Travis_Beacham" title="Travis Beacham">Travis Beacham</a> and del Toro, with a story by Beacham.</p>
<p>The film is set in the 2020s, when Earth is at war with the <a href="/wiki/Kaiju" title="Kaiju">Kaijus</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>a<span>]</span></a></sup> colossal monsters which have emerged from an interdimensional <a href="/wiki/Portal_(doorway)" title="Portal (doorway)" class="mw-redirect">portal</a> on the bottom of the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a>. To combat the monsters, humanity unites to create the Jaegers,<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span>[</span>b<span>]</span></a></sup> gigantic humanoid <a href="/wiki/Mecha" title="Mecha">mechas</a> each controlled by at least two pilots, whose minds are joined by a neural bridge. Focusing on the war's later days, the story follows Raleigh Becket, a washed-up Jaeger pilot called out of retirement and teamed with rookie pilot Mako Mori as part of a last-ditch effort to defeat the Kaijus.</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Principal_photography" title="Principal photography">Principal photography</a> began on November 14, 2011 in <a href="/wiki/Toronto" title="Toronto">Toronto</a> and lasted through April 2012. The film was produced by <a href="/wiki/Legendary_Pictures" title="Legendary Pictures" class="mw-redirect">Legendary Pictures</a> and distributed by <a href="/wiki/Warner_Bros." title="Warner Bros.">Warner Bros. Pictures</a>. It was released on July 12, 2013 including releases in <a href="/wiki/3D_film" title="3D film">3-D</a> and <a href="/wiki/IMAX_3D" title="IMAX 3D" class="mw-redirect">IMAX 3D</a>, receiving generally positive reviews; the visual effects and action sequences were highly praised. While the film was a box office disappointment in the United States, it was highly successful in other territories.<sup id="cite_ref-A_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-A-9"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> It earned a worldwide total of more than $411 million, including $114 million in China, its largest market, becoming Del Toro's most commercially successful film to date. A sequel with the working title <i>Maelstrom</i> was announced in 2014, and was scheduled to be released by <a href="/wiki/Universal_Studios" title="Universal Studios">Universal Studios</a> on August 4, 2017. In September 2015, the sequel was reported to have been "halted indefinitely"<sup id="cite_ref-hr16_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hr16-10"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup> however, Del Toro and Universal Pictures confirmed that the sequel has only been delayed and will continue to proceed forward.<sup id="cite_ref-ewdel_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ewdel-11"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-var29_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-var29-12"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>In 2013, an inter-dimensional portal, the Breach, appears at the bottom of the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a>. From the Breach, giant monsters called <a href="/wiki/Kaiju" title="Kaiju">Kaiju</a> periodically emerge and attack cities on the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Rim" title="Pacific Rim">Pacific Rim</a>. The <a href="/wiki/United_nations" title="United nations" class="mw-redirect">United Nations</a> fund the Jaeger Program to construct the Jaegers, giant <a href="/wiki/Mecha" title="Mecha">mecha</a> robots, to fight the Kaiju. Each Jaeger is controlled by two or more pilots, who are mentally linked (called "drifting") to share the mental burden of piloting the machines.</p>
<p>In 2020, pilots Raleigh and Yancy Becket are assigned to protect the Alaskan coastline from a Kaiju in their Jaeger, <i>Gipsy Danger</i>. The Kaiju survives their initial assault and blindsides <i>Gipsy Danger</i>, wrecking it and killing Yancy. Raleigh is able to single-handedly kill the Kaiju and pilot the heavily damaged <i>Gipsy Danger</i> back to shore. Traumatized by Yancy, his brother and only remaining family's death, he quits the program.</p>
<p>By 2025, the Jaeger Program is deemed inefficient by world leaders, as the increasing numbers and strength of the Kaiju are destroying them at a faster rate than they can be built. They decide to shut down the program and construct defensive coastal walls instead. <a href="/wiki/Marshal" title="Marshal">Marshal</a> Stacker Pentecost, commander of the Jaegers, plans to launch a final assault on the Breach with a <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_bomb" title="Nuclear bomb" class="mw-redirect">nuclear bomb</a>, despite past attempts being unsuccessful. He tracks down Raleigh and recruits him back into the program.</p>
<p>At the <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> base (Shatterdome), Raleigh meets the crews for the remaining Jaegers, and Pentecosts adopted daughter Mako Mori. She shows great potential as a pilot, and Raleigh manages to convince Pentecost to let her drift with him. In their first drift in the repaired <i>Gipsy Danger</i>, Raleigh briefly falls out of synch. Mako becomes lost in her childhood memory of the Kaiju attack on <a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">Tokyo</a> that orphaned her, and nearly discharges <i>Gipsy Danger's</i> plasma cannon until the Jaeger is shut down. Pentecost <a href="/wiki/Grounding" title="Grounding" class="mw-disambig">grounds</a> an ashamed Mako, leaving Raleigh without a copilot.</p>
<p>Meanwhile, scientist Newton Geiszler creates a device that allows him to drift with a Kaiju brain fragment. He discovers that the Kaiju are <a href="/wiki/Bioweapon" title="Bioweapon" class="mw-redirect">bioweapons</a> created by extraterrestrial colonists to wipe out humanity. Pentecost sends him to find Kaiju <a href="/wiki/Black_market" title="Black market">black market</a> dealer Hannibal Chau, who operates within Hong Kong, to obtain an intact Kaiju brain and acquire more information. He soon learns that, during the drift, the Kaiju <a href="/wiki/Group_mind_(science_fiction)" title="Group mind (science fiction)">hive mind</a> becomes aware of his consciousness. As a result, two Kaiju are unleashed upon the city.</p>
<p>The other Jaegers, <i>Crimson Typhoon</i>, <i>Cherno Alpha</i>, and <i>Striker Eureka</i>, are sent to slay the Kaiju, but the first two are destroyed while <i>Striker</i> is immobilized by an <a href="/wiki/Electromagnetic_pulse_in_fiction_and_popular_culture" title="Electromagnetic pulse in fiction and popular culture">EMP blast</a>. Out of options, Pentecost allows Raleigh and Mako to pilot <i>Gipsy Danger</i>, and the two pilots successfully kill both Kaiju. Newton and Hannibal go to retrieve one of the Kaijus brain and discover it is pregnant. The infant Kaiju swallows Hannibal but is strangled by its own <a href="/wiki/Umbilical_cord" title="Umbilical cord">umbilical cord</a>. Newton and Hermann Gottlieb, another scientist, drift together with the infant Kaiju's brain. They discover that only the Kaiju can travel through the Breach and warn the Jaeger team.</p>
<p>Raleigh finds out Pentecost is terminally ill due to piloting a first generation Jaeger with no radiation shielding. The last time he piloted a Jaeger was during the Tokyo attack, during which he was forced to single-handedly kill the Kaiju, making him and Raleigh the only pilots who have killed a Kaiju without a copilot (known as solo combat). The Jaeger teams resume the original plan, with Pentecost and Chuck Hansen piloting <i>Striker Eureka</i> which carries a nuclear bomb. They, along with <i>Gipsy Danger</i>, travel to the Breach. They are confronted by three Kaiju, including the biggest one they have seen. Both Jaegers are severely damaged in the battle. Overwhelmed, Pentecost and Chuck decide to detonate the bomb and kill two of the Kaiju.</p>
<p><i>Gipsy Danger</i> kills the surviving Kaiju and rides its body through the Breach into the alien dimension. Raleigh ejects Makos escape pod and manually overloads <i>Gipsy Danger</i>s <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reactor" title="Nuclear reactor">nuclear reactor</a>. He then escapes in the remaining pod. The Jaeger explodes, destroying the aliens and sealing the Breach. Raleigh and Mako surface in the Pacific Ocean and embrace for their victory as rescue helicopters arrive.</p>
<p>In a mid-credits scene, Hannibal cuts his way out of the dead infant Kaiju.</p>
<p>Additional Jaeger pilots include Charles Luu, Lance Luu and Mark Luu as the Wei Tang triplets (China), and <a href="/wiki/Robert_Maillet" title="Robert Maillet">Robert Maillet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Heather_Doerksen" title="Heather Doerksen">Heather Doerksen</a> as Sasha and Aleksis Kaidanovsky (Russia). <a href="/wiki/Joe_Pingue" title="Joe Pingue">Joe Pingue</a> portrays Captain Merrit, the captain of a fishing boat caught in a battle between Jaeger and Kaiju. <a href="/wiki/Santiago_Segura" title="Santiago Segura">Santiago Segura</a> plays an aide to Hannibal Chau.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Brad_William_Henke" title="Brad William Henke">Brad William Henke</a> and <a href="/wiki/Larry_Joe_Campbell" title="Larry Joe Campbell">Larry Joe Campbell</a> portray members of a construction team Raleigh joins after retiring from the Pan Pacific Defense Corps. <a href="/wiki/Robin_Thomas" title="Robin Thomas">Robin Thomas</a>, Julian Barnes, and <a href="/wiki/David_Richmond-Peck" title="David Richmond-Peck">David Richmond-Peck</a> portray <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">U.N.</a> representatives from the United States, Great Britain, and Canada respectively. <a href="/wiki/Sebastian_Pigott" title="Sebastian Pigott">Sebastian Pigott</a> appears as a Jaeger engineer and Joshua Peace appears as an officer, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jonathan_Foxon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jonathan Foxon (page does not exist)">Jonathan Foxon</a> appears as an frantic civilian. <a href="/wiki/David_Fox_(actor)" title="David Fox (actor)">David Fox</a> plays an old man on a beach, while Jane Watson portrays Raleigh and Yancy's mother in a flashback sequence.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span>[</span>38<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span>[</span>39<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span>[</span>40<span>]</span></a></sup> Producer Thomas Tull makes a cameo appearance.<sup id="cite_ref-Wired-Watercutter_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wired-Watercutter-43"><span>[</span>41<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In the film, a Jaeger's neural load is too much for a single pilot to handle alone, meaning they must first be psychically linked to another pilota concept called "drifting". When pilots drift, they quickly gain intimate knowledge of each other's memories and feelings, and have no choice but to accept them; del Toro found this concept's dramatic potential compelling. The director expressed his intention that the empathy metaphors extend to real life:</p>
<p>The pilots' smaller stories actually make a bigger point, which is that we're all together in the same robot [in life]... Either we get along or we die. I didn't want this to be a recruitment ad or anything jingoistic. The idea of the movie is just for us to trust each other, to cross over barriers of color, sex, beliefs, whatever, and just stick together.</p>
<p>Del Toro acknowledged this message's simplicity, but said he would have liked to have seen adventure films with similar morals when he was a child.<sup id="cite_ref-Boston_33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boston-33"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup> The film's ten primary characters all have "little arcs" conducive to this idea; del Toro stated: "I think that's a great message to give kids... 'That guy you were beating the shit out of ten minutes ago? That's the guy you have to work with five minutes later.' That's life... We can only be complete when we work together." The director noted that <i><a href="/wiki/Hellboy_(film)" title="Hellboy (film)">Hellboy</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Devil%27s_Backbone" title="The Devil's Backbone">The Devil's Backbone</a></i> told the same message, though the latter conveyed it in a very different way.<sup id="cite_ref-Beaks1_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Beaks1-44"><span>[</span>42<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film centers on the relationship between Becket and Mori, but is not a love story in a conventional sense. Both are deeply damaged human beings who have decided to suppress their respective traumas. While learning to pilot their Jaeger, they undergo a process of "opening up", gaining access to each other's thoughts, memories and secrets. Their relationship is necessarily one of respect and "perfect trust". Hunnam commented that the film is "a love story without a love story. It's about all of the necessary elements of love without arriving at love itself".<sup id="cite_ref-trauma_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-trauma-20"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45"><span>[</span>43<span>]</span></a></sup> Both Becket and Mori have suffered profound personal tragedies; one of the script's central ideas is that two damaged people can metaphorically "become one", with their figurative missing pieces connecting almost like a puzzle.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46"><span>[</span>44<span>]</span></a></sup> Del Toro emphasized the characters' emotional intimacy by filming their training fight scene the way he would a sex scene.<sup id="cite_ref-timeout-QA_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-timeout-QA-47"><span>[</span>45<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Del Toro, a self-described <a href="/wiki/Pacifist" title="Pacifist" class="mw-redirect">pacifist</a>, avoided what he termed "car commercial aesthetics" or "army recruitment video aesthetics", and gave the characters <a href="/wiki/Western_(genre)" title="Western (genre)">Western</a> ranks including "marshal" and "ranger" rather than military ranks such as "captain", "major" or "general". The director stated: "I avoided making any kind of message that says war is good. We have enough firepower in the world."<sup id="cite_ref-Star_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Star-21"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> Del Toro wanted to break from the mass death and destruction featured in contemporary blockbuster films, and made a point of showing the streets and buildings being evacuated before Kaiju attacks, ensuring that the destruction depicted is "completely remorseless". The director stated:</p>
<p>I don't want people being crushed. I want the joy that I used to get seeing <a href="/wiki/Godzilla" title="Godzilla">Godzilla</a> toss a tank without having to think there are guys in the tank... What I think is you could do nothing but echo the moment you're in. There is a global anxiety about how fragile the status quo is and the safety of citizens, but in my mindhonestlythis film is in another realm. There is no correlation to the real world. There is no fear of a copycat Kaiju attack because a Kaiju saw it on the news and said, 'I'm going to destroy Seattle.' In my case, I'm picking up a tradition. One that started right after World War II and was a coping mechanism, in a way, for Japan to heal the wounds of that war. And it's integral for a Kaiju to rampage in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48"><span>[</span>46<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Writing for the <i><a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Review_of_Books" title="Los Angeles Review of Books">Los Angeles Review of Books</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Wai_Chee_Dimock" title="Wai Chee Dimock">Wai Chee Dimock</a> connected the film's central theme of <i>togetherness</i> to its recurring image of missing shoes, stating the "utopian dream" driving the characters is</p>
<p>that puny humans like us could be 'together'not only in the specific neural melding that must take place between the two Jaeger co-pilots but also, more generally speaking, in a <a href="/wiki/Fractal" title="Fractal">fractal</a> web of resemblance, filling the world with copies of ourselves at varying orders of magnitude and with varying degrees of re-expression, beginning with the shoes on our feet.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49"><span>[</span>47<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In February 2006, it was reported that <a href="/wiki/Guillermo_del_Toro" title="Guillermo del Toro">Guillermo del Toro</a> would direct <a href="/wiki/Travis_Beacham" title="Travis Beacham">Travis Beacham</a>'s fantasy screenplay, <i>Killing on Carnival Row</i>, but the project never materialized.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50"><span>[</span>48<span>]</span></a></sup> Beacham conceived <i>Pacific Rim</i> the following year. While walking on the beach near <a href="/wiki/Santa_Monica_Pier" title="Santa Monica Pier">Santa Monica Pier</a>, the screenwriter imagined a giant robot and a giant monster fighting to the death. "They just sort of materialized out of the fog, these vast, godlike things." He later conceived the idea that each robot had two pilots, asking "what happens when one of those people dies?" Deciding this would be "a story about loss, moving on after loss, and dealing with <a href="/wiki/Survivor_guilt" title="Survivor guilt">survivor's guilt</a>", Beacham commenced writing the film.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span>[</span>49<span>]</span></a></sup> On May 28, 2010, it was reported that <a href="/wiki/Legendary_Pictures" title="Legendary Pictures" class="mw-redirect">Legendary Pictures</a> had purchased Beacham's detailed 25-page <a href="/wiki/Film_treatment" title="Film treatment">film treatment</a>, now titled <i>Pacific Rim</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52"><span>[</span>50<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On July 28, 2010, it was reported that del Toro would next direct an adaptation of <a href="/wiki/H._P._Lovecraft" title="H. P. Lovecraft">H. P. Lovecraft</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/At_the_Mountains_of_Madness" title="At the Mountains of Madness">At the Mountains of Madness</a></i> for <a href="/wiki/Universal_Studios" title="Universal Studios">Universal Studios</a>, with <a href="/wiki/James_Cameron" title="James Cameron">James Cameron</a> producing.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53"><span>[</span>51<span>]</span></a></sup> When del Toro met with Legendary Pictures to discuss the possibility of collaborating with them on a film, he was intrigued by Beacham's treatmentstill a "very small pitch" at this point.<sup id="cite_ref-Huffington_Post_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Huffington_Post-54"><span>[</span>52<span>]</span></a></sup> Del Toro struck a deal with Legendary: while directing <i>At the Mountains of Madness</i>, he would produce and co-write <i>Pacific Rim</i>; because of the films' conflicting production schedules, he would direct <i>Pacific Rim</i> only if <i>At the Mountains of Madness</i> were cancelled.<sup id="cite_ref-AICN-Quint_38-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AICN-Quint-38"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tom_Cruise" title="Tom Cruise">Tom Cruise</a> was attached to star in the Lovecraft adaptation.<sup id="cite_ref-GDT-Collider_14-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GDT-Collider-14"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On March 7, 2011, it was reported that Universal would not proceed with <i>At the Mountains of Madness</i> because del Toro was unwilling to compromise on the $150 million budget and <a href="/wiki/Motion_Picture_Association_of_America_film_rating_system" title="Motion Picture Association of America film rating system">R rating</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55"><span>[</span>53<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span>[</span>54<span>]</span></a></sup> The director later reflected, "When it happened, this has never happened to me, but I actually cried that weekend a lot. I don't want to sound like a puny soul, but I really was devastated. I was weeping for the movie."<sup id="cite_ref-HeroComplex_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HeroComplex-57"><span>[</span>55<span>]</span></a></sup> The project collapsed on a Friday, and del Toro signed to direct <i>Pacific Rim</i> the following Monday.<sup id="cite_ref-GDT-Collider_14-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GDT-Collider-14"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Del Toro spent a year working with Beacham on the screenplay, and is credited as co-writer. He introduced ideas he had always wished to see in the genre, such as a Kaiju birth and a Kaiju attack seen from a child's perspective.<sup id="cite_ref-timeout-QA_47-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-timeout-QA-47"><span>[</span>45<span>]</span></a></sup> The script also received an uncredited rewrite from <a href="/wiki/Neil_Cross" title="Neil Cross">Neil Cross</a>, who previously created the Idris Elba-starring drama series <i><a href="/wiki/Luther_(TV_series)" title="Luther (TV series)">Luther</a></i> and wrote the del Toro-produced <a href="/wiki/Horror_film" title="Horror film">horror film</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Mama_(2013_film)" title="Mama (2013 film)">Mama</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58"><span>[</span>56<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Melton" title="Patrick Melton">Patrick Melton</a> and <a href="/wiki/Marcus_Dunstan" title="Marcus Dunstan">Marcus Dunstan</a> were enlisted to perform uncredited rewrites when their <a href="/wiki/Spec_script" title="Spec script">spec script</a> <i>Monstropolis</i> caught the filmmaker's attention.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span>[</span>57<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Drew_Pearce" title="Drew Pearce">Drew Pearce</a> also carried out uncredited work on the script.<sup id="cite_ref-scriptuncredited_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scriptuncredited-60"><span>[</span>58<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Principal_photography" title="Principal photography">Filming</a> began on November 14, 2011<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61"><span>[</span>59<span>]</span></a></sup> and continued in <a href="/wiki/Toronto" title="Toronto">Toronto</a> into April 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62"><span>[</span>60<span>]</span></a></sup> Del Toro gave an update after the second week on filming finished.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63"><span>[</span>61<span>]</span></a></sup> The film was referred to as <i>Silent Seas</i> and <i>Still Seas</i> during production.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64"><span>[</span>62<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Del Toro had never shot a film in less than 115 days, but had only 103 to shoot <i>Pacific Rim</i>. In order to achieve this, del Toro scheduled a splinter unit that he could direct early in the day, before main unit, and on his off-days. The director worked 17 to 18 hours a day, seven days a week, for much of the schedule. Del Toro took a new approach to directing actors, allowing "looser" movements and improvisation; the director maintained tight control over the production: "Everything, 100% goes through me sooner or later. I do not delegate anything. Some people like it, some people don't, but it has to be done that way."<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65"><span>[</span>63<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film was shot using <a href="/wiki/Red_Epic" title="Red Epic" class="mw-redirect">Red Epic</a> cameras.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66"><span>[</span>64<span>]</span></a></sup> At first Guillermo del Toro decided not to shoot or convert the film to <a href="/wiki/3D_film" title="3D film">3D</a>, as the effect would not work due to the sheer size of the film's robots and monsters, explaining</p>
<p>I didn't want to make the movie 3D because when you have things that big... the thing that happens naturally, you're looking at two buildings lets say at 300 feet [away], if you move there is no <a href="/wiki/Parallax" title="Parallax">parallax</a>. They're so big that, in 3D, you barely notice anything no matter how fast you move... To force the 3D effects for robots and monsters that are supposed to be big you are making their [perspective] miniaturized, making them human scale.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67"><span>[</span>65<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>It was later announced that the film would be converted to 3D, with the conversion taking 40 weeks longer than most. Del Toro said: "What can I tell you? I changed my mind. I'm not running for office. I can do a <a href="/wiki/Mitt_Romney" title="Mitt Romney">Romney</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68"><span>[</span>66<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Del Toro cut approximately an hour of material from the film. The unused footage explored the characters and their arcs in greater detail, but the director felt it was necessary to strike a balance, stating: "We cannot pretend this is <a href="/wiki/Henrik_Ibsen" title="Henrik Ibsen">Ibsen</a> with monsters and giant robots. I cannot pretend I'm doing a profound reflection on mankind." Each character's arc was edited down to its minimal requirements.<sup id="cite_ref-Beaks1_44-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Beaks1-44"><span>[</span>42<span>]</span></a></sup> The director wanted to keep the film around two hours, particularly for younger viewers. <a href="/wiki/Alejandro_Gonz%C3%A1lez_I%C3%B1%C3%A1rritu" title="Alejandro Gonzlez Irritu">Alejandro Gonzlez Irritu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alfonso_Cuar%C3%B3n" title="Alfonso Cuarn">Alfonso Cuarn</a> helped with the editing; Irritu removed ten minutes of footage, while Cuarn removed "a few minutes" and rearranged several scenes.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69"><span>[</span>67<span>]</span></a></sup> Irritu and Cuarn receive a "special thanks" in the film's end credits, as do <a href="/wiki/James_Cameron" title="James Cameron">James Cameron</a> and <a href="/wiki/David_Cronenberg" title="David Cronenberg">David Cronenberg</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70"><span>[</span>68<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Del Toro envisioned <i>Pacific Rim</i> as an earnest, colorful adventure story, with an "incredibly airy and light feel", in contrast to the "super-brooding, super-dark, cynical summer movie". The director focused on "big, beautiful, sophisticated visuals" and action that would satisfy an adult audience, but has stated his "real hope" is to introduce the Kaiju and mecha genres to a generation of children.<sup id="cite_ref-HeroComplex_57-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HeroComplex-57"><span>[</span>55<span>]</span></a></sup> While the film draws heavily on these genres, it avoids direct references to previous works. Del Toro intended to create something original but "madly in love" with its influences, instilled with "epic beauty" and "operatic grandeur".<sup id="cite_ref-Blastr_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Blastr-71"><span>[</span>69<span>]</span></a></sup> The end credits dedicate the film to <a href="/wiki/Ray_Harryhausen" title="Ray Harryhausen">Ray Harryhausen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ishir%C5%8D_Honda" title="Ishir Honda">Ishir Honda</a>, who helped to establish the giant monster genre with films such as <i><a href="/wiki/The_Beast_from_20,000_Fathoms" title="The Beast from 20,000 Fathoms">The Beast from 20,000 Fathoms</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Godzilla_(1954_film)" title="Godzilla (1954 film)">Godzilla</a></i> respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72"><span>[</span>70<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film was to honor the Kaiju and mecha genres while creating an original stand-alone film, something "conscious of the heritage, but not a pastiche or an homage or a greatest hits of everything". The director made a point of starting from scratch, without emulating or referencing any previous examples of those genres. He cautioned his designers not to turn to films like <i><a href="/wiki/Gamera_(film)" title="Gamera (film)">Gamera</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Godzilla_(1954_film)" title="Godzilla (1954 film)">Godzilla</a></i>, or <i><a href="/wiki/The_War_of_the_Gargantuas" title="The War of the Gargantuas">The War of the Gargantuas</a></i> for inspiration, stating: "I didn't want to be <a href="/wiki/Postmodernist_film" title="Postmodernist film">postmodern</a>, or referential, or just belong to a genre. I really wanted to create something new, something madly in love with those things. I tried to bring epic beauty to it, and drama and operatic grandeur."<sup id="cite_ref-Blastr_71-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Blastr-71"><span>[</span>69<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73"><span>[</span>71<span>]</span></a></sup> Rather than popular culture, he drew inspiration from works of art such as <i><a href="/wiki/The_Colossus_(painting)" title="The Colossus (painting)">The Colossus</a></i> and <a href="/wiki/George_Bellows" title="George Bellows">George Bellows</a>'s boxing paintings.<sup id="cite_ref-Huffington_Post_54-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Huffington_Post-54"><span>[</span>52<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Huffington_Post_2_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Huffington_Post_2-74"><span>[</span>72<span>]</span></a></sup> The film's designers include <a href="/wiki/Wayne_Barlowe" title="Wayne Barlowe">Wayne Barlowe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Chichoni" title="Oscar Chichoni">Oscar Chichoni</a>, monster sculptors David Meng and Simon Lee, and <i><a href="/wiki/Hellboy_II:_The_Golden_Army" title="Hellboy II: The Golden Army">Hellboy II</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hobbit_(film_series)" title="The Hobbit (film series)">The Hobbit</a></i> designer Francisco Ruiz Velasco.<sup id="cite_ref-Huffington_Post_54-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Huffington_Post-54"><span>[</span>52<span>]</span></a></sup> Del Toro has acknowledged that some designs created for his cancelled <i><a href="/wiki/At_the_Mountains_of_Madness" title="At the Mountains of Madness">At the Mountains of Madness</a></i> adaptation may have been used in <i>Pacific Rim</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-timeout-QA_47-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-timeout-QA-47"><span>[</span>45<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
