<p>Approximately one hundred Kaijus and one hundred Jaegers were designed, but only a fraction of these appear in the film; every week the filmmakers would "do an <i><a href="/wiki/American_Idol" title="American Idol">American Idol</a></i>" and vote for the best.<sup id="cite_ref-Sacks_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sacks-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> In designing Kaijus, the film's artists frequently drew inspiration from nature rather than other works. The director commented: "Kaijus are essentially outlandish in a way, but on the other hand they come sort of in families: you've got the reptilian Kaiju, the insect Kaiju, the sort of crustacean Kaiju... So to take an outlandish design and then render it with an attention to real animal anatomy and detail is interesting."<sup id="cite_ref-aintitcool50956_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aintitcool50956-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> Del Toro avoided making the Kaijus too similar to any Earth creatures, instead opting to make them otherworldly and alien.<sup id="cite_ref-io9-Barlowe_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-io9-Barlowe-75"><span>[</span>73<span>]</span></a></sup> Del Toro called the film's Kaijus "weapons", stating that they are "the cleaning crew, the cats sent into the warehouse to clean out the mice." Certain design elements are shared by all the Kaijus; this is intended to suggest that they are connected and were designed for a similar purpose.<sup id="cite_ref-AICN-Quint_38-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AICN-Quint-38"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup> Each Kaiju was given a vaguely humanoid silhouette to echo the man-in-suit aesthetic of early Japanese Kaiju films.<sup id="cite_ref-Unbelievable_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Unbelievable-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> While del Toro's other films feature ancient or damaged monsters, the Kaijus lack scars or any evidence of prior culture, indicating that they are engineered creations rather than the result of an evolutionary system.<sup id="cite_ref-io9-Barlowe_75-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-io9-Barlowe-75"><span>[</span>73<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Knifehead, the first Kaiju to appear in the film, is a tribute to the plodding kaiju of 1960s Japanese films, and is intended to look almost like a man in a rubber suit; its head was inspired by that of a <a href="/wiki/Goblin_shark" title="Goblin shark">goblin shark</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Beaks1_44-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Beaks1-44"><span>[</span>42<span>]</span></a></sup> Leatherback, the bouncer-like Kaiju which spews electro-magnetic charges, is a favorite of del Toro, who conceived it as a "brawler with this sort of beer belly"; the lumbering movements of gorillas were used as a reference.<sup id="cite_ref-USAToday_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USAToday-76"><span>[</span>74<span>]</span></a></sup> The Kaiju Otachi homages the dragons of Chinese mythology. The director called it a "Swiss army knife of a Kaiju"; with almost 20 minutes of screen time, it was given numerous features so the audience would not tire of it. The creature moves like a Komodo dragon in water, sports multiple jaws and an acid-filled neck sack, and unfurls wings when necessary.<sup id="cite_ref-Sacks_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sacks-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> It is also more intelligent than the other Kaijus, employing eagle-inspired strategies against the Jaegers.<sup id="cite_ref-USAToday_76-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USAToday-76"><span>[</span>74<span>]</span></a></sup> Onibaba, the Kaiju that orphans Mako Mori, resembles a fusion of a Japanese temple and a crustacean.<sup id="cite_ref-USAToday_76-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USAToday-76"><span>[</span>74<span>]</span></a></sup> Slattern, the largest Kaiju, is distinguished by its extremely long neck and "half-horn, half-crown" head, which del Toro considered both demonic and majestic.<sup id="cite_ref-USAToday_76-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USAToday-76"><span>[</span>74<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Gipsy Danger</i>, the American Jaeger, was based on the shape of New York City's <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a> buildings, such as the <a href="/wiki/Chrysler_Building" title="Chrysler Building">Chrysler Building</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Empire_State_Building" title="Empire State Building">Empire State Building</a>, but infused with <a href="/wiki/John_Wayne" title="John Wayne">John Wayne</a>'s gunslinger gait and hip movements. <i>Cherno Alpha</i>, the Russian Jaeger, was based on the shape and paint patterns of a T-series Russian tank, combined with a giant containment silo to give the appearance of a walking nuclear power plant with a <a href="/wiki/Cooling_tower" title="Cooling tower">cooling tower</a> on its head.<sup id="cite_ref-Sacks_3-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sacks-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>Crimson Typhoon</i>, the three-armed Chinese Jaeger, is piloted by triplets and resembles a "medieval little warrior"; its texture evokes Chinese lacquered wood with golden edges.<sup id="cite_ref-USAToday_76-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USAToday-76"><span>[</span>74<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>Striker Eureka</i>, the Australian Jaeger, is likened by del Toro to a <a href="/wiki/Land_Rover" title="Land Rover">Land Rover</a>; the most elegant and masculine Jaeger, it has a jutting chest, a camouflage paint scheme recalling the Australian outback, and the bravado of its pilots.<sup id="cite_ref-USAToday_76-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USAToday-76"><span>[</span>74<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film's costumes were designed by <a href="/wiki/Shane_Mahan" title="Shane Mahan">Shane Mahan</a> and Kate Hawley, who spent several months on the costumes of the Jaeger pilots. The Russian pilot suits are old-fashioned and echo cosmonaut space suits.<sup id="cite_ref-Huffington_Post_54-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Huffington_Post-54"><span>[</span>52<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Industrial_Light_%26_Magic" title="Industrial Light &amp; Magic">Industrial Light &amp; Magic</a> was chosen to the visual effects for <i>Pacific Rim</i>. Del Toro hired <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award" title="Academy Award" class="mw-redirect">Oscar</a> winners <a href="/wiki/John_Knoll" title="John Knoll">John Knoll</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hal_T._Hickel" title="Hal T. Hickel" class="mw-redirect">Hal T. Hickel</a>, both known for their work on the <i><a href="/wiki/Star_Wars" title="Star Wars">Star Wars</a></i> <a href="/wiki/Prequel_trilogy" title="Prequel trilogy" class="mw-redirect">prequel trilogy</a> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean" title="Pirates of the Caribbean">Pirates of the Caribbean</a></i> films. <a href="/wiki/Legacy_Effects" title="Legacy Effects">Legacy Effects</a> co-owner <a href="/wiki/Shane_Mahan" title="Shane Mahan">Shane Mahan</a>, known for creating the armored suits for <i><a href="/wiki/Iron_Man_(2008_film)" title="Iron Man (2008 film)">Iron Man</a></i>, was tasked with building the suits, helmets and conn-pods.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77"><span>[</span>75<span>]</span></a></sup> Oscar winner <a href="/wiki/Clay_Pinney" title="Clay Pinney">Clay Pinney</a>, known for his work on <i><a href="/wiki/Independence_Day_(1996_film)" title="Independence Day (1996 film)">Independence Day</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Star_Trek_(film)" title="Star Trek (film)">Star Trek</a></i>, was also brought on board. <a href="/wiki/Hybride_Technologies" title="Hybride Technologies" class="mw-redirect">Hybride Technologies</a>, a division of <a href="/wiki/Ubisoft" title="Ubisoft">Ubisoft</a>, and Rodeo FX also contributed to the visual effects.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78"><span>[</span>76<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79"><span>[</span>77<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Del Toro conceived the film as an <i>operatic</i> work:</p>
<p>That was one of the first words I said to the entire team at ILM. I said, 'This movie needs to be theatrical, operatic, romantic.' We used a lot of words not usually associated with high-tech blockbusters ... We went for a very, very, very, very saturated color palette for the battle for Hong Kong. I kept asking John to tap into his inner Mexican and be able to saturate the greens and the purples and the pinks and the oranges.</p>
<p>The classic Japanese <a href="/wiki/Woodblock_print" title="Woodblock print" class="mw-redirect">woodblock print</a> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Great_Wave_off_Kanagawa" title="The Great Wave off Kanagawa">The Great Wave off Kanagawa</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Hokusai" title="Hokusai">Hokusai</a> was a common motif in the ocean battles; Del Toro recalled, "I would say 'Give me a Hokusai wave'  we use the waves and weather in the movie very operatically."<sup id="cite_ref-Variety_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Variety-80"><span>[</span>78<span>]</span></a></sup> The director asked that Knoll not necessarily match the lighting from shot to shot: "It's pretty unorthodox to do that, but I think the results are really beautiful and very artistically free and powerful, not something you would associate with a big sci-fi action movie." Del Toro considers the film's digital water its most exciting visual effect: "The water dynamics in this movie are technically beautiful, but also artistically incredibly expressive. We agreed on making the water become almost another character. We would time the water very precisely. I'd say 'Get out of the wave [on this frame].'"<sup id="cite_ref-Variety_80-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Variety-80"><span>[</span>78<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film also features extensive <a href="/wiki/Miniature_effect" title="Miniature effect">miniature effect</a> shots provided by 32TEN Studios, under the supervision of ILM VFX Producer Susan Greenhow and ILM VFX Supervisors John Knoll and Lindy DeQuattro. Shot using RED Epic cameras on 3D rigs, the scenes produced by 32TEN involved the creation of a  scale office building interior which was destroyed by the fist of a Jaeger robot which was on a separate pneumatically controlled rig, as well as a sequence which depicted several rows of seats in a soccer stadium being blown apart as a Jaeger lands in the stadium, which was created by using -scale seats blown apart by air cannons. Additionally 32TEN provided several <a href="/wiki/Practical_effects" title="Practical effects" class="mw-redirect">practical</a> elements for ILMs compositing team including dust clouds, breaking glass and water effects.<sup id="cite_ref-32TEN_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32TEN-81"><span>[</span>79<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>A single-player fighting video game based on the film was announced by the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Classification_Board" title="Australian Classification Board">Australian Classification Board</a> for <a href="/wiki/Xbox_360" title="Xbox 360">Xbox 360</a> and <a href="/wiki/PlayStation_3" title="PlayStation 3">PlayStation 3</a>. Published and developed by <a href="/wiki/Yuke%27s" title="Yuke's">Yuke's</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Pacific_Rim_(video_game)" title="Pacific Rim (video game)">Pacific Rim: The Video Game</a></i> was released along with the film on July 12, 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82"><span>[</span>80<span>]</span></a></sup> The game received generally negative reviews.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83"><span>[</span>81<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Reliance_Entertainment" title="Reliance Entertainment">Reliance Games</a> developed a <i>Pacific Rim</i> tie-in game for <a href="/wiki/Smartphone" title="Smartphone">smartphone</a> platforms, such as <a href="/wiki/IOS" title="IOS">iOS</a> and <a href="/wiki/Android_(operating_system)" title="Android (operating system)">Android</a> devices;<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> this version also received negative reviews.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84"><span>[</span>82<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film's score was composed by <a href="/wiki/Ramin_Djawadi" title="Ramin Djawadi">Ramin Djawadi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85"><span>[</span>83<span>]</span></a></sup> Del Toro selected Djawadi based on his works on <i><a href="/wiki/Prison_Break" title="Prison Break">Prison Break</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Iron_Man_(2008_film)" title="Iron Man (2008 film)">Iron Man</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Game_of_Thrones" title="Game of Thrones">Game of Thrones</a></i>, stating: "His scores have a grandeur, but they have also an incredible sort of human soul." The director also stated that some Russian rap would be featured in the film.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86"><span>[</span>84<span>]</span></a></sup> The soundtrack was released on digital download from <a href="/wiki/Amazon.com" title="Amazon.com">Amazon</a> on June 18, 2013 and CD on June 25, 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87"><span>[</span>85<span>]</span></a></sup> The physical version of the soundtrack was released on July 9, 2013 by <a href="/wiki/WaterTower_Music" title="WaterTower Music">WaterTower Music</a>, three days before the theatrical release of the film itself.<sup id="cite_ref-FMR_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FMR-88"><span>[</span>86<span>]</span></a></sup> Guest musicians <a href="/wiki/Tom_Morello" title="Tom Morello">Tom Morello</a> and <a href="/wiki/Priscilla_Ahn" title="Priscilla Ahn">Priscilla Ahn</a> also feature as soloists on the score.<sup id="cite_ref-FMR_88-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FMR-88"><span>[</span>86<span>]</span></a></sup> Two songs appear in the film which are not included on the soundtrack are "Just Like Your Tenderness" by Luo Xiaoxuan, and the ending theme "Drift", performed by Blake Perlman featuring <a href="/wiki/Rza" title="Rza" class="mw-redirect">Rza</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89"><span>[</span>87<span>]</span></a></sup> The OST received mostly positive reviews. <i>The Action Elite</i> rated the album with a perfect five stars,<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90"><span>[</span>88<span>]</span></a></sup> the <i><a href="/wiki/Empire_(magazine)" title="Empire (magazine)" class="mw-redirect">Empire</a></i> gave four,<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91"><span>[</span>89<span>]</span></a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/MSN" title="MSN">MSN</a> and <i>Filmtracks</i> also gave the soundtrack four out of five stars.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92"><span>[</span>90<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Filmtracks_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Filmtracks-93"><span>[</span>91<span>]</span></a></sup> On July 27, 2013, the soundtrack was appeared at peak position number 7 on "US <i>Billboard</i> Top Soundtracks."<sup id="cite_ref-Billboard_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Billboard-94"><span>[</span>92<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On November 28, 2012, the official film website premiered alongside two viral videosone depicting the initial Kaiju attack as captured by a handheld camera.<sup id="cite_ref-panpacificdefense.com_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-panpacificdefense.com-95"><span>[</span>93<span>]</span></a></sup> Blueprints depicting the designs for the Jaeger machines were also released online.<sup id="cite_ref-panpacificdefense.com_95-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-panpacificdefense.com-95"><span>[</span>93<span>]</span></a></sup> On June 5, 2013, the graphic novel <i>Pacific Rim: Tales from Year Zero</i> was released. Written by Travis Beacham and featuring cover art by <a href="/wiki/Alex_Ross" title="Alex Ross">Alex Ross</a>, <i>Tales from Year Zero</i> serves as an introductory prologue to the film, and is set twelve years before its events.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96"><span>[</span>94<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97"><span>[</span>95<span>]</span></a></sup> On June 18, Insight Editions published <i>Pacific Rim: Man, Machines, and Monsters</i>, an art book written by David S. Cohen. The book chronicles the film's production with concept art, photography, the cast and crew's accounts of the shoot, and a foreword by del Toro.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98"><span>[</span>96<span>]</span></a></sup> On July 2, a viral video was released in which Ron Perlman's character, Hannibal Chau, advertises his fictional Kaiju organ dealership, Kaiju Remedies.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99"><span>[</span>97<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On the day of the film's release, July 12, 2013, another viral video was released to promote the film. It involved the collaboration of the film studio (including del Toro himself) and the <a href="/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a> network Polaris (also known as The Game Station). It featured members of the YouTube network (such as the <i><a href="/wiki/Game_Grumps" title="Game Grumps">Game Grumps</a></i>) as Jaeger pilots fighting Kaiju.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100"><span>[</span>98<span>]</span></a></sup> On July 16, a novelization by <a href="/wiki/Alexander_C._Irvine" title="Alexander C. Irvine">Alex Irvine</a> was released.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101"><span>[</span>99<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/National_Entertainment_Collectibles_Association" title="National Entertainment Collectibles Association">NECA</a> began selling <a href="/wiki/Action_figures" title="Action figures" class="mw-redirect">action figures</a> of the film's Kaijus and Jaegers.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102"><span>[</span>100<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Pacific Rim</i> was initially expected to reach theaters in July 2012. However, Warner Bros. decided to postpone the film's release date to May 10, 2013. In March 2012, it was announced that the film would be released on July 12, 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103"><span>[</span>101<span>]</span></a></sup> The film premiered in <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a> on July 1, 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104"><span>[</span>102<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Pacific Rim</i> grossed $101.8 million in North America, and has had a favorable international release, grossing $309.2 million in other countries, for a worldwide total of $411,002,906.<sup id="cite_ref-mojo_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mojo-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film grossed $3.6 million from Thursday night showings, 23 percent of which came from IMAX showings. It then faced competition from <i><a href="/wiki/Grown_Ups_2" title="Grown Ups 2">Grown Ups 2</a></i> and ultimately fell behind it on opening day, earning $14.6 million.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105"><span>[</span>103<span>]</span></a></sup> The film reached the #3 spot during the opening weekend with $37.2 million, behind <i><a href="/wiki/Despicable_Me_2" title="Despicable Me 2">Despicable Me 2</a></i> and <i>Grown Ups 2</i>. This is the highest ever opening for a film by del Toro, surpassing <i><a href="/wiki/Hellboy_II:_The_Golden_Army" title="Hellboy II: The Golden Army">Hellboy II: The Golden Army</a></i>. Around 50 percent of tickets were in 3D, which makes it the second highest 3D share of 2013, behind <i><a href="/wiki/Gravity_(film)" title="Gravity (film)">Gravity</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106"><span>[</span>104<span>]</span></a></sup> During its second weekend, the film dropped a steep 57% with a gross of $16 million, and during its third weekend, had dropped a further 52% with a gross of $7.7 million.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107"><span>[</span>105<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108"><span>[</span>106<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On July 22, 2013, it was reported that the film had reached #1 at the international box office over the weekend.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109"><span>[</span>107<span>]</span></a></sup> The film had a successful opening in China, grossing $45.2 million, until overtaken by <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hobbit:_The_Battle_of_the_Five_Armies" title="The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies">The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-China_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-China-110"><span>[</span>108<span>]</span></a></sup> the largest opening in China for a Warner Bros. title, and the sixth-largest Chinese debut of all time for any Hollywood film.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111"><span>[</span>109<span>]</span></a></sup> On August 19, 2013, its gross crossed $100 million in China alone, becoming the sixth-highest grossing American film ever in China.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112"><span>[</span>110<span>]</span></a></sup> It grossed a total of $114.3 million in the country, making China the largest market for the film.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113"><span>[</span>111<span>]</span></a></sup> In Japan, the film landed in the fifth position on opening weekend, with an initial earning of $3 million (behind <i><a href="/wiki/World_War_Z_(film)" title="World War Z (film)">World War Z</a></i><span style="padding-left:0.2em;">'</span>s gross of $3.4 million).<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114"><span>[</span>112<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115"><span>[</span>113<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In September 2013, <i><a href="/wiki/Forbes" title="Forbes">Forbes</a></i> highlighted <i>Pacific Rim</i> as "the rare English-language film in history to cross $400 million while barely crossing $100 million domestic".<sup id="cite_ref-A_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-A-9"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Pacific Rim</i> received generally positive reviews from critics. Review aggregation website <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a> gives a rating of 64 out of 100 based on reviews from 48 critics, which indicates "generally favorable" reviews.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116"><span>[</span>114<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Review_aggregator" title="Review aggregator">review aggregator</a> website <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> reported a 72% approval rating with an average rating of 6.7/10 based on 253 reviews. The website's consensus reads, "It may sport more style than substance, but <i>Pacific Rim</i> is a solid modern creature feature bolstered by fantastical imagery and an irresistible sense of fun."<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117"><span>[</span>115<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph" title="The Daily Telegraph">The Daily Telegraph</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s <a href="/wiki/Robbie_Collin" title="Robbie Collin">Robbie Collin</a> awarded the film five stars out of five, likening the experience of watching it to rediscovering a favorite childhood cartoon. He praised del Toro for investing his own affection for the genre and sense of artistry into the project in such a way that the viewer found themselves immersed in the film rather than watching from afar, noting the director had catered to younger and older audiences alike and expressed surprise that the film could rise above the sum of its parts.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118"><span>[</span>116<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Todd_McCarthy" title="Todd McCarthy">Todd McCarthy</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter" title="The Hollywood Reporter">The Hollywood Reporter</a></i> gave a positive review, describing the film as the sum of the potential every monster film had ever tried to fulfill.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119"><span>[</span>117<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lou_Lumenick" title="Lou Lumenick">Lou Lumenick</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Post" title="The New York Post" class="mw-redirect">The New York Post</a></i> gave the film four stars out of four, and said it had "no shortage of brains, brawn, eye candy, wit and even some poetry", praising the "clean and coherent" action sequences and the "terrific chemistry" between Hunnam and Kikuchi.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120"><span>[</span>118<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Drew_McWeeny" title="Drew McWeeny">Drew McWeeny</a> of <a href="/wiki/HitFix" title="HitFix">HitFix</a> highlighted other aspects of the film, paying particular attention to the production and art design. He also praised the cinematography for "perfectly capturing" the film, and described the score as "ridiculously cool".<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121"><span>[</span>119<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone" title="Rolling Stone">Rolling Stone</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s <a href="/wiki/Peter_Travers" title="Peter Travers">Peter Travers</a> called the film "the work of a humanist ready to banish cynicism for compassion", saying that del Toro "drives the action with a heartbeat".<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122"><span>[</span>120<span>]</span></a></sup> Keith Uhlich of <i><a href="/wiki/Time_Out_(magazine)" title="Time Out (magazine)">Time Out</a></i> called the film "pure, pleasurable comic-book absurdity", and noted that del Toro had lent the proceedings a "plausible humanity" lacking in most of summer 2013's destruction-heavy blockbusters. He said the Kaijus' civilian victims make a "palpably personal impression", deeming one scene with Mako Mori "as mythically moving as anything in the mecha anime, like <i><a href="/wiki/Neon_Genesis_Evangelion" title="Neon Genesis Evangelion">Neon Genesis Evangelion</a></i>, that the director emulates with expert aplomb."<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123"><span>[</span>121<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Village_Voice" title="The Village Voice">The Village Voice</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s Stephanie Zacharek called it "summer entertainment with a pulse", praising its "dumbly brilliant" action and freedom from elitism, but noted the story is predictable and suggested del Toro's time would be better spent on more visionary films.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124"><span>[</span>122<span>]</span></a></sup> Angela Watercutter of <i><a href="/wiki/Wired_(magazine)" title="Wired (magazine)">Wired</a></i> called it the "most awesome movie of the summer", a "fist-pumping, awe-inspiring ride", and opined that its focus on spectacle rather than characterization "simply does not matter" in the summer blockbuster context.<sup id="cite_ref-Wired-Watercutter_43-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wired-Watercutter-43"><span>[</span>41<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Richard_Roeper" title="Richard Roeper">Richard Roeper</a> gave the film a B, commenting that either the Jaegers or Kaijus "can take down any of the <a href="/wiki/Transformers_(film_series)" title="Transformers (film series)">Transformers</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125"><span>[</span>123<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Leonard_Maltin" title="Leonard Maltin">Leonard Maltin</a> gave the film two-and-a-half out of four stars, calling it "three-quarters of a really good movie that doesn't know when to quit."<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126"><span>[</span>124<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s Andrew Pulver was less enthusiastic, calling the film a mix of "wafer-thin psychodrama" and "plot-generator dialogue".<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127"><span>[</span>125<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s <a href="/wiki/Richard_Corliss" title="Richard Corliss">Richard Corliss</a> said the action was let down by "inert" drama, describing the film as "45 minutes of awesome encased in 90 minutes of yawnsome."<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128"><span>[</span>126<span>]</span></a></sup> Justin Chang of <i><a href="/wiki/Variety_(magazine)" title="Variety (magazine)">Variety</a></i> criticized it as loud and lacking the nuance and subtlety of del Toro's previous films.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129"><span>[</span>127<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_Yorker" title="The New Yorker">The New Yorker</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s Anthony Lane's verdict read as "It is possible to applaud <i>Pacific Rim</i> for the efficacy of its business model while deploring the tale that has been engendered  long, loud, dark, and very wet. You might as well watch the birth of an elephant."<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130"><span>[</span>128<span>]</span></a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Chronicle" title="San Francisco Chronicle">San Francisco Chronicle</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s Mike LaSalle reacted extremely negatively by stating "If this is the best we can do in terms of movies - if something like this can speak to the soul of audiences - maybe we should just turn over the cameras and the equipment to the alien dinosaurs and see what they come up with... Director Guillermo del Toro, who gave us <i><a href="/wiki/Pan%27s_Labyrinth" title="Pan's Labyrinth">Pan's Labyrinth</a></i> not too many years ago, used to be known as an artistic and discerning filmmaker, despite his affection for blockbuster action and grotesqueness. But too often he gets lost in his computer...Why go to the movies to look at somebody else's computer after looking at your own all week?... The actors can't make <i>Pacific Rim</i> any better. They can only relieve some of the pain."<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131"><span>[</span>129<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Slant_Magazine" title="Slant Magazine">Slant Magazine</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s Ed Gonzalez, who said the film lacked poignancy, compared it to a video game: "a stylish but programmatic ride toward an inevitable final boss battle".<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132"><span>[</span>130<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>The Wrap</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s <a href="/wiki/Alonso_Duralde" title="Alonso Duralde">Alonso Duralde</a> criticized the choice to set most battles at night or during the rain, feeling it detracted from the action, and said the comic relief actorsDay, Gorman, and Perlmanstole the film from the less interesting leads.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133"><span>[</span>131<span>]</span></a></sup> Jordan Hoffman of <a href="/wiki/RealNetworks" title="RealNetworks">Film.com</a> identified Hunnam as the weak link in the cast, calling him a "charisma black hole".<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134"><span>[</span>132<span>]</span></a></sup> Giles Hardie of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Sydney_Morning_Herald" title="The Sydney Morning Herald">The Sydney Morning Herald</a></i> was particularly critical of the film, awarding the action sequences "five <a href="/wiki/Intelligence_quotient" title="Intelligence quotient">IQ points</a> out of five" as he described the film as an hour and twenty minutes of fight sequences vaguely connected by ten minutes of story.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135"><span>[</span>133<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Director <a href="/wiki/Rian_Johnson" title="Rian Johnson">Rian Johnson</a> praised the film,<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136"><span>[</span>134<span>]</span></a></sup> as did Japanese game director <a href="/wiki/Hideo_Kojima" title="Hideo Kojima">Hideo Kojima</a>, who called it the "ultimate <a href="/wiki/Otaku" title="Otaku">otaku</a> film" and stated he "never imagined [he] would be fortunate enough to see a film like this in [his] life".<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137"><span>[</span>135<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Go_Nagai" title="Go Nagai">Go Nagai</a>, who pioneered the idea of mecha piloted from an interior cockpit, praised the film's fun and intense action, while game developer <a href="/wiki/Fumito_Ueda" title="Fumito Ueda">Fumito Ueda</a> said its battle scenes surpassed memories of the <a href="/wiki/Tokusatsu" title="Tokusatsu">tokusatsu</a> films he saw as an impressionable child.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138"><span>[</span>136<span>]</span></a></sup> Science fiction author <a href="/wiki/William_Gibson" title="William Gibson">William Gibson</a> called the film "A ravishing display of intelligent, often wonderfully witty visual design, every frame alive with coherent language, in the service of what is at heart a children's story... A baroque that doesn't curdle, that never fetishizes itself."<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139"><span>[</span>137<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The inclusion of only one female character of note resulted in <i>Pacific Rim</i> not passing the <a href="/wiki/Bechdel_test" title="Bechdel test">Bechdel test</a>. This became a topic of discussion in the media and on the Internet. Opinions were divided between those pointing to the film as an example of Hollywood's practice of ostracizing women, and those noting that the film did not <a href="/wiki/Sexual_objectification" title="Sexual objectification">sexually objectify</a> Mako Mori and gave her a narrative arc not revolving around a man.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Daily_Dot_18_August_2013_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Daily_Dot_18_August_2013-140"><span>[</span>138<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Metro_18_July_2013_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Metro_18_July_2013-141"><span>[</span>139<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Pacific Rim</i> became available for download on the <a href="/wiki/ITunes_Store" title="ITunes Store">iTunes Store</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vudu" title="Vudu">Vudu</a> on October 1, 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142"><span>[</span>140<span>]</span></a></sup> The film was released on DVD and <a href="/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc" title="Blu-ray Disc" class="mw-redirect">Blu-ray Disc</a> in the USA on October 15, 2013. It will be released on home video in the UK and other countries on November 25.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143"><span>[</span>141<span>]</span></a></sup> A collector's edition was also available on the same date.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144"><span>[</span>142<span>]</span></a></sup> To help promote the home media release, Bryan Harley and Roque Rodriguez of <a href="/wiki/Fresno,_California" title="Fresno, California">Fresno, California</a>, produced a "<a href="/wiki/Sweded" title="Sweded" class="mw-redirect">sweded</a>" version of the film's <i>Gipsy Danger</i> vs. Otachi battle scene, after del Toro was impressed by the duo's "sweded" trailer released on YouTube in March 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145"><span>[</span>143<span>]</span></a></sup> As of March 2014, Pacific Rim has sold 961,845 DVDs along with 1,427,692 Blu-ray discs in the United States for $10,045,530 and $24,634,992 in revenue respectively for a total of $37,079,122.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146"><span>[</span>144<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><span id="Sequel"></span><span id="Sequels"></span> In July 2012, del Toro discussed the possibility of making a <i>Pacific Rim</i> sequel. "We always leave ideas that were in the first draft as you go along. You know, either a set piece that was great but too expensive, an idea that was really bright, but it couldn't quite fit the structure... so we have a little stash of stuff we wanted to do that we didn't get to do. So if that's a possibility, A) I would be very happy to do a sequel, but B) a lot of these ideas, set pieces and all that, actually have in them a really good seed for a sequel."<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147"><span>[</span>145<span>]</span></a></sup> On December 4, Legendary Pictures announced that it had selected <i>Pacific Rim</i> co-writer Travis Beacham to write the sequel, along with del Toro, though there was no comment as to whether del Toro would return to direct the second film.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148"><span>[</span>146<span>]</span></a></sup> At <a href="/wiki/WonderCon" title="WonderCon">WonderCon</a> 2013, del Toro expressed enthusiasm for a potential crossover between <i>Pacific Rim</i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Godzilla_(2014_film)" title="Godzilla (2014 film)">Godzilla</a></i>another Legendary Pictures Kaiju filmbut stressed that no such plans were in place.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149"><span>[</span>147<span>]</span></a></sup> In July 2013, del Toro discussed the sequel, stating: "The main idea that we're bouncing off is the fact that Newt drifted with a Kaiju brain, and all Kaiju brains are connected. We say that. They are like a hive mentality. So, you know, draw your own conclusions."<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150"><span>[</span>148<span>]</span></a></sup> The director has also stated the sequel will feature "<i>Gipsy 2.0</i><span style="padding-left:.2em;">"</span>, as well as a "merging of Kaiju and Jaeger".<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151"><span>[</span>149<span>]</span></a></sup> In October 2013, del Toro revealed that he and Beacham would return to write the sequel, despite the film not yet being greenlit at the time.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152"><span>[</span>150<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In June 2014, when the sequel was still unconfirmed, del Toro stated that he had secretly been working on the script with <a href="/wiki/Zak_Penn" title="Zak Penn">Zak Penn</a> for several months and confirmed that Raleigh and Mako would return. Beacham initially developed the storyline with del Toro, but dropped out to work on the TV series <i><a href="/wiki/Hieroglyph_(TV_series)" title="Hieroglyph (TV series)">Hieroglyph</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153"><span>[</span>151<span>]</span></a></sup> Later in June 2014, del Toro confirmed that he would direct the sequel, and that it would be released by <a href="/wiki/Universal_Studios" title="Universal Studios">Universal Studios</a>, Legendary's new financing and distribution partner, on April 7, 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-SequelDate_154-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SequelDate-154"><span>[</span>152<span>]</span></a></sup> A non-episodic animated series connecting both films<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155"><span>[</span>153<span>]</span></a></sup> and a continuation of the graphic novel were also announced.<sup id="cite_ref-SequelDate_154-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SequelDate-154"><span>[</span>152<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156"><span>[</span>154<span>]</span></a></sup> On July 9, del Toro announced that the design production for <i>Pacific Rim 2</i> would start in August 2014, and that scouting for the location would take place in July 2015, with <a href="/wiki/Principal_photography" title="Principal photography">principal photography</a> commencing in November that year.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157"><span>[</span>155<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158"><span>[</span>156<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On October 16, 2014, del Toro talked about beginning production for <i>Pacific Rim 2</i> in late 2015, and also mentioned the possibility of a <i>Pacific Rim 3</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159"><span>[</span>157<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In November 2014, del Toro confirmed that the sequel will not be an immediate follow-up and will take place years after the first film, focusing on the aftermath of the Kaiju war and fate of the Jaeger technology. Del Toro additionally confirmed that the characters for <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Day" title="Charlie Day">Charlie Day</a> and <a href="/wiki/Burn_Gorman" title="Burn Gorman">Burn Gorman</a> will return, with the sequel set to feature "very different" types of Jaegers and Kaijus and that the film will be "quite a different adventure".<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160"><span>[</span>158<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In January 2015, Penn revealed that film's sequel will focus on the origins of Kaijus.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161"><span>[</span>159<span>]</span></a></sup> In April 2015, Legendary announced that the sequel film's release date has been moved to August 4, 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162"><span>[</span>160<span>]</span></a></sup> Filming is expected to begin in November 2015 at Toronto's Pinewood Studios with the working title <i>Maelstrom</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163"><span>[</span>161<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164"><span>[</span>162<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On September 16, 2015, the sequel was reported to have been "halted indefinitely" due to conflicts between Legendary and Universal Pictures<sup id="cite_ref-hr16_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hr16-10"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup> however, Del Toro later clarified that the sequel was simply "moved further" and the film will continue to proceed, stating, "We are still turning in a screenplay and a budget in three weeks. As far as Im concerned, its not gone. Were still on it."<sup id="cite_ref-ewdel_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ewdel-11"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> On September 29, 2015, Universal Pictures removed the sequel from their release calendar but confirmed that the sequel is still moving forward, stating that the extra time will be used to ensure the sequel is the "vanguard, fully-immersive experience that the franchise deserves."<sup id="cite_ref-var29_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-var29-12"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> del Toro expressed interest in casting <a href="/wiki/Maisie_Williams" title="Maisie Williams">Maisie Williams</a> in the film.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165"><span>[</span>163<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166"><span>[</span>164<span>]</span></a></sup> del Toro later tweeted that the budget and the script of the film are finished.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167"><span>[</span>165<span>]</span></a></sup> On January 7, 2016, it was announced by <a href="/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter" title="The Hollywood Reporter">The Hollywood Reporter</a> that the sequel is off the table.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168"><span>[</span>166<span>]</span></a></sup> But as of February 2016, media reports said that the sequel was back on track.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169"><span>[</span>167<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>The Bourne Supremacy</i> (film)</h1>
<p><i><b>The Bourne Supremacy</b></i> is a 2004 American-German <a href="/wiki/Action_film" title="Action film">action</a> <a href="/wiki/Spy_film" title="Spy film">spy</a> <a href="/wiki/Thriller_(genre)" title="Thriller (genre)">thriller</a> film starring <a href="/wiki/Robert_Ludlum" title="Robert Ludlum">Robert Ludlum</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Jason_Bourne" title="Jason Bourne">Jason Bourne</a> character. Though it takes the name of <a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Supremacy" title="The Bourne Supremacy">the second Bourne novel</a>, its plot is entirely different. The film was directed by <a href="/wiki/Paul_Greengrass" title="Paul Greengrass">Paul Greengrass</a> from a screenplay by <a href="/wiki/Tony_Gilroy" title="Tony Gilroy">Tony Gilroy</a>. <a href="/wiki/Universal_Studios" title="Universal Studios">Universal Pictures</a> released the film to theaters in the United States on July 23, 2004. It is the second in the <a href="/wiki/Bourne_(film_series)" title="Bourne (film series)"><i>Bourne</i> film series</a>. It is preceded by <i><a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Identity_(2002_film)" title="The Bourne Identity (2002 film)">The Bourne Identity</a></i> (2002) and followed by <i><a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Ultimatum_(film)" title="The Bourne Ultimatum (film)">The Bourne Ultimatum</a></i> (2007) and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Legacy_(film)" title="The Bourne Legacy (film)">The Bourne Legacy</a></i> (2012).</p>
<p><i>The Bourne Supremacy</i> continues the story of <a href="/wiki/Jason_Bourne" title="Jason Bourne">Jason Bourne</a>, a former <a href="/wiki/CIA" title="CIA" class="mw-redirect">CIA</a> <a href="/wiki/Assassin" title="Assassin" class="mw-redirect">assassin</a> suffering from <a href="/wiki/Psychogenic_amnesia" title="Psychogenic amnesia">psychogenic amnesia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> Bourne is portrayed by <a href="/wiki/Matt_Damon" title="Matt Damon">Matt Damon</a>. The film focuses on his attempt to learn more of his past as he is once more enveloped in a conspiracy involving the CIA and Operation Treadstone. The film also stars <a href="/wiki/Brian_Cox_(actor)" title="Brian Cox (actor)">Brian Cox</a> as Ward Abbott, <a href="/wiki/Joan_Allen" title="Joan Allen">Joan Allen</a> as Pamela Landy and <a href="/wiki/Julia_Stiles" title="Julia Stiles">Julia Stiles</a> as Nicky Parsons.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>Two years after the events of the first film, <a href="/wiki/Jason_Bourne" title="Jason Bourne">Jason Bourne</a> and Marie Kreutz are now in <a href="/wiki/Goa" title="Goa">Goa</a>, <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>. Still experiencing <a href="/wiki/Flashback_(psychology)" title="Flashback (psychology)">flashbacks</a> about his former life as a <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">CIA</a> assassin, he records them in a notebook.</p>
<p>In <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a>, CIA agents subordinate to <a href="/wiki/Deputy_Director_of_the_Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Deputy Director of the Central Intelligence Agency">Deputy Director</a> Pamela Landy are paying US$3 million for the "Neski files", documents on the theft of $20 million in <a href="/wiki/Black_budget" title="Black budget">allocation money</a> seven years prior. The deal is interrupted by Kirill, an agent for <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Federal_Security_Service" title="Federal Security Service">Federal Security Service</a> who works for Russian oil <a href="/wiki/Russian_oligarchs" title="Russian oligarchs" class="mw-redirect">oligarch</a> Yuri Gretkov. Kirill plants Bourne's fingerprint at the scene, interrupts the deal, kills everyone involved and steals the files and money. He travels to Goa to kill Bourne, but Bourne spots him and flees with Marie. Mistakenly believing Bourne is the driver, Kirill shoots at the driver seat and kills Marie. Their vehicle plunges into a river and Bourne leaves after unsuccessfully attempting to revive Marie.</p>
<p>Bourne travels to <a href="/wiki/Naples,_Italy" title="Naples, Italy" class="mw-redirect">Naples, Italy</a> with money and passports. After finding Bourne's fingerprint that Kirill planted, Landy asks Deputy Director Ward Abbott about Operation Treadstone, the defunct CIA program to which Bourne belonged. She tells Abbott that the CIA agent who stole the $20 million was named in the Neski files. Some years previously, Russian politician Vladimir Neski was about to identify the thief when he was supposedly murdered by his wife in a Berlin hotel. Landy believes that Bourne and Treadstone's late supervisor, Alexander Conklin, were somehow involved. She also believes that Bourne killed her two agents. Both Abbott and Landy go to Berlin to capture Bourne.</p>
<p>In Naples, Bourne allows himself to be identified by security. He subdues his CIA interrogator and <a href="/wiki/SIM_cloning" title="SIM cloning" class="mw-redirect">copies the SIM card</a> from his cell phone. From the subsequent phone call, he learns about Landy and his frame up. Bourne goes to <a href="/wiki/Munich" title="Munich">Munich</a> to visit Jarda, the only other remaining Treadstone operative. Jarda informs Bourne that Treadstone was shut down after Conklin's death, and tries to incapacitate him. Bourne kills Jarda and escapes before the CIA arrives. Bourne follows Landy and Abbott as they meet former Treadstone support technician Nicky Parsons to question her about Bourne. Believing that the CIA is hunting him again, Bourne calls Landy from a nearby roof and is told of the reason for his pursuit. He demands a meet-up with Nicky and indicates to Landy that he can see her in the office, shocking the entire CIA team.</p>
<p>Bourne kidnaps Nicky at the meet-up in <a href="/wiki/Alexanderplatz" title="Alexanderplatz">Alexanderplatz</a>, and learns from her that Abbott was the head of Treadstone, not Conklin. He remembers that he murdered Neski in Berlin, but Nicky knows nothing about it, so he lets her go. Bourne then visits the hotel where the killing took place and recalls more of his missionhe killed Neski on Conklin's orders, and when Neski's wife showed up, he shot her to make it look like a <a href="/wiki/Murder%E2%80%93suicide" title="Murdersuicide">murdersuicide</a>. When Danny Zorn (Conklin's assistant) suspects a conspiracy against Bourne, he confides in Abbott, who kills him. Bourne breaks into Abbott's hotel room and records a conversation between him and Gretkov that incriminates them in the theft of the 20 million. Abbott admits to Bourne that he stole the money, ordered Bourne to murder Neski, ordered Kirill to retrieve the files, and have Bourne framed and silenced in Goa. After Bourne leaves, Landy confronts Abbott about her suspicion and he commits suicide. Bourne sends the tape of the confession to Landy, vindicating himself.</p>
<p>Bourne goes to <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">Moscow</a> to find Irena Neski, the daughter of Vladimir Neski. Kirill, tasked once again by Gretkov with killing Bourne, finds and wounds him. Bourne flees on a stolen taxi and Kirill chases him. After a long high-speed chase also involving police vehicles, Bourne forces Kirill's vehicle into a concrete divider. Bourne walks away, leaving a <a href="/wiki/Mortal_wound" title="Mortal wound">mortally wounded</a> Kirill. Gretkov is subsequently arrested. Bourne locates Irena, confesses to murdering her parents and apologizes to her, then leaves.</p>
<p>There were no plans to make a sequel to <i>The Bourne Identity</i> (2002) when it was conceived. Matt Damon commented, "When <i>The Bourne Identity</i> came out I said, 'There is very little chance we will do a second film, just because nobody on the team who made the first wants to make another movie if it can't be as good as, or better than, the first one.<span style="padding-right:.2em;">'</span>" According to producer <a href="/wiki/Frank_Marshall_(film_producer)" title="Frank Marshall (film producer)" class="mw-redirect">Frank Marshall</a>, the plot point of Marie's kidnapping to force Bourne back into his assassin persona in the novel <i>The Bourne Supremacy</i> and Bourne's threat to come after the CIA if they came after him again in the previous film, were the inspiration for the plot. Marshall said that screenwriter <a href="/wiki/Tony_Gilroy" title="Tony Gilroy">Tony Gilroy</a> thought of an idea that Bourne "would go on what amounts to the samurai's journey, this journey of atonement." Producer Paul L. Sandberg felt that Gilroy's "veering away from the plot of the book" was necessary "because so much of the world has changed since the book's publication." The producers replaced director Doug Liman. This was mainly due to the difficulties Liman had with the studio when making the first film, and their unwillingness to work with him again. British director <a href="/wiki/Paul_Greengrass" title="Paul Greengrass">Paul Greengrass</a> was selected to direct the film after the producers saw <i><a href="/wiki/Bloody_Sunday_(TV_film)" title="Bloody Sunday (TV film)" class="mw-redirect">Bloody Sunday</a></i> (2002), Greengrass' depiction of the Bloody Sunday shootings in Northern Ireland, at Gilroy's suggestion. Producer Patrick Crowley liked Greengrass' "sense of the camera as participatory viewer", a visual style Crowley thought would work well for <i>The Bourne Supremacy</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> The film was shot in reverse order of its settings: some portions of the car chase and the film's ending were shot in Moscow, then most of the rest of the film was shot in and around Berlin, and the opening scenes in Goa were filmed last.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>According to a June 2008 article from <i>The Guardian</i>, "Two weeks before [the film's] release, [Greengrass] got together with its star, Matt Damon, came up with a new ending and phoned the producers saying the new idea was way better. And it would cost $200,000 and involve pulling Damon from the set of <i><a href="/wiki/Ocean%27s_Twelve" title="Ocean's Twelve">Ocean's 12</a></i> for a <a href="/wiki/Re-shoot" title="Re-shoot" class="mw-redirect">re-shoot</a>. Reluctantly the producers agreedthe movie <a href="/wiki/Test_screening" title="Test screening">tested</a> 10 points higher with the new ending".<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><span id="Box_office"></span> <i>The Bourne Supremacy</i> grossed $288,500,217.<sup id="cite_ref-BoxOfficeMojo_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoxOfficeMojo-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><span id="Critics"></span><span id="Critical_response"></span> The film received positive reviews from critics. Review aggregation website <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> gives the film a score of 81% based on reviews from 189 critics, with an average score of 7.2/10. The site's consensus reads "A well-made sequel that delivers the thrills."<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup> At <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>, which assigns a normalised rating out of 100 based on individual reviews, the film achieved an average of 73 based on 39 reviews, indicating generally favorable reviews.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><span id="Awards"></span><span id="Accolades"></span> At the 2005 <a href="/wiki/Taurus_World_Stunt_Awards" title="Taurus World Stunt Awards">Taurus World Stunt Awards</a>, veteran Russian <a href="/wiki/Stunt_coordinator" title="Stunt coordinator">stunt coordinator</a> <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Ivanov_(Stunt_Coordinator)" title="Viktor Ivanov (Stunt Coordinator)" class="mw-redirect">Viktor Ivanov</a> and Scottish stunt driver <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gillie_McKenzie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gillie McKenzie (page does not exist)">Gillie McKenzie</a> won the "Best Vehicle" award for their driving in the Moscow <a href="/wiki/Car_chase" title="Car chase">car chase</a> scene. Dan Bradley, the film's <a href="/wiki/Second_unit" title="Second unit">second unit director</a> won the overall award for stunt coordinator.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> The film ranks 454th on <a href="/wiki/Empire_magazine" title="Empire magazine" class="mw-redirect">Empire magazine</a>'s 2008 list of the 500 greatest movies of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>The Bourne Ultimatum</i> (film)</h1>
<p><i><b>The Bourne Ultimatum</b></i> is a 2007 American-German <a href="/wiki/Action_film" title="Action film">action</a> <a href="/wiki/Spy_film" title="Spy film">spy</a> <a href="/wiki/Thriller_(genre)" title="Thriller (genre)">thriller film</a> directed by <a href="/wiki/Paul_Greengrass" title="Paul Greengrass">Paul Greengrass</a> loosely based on the <a href="/wiki/Robert_Ludlum" title="Robert Ludlum">Robert Ludlum</a> <a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Ultimatum" title="The Bourne Ultimatum">novel of the same title</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> The screenplay was written by <a href="/wiki/Tony_Gilroy" title="Tony Gilroy">Tony Gilroy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scott_Z._Burns" title="Scott Z. Burns">Scott Z. Burns</a> and <a href="/wiki/George_Nolfi" title="George Nolfi">George Nolfi</a>. <i>The Bourne Ultimatum</i> is the third in the <a href="/wiki/Bourne_(film_series)" title="Bourne (film series)"><i>Bourne</i> film series</a>, being preceded by <i><a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Identity_(2002_film)" title="The Bourne Identity (2002 film)">The Bourne Identity</a></i> (2002) and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Supremacy_(film)" title="The Bourne Supremacy (film)">The Bourne Supremacy</a></i> (2004). The fourth film, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Legacy_(film)" title="The Bourne Legacy (film)">The Bourne Legacy</a></i>, was released in August 2012.</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Matt_Damon" title="Matt Damon">Matt Damon</a> reprises his role as Ludlum's signature character, former <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">CIA</a> <a href="/wiki/Assassin" title="Assassin" class="mw-redirect">assassin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Psychogenic_amnesia" title="Psychogenic amnesia">psychogenic amnesiac</a> <a href="/wiki/Jason_Bourne" title="Jason Bourne">Jason Bourne</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> In the film, he continues his search for information about his past before he was part of Operation Treadstone and becomes a target of a similar assassin program.</p>
<p><i>The Bourne Ultimatum</i> was produced by <a href="/wiki/Universal_Studios" title="Universal Studios">Universal Pictures</a> and was released on August 3, 2007, in North America, where it grossed $69.3 million in ticket sales in its first weekend of release, and was, at the time, Damon's highest-grossing film with him as the lead. The three films have been commercially successful and critically acclaimed and <i>The Bourne Ultimatum</i> won all three of its nominations at the <a href="/wiki/80th_Academy_Awards" title="80th Academy Awards">80th Academy Awards</a>: <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Film_Editing" title="Academy Award for Best Film Editing">Best Film Editing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Sound" title="Academy Award for Best Sound">Best Sound Mixing</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Sound_Editing" title="Academy Award for Best Sound Editing">Best Sound Editing</a>.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>Following his <a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Supremacy_(film)" title="The Bourne Supremacy (film)">pursuit by Kirill</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jason_Bourne" title="Jason Bourne">Jason Bourne</a> (<a href="/wiki/Matt_Damon" title="Matt Damon">Matt Damon</a>) evades <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">Moscow</a> police. Six weeks later, <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">CIA</a> <a href="/wiki/Deputy_Director_of_the_Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Deputy Director of the Central Intelligence Agency">Deputy Director</a> Pamela Landy (<a href="/wiki/Joan_Allen" title="Joan Allen">Joan Allen</a>) divulges the audiotaped confession of Ward Abbott, the late former head of Operation Treadstone, to <a href="/wiki/Director_of_the_Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Director of the Central Intelligence Agency">Director</a> Ezra Kramer (<a href="/wiki/Scott_Glenn" title="Scott Glenn">Scott Glenn</a>). Meanwhile, in <a href="/wiki/Turin" title="Turin">Turin</a>, journalist Simon Ross (<a href="/wiki/Paddy_Considine" title="Paddy Considine">Paddy Considine</a>) of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i> meets an informant to learn about Jason and Operation Blackbriar, the program succeeding Treadstone. The CIA tracks Ross as he returns to <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>, after his mention of "Blackbriar" during a cell-phone call to his editor is detected by the <a href="/wiki/ECHELON" title="ECHELON">ECHELON</a> system. Jason reappears in <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">Paris</a> to inform Martin Kreutz (<a href="/wiki/Daniel_Br%C3%BChl" title="Daniel Brhl">Daniel Brhl</a>), the step-brother of his girlfriend Marie Helena Kreutz (<a href="/wiki/Franka_Potente" title="Franka Potente">Franka Potente</a>) of her assassination in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>.</p>
<p>Jason reads Ross's articles and arranges a meeting with him at <a href="/wiki/London_Waterloo_station" title="London Waterloo station">London Waterloo station</a>. Jason realizes that the CIA is following Ross and helps him evade capture, but Ross ignores Jason's instructions, despite warning him and is quickly assassinated by Blackbriar assassin Paz (<a href="/wiki/Edgar_Ramirez" title="Edgar Ramirez" class="mw-redirect">Edgar Ramirez</a>), on orders of Deputy Director Noah Vosen (<a href="/wiki/David_Straithairn" title="David Straithairn" class="mw-redirect">David Straithairn</a>) right in front of the crowd of citizens. Vosen's team, reluctantly assisted by Landy, analyzes Ross's notes and realize Neal Daniels (<a href="/wiki/Colin_Stinton" title="Colin Stinton">Colin Stinton</a>), a CIA <a href="/wiki/Station_chief" title="Station chief">Station chief</a> involved with Treadstone and Blackbriar, was his source. Jason makes his way to Daniels's office in <a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">Madrid</a> but finds it empty. He incapacitates gunmen sent by Vosen and Landy. Nicolette "Nicky" Parsons (<a href="/wiki/Julia_Stiles" title="Julia Stiles">Julia Stiles</a>), a former Treadstone technician who shares a history with Jason, tells him that Daniels has fled to <a href="/wiki/Tangier" title="Tangier">Tangier</a> and aids his escape from an arriving CIA unit.</p>
<p>Nicky learns that Blackbriar "asset" Desh Bouksani (<a href="/wiki/Joey_Ansah" title="Joey Ansah">Joey Ansah</a>) has been tasked with killing Daniels. Vosen sees that Nicky accessed information about Daniels and sends Bouksani after Nicky and Jason as well, a decision with which Landy fiercely disagrees. Jason follows Bouksani to Daniels but fails to prevent Daniels's death by a planted bomb. However, Jason manages to kill Bouksani before he can kill Nicky. After sending Nicky into hiding, Jason examines the contents of Daniels's briefcase and finds the address of the deep-cover CIA bureau in <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>, where Vosen directs Blackbriar. Jason travels to New York.</p>
<p>Landy receives a phone call from Jason, which is intercepted by Vosen. Landy tells him that his real name is David Webb and mentions "4-15-71". Bourne tells Landy to "get some rest" because she "look[s] tired", tipping off his presence in New York. Vosen intercepts a text to Landy from Jason, apparently of a location to meet up and leaves his office with a <a href="/wiki/Extraordinary_rendition" title="Extraordinary rendition">rendition</a> team to capture him. Instead, Jason enters Vosen's office and takes classified Blackbriar documents. Realizing that he has been hoodwinked, Vosen sends Paz after Jason, resulting in Paz forcing Jason's car to crash into a concrete barrier. Jason holds Paz at gunpoint before sparing his life.</p>
<p>Jason arrives at a hospital at 415 East 71st Street, memories of which were triggered by the numbers that Landy had given him earlier. Outside, Jason meets Landy and gives her the Blackbriar files before going inside. Vosen figures out Landy's code and warns Dr. Albert Hirsch (<a href="/wiki/Albert_Finney" title="Albert Finney">Albert Finney</a>), who ran Treadstone's <a href="/wiki/Behavior_modification" title="Behavior modification">behavior modification</a> program, that Jason is coming. He follows Landy inside the building but is too late to stop her from faxing the Blackbriar documents out. Meanwhile, Jason encounters Hirsch on an upper floor and, with Hirsch's help, remembers that he volunteered for Treadstone. As Jason flees to the roof, he is confronted by Paz, who asks, "Why didn't you take the shot?" Jason repeats the dying words of <a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Identity_(2002_film)" title="The Bourne Identity (2002 film)">The Professor</a>: "Look at us. Look at what they make you give." Paz lowers his gun, but Vosen appears and shoots at Jason as he collapses into the <a href="/wiki/East_River" title="East River">East River</a>.</p>
<p>Some time later, Nicky watches a news broadcast about the exposure of Operation Blackbriar, the arrests of Hirsch and Vosen, a criminal investigation against Kramer, and the whereabouts of David Webb a.k.a. Jason Bourne. Upon hearing that his body has not been found after a three-day search of the river, Nicky smiles. Jason is shown having survived from his attempted killing and swims away.</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Tom_Gallop" title="Tom Gallop">Tom Gallop</a> reprises his role as Special Agent Tom Cronin, Pamela Landy's assistant. <a href="/wiki/Corey_Johnson_(actor)" title="Corey Johnson (actor)">Corey Johnson</a> plays Ray Wills, Vosen's deputy at Operation Blackbriar. <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Br%C3%BChl" title="Daniel Brhl">Daniel Brhl</a> plays Martin Kreutz, Marie's brother. <a href="/wiki/Joey_Ansah" title="Joey Ansah">Joey Ansah</a> plays Desh Bouksani, a Blackbriar asset tasked to kill Bourne in Tangier. <a href="/wiki/Colin_Stinton" title="Colin Stinton">Colin Stinton</a> plays Neil Daniels, CIA Station Chief in Madrid and a former member of Treadstone, who observed David Webb's initiation into the project and his transition to Jason Bourne. <a href="/wiki/Lucy_Liemann" title="Lucy Liemann">Lucy Liemann</a> plays Lucy, a Blackbriar technician. <a href="/wiki/Franka_Potente" title="Franka Potente">Franka Potente</a> has an uncredited appearance in a flashback as Marie Helena Kreutz, Bourne's murdered girlfriend.</p>
<p><i>The Bourne Ultimatum</i> was filmed at <a href="/wiki/Pinewood_Studios" title="Pinewood Studios">Pinewood Studios</a> near London and in multiple locations around the world, including Tangier, London, Paris, Madrid (as itself and double for Turin), Berlin (as double for Moscow), New York City including the <a href="/wiki/Springs_Mills_Building" title="Springs Mills Building">Springs Mills Building</a> (as the deep cover CIA offices), and other locations in the U.S.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Tony_Gilroy" title="Tony Gilroy">Tony Gilroy</a>, who had co-written the screenplays of the first two <i>Bourne</i> films, had intended <i>The Bourne Supremacy</i> to emphasise Bourne's repentance and atonement for his murders, but felt that the released film omitted this focus.<sup id="cite_ref-NY-Gilroy_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NY-Gilroy-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup> Gilroy was persuaded to write an initial draft of <i>The Bourne Ultimatum</i>, but did not participate further, and as of 2009 had not watched the finished film.<sup id="cite_ref-NY-Gilroy_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NY-Gilroy-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup> Gilroy's screenplay draft was subsequently criticized by Matt Damon.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Tom_Stoppard" title="Tom Stoppard">Tom Stoppard</a> wrote a draft of the screenplay, later saying "I don't think there's a single word of mine in the film."<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Paul Greengrass spoke about the characterization of Jason Bourne in <i>The Bourne Ultimatum</i> shortly before its release:</p>
<p>Bourne is a real man in a real world in pursuit of a mythic quest. What's wonderful is that it's an oppositional story. Is he a killer, or was he made to be a killer? There is an underlying feeling that Bourne is one of us, and he's running away from "them." He's trying to get answers, and he doesn't trust them. They're all bad, and the system's corrupted. To convey that with a sense of excitement in a very contemporary land-scape is great fun. [...] If you opened your door in New York or Paris or London or whatever, you've got to believe that whatever the story it is that Bourne's engaged in [, something] could be happening there. [...] What attracts me to Bourne's world is that it is a real world and I think I'm most comfortable there.<sup id="cite_ref-Dodds_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dodds-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In the <a href="/wiki/Audio_commentary" title="Audio commentary">audio commentary</a> for the <a href="/wiki/DVD" title="DVD">DVD</a> release of <i>The Bourne Ultimatum</i>, <a href="/wiki/Film_director" title="Film director">director</a> Paul Greengrass confirmed the following scenes were deliberate allusions to scenes from the previous installments of the Bourne film franchise.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup> They include:</p>
<p>As with the previous films in the trilogy, the score was composed by <a href="/wiki/John_Powell_(composer)" title="John Powell (composer)" class="mw-redirect">John Powell</a>. A new version of <a href="/wiki/Moby" title="Moby">Moby</a>'s "<a href="/wiki/Extreme_Ways" title="Extreme Ways">Extreme Ways</a>", entitled "Extreme Ways (Bourne's Ultimatum)", was recorded for the film's end credits.</p>
<p><i>The Bourne Ultimatum</i> was released nationwide on August 30, 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In addition to the stand-alone DVD release, there is a limited edition 'The Jason Bourne Collection' gift set, featuring all three films on DVD and a bonus disc with myriad bonus features such as deleted scenes and featurettes. The gift set features <a href="/wiki/Swiss_bank_account" title="Swiss bank account" class="mw-redirect">Swiss Bank</a> <a href="/wiki/Safe_deposit_box" title="Safe deposit box">safe deposit box</a> packaging including foreign currency and a Jason Bourne <a href="/wiki/Passport" title="Passport">passport</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film and special features on the HD DVD version are presented in 2:35:1 Widescreen high definition <a href="/wiki/1080i" title="1080i">1080i</a> and offer Dolby <a href="/wiki/TrueHD" title="TrueHD" class="mw-redirect">TrueHD</a> <a href="/wiki/5.1" title="5.1" class="mw-redirect">5.1</a> <a href="/wiki/Meridian_Lossless_Packing" title="Meridian Lossless Packing">lossless</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dolby_Digital_Plus" title="Dolby Digital Plus">Dolby Digital Plus</a> 5.1 audio options.<sup id="cite_ref-HDDVDFeatures_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HDDVDFeatures-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>The Bourne Ultimatum</i> earned $69,283,690 during its opening weekend at the box office,<sup id="cite_ref-BoxOfficeMojo_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoxOfficeMojo-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> which at the time held the record for the highest grossing August opening for seven years, later overtaken by <i><a href="/wiki/Guardians_of_the_Galaxy_(film)" title="Guardians of the Galaxy (film)">Guardians of the Galaxy</a></i> in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On the review aggregator <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a>, the film had an overall approval rating of 93% based on 257 reviews and an average score of 8/10, higher than both predecessors.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup> The site's consensus describes the film as "(...) an intelligent, finely tuned non-stop thrill ride. Another strong performance from Matt Damon and sharp camerawork from Paul Greengrass make this the finest installment of the Bourne trilogy,"<sup id="cite_ref-RottenTomatoes_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RottenTomatoes-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup> At <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>, which assigns a <a href="/wiki/Weighted_average" title="Weighted average" class="mw-redirect">weighted average</a> score out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, the film received an average score of 85 based on 38 reviews, again higher than the first two films.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup> At the end of its theatrical release, the film grossed at total of $227,471,070 in the U.S. and $215,353,068 in foreign markets for a worldwide total of $442,824,138, making it the highest grossing film in the series.<sup id="cite_ref-BoxOfficeMojo_3-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoxOfficeMojo-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Like its predecessor, <i>The Bourne Supremacy</i>, the film was criticized for its use of "<a href="/wiki/Shaky_camera" title="Shaky camera">shaky camera</a>" work, as <a href="/wiki/Richard_Corliss" title="Richard Corliss">Richard Corliss</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i> magazine, in an otherwise positive review, wondered "why, in the chat scenes, the camera is afflicted with <a href="/wiki/Parkinson%27s" title="Parkinson's" class="mw-redirect">Parkinson's</a>? The film frame trembles, obscures the speaker with the listener's shoulder, annoys viewers and distracts them from the content of the scene."<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In the British press, the inclusion of a fictional journalist from the real British paper <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i> and scenes set in the United Kingdom (particularly Waterloo railway station) were commented upon. In particular, that newspaper's reviewer joked that "dodging bullets from a CIA sniper... is the sort of thing which happens to us <i>Guardian</i> journalists all the time."<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30"><span>[</span>30<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film was also well received in the <a href="/wiki/Hacker_(computer_security)" title="Hacker (computer security)">hacker</a> subculture, as it showed actual real-world applications such as the <a href="/wiki/Bourne-again_shell" title="Bourne-again shell" class="mw-redirect">Bourne-again shell</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nmap" title="Nmap">Nmap</a>, unlike many other films featuring hacking scenes (such as <i><a href="/wiki/Hackers_(film)" title="Hackers (film)">Hackers</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film appeared on several critics' top ten lists of the best films of 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34"><span>[</span>34<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film won in all three categories in which it was nominated, giving it the second highest number of awards at the <a href="/wiki/80th_Academy_Awards" title="80th Academy Awards">80th Academy Awards</a> (behind <i><a href="/wiki/No_Country_for_Old_Men_(film)" title="No Country for Old Men (film)">No Country for Old Men</a></i>):<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In May 2007, prior to the release of <i>The Bourne Ultimatum</i>, <a href="/wiki/Matt_Damon" title="Matt Damon">Matt Damon</a> claimed that he would not be interested in returning for a fourth <i>Bourne</i> film, stating (of his participation in the <i>Bourne</i> franchise): "We have ridden that horse as far as we can."<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span>[</span>40<span>]</span></a></sup> Damon said in August 2007:</p>
