<p>I think in terms of another one, the story of this guy's search for his identity is over, because he's got all the answers, so there's no way we can trot out the same character, and so much of what makes him interesting is that internal struggle that was happening for him, am I a good guy, am I a bad guy, what is the secret behind my identity, what am I blocking out, why am I remembering these disturbing images? So all of that internal propulsive mechanism that drives the character is not there, so if there was to be another one then it would have to be a complete reconfiguration, you know, where do you go from there? For me I kind of feel like the story that we set out to tell is has now been told. I love the character, and if Paul Greengrass calls me in ten years and says, 'Now we can do it, because it's been ten years and I have a way to bring him back,' then there's a world in which I can go, 'Yeah, absolutely.' We could get the band back together if there was a great idea behind it, but in terms of now and this story, that partthe story's been told...<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span>[</span>41<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>However, on February 22, 2008, <i><a href="/wiki/Variety_(magazine)" title="Variety (magazine)">Variety</a></i> reported that a fourth film was indeed in the works, with both Damon and Greengrass on board.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span>[</span>42<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On October 16, 2008, it was announced that George Nolfi would write the script, with Frank Marshall producing, and Jeffrey Weiner and Henry Morrison executive producing. Matt Damon, <a href="/wiki/Julia_Stiles" title="Julia Stiles">Julia Stiles</a>, Joan Allen, and Paul Greengrass were also attached to the film.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span>[</span>43<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44"><span>[</span>44<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45"><span>[</span>45<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Joshua_Zetumer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Joshua Zetumer (page does not exist)">Joshua Zetumer</a> had been hired to write a parallel scripta draft which could be combined with another (Nolfi's, in this instance)by August 2009 since Nolfi would be directing <i><a href="/wiki/The_Adjustment_Bureau" title="The Adjustment Bureau">The Adjustment Bureau</a></i> that September.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46"><span>[</span>46<span>]</span></a></sup> That December, Greengrass announced that he had decided not to direct the fourth Bourne film, saying that "[his] decision to not return a third time as director is simply about feeling the call for a different challenge."<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span>[</span>47<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On February 1, 2010, Damon, speaking at the UK premiere of <i><a href="/wiki/Invictus_(film)" title="Invictus (film)">Invictus</a></i>, revealed that a follow-up to <i>The Bourne Ultimatum</i> was "at least five years away". Greengrass, also at the premiere, re-stated that he would not be part of any further <i>Bourne</i> films "unless the right script came along". However, Damon revealed that in the meantime there may be a <i>Bourne</i> "prequel of some kind, with another actor and another director".<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48"><span>[</span>48<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Matt_Damon" title="Matt Damon">Matt Damon</a> reconfirmed this on a March 10, 2010 appearance of <i><a href="/wiki/Today_(NBC_program)" title="Today (NBC program)" class="mw-redirect">Today</a></i> and that he would only be involved if Greengrass was directing.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49"><span>[</span>49<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In June 2010, it was announced that Tony Gilroy would be writing <i>The Bourne Legacy</i> and it would have a 2012 release date.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50"><span>[</span>50<span>]</span></a></sup> That October, Gilroy was announced as the director of <i>The Bourne Legacy</i>;<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span>[</span>51<span>]</span></a></sup> he confirmed that Damon would not return for this film and that there would be "a whole new hero":</p>
<p>This is not a <a href="/wiki/Reboot_(fiction)" title="Reboot (fiction)">reboot</a>, it's a whole new chapter. The easiest way to think of it is an expansion or a reveal. Jason Bourne will not be in this film, but he's very much alive. What happened in the first three films is the trigger for <i>The Bourne Legacy</i>, and everyone who got into them will be rewarded for paying attention. I'm building a legend and an environment and a wider conspiracy. We're going to show you the bigger picture, the bigger canvas... The world we're making enhances and advances and invites Jason Bourne's reappearance somewhere down the road."<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52"><span>[</span>52<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Legacy_(film)" title="The Bourne Legacy (film)">The Bourne Legacy</a></i> was released in the U.S. on August 10, 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53"><span>[</span>53<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>American Sniper</i></h1>
<p><i><b>American Sniper</b></i> is a 2014 American <a href="/wiki/Biographical_film" title="Biographical film">biographical</a> <a href="/wiki/War_film" title="War film">war film</a><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> directed by <a href="/wiki/Clint_Eastwood" title="Clint Eastwood">Clint Eastwood</a> and written by <a href="/wiki/Jason_Hall_(screenwriter)" title="Jason Hall (screenwriter)">Jason Hall</a>. It is loosely based on the memoir <i><a href="/wiki/American_Sniper_(book)" title="American Sniper (book)">American Sniper: The Autobiography of the Most Lethal Sniper in U.S. Military History</a></i> (2012) by <a href="/wiki/Chris_Kyle" title="Chris Kyle">Chris Kyle</a>, with Scott McEwen and Jim DeFelice. The film follows the life of Kyle, who became the deadliest <a href="/wiki/Sniper" title="Sniper">marksman</a> in U.S. military history with 255 kills from four tours in the <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">Iraq War</a>, 160 of which were officially confirmed by the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense" title="United States Department of Defense">Department of Defense</a>. While Kyle was celebrated for his military successes, his tours of duty took a heavy toll on his personal and family life. The film stars <a href="/wiki/Bradley_Cooper" title="Bradley Cooper">Bradley Cooper</a> as Kyle and <a href="/wiki/Sienna_Miller" title="Sienna Miller">Sienna Miller</a> as his wife <a href="/wiki/Taya_Kyle" title="Taya Kyle">Taya</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Luke_Grimes" title="Luke Grimes">Luke Grimes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jake_McDorman" title="Jake McDorman">Jake McDorman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cory_Hardrict" title="Cory Hardrict">Cory Hardrict</a>, Kevin Lacz, <a href="/wiki/Navid_Negahban" title="Navid Negahban">Navid Negahban</a> and <a href="/wiki/Keir_O%27Donnell" title="Keir O'Donnell">Keir O'Donnell</a> in supporting roles.</p>
<p>The world premiere was on November 11, 2014, at the <a href="/wiki/AFI_Fest" title="AFI Fest" class="mw-redirect">American Film Institute Festival</a>, followed by a limited theatrical release in the United States on December 25, 2014 and a wide release on January 16, 2015. The film became a major success, with a worldwide gross of over $547 million,<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> making it the highest-grossing film of 2014 in the United States ($350 million), the highest-grossing war film of all time unadjusted for inflation, and Eastwood's highest-grossing film to date.</p>
<p>The film received mostly positive reviews from critics, with the majority of praise directed towards Cooper's lead performance and Eastwood's direction, though it attracted some controversy over its portrayal of both the <a href="/wiki/2003_invasion_of_Iraq" title="2003 invasion of Iraq">War in Iraq</a> and of Chris Kyle. At the <a href="/wiki/87th_Academy_Awards" title="87th Academy Awards">87th Academy Awards</a>, <i>American Sniper</i> received six nominations, including <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Best Picture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Adapted_Screenplay" title="Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay">Best Adapted Screenplay</a> and <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Actor" title="Academy Award for Best Actor">Best Actor</a> for Cooper, ultimately winning one award for <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Sound_Editing" title="Academy Award for Best Sound Editing">Best Sound Editing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>Growing up in <a href="/wiki/Texas" title="Texas">Texas</a>, Chris Kyle is taught by his father how to shoot a rifle and hunt deer. Years later, Chris has become a ranch hand and <a href="/wiki/Rodeo" title="Rodeo">rodeo</a> cowboy, and returns home early, to find his girlfriend in bed with another man. After telling her to leave, he is mulling it over with his brother when he sees news coverage of the <a href="/wiki/1998_U.S._embassy_bombings" title="1998 U.S. embassy bombings" class="mw-redirect">1998 U.S. embassy bombings</a> and decides to enlist in the Navy. He qualifies for special training and becomes a <a href="/wiki/U.S._Navy_SEALs" title="U.S. Navy SEALs" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Navy SEALs</a> sniper.</p>
<p>Chris meets Taya Renae at a bar, and the two soon marry. He is sent to <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a> after the <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11, 2001 attacks</a>. His first kills are a woman and boy who attacked U.S. Marines with a Russian made <a href="/wiki/RKG-3_anti-tank_grenade" title="RKG-3 anti-tank grenade">RKG-3 anti-tank grenade</a>. Chris is visibly upset by the experience but later earns the nickname "Legend" for his many kills. Assigned to hunt for the <a href="/wiki/Al-Qaeda" title="Al-Qaeda">al-Qaeda</a> leader <a href="/wiki/Abu_Musab_al-Zarqawi" title="Abu Musab al-Zarqawi">Abu Musab al-Zarqawi</a>, Chris interrogates a family whose father offers to lead the SEALs to "The Butcher", al-Zarqawi's second-in-command. The plan goes awry when The Butcher captures the father and his son, killing them while Chris is pinned down by a sniper using a Romanian <a href="/wiki/PSL_(rifle)" title="PSL (rifle)">PSL</a> <a href="/wiki/Sniper_rifle" title="Sniper rifle">sniper rifle</a>. This sniper goes by the name Mustafa and is an <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympic Games</a> medalist from <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a>. Meanwhile, the insurgents issue a bounty on Chris.</p>
<p>Chris returns home to his wife and the birth of his son. He is distracted by memories of his war experiences and by Tayas concern for them as a couple; she wishes he would focus on his home and family.</p>
<p>Chris leaves for a second tour and is promoted to <a href="/wiki/Chief_Petty_Officer" title="Chief Petty Officer" class="mw-redirect">Chief Petty Officer</a>. Involved in a shootout with The Butcher, he helps in killing him. When he returns home to a newborn daughter, Chris becomes increasingly distant from his family. On Chris' third tour, Mustafa seriously injures a unit member, Ryan "Biggles" Job, and the unit is evacuated back to base. When they decide to return to the field and continue the mission, another SEAL, <a href="/wiki/Marc_Alan_Lee" title="Marc Alan Lee">Marc Lee</a>, is killed by gunfire.</p>
<p>Guilt compels Chris to undertake a fourth tour, and Taya tells him that she may not be there when he returns. Back in Iraq, Chris is assigned to kill Mustafa, who has been sniping U.S. Army combat engineers building a barricade. Chris' sniper team is placed on a rooftop inside enemy territory. Chris spots Mustafa and takes him out with a risky long distance shot at 2100 yards (1920 meters), but this exposes his team's position to numerous armed insurgents. In the midst of the firefight, and low on ammunition, Chris tearfully calls Taya and tells her he is ready to come home. A sandstorm provides cover for a chaotic escape in which Chris is injured and almost left behind.</p>
<p>After Chris gets back, on edge and unable to adjust fully to civilian life, he is asked by a <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Veterans_Affairs" title="United States Department of Veterans Affairs">Veterans Affairs</a> psychiatrist if he is haunted by all the things he did in war. When he replies that it is all the guys [he] couldn't save" that haunt him, the psychiatrist encourages him to help severely wounded veterans in the VA hospital. After that Chris gradually begins to adjust to home life.</p>
<p>Years later, on February 2, 2013, a happy Chris says goodbye to his wife and family as he leaves to spend time with a veteran at a shooting range. An on-screen subtitle reveals: "Chris Kyle was killed that day by a veteran he was trying to help", followed by archive footage of crowds standing along the highway for his funeral procession.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> More are shown attending his memorial service.</p>
<p>On May 24, 2012, it was announced that <a href="/wiki/Warner_Bros." title="Warner Bros.">Warner Bros.</a> (WB) had acquired the rights to the book with <a href="/wiki/Bradley_Cooper" title="Bradley Cooper">Bradley Cooper</a> set to produce and star in the screen adaptation.<sup id="cite_ref-hollywoodreporter1_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hollywoodreporter1-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> Cooper had thought of <a href="/wiki/Chris_Pratt" title="Chris Pratt">Chris Pratt</a> to play Kyle, but WB agreed to buy it only if Cooper would star.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup> On September 2012, <a href="/wiki/David_O._Russell" title="David O. Russell">David O. Russell</a> said he was interested in directing the film.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup> On February 2, 2013, <a href="/wiki/Chris_Kyle#Death" title="Chris Kyle">Chris Kyle was murdered</a>. On May 2, 2013, it was announced that <a href="/wiki/Steven_Spielberg" title="Steven Spielberg">Steven Spielberg</a> would direct.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup> Spielberg had read Kyle's book, though he desired to have a more psychological conflict present in the screenplay so an "enemy sniper" character can serve as the insurgent sharpshooter who was trying to track down and kill Kyle. Spielberg's ideas contributed to the development of a lengthy screenplay approaching 160 pages. Due to WB's budget constraints, Spielberg felt he could not bring his vision of the story to the screen.<sup id="cite_ref-makingof_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-makingof-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> On August 5, 2013, Spielberg dropped out of directing.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> On August 21, 2013, it was reported that <a href="/wiki/Clint_Eastwood" title="Clint Eastwood">Clint Eastwood</a> would instead direct the film.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On March 14, 2014, <a href="/wiki/Sienna_Miller" title="Sienna Miller">Sienna Miller</a> joined the cast.<sup id="cite_ref-slashfilm1_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-slashfilm1-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup> On March 16, 2014, <a href="/wiki/Kyle_Gallner" title="Kyle Gallner">Kyle Gallner</a> was cast,<sup id="cite_ref-thewrap1_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thewrap1-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup> as was <a href="/wiki/Cory_Hardrict" title="Cory Hardrict">Cory Hardrict</a> on March 18, 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-deadline2_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-deadline2-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup> On March 20, 2014, <a href="/wiki/Navid_Negahban" title="Navid Negahban">Navid Negahban</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eric_Close" title="Eric Close">Eric Close</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eric_Ladin" title="Eric Ladin">Eric Ladin</a>, Rey Gallegos, and <a href="/wiki/Jake_McDorman" title="Jake McDorman">Jake McDorman</a> also joined the cast,<sup id="cite_ref-thewrap2_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thewrap2-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-deadline3_16-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-deadline3-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup> as did <a href="/wiki/Luke_Grimes" title="Luke Grimes">Luke Grimes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sam_Jaeger" title="Sam Jaeger">Sam Jaeger</a> on March 25, 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-variety1_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-variety1-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-deadline1_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-deadline1-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup> Kevin Lacz, a former Navy SEAL, was also cast and served as a technical advisor.<sup id="cite_ref-fredericksburg1_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fredericksburg1-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup> Another former Navy SEAL, Joel Lambert, also joined the film, portraying a <a href="/wiki/Delta_Force" title="Delta Force">Delta</a> sniper.<sup id="cite_ref-Joel_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Joel-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup> On June 3, <a href="/wiki/Max_Charles" title="Max Charles">Max Charles</a> was added to the cast to portray Kyle's son, Colton Kyle.<sup id="cite_ref-Charles_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Charles-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Principal_photography" title="Principal photography">Principal photography</a> began on March 31, 2014 in <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup> it was also shot in <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup> On April 23, the <i><a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times" title="Los Angeles Times">Los Angeles Times</a></i> reported that ten days of filming set in an Afghan village was set to begin at the Blue Cloud Movie Ranch in the <a href="/wiki/Santa_Clarita,_California" title="Santa Clarita, California">Santa Clarita</a> area.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup> On May 7, shooting of the film was spotted around <a href="/wiki/El_Centro,_California" title="El Centro, California">El Centro</a>; a milk factory was used as the abandoned <a href="/wiki/Date_palm" title="Date palm">date</a> factory which insurgents close in on from all directions at the climax of the film.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30"><span>[</span>30<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup> Later on May 14, Cooper was spotted filming some scenes in <a href="/wiki/Culver_City,_California" title="Culver City, California">Culver City, California</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup> and then he followed by shooting scenes again in Los Angeles on May 16.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup> On May 30, Cooper and Miller were spotted during the filming of their characters' wedding scenes; they were filming aboard a yacht in <a href="/wiki/Marina_del_Rey,_California" title="Marina del Rey, California">Marina del Rey</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34"><span>[</span>34<span>]</span></a></sup> On June 3, Cooper was spotted in the uniform of a Navy SEAL marksman aiming during the filming of some scenes at a Los Angeles shooting range.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35"><span>[</span>35<span>]</span></a></sup> The pier and bar scenes were filmed in <a href="/wiki/Seal_Beach,_California" title="Seal Beach, California">Seal Beach, California</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bradley_Cooper" title="Bradley Cooper">Bradley Cooper</a> gained 40 pounds for his role.</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Cinematographer" title="Cinematographer">Cinematographer</a> <a href="/wiki/Tom_Stern_(cinematographer)" title="Tom Stern (cinematographer)">Tom Stern</a> shot the film with <a href="/wiki/Arri_Alexa#Alexa_XT" title="Arri Alexa">Arri Alexa XT</a> <a href="/wiki/Digital_cinematography" title="Digital cinematography">digital cameras</a> and <a href="/wiki/Panavision" title="Panavision">Panavision</a> <a href="/wiki/Anamorphic_format#Origination" title="Anamorphic format">C-, E- and G-Series</a> <a href="/wiki/Anamorphic_format" title="Anamorphic format">anamorphic lenses</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-PV_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PV-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup> The film is Eastwood's second to be shot digitally, after <i><a href="/wiki/Jersey_Boys_(film)" title="Jersey Boys (film)">Jersey Boys</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-AC_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AC-38"><span>[</span>38<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>There is no "Music by" credit on this film. Clint Eastwood, who has composed the <a href="/wiki/Film_score" title="Film score">scores</a> for most of his films since <i><a href="/wiki/Mystic_River_(film)" title="Mystic River (film)">Mystic River</a></i> (2003), is credited as the composer of "Taya's Theme". Joseph S. DeBeasi is credited as composer of additional music and as music editor.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39"><span>[</span>39<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span>[</span>40<span>]</span></a></sup> The film also features the song <a href="/wiki/Someone_Like_You_(Van_Morrison_song)" title="Someone Like You (Van Morrison song)" class="mw-redirect">"Someone Like You"</a> by <a href="/wiki/Van_Morrison" title="Van Morrison">Van Morrison</a>, which plays during the wedding scene, and "The Funeral" by <a href="/wiki/Ennio_Morricone" title="Ennio Morricone">Ennio Morricone</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span>[</span>41<span>]</span></a></sup> <span id="Controversies"></span></p>
<p><i>American Sniper</i> grossed $350.1 million in North America and $197 million in other territories for a worldwide total of $547.1 million, against a budget of around $58 million.<sup id="cite_ref-mojo_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mojo-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> Calculating in all expenses and revenues, <a href="/wiki/Deadline.com" title="Deadline.com">Deadline.com</a> estimated that the film made a profit of $243 million, making it the second most profitable film of 2014 only behind <a href="/wiki/Paramount_Pictures" title="Paramount Pictures">Paramount</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Transformers:_Age_of_Extinction" title="Transformers: Age of Extinction">Transformers: Age of Extinction</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span>[</span>42<span>]</span></a></sup> Worldwide, it is the highest-grossing war film of all time (breaking <i><a href="/wiki/Saving_Private_Ryan" title="Saving Private Ryan">Saving Private Ryan</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'s</span> record)<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span>[</span>43<span>]</span></a></sup> and Eastwood's highest-grossing film to date. It is the seventh R-rated film to gross over $500 million.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44"><span>[</span>44<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In North America, it is the highest-grossing film of 2014,<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45"><span>[</span>45<span>]</span></a></sup> the highest-grossing war film unadjusted for inflation and on an adjusted basis it stands second to <i><a href="/wiki/Saving_Private_Ryan" title="Saving Private Ryan">Saving Private Ryan</a></i> with $379 million.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46"><span>[</span>46<span>]</span></a></sup> It is the second highest-grossing R-rated film of all time (behind <i><a href="/wiki/The_Passion_of_the_Christ" title="The Passion of the Christ">The Passion of the Christ</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span>[</span>47<span>]</span></a></sup> It is Warner Bros' fourth highest-grossing film (behind <i><a href="/wiki/The_Dark_Knight_(film)" title="The Dark Knight (film)">The Dark Knight</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Dark_Knight_Rises" title="The Dark Knight Rises">The Dark Knight Rises</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows_%E2%80%93_Part_2" title="Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows  Part 2">Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows  Part 2</a></i>),<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48"><span>[</span>48<span>]</span></a></sup> and the eight highest-grossing <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Best Picture</a> nominee film (behind <i><a href="/wiki/Avatar_(2009_film)" title="Avatar (2009 film)">Avatar</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Titanic_(1997_film)" title="Titanic (1997 film)">Titanic</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Star_Wars_(film)" title="Star Wars (film)">Star Wars</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/E.T._the_Extra-Terrestrial" title="E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial">E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Toy_Story_3" title="Toy Story 3">Toy Story 3</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Return_of_the_King" title="The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King">The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Two_Towers" title="The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers">The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-SM_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SM-49"><span>[</span>49<span>]</span></a></sup> It became the seventh Warner Bros' film to earn over $300 million in the U.S. and Canada and the 50th film to reach the mark.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50"><span>[</span>50<span>]</span></a></sup> It earned as much as the combined earnings of all of the other <a href="/wiki/87th_Academy_Awards" title="87th Academy Awards">2014 Best Picture nominees</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-earn_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-earn-51"><span>[</span>51<span>]</span></a></sup> On March 8, 2015, it surpassed <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hunger_Games:_Mockingjay_%E2%80%93_Part_1" title="The Hunger Games: Mockingjay  Part 1">The Hunger Games: Mockingjay  Part 1</a></i> to become the highest-grossing film of 2014,<sup id="cite_ref-SM_49-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SM-49"><span>[</span>49<span>]</span></a></sup> making it the first R-rated film since <i><a href="/wiki/Saving_Private_Ryan" title="Saving Private Ryan">Saving Private Ryan</a></i> (1998) and the first non-franchise film since <i><a href="/wiki/Dr._Seuss%27_How_the_Grinch_Stole_Christmas_(film)" title="Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas (film)">The Grinch</a></i> (2000) to top the year-end rankings.<sup id="cite_ref-SM_49-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SM-49"><span>[</span>49<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>American Sniper</i> <a href="/wiki/Film_premiere" title="Film premiere" class="mw-redirect">premiered</a> at the <a href="/wiki/AFI_Fest" title="AFI Fest" class="mw-redirect">AFI Fest</a> on November 11, 2014, just after a screening of <i><a href="/wiki/Selma_(film)" title="Selma (film)">Selma</a></i> at <a href="/wiki/Grauman%27s_Egyptian_Theatre" title="Grauman's Egyptian Theatre">Grauman's Egyptian Theatre</a> in <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52"><span>[</span>52<span>]</span></a></sup> In North America, the film opened to a <a href="/wiki/Limited_release" title="Limited release">limited release</a> on December 25, 2014, playing at four theaters  two in New York, one in Los Angeles, and one in Dallas  and earned $610,000 in its opening weekend ($850,000 including Christmas Day) at an average of $152,500 per venue debuting at #22.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53"><span>[</span>53<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54"><span>[</span>54<span>]</span></a></sup> The following week the film earned $676,909 playing at the same number of locations at an average of $169,277 per theater, which is the second-biggest weekend average ever for a live-action movie (previously held by 2001's <i><a href="/wiki/Moulin_Rouge!" title="Moulin Rouge!">Moulin Rouge!</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55"><span>[</span>55<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>American Sniper</i> holds the record for the most entries in the top 20 Top Weekend Theater Averages with 3 entries. It earned a total of $3.4 million from limited release in three weekends.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span>[</span>56<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film began its wide debut across North American theaters on January 16, 2015 (Thursday night showings began at 7:00 pm).<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57"><span>[</span>57<span>]</span></a></sup> It set an all-time highest Thursday night opening record for an <a href="/wiki/Motion_Picture_Association_of_America_film_rating_system" title="Motion Picture Association of America film rating system">R-rated</a> drama with $5.3 million (previously held by <i>Lone Survivor</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58"><span>[</span>58<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span>[</span>59<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60"><span>[</span>60<span>]</span></a></sup> The film topped the box office on its opening day grossing $30.5 million (including Thursday previews) from 3,555 theaters setting January records for both biggest debut opening (previously held by <i><a href="/wiki/Cloverfield" title="Cloverfield">Cloverfield</a></i>) and single-day gross (previously held by <i><a href="/wiki/Avatar_(2009_film)" title="Avatar (2009 film)">Avatar</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61"><span>[</span>61<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62"><span>[</span>62<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63"><span>[</span>63<span>]</span></a></sup> In its traditional three-day opening the film earned $89.2 million which was double than expected and broke the record for the largest January opening (previously held by <i><a href="/wiki/Ride_Along" title="Ride Along" class="mw-redirect">Ride Along</a></i>)<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64"><span>[</span>64<span>]</span></a></sup> and the largest winter opening,<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65"><span>[</span>65<span>]</span></a></sup> which is also Eastwood's top opening as a director (breaking <i><a href="/wiki/Gran_Torino" title="Gran Torino">Gran Torino</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s opening).<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66"><span>[</span>66<span>]</span></a></sup> The three-day opening is also the biggest opening weekend for a drama film (previously held by <i><a href="/wiki/The_Passion_of_the_Christ" title="The Passion of the Christ">The Passion of the Christ</a></i>),<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67"><span>[</span>67<span>]</span></a></sup> the second biggest debut for a Best Picture Oscar nominee (behind <i><a href="/wiki/Toy_Story_3" title="Toy Story 3">Toy Story 3</a></i>),<sup id="cite_ref-Forbes_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Forbes-68"><span>[</span>68<span>]</span></a></sup> the second biggest debut for an R-rated film (behind <i><a href="/wiki/The_Matrix_Reloaded" title="The Matrix Reloaded">The Matrix Reloaded</a></i>), and the third biggest for a non-comic book, non-fantasy/sci-fi film (behind <i><a href="/wiki/Furious_7" title="Furious 7">Furious 7</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Fast_and_Furious_6" title="Fast and Furious 6" class="mw-redirect">Fast and Furious 6</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Forbes_68-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Forbes-68"><span>[</span>68<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69"><span>[</span>69<span>]</span></a></sup> It also set an <a href="/wiki/IMAX" title="IMAX">IMAX</a> January opening and single weekend record with $10.6 million (previously held by <i>Avatar</i> in its fourth weekend) and an R-rated IMAX debut record (previously held by <i><a href="/wiki/Prometheus_(2012_film)" title="Prometheus (2012 film)">Prometheus</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70"><span>[</span>70<span>]</span></a></sup> It earned $107.2 million during its four-day <a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr._Day" title="Martin Luther King Jr. Day" class="mw-redirect">Martin Luther King</a> weekend setting a record for the biggest R-rated four day gross.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71"><span>[</span>71<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In its <a href="/wiki/Second_weekend_in_box_office_performance" title="Second weekend in box office performance">second weekend</a>, the film expanded to 3,705 theaters making it the second widest launch for an R-rated movie (behind the film itself).<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72"><span>[</span>72<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73"><span>[</span>73<span>]</span></a></sup> It grossed an estimated $64.6 million in its second weekend, declining only by 28%and set the record for the second-best hold ever for a movie opening to more than $85 million and also set the record for the eight largest second-weekend gross.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74"><span>[</span>74<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75"><span>[</span>75<span>]</span></a></sup> In just 10 days of release, the film surpassed <i><a href="/wiki/Pearl_Harbor_(film)" title="Pearl Harbor (film)">Pearl Harbor</a></i> ($198.5 million) to became the second highest-grossing war film in North America.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76"><span>[</span>76<span>]</span></a></sup> By its second weekend, <a href="/wiki/Box_Office_Mojo" title="Box Office Mojo">Box Office Mojo</a> had already reported that the film was on poise to become the highest-grossing film of 2014 in North America, a record that was, at the time held by <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hunger_Games:_Mockingjay_%E2%80%93_Part_1" title="The Hunger Games: Mockingjay  Part 1">The Hunger Games: Mockingjay  Part 1</a></i> ($334 million), judging from its gradual decline and strong holdovers.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77"><span>[</span>77<span>]</span></a></sup> It became the highest-grossing IMAX film of January grossing $18.8 million from 333 IMAX theaters.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78"><span>[</span>78<span>]</span></a></sup> On Thursday, January 29, 2015  35 days after its initial release, the film surpassed <i><a href="/wiki/Saving_Private_Ryan" title="Saving Private Ryan">Saving Private Ryan</a></i> ($216.5 million) to become the highest-grossing war film in North America, unadjusted for inflation.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79"><span>[</span>79<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>By its third weekend of wide release, the film expanded to 3,885 theaters (180 additional theaters added), breaking its own record of being the widest R-rated film ever released.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80"><span>[</span>80<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81"><span>[</span>81<span>]</span></a></sup> The film topped the box office through its third weekend earning $30.66 million, which is the second highest <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl" title="Super Bowl">Super Bowl</a> weekend gross (behind <i><a href="/wiki/Hannah_Montana_and_Miley_Cyrus:_Best_of_Both_Worlds_Concert" title="Hannah Montana and Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert">Hannah Montana and Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82"><span>[</span>82<span>]</span></a></sup> After topping the box office for three consecutive weekends, the film was overtaken by <i><a href="/wiki/The_SpongeBob_Movie:_Sponge_Out_of_Water" title="The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water">The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water</a></i> in its fourth weekend.<sup id="cite_ref-earn_51-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-earn-51"><span>[</span>51<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film had the biggest debut weekend for a Clint Eastwood movie ever and went on to become the director's top grossing movie of all time in each of the countries it was released in.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83"><span>[</span>83<span>]</span></a></sup> It opened in Italy at number two with $7.1 million which is Eastwood's best opening of all time and Warner Bros' second biggest opening for a non-franchise U.S. film there<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84"><span>[</span>84<span>]</span></a></sup> and topped the box office the following weekend.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85"><span>[</span>85<span>]</span></a></sup> Its other largest openings occurred in France ($6.3 million),<sup id="cite_ref-ot_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ot-86"><span>[</span>86<span>]</span></a></sup> where it topped the box office for four consecutive weekends,<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87"><span>[</span>87<span>]</span></a></sup> Australia ($4.3 million, $4.6 million including previews),<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88"><span>[</span>88<span>]</span></a></sup> the UK, Ireland and Malta ($3.8 million),<sup id="cite_ref-UKK_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UKK-89"><span>[</span>89<span>]</span></a></sup> Spain ($3.2 million), Japan ($2.8 million), Mexico ($2.6 million), Brazil ($1.8 million), and South Korea ($1.2 million).<sup id="cite_ref-ot_86-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ot-86"><span>[</span>86<span>]</span></a></sup> In total earnings, its largest market outside of the U.S. are Italy ($23 million) and France ($22.8 million).<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90"><span>[</span>90<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>American Sniper</i> received positive reviews from critics. <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> gives the film a "Certified Fresh" rating of 72%, based on 243 reviews from critics, with an average rating of 6.9/10. The site's consensus states, "Powered by Clint Eastwood's sure-handed direction and a gripping central performance from Bradley Cooper, <i>American Sniper</i> delivers a tense, vivid tribute to its real-life subject."<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91"><span>[</span>91<span>]</span></a></sup> On <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>, the film has a score of 72 out of 100, based on reviews from 48 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92"><span>[</span>92<span>]</span></a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/CinemaScore" title="CinemaScore">CinemaScore</a> polls conducted during the opening weekend, cinema audiences gave <i>American Sniper</i> a rare grade of "A+" on an A+ to F scale.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93"><span>[</span>93<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Todd_McCarthy" title="Todd McCarthy">Todd McCarthy</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter" title="The Hollywood Reporter">The Hollywood Reporter</a></i> wrote: "A taut, vivid and sad account of the brief life of the most accomplished marksman in American military annals."<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94"><span>[</span>94<span>]</span></a></sup> Justin Chang of <i><a href="/wiki/Variety_(magazine)" title="Variety (magazine)">Variety</a></i> gave the film a positive review, saying "...an excellent performance from a bulked-up Bradley Cooper, this harrowing and intimate character study offers fairly blunt insights into the physical and psychological toll exacted on the front lines..."<sup id="cite_ref-variety-chang_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-variety-chang-95"><span>[</span>95<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/David_Denby" title="David Denby">David Denby</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_Yorker" title="The New Yorker">The New Yorker</a></i> gave the film a positive review, saying "Both a devastating war movie and a devastating antiwar movie, a subdued celebration of a warrior's skill and a sorrowful lament over his alienation and misery."<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96"><span>[</span>96<span>]</span></a></sup> Keith Phipps of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Dissolve" title="The Dissolve">The Dissolve</a></i> wrote that the film, while well-made missed a chance to explore the toll that such service exacts on soldiers.<sup id="cite_ref-Dissolve_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dissolve-97"><span>[</span>97<span>]</span></a></sup> Chris Nashawaty of <i><a href="/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly" title="Entertainment Weekly">Entertainment Weekly</a></i> gave the film a C+, saying "The film's just a repetition of context-free combat missions and one-dimensional targets."<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98"><span>[</span>98<span>]</span></a></sup> Elizabeth Weitzman of <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_Daily_News" title="New York Daily News" class="mw-redirect">New York Daily News</a></i> gave the film four out of five stars, saying "The best movies are ever-shifting, intelligent and open-hearted enough to expand alongside an audience. <i>American Sniper</i> [...] is built on this foundation of uncommon compassion."<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99"><span>[</span>99<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kyle_Smith" title="Kyle Smith">Kyle Smith</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_Post" title="New York Post">New York Post</a></i> gave the film four out of five stars, saying "After 40 years of Hollywood counterpropaganda telling us war is necessarily corrupting and malign, [...] <i>American Sniper</i> nobly presents the case for the other side."<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100"><span>[</span>100<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Peter_Travers" title="Peter Travers">Peter Travers</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone" title="Rolling Stone">Rolling Stone</a></i> gave the film three and a half stars out of four, saying "Bradley Cooper, as Navy SEAL Chris Kyle, and director Eastwood salute Kyle's patriotism best by not denying its toll. Their targets are clearly in sight, and their aim is true."<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101"><span>[</span>101<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ignatiy_Vishnevetsky" title="Ignatiy Vishnevetsky">Ignatiy Vishnevetsky</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_A.V._Club" title="The A.V. Club">The A.V. Club</a></i> gave the film a B, saying "<i>American Sniper</i> is imperfect and at times a little corny, but also ambivalent and complicated in ways that are uniquely Eastwoodian."<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102"><span>[</span>102<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/James_Berardinelli" title="James Berardinelli">James Berardinelli</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/ReelViews" title="ReelViews" class="mw-redirect">ReelViews</a></i> gave the film three and a half stars out of four, saying "<i>American Sniper</i> lifts director Clint Eastwood out of the doldrums that have plagued his last few films."<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103"><span>[</span>103<span>]</span></a></sup> Rafer Guzman of <i><a href="/wiki/Newsday" title="Newsday">Newsday</a></i> gave the film three out of four stars, saying "Cooper nails the role of an American killing machine in Clint Eastwood's clear-eyed look at the Iraq War."<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104"><span>[</span>104<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kenneth_Turan" title="Kenneth Turan">Kenneth Turan</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times" title="Los Angeles Times">Los Angeles Times</a></i> gave the film a positive review, saying "Eastwood's impeccably crafted action sequences so catch us up in the chaos of combat we are almost not aware that we're watching a film at all."<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105"><span>[</span>105<span>]</span></a></sup> Claudia Puig of <i><a href="/wiki/USA_Today" title="USA Today">USA Today</a></i> gave the film three out of four stars, saying "It's clearly Cooper's show. Substantially bulked up and affecting a believable Texas drawl, Cooper embodies Kyle's confidence, intensity and vulnerability."<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106"><span>[</span>106<span>]</span></a></sup> Joshua Rothkopf of <i><a href="/wiki/Time_Out_New_York" title="Time Out New York" class="mw-redirect">Time Out New York</a></i> gave the film four out of five stars, saying "Only Clint Eastwood could make a movie about an Iraq War veteran and infuse it with doubts, mission anxiety and ruination."<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107"><span>[</span>107<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Dean_Obeidallah" title="Dean Obeidallah">Dean Obeidallah</a> praised the film, saying "His focus was not on whom we were fighting, but the unbearably high price Americans pay for waging war regardless of its target. The film is a cautionary tale for Americans about why we must avoid war. It is not a celebration of waging it." <sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108"><span>[</span>108<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Matt_Taibbi" title="Matt Taibbi">Matt Taibbi</a>, of <i><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone_(magazine)" title="Rolling Stone (magazine)" class="mw-redirect">Rolling Stone</a></i>, wrote that the movie turned the complicated moral questions and mass-bloodshed of the Iraq war into a black and white fairy tale, without presenting the historical context.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109"><span>[</span>109<span>]</span></a></sup> John Wight of <i><a href="/wiki/Russia_Today" title="Russia Today" class="mw-redirect">Russia Today</a></i> stated that <i>American Sniper</i> depicted the Iraqi people as a dehumanized mass of savages, which the white man was in the process of civilizing.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110"><span>[</span>110<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Alex_von_Tunzelmann" title="Alex von Tunzelmann">Alex von Tunzelmann</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i> argued that the film presented a simplified black and white portrayal of the Iraq war, and that it features the distortion of facts into unreliable myths based upon previous legends.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111"><span>[</span>111<span>]</span></a></sup> David Masciotra of <i><a href="/wiki/Salon_(website)" title="Salon (website)">Salon</a></i> criticized the movie's focus on physical rather than moral courage as the ultimate manly virtue.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112"><span>[</span>112<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Cavalry_Scout" title="Cavalry Scout" class="mw-redirect">Cavalry Scout</a> Sniper Garett Reppenhagen stated that he did not view Iraqi civilians as savages, but as part of a friendly culture for which the movie has furthered ignorance, fear, and bigotry.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113"><span>[</span>113<span>]</span></a></sup> Cinematographer <a href="/wiki/Paul_Edwards_(cinematographer)" title="Paul Edwards (cinematographer)" class="mw-redirect">Paul Edwards</a> wrote in <i><a href="/wiki/CounterPunch" title="CounterPunch">CounterPunch</a></i> that he believes the film to be dangerous due to mutilating the classic <a href="/wiki/Hero%27s_journey" title="Hero's journey" class="mw-redirect">hero's journey</a> into a simplistic, brutal, and sadistic destruction of "evildoers".<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114"><span>[</span>114<span>]</span></a></sup> Inkoo Kang of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wrap" title="The Wrap" class="mw-redirect">The Wrap</a></i> gave the film a negative review, saying "Director Clint Eastwoods focus on Kyle is so tight that no other character, including wife Taya (Sienna Miller), comes through as a person, and the scope so narrow that the film engages only superficially with the many moral issues surrounding the Iraq War."<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115"><span>[</span>115<span>]</span></a></sup> Several other articles have also been critical of the movie.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116"><span>[</span>116<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117"><span>[</span>117<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118"><span>[</span>118<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119"><span>[</span>119<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120"><span>[</span>120<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Responding to critics, Eastwood said that <i>American Sniper</i> shows "what it (war) does to the people left behind",<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121"><span>[</span>121<span>]</span></a></sup> and that presenting "the fact of what [war] does to the family and the people who have to go back into civilian life like Chris Kyle did" is the "biggest <a href="/wiki/Anti-war_films" title="Anti-war films" class="mw-redirect">antiwar</a> statement any film" can make.<sup id="cite_ref-BiggestAntiwarStatement_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BiggestAntiwarStatement-122"><span>[</span>122<span>]</span></a></sup> He stated: "One of my favorite war movies that I've been involved with is <i><a href="/wiki/Letters_from_Iwo_Jima" title="Letters from Iwo Jima">Letters from Iwo Jima</a></i> and that was about family, about being taken away from life, being sent someplace. In World War II, everybody just sort of went home and got over it. Now there is some effort to help people through it."<sup id="cite_ref-BiggestAntiwarStatement_122-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BiggestAntiwarStatement-122"><span>[</span>122<span>]</span></a></sup> He also said: "I was a child growing up during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>. That was supposed to be the one to end all wars. And four years later, I was standing at the <a href="/wiki/Draft_board" title="Draft board">draft board</a> being drafted during the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean conflict</a>, and then after that there was Vietnam, and it goes on and on forever ... I just wonder ... does this ever stop? And no, it doesn't. So each time we get in these conflicts, it deserves a lot of thought before we go wading in or wading out. Going in or coming out. It needs a better thought process, I think."<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123"><span>[</span>123<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Bradley_Cooper" title="Bradley Cooper">Bradley Cooper</a> stated that much of the criticism ignores that the film was about widespread neglect of returning veterans, and that people who take issue with Kyle should redirect their attention to the leaders who put troops there in the first place. He said: "We looked at hopefully igniting attention about the lack of care that goes to vets. Discussion that has nothing to do with vets or what we did or did not do, every conversation in those terms is moving farther and farther from what our soldiers go through, and the fact that 22 veterans commit suicide each day." Cooper said that an increasing number of soldiers are returning from conflict psychologically damaged, only to be more or less discarded.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124"><span>[</span>124<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>First Lady <a href="/wiki/Michelle_Obama" title="Michelle Obama">Michelle Obama</a> and former <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">Republican Party</a> vice presidential nominee <a href="/wiki/Sarah_Palin" title="Sarah Palin">Sarah Palin</a> also spoke out in support of the movie.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125"><span>[</span>125<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126"><span>[</span>126<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127"><span>[</span>127<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Several major news sources commented on the accuracy of the film and how it differs from Chris Kyle's written accounts. The enemy sniper Mustafa is a major character in the film but receives only a small mention in the memoir; Kyle noted: "I never saw him, but other snipers later killed an Iraqi sniper we think was him."<sup id="cite_ref-guardian_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guardian-128"><span>[</span>128<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-slate_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-slate-129"><span>[</span>129<span>]</span></a></sup> According to the memoir, Kyle's 2100-yard shot was taken against an insurgent holding a rocket launcher, not Mustafa.<sup id="cite_ref-slate_129-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-slate-129"><span>[</span>129<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wapo_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wapo-130"><span>[</span>130<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">TIME</a></i> notes that according to screenwriter Jason Hall, Kyle said of Mustafa: "He shot my friend. I'm not going to put his name in my book." <sup id="cite_ref-time_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-time-131"><span>[</span>131<span>]</span></a></sup> The first combat scene in the film has Kyle killing a boy and mother who try to attack U.S. troops with a grenade; the boy was added for the film.<sup id="cite_ref-guardian_128-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guardian-128"><span>[</span>128<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-slate_129-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-slate-129"><span>[</span>129<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-time_131-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-time-131"><span>[</span>131<span>]</span></a></sup> The film depicts Ryan "Biggles" Job as dying shortly after he is shot by Mustafa; in reality, Job survived for several years after the incident but passed away after surgical complications from an operation on his face.<sup id="cite_ref-slate_129-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-slate-129"><span>[</span>129<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wapo_130-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wapo-130"><span>[</span>130<span>]</span></a></sup> The character "the Butcher" was created for the film,<sup id="cite_ref-guardian_128-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guardian-128"><span>[</span>128<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-time_131-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-time-131"><span>[</span>131<span>]</span></a></sup> although this character may have been based on the real-life <a href="/wiki/Abu_Deraa" title="Abu Deraa">Abu Deraa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-guardian_128-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guardian-128"><span>[</span>128<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>One aspect of the film that received negative comment was its use of a fake baby doll in one scene, which was so obviously artificial that it became a distraction.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132"><span>[</span>132<span>]</span></a></sup> In at least one media screening of the film, the audience laughed out loud at how artificial the doll appeared.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133"><span>[</span>133<span>]</span></a></sup> When discussing the film's prospects for winning an Academy Award, <a href="/wiki/Fandango_(ticket_service)" title="Fandango (ticket service)">Fandango</a> critic Dave Karger said, "The reason why <i>American Sniper</i> is not going to win is because of the plastic baby."<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134"><span>[</span>134<span>]</span></a></sup> In <i><a href="/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph" title="The Daily Telegraph">The Telegraph</a></i>, journalist Mark Harris said, "That plastic baby is going to be rationalised by Eastwood <i>auteur</i> cultists until the end of days."<sup id="cite_ref-TelegraphBaby_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TelegraphBaby-135"><span>[</span>135<span>]</span></a></sup> In response, screenwriter <a href="/wiki/Jason_Hall_(screenwriter)" title="Jason Hall (screenwriter)">Jason Hall</a> replied, "Hate to ruin the fun but real baby #1 showed up with a fever. Real baby #2 was no show. [Clint voice] 'Gimme the doll, kid.'"<sup id="cite_ref-TelegraphBaby_135-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TelegraphBaby-135"><span>[</span>135<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136"><span>[</span>136<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>American Sniper</i> was listed on many critics' top ten lists.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137"><span>[</span>137<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>American Sniper</i> was released on <a href="/wiki/Blu-ray" title="Blu-ray">Blu-ray</a> and <a href="/wiki/DVD" title="DVD">DVD</a> on May 19, 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138"><span>[</span>138<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Upon its first week of release on home media in the U.S., the film topped both the Nielsen VideoScan First Alert chart, which tracks overall disc sales, as well as the Blu-ray Disc sales chart in the week ending May 24, 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139"><span>[</span>139<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><span id="Awards"></span><span id="Accolades"></span></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Stand by Me</i> (film)</h1>
<p><i><b>Stand by Me</b></i> is a 1986 American <a href="/wiki/Coming_of_age" title="Coming of age">coming of age</a> <a href="/wiki/Drama" title="Drama">drama</a> <a href="/wiki/Adventure_film" title="Adventure film">adventure film</a> directed by <a href="/wiki/Rob_Reiner" title="Rob Reiner">Rob Reiner</a> and starring <a href="/wiki/Wil_Wheaton" title="Wil Wheaton">Wil Wheaton</a>, <a href="/wiki/River_Phoenix" title="River Phoenix">River Phoenix</a>, <a href="/wiki/Corey_Feldman" title="Corey Feldman">Corey Feldman</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jerry_O%27Connell" title="Jerry O'Connell">Jerry O'Connell</a>. Based on <a href="/wiki/Stephen_King" title="Stephen King">Stephen King</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Novella" title="Novella">novella</a> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Body_(novella)" title="The Body (novella)">The Body</a></i>, the title is derived from the <a href="/wiki/Ben_E._King" title="Ben E. King">Ben E. King</a> <a href="/wiki/Stand_by_Me_(song)" title="Stand by Me (song)">song of the same name</a>, which plays over the opening and end credits. The film tells the story of four boys in small town <a href="/wiki/Oregon" title="Oregon">Oregon</a> who go on a hike across the countryside to find the dead body of a missing child.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>Author Gordie Lachance (<a href="/wiki/Richard_Dreyfuss" title="Richard Dreyfuss">Richard Dreyfuss</a>) writes about a childhood incident when he and three buddies undertook a journey to find the body of a missing boy near the town of <a href="/wiki/Castle_Rock,_Tillamook_County,_Oregon" title="Castle Rock, Tillamook County, Oregon">Castle Rock, Oregon</a> over <a href="/wiki/Labor_Day" title="Labor Day">Labor Day</a> weekend in 1959.</p>
<p>Young Gordie (<a href="/wiki/Wil_Wheaton" title="Wil Wheaton">Wil Wheaton</a>) is a quiet, bookish boy with a penchant for writing and telling stories. His parents, grieving the recent death of Gordie's older brother, neglect their youngest son. To cope, Gordie spends much time with his friends: Chris Chambers (<a href="/wiki/River_Phoenix" title="River Phoenix">River Phoenix</a>), whose family are criminals and alcoholics; Teddy Duchamp (<a href="/wiki/Corey_Feldman" title="Corey Feldman">Corey Feldman</a>), an eccentric and physically scarred boy; and Vern Tessio (<a href="/wiki/Jerry_O%27Connell" title="Jerry O'Connell">Jerry O'Connell</a>), who is overweight and timid, often making him the target of <a href="/wiki/Bullying" title="Bullying">bullying</a>.</p>
<p>Vern overhears his older brother, Billy (<a href="/wiki/Casey_Siemaszko" title="Casey Siemaszko">Casey Siemaszko</a>), and Billy's friend, Charlie Hogan (<a href="/wiki/Gary_Riley" title="Gary Riley">Gary Riley</a>), discussing Ray Brower, a young boy who was reportedly struck and killed by a train. They want to search for the body, but Gordie, Chris, Teddy, and Vern decide to follow the local rail line and find Ray first, and making them local heroes. Chris steals his father's <a href="/wiki/M1911_pistol" title="M1911 pistol">M1911 pistol</a> and he, Gordie, Vern and Teddy head out on the train tracks.</p>
<p>The boys stop at a nearby junkyard to get a drink using a pump. The junkyard owner is notorious around Castle Rock for being the owner of a vicious and rarely seen dog, Chopper, famous for being able to attack certain parts of the human anatomy. They hang out in the junkyard for a while when the boys send Gordie out to buy food at a nearby general store. When Gordie returns, he sees the other three boys jumping the fence. Gordie walks over to join them, but Milo Pressman, the junkman, spots him and sends Chopper after him. Gordie runs and jumps the fence with Chopper in close pursuit, nearly escaping the dog. The boys discover that Chopper is a small dog and could easily be overthrown by an adolescent. They tease Chopper, but Pressman arrives and calls Teddy's father a loony, inciting Teddy's rage, causing the other boys to keep him from killing Pressman. Teddy is saddened by the insult, and Vern, Chris and Gordie help him.</p>
<p>At nighttime, Gordie tells the other boys a story of Davie "Lard-Ass" Hogan, an overweight boy who is constantly teased and bullied. He was born with a glandular condition which caused him to become obese and overweight, resulting in other kids and family members ridiculing and teasing him. Hogan enters a pie-eating contest, but his main goal was not to win, but to exact revenge. Prior to the contest, Hogan had consumed <a href="/wiki/Castor_oil" title="Castor oil">castor oil</a> and a raw <a href="/wiki/Egg" title="Egg">egg</a>, working as <a href="/wiki/Vomiting#Emetics" title="Vomiting">emetics</a>, planning to vomit on one of the other contestants, triggering a chain reaction of every witness vomiting, the majority being the bullies which had abused him earlier. After eating a fifth pie, he vomits, inducing the vomiting of all the crowd members, resulting in humiliation and embarrassment of his tormentors. The boys are impressed with the story, but are disappointed with the end.</p>
<p>After a series of misadventures and much self-revelation, the boys locate the body. However, local hoodlum "Ace" Merrill (<a href="/wiki/Kiefer_Sutherland" title="Kiefer Sutherland">Kiefer Sutherland</a>) and his gang including Chris' older brother "Eyeball" (<a href="/wiki/Bradley_Gregg" title="Bradley Gregg">Bradley Gregg</a>), Billy, Charlie, Vince Desjardins (Jason Oliver) and two other gang members arrive in cars to claim the body and the credit for finding it. When Chris refuses to step aside, Ace attempts to kill him until Gordie threatens to shoot Ace with the pistol from before. Outmatched, Ace and his gang retreat. The boys agree to report the body via an anonymous phone call to the authorities. They hike back to Castle Rock, bid each other farewell until they see each other in a few days at Junior High School.</p>
<p>The present-day Gordie writes that the friends drifted apart shortly thereafter. Vern married immediately after high school, had four children, and drives a forklift at a local lumber yard. Teddy tried enlisting in the army but was turned down due to his ear injury and impaired eyesight. He had served some time in prison and now does odd jobs around Castle Rock. Chris went on to college and became a lawyer. When attempting to break up a fight in a fast-food restaurant, he was fatally stabbed in the neck. Gordie finishes his memoir and takes his son and friend swimming.</p>
<p>In a 2011 interview with <a href="/wiki/National_Public_Radio" title="National Public Radio" class="mw-redirect">NPR</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wil_Wheaton" title="Wil Wheaton">Wheaton</a> attributed the film's success to the director's casting choices:</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Rob_Reiner" title="Rob Reiner">Rob Reiner</a> found four young boys who basically were the characters we played. I was awkward and nerdy and shy and uncomfortable in my own skin and really, really sensitive, and <a href="/wiki/River_Phoenix" title="River Phoenix">River</a> was cool and really smart and passionate and even at that age kind of like a father figure to some of us, <a href="/wiki/Jerry_O%27Connell" title="Jerry O'Connell">Jerry</a> was one of the funniest people I had ever seen in my life, either before or since, and <a href="/wiki/Corey_Feldman" title="Corey Feldman">Corey</a> was unbelievably angry and in an incredible amount of pain and had an absolutely terrible relationship with his parents.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Parts of the film were shot in <a href="/wiki/Brownsville,_Oregon" title="Brownsville, Oregon">Brownsville, Oregon</a>, which stood in for the fictional town of Castle Rock. Scenes that include the "mailbox baseball" game and the junkyard scenes were filmed in <a href="/wiki/Veneta,_Oregon" title="Veneta, Oregon">Veneta, Oregon</a>. The junkyard is still in operation. The campout/standing guard scene was filmed in <a href="/wiki/Eugene,_Oregon" title="Eugene, Oregon">Eugene, Oregon</a>, just a few miles from Veneta. The general store is in <a href="/wiki/Franklin,_Oregon" title="Franklin, Oregon">Franklin, Oregon</a>, just north of Veneta. Scenes along the railroad tracks were shot near <a href="/wiki/Cottage_Grove,_Oregon" title="Cottage Grove, Oregon">Cottage Grove, Oregon</a>, along the right-of-way of the <a href="/wiki/Oregon,_Pacific_and_Eastern_Railway" title="Oregon, Pacific and Eastern Railway">Oregon, Pacific and Eastern Railway</a>, now used as the <a href="/wiki/Row_River_National_Recreation_Trail" title="Row River National Recreation Trail">Row River National Recreation Trail</a>. The scene where the boys outrace a locomotive across a trestle was filmed at <a href="/wiki/Lake_Britton" title="Lake Britton">Lake Britton</a> on the <a href="/wiki/McCloud_Railway" title="McCloud Railway">McCloud River Railroad</a>, near <a href="/wiki/McArthur-Burney_Falls_Memorial_State_Park" title="McArthur-Burney Falls Memorial State Park" class="mw-redirect">McArthur-Burney Falls Memorial State Park</a>, California.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<p>In March 1986, <a href="/wiki/Columbia_Pictures" title="Columbia Pictures">Columbia Pictures</a>, concerned that the original title, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Body_(novella)" title="The Body (novella)">The Body</a></i>, was misleading, renamed the film <i>Stand by Me</i>. According to screenwriter Raynold Gideon, "...it sounded like either a sex film, a bodybuilding film or another Stephen King horror film. Rob came up with <i>Stand by Me</i>, and it ended up being the least unpopular option."<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film's musical score was composed by <a href="/wiki/Jack_Nitzsche" title="Jack Nitzsche">Jack Nitzsche</a>. On August 8, 1986, a soundtrack album was released containing many of the 1950s and early 1960s classic rock songs featured in the film.</p>
<p>The film was a box office success in North America. It opened in a <a href="/wiki/Limited_release" title="Limited release">limited release</a> on August 8, 1986 in 16 theaters and grossed $242,795, averaging $15,174 per theater. The film then had its wide opening in 745 theaters on August 22 and grossed $3,812,093, averaging $5,116 per theater and ranking #2. The film's widest release was 848 theaters, and it ended up earning $52,287,414 overall, well above its $8 million budget.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Review_aggregator" title="Review aggregator">review aggregator</a>, reports that 91% of 53 surveyed critics gave the film a positive rating; the average rating was 8/10.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>King, whose story this film was adapted from, was very impressed with the finished result<sup id="cite_ref-pez_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pez-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> and indicated, on the special features of the 25th anniversary Blu-ray set, that he considered the film to be the first successful translation to film of any of his works.</p>
<p><b>Nominations</b></p>
<p>In 1987, following the success of <i>Stand by Me</i>, Reiner co-founded a film and television production company and named it <a href="/wiki/Castle_Rock_Entertainment" title="Castle Rock Entertainment">Castle Rock Entertainment</a>, after the fictional setting of the story.<sup id="cite_ref-pez_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pez-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On July 24, 2010, a 25th Anniversary Celebration of the filming of <i>Stand by Me</i> was held in Brownsville, Oregon. The event included a cast and crew Q&amp;A session, an amateur blueberry pie eating contest, and an outdoor showing of the film.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The opening track to the seventh album of the Welsh post hardcore band, <a href="/wiki/Funeral_for_a_Friend" title="Funeral for a Friend">Funeral for a Friend</a>, titled <i><a href="/wiki/Chapter_and_Verse_(Funeral_for_a_Friend_album)" title="Chapter and Verse (Funeral for a Friend album)" class="mw-redirect">Chapter and Verse</a></i>, makes reference to <i>Stand by Me</i> with the line: "I've sat and watched <i>Stand by Me</i> for the millionth time, it's a lifeline. I wish I was Chris Chambers, but in truth I'm more like Vern".</p>
<p>In <a href="/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Red_and_Blue" title="Pokmon Red and Blue">Pokmon Red, Blue</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_Yellow" title="Pokmon Yellow">Yellow</a>, <i>Stand By Me</i> is the film playing on the television set at the character's house. The description reads, "There's a movie on TV. Four boys are walking down a railroad track."</p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>The Bourne Identity</i> (2002 film)</h1>
<p><i><b>The Bourne Identity</b></i> is a 2002 American-German<sup id="cite_ref-BFI_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BFI-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Action_film" title="Action film">action</a> <a href="/wiki/Spy_film" title="Spy film">spy</a> <a href="/wiki/Thriller_(genre)" title="Thriller (genre)">thriller</a> film adaptation of <a href="/wiki/Robert_Ludlum" title="Robert Ludlum">Robert Ludlum</a>'s <a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Identity_(novel)" title="The Bourne Identity (novel)">novel of the same name</a>. It stars <a href="/wiki/Matt_Damon" title="Matt Damon">Matt Damon</a> as <a href="/wiki/Jason_Bourne" title="Jason Bourne">Jason Bourne</a>, a man suffering from <a href="/wiki/Psychogenic_amnesia" title="Psychogenic amnesia">extreme memory loss</a> and attempting to discover his true identity amidst a clandestine conspiracy within the <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">Central Intelligence Agency</a> (CIA). The film also features <a href="/wiki/Franka_Potente" title="Franka Potente">Franka Potente</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chris_Cooper" title="Chris Cooper">Chris Cooper</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clive_Owen" title="Clive Owen">Clive Owen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Julia_Stiles" title="Julia Stiles">Julia Stiles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brian_Cox_(actor)" title="Brian Cox (actor)">Brian Cox</a> and <a href="/wiki/Adewale_Akinnuoye-Agbaje" title="Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje">Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje</a>. This, the first in the <a href="/wiki/Bourne_(film_series)" title="Bourne (film series)"><i>Bourne</i> film series</a>, is followed by <i><a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Supremacy_(film)" title="The Bourne Supremacy (film)">The Bourne Supremacy</a></i> (2004), <i><a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Ultimatum_(film)" title="The Bourne Ultimatum (film)">The Bourne Ultimatum</a></i> (2007), <i><a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Legacy_(film)" title="The Bourne Legacy (film)">The Bourne Legacy</a></i> (2012) and <i><a href="/wiki/Jason_Bourne_(film)" title="Jason Bourne (film)">Jason Bourne</a></i> (2016) scheduled for release in 2016.</p>
<p>The film was directed by <a href="/wiki/Doug_Liman" title="Doug Liman">Doug Liman</a> and adapted for the screen by <a href="/wiki/Tony_Gilroy" title="Tony Gilroy">Tony Gilroy</a> and <a href="/wiki/William_Blake_Herron" title="William Blake Herron">William Blake Herron</a>. Although Robert Ludlum died in 2001, he is credited as the film's producer alongside <a href="/wiki/Frank_Marshall_(film_producer)" title="Frank Marshall (film producer)" class="mw-redirect">Frank Marshall</a>. <a href="/wiki/Universal_Pictures" title="Universal Pictures" class="mw-redirect">Universal Pictures</a> released the film to theatres in the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> on June 14, 2002, and it received a positive critical and public reaction.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>In the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a>, Italian fishermen rescue an unconscious American man (<a href="/wiki/Matt_Damon" title="Matt Damon">Matt Damon</a>) floating adrift with two gunshot wounds in his back. They tend to his wounds, and when the man wakes, they find he suffers from dissociative amnesia: he has no idea of his identity but is aware of advanced combat skills and fluent in several languages. The skipper finds a tiny laser projector under the man's skin that, when activated, gives a number of a <a href="/wiki/Safe_deposit_box" title="Safe deposit box">safe deposit box</a> in <a href="/wiki/Z%C3%BCrich" title="Zrich">Zrich</a>. Upon landing, the man heads to investigate the box. Arriving at the bank, the man finds the box contains a large sum of money in various currencies, numerous passports and identity cards, and a handgun; the man takes everything but the gun, and leaves, opting to use the name on the American passport, <a href="/wiki/Jason_Bourne" title="Jason Bourne">Jason Bourne</a>.</p>
<p>A bank employee contacts Operation Treadstone, a <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">CIA</a> <a href="/wiki/Black_operation" title="Black operation">black operation</a> program after Bourne's departure. Treadstone's head, Alexander Conklin (<a href="/wiki/Chris_Cooper" title="Chris Cooper">Chris Cooper</a>), contacts CIA <a href="/wiki/Deputy_Director_of_the_Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Deputy Director of the Central Intelligence Agency">Deputy Director</a> Ward Abbott (<a href="/wiki/Brian_Cox_(actor)" title="Brian Cox (actor)">Brian Cox</a>) about the reappearance of Bourne. Abbott warns that Bourne, a CIA agent, had been assigned the silent assassination of exiled African dictator Nykwana Wombosi (<a href="/wiki/Adewale_Akinnuoye-Agbaje" title="Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje">Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje</a>), but the attempt failed, and Bourne must be dealt with. Conklin activates three agents to take down Bourne: Castel (Nicky Naude), Manheim (Russell Levy), and the Professor (<a href="/wiki/Clive_Owen" title="Clive Owen">Clive Owen</a>), while also issuing alerts to local police to capture Bourne.</p>
<p>Bourne attempts to get more information from the U.S. <a href="/wiki/Consul_(representative)#Consulates_and_embassies" title="Consul (representative)">consulate</a>, but he is discovered by guards. He evades capture, leaves the embassy, and gives a German woman, Marie Helena Kreutz (<a href="/wiki/Franka_Potente" title="Franka Potente">Franka Potente</a>), $20,000 to drive him to an address in Paris listed on his French driving license. At the address, an apartment, he hits redial on the phone and reaches a hotel. He inquires about the names on his passports there, learning that a "John Michael Kane" had been registered but died two weeks prior in a car accident. Castel ambushes them in the apartment, but Bourne gets the upper hand. Instead of allowing himself to be interrogated, Castel throws himself out a window to his death. Kreutz finds wanted posters of Bourne and herself, and agrees to continue to help Bourne.</p>
<p>Meanwhile, Wombosi approaches the police about the attempt on his life.
