Conklin, having anticipated this, had planted a body in the Paris morgue to appear as the assailant, but Wombosi is not fooled and threatens to report this. The Professor assassinates Wombosi on Conklin's orders. Bourne, posing as Kane, learns about Wombosi's yacht, and that the assailant had been shot twice during the escape; Bourne now considers himself to have been the assailant. He and Kreutz take refuge at the French countryside home of her ex-lover Eamon (<a href="/wiki/Tim_Dutton" title="Tim Dutton">Tim Dutton</a>) and his children. Conklin tracks their position and sends the Professor there, but Bourne mortally wounds him. The Professor reveals their shared connection to Treadstone before dying. He sends Kreutz, Eamon and his children away for their protection, and then contacts Conklin via the Professor's phone to arrange a meet. From a rooftop near the arranged location in Paris, Bourne sees Conklin has brought backup, so abandons the meeting but uses the opportunity to place a tracking device on his car, leading him to the Treadstone's <a href="/wiki/Safe_house" title="Safe house">safe house</a>.</p>
<p>Bourne breaks in and holds Conklin and logistics technician Nicolette "Nicky" Parsons (<a href="/wiki/Julia_Stiles" title="Julia Stiles">Julia Stiles</a>) at gunpoint. Bourne starts to recall fully the assassination attempt through successive <a href="/wiki/Flashback_(psychology)" title="Flashback (psychology)">flashbacks</a>. As Kane, and working under orders from Treadstone, Bourne infiltrated Wombosi's yacht but could not bring himself to kill Wombosi while Wombosi's children were present, and instead fled, being shot at during his escape. Bourne announces he is resigning from Treadstone and not to be followed. As agents descend on the safehouse, Bourne fights his way free. Meanwhile, when Conklin goes to leave the safe house, he is killed by Manheim, who was ordered to terminate Treadstone by Abbott.</p>
<p>Abbott reports on the dismissal of Treadstone before an oversight committee but announces a new project codenamed "Blackbriar". Some time later, Bourne finds Kreutz renting out <a href="/wiki/Scooter_(motorcycle)" title="Scooter (motorcycle)">scooters</a> to tourists on <a href="/wiki/Mykonos" title="Mykonos">Mykonos</a>, and the two reunite.</p>
<p>Director Doug Liman stated that he had been a fan of the source novel by Robert Ludlum since he read it in high school. Near the end of production of Liman's previous film <i><a href="/wiki/Swingers_(1996_film)" title="Swingers (1996 film)">Swingers</a></i>, Liman decided to develop a film adaptation of the novel. After more than two years of securing rights to the book from <a href="/wiki/Warner_Bros." title="Warner Bros.">Warner Bros.</a> and a further year of screenplay development with screenwriter Tony Gilroy, the film went through two years of production.<sup id="cite_ref-DVD.com_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DVD.com-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Universal_Studios" title="Universal Studios">Universal Pictures</a> acquired the film rights to Ludlum's books in the hopes of starting a new film franchise.<sup id="cite_ref-Pitt_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pitt-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/William_Blake_Herron" title="William Blake Herron">William Blake Herron</a> was brought in to rewrite the script in 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The inner workings of the fictitious Treadstone organization were inspired by Liman's father's job in the <a href="/wiki/National_Security_Agency" title="National Security Agency">National Security Agency</a> (NSA) under <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a>. Of particular inspiration were Liman's father's memoirs regarding his involvement in the investigation of the <a href="/wiki/Iran-Contra_affair" title="Iran-Contra affair" class="mw-redirect">Iran-Contra affair</a>. Many aspects of the Alexander Conklin character were based on his father's recollections of <a href="/wiki/Oliver_North" title="Oliver North">Oliver North</a>. Liman admitted that he jettisoned much of the content of the novel beyond the central premise, in order to modernize the material and to conform it to his own beliefs regarding United States foreign policy. However, Liman was careful not to cram his political views down "the audience's throat". There were initial concerns regarding the film's possible obsolescence and overall reception in the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11 attacks</a>, but these concerns proved groundless.<sup id="cite_ref-DVD.com_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DVD.com-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Liman approached a wide range of actors for the role of Bourne, including <a href="/wiki/Brad_Pitt" title="Brad Pitt">Brad Pitt</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Pitt_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pitt-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> who turned it down to star in <i><a href="/wiki/Spy_Game" title="Spy Game">Spy Game</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> as well as <a href="/wiki/Russell_Crowe" title="Russell Crowe">Russell Crowe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sylvester_Stallone" title="Sylvester Stallone">Sylvester Stallone</a>, before he eventually cast Damon. Liman found that Damon understood and appreciated that, though <i>The Bourne Identity</i> would have its share of action, the focus was primarily on character and plot.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> Damon, who had never played such a physically demanding role, insisted on performing many of the stunts himself. With stunt choreographer Nick Powell, he underwent three months of extensive training in stunt work, the use of weapons, <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">boxing</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Eskrima" title="Eskrima" class="mw-redirect">eskrima</a>. He eventually performed a significant number of the film's stunts himself, including hand-to-hand combat and climbing the safe house walls near the film's conclusion.<sup id="cite_ref-DVDDocumentary_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DVDDocumentary-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>From the onset of filming, difficulties with the studio slowed the film's development and caused a rift between the director and Universal Pictures, as executives were unhappy with the film's pacing, emphasis on small scale action sequences, and the general relationship between themselves and Liman, who was suspicious of direct studio involvement.<sup id="cite_ref-Wall_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wall-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> A number of reshoots and rewrites late in development and scheduling problems delayed the film from its original release target date of September 2001 to June 2002 and took it $8,000,000 over budget from the initial budget of $60 million; screenwriter <a href="/wiki/Tony_Gilroy" title="Tony Gilroy">Tony Gilroy</a> faxed elements of screenplay rewrites almost throughout the entire duration of filming.<sup id="cite_ref-Wall_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wall-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> A particular point of contention with regard to the original Gilroy script were the scenes set in the farmhouse near the film's conclusion. Liman and Matt Damon fought to keep the scenes in the film after they were excised in a third-act rewrite that was insisted upon by the studio. Liman and Damon argued that, though the scenes were low key, they were integral to the audience's understanding of the Bourne character and the film's central themes. The farmhouse sequence consequently went through many rewrites from its original incarnation before its inclusion in the final product.<sup id="cite_ref-Wall_9-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wall-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Other issues included the studio's desire to substitute <a href="/wiki/Montreal" title="Montreal">Montreal</a> or <a href="/wiki/Prague" title="Prague">Prague</a> for Paris in order to lower costs, Liman's insistence on the use of a French-speaking film crew, and poor test audience reactions to the film's Paris finale. The latter required a late return to location in order to shoot a new, more action-oriented conclusion to the Paris story arc.<sup id="cite_ref-Reel_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reel-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> In addition to Paris, filming took place in Prague, <a href="/wiki/Imperia_(city)" title="Imperia (city)" class="mw-redirect">Imperia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Rome</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mykonos" title="Mykonos">Mykonos</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Z%C3%BCrich" title="Zrich">Zrich</a>; several scenes set in Zrich were also filmed in Prague.<sup id="cite_ref-DVD.com_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DVD.com-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> Damon described the production as a struggle, citing the early conflicts that he and Liman had with the studio, but denied that it was an overtly difficult process, stating, "When I hear people saying that the production was a nightmare it's like, a 'nightmare'? Shooting's always hard, but we finished."<sup id="cite_ref-MH_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MH-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Liman's directorial method was often hands-on. Many times he operated the camera himself in order to create what he believed was a more intimate relationship between himself, the material, and the actors. He felt that this connection was lost if he simply observed the recording on a monitor. This was a mindset he developed from his background as a small-scale indie film maker.<sup id="cite_ref-DVDDocumentary_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DVDDocumentary-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The acclaimed car chase sequence was filmed primarily by the <a href="/wiki/Second_unit" title="Second unit">second unit</a> under <a href="/wiki/Second_unit_director" title="Second unit director" class="mw-redirect">director</a> <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Witt" title="Alexander Witt">Alexander Witt</a>. The unit shot in various locations around Paris while Liman was filming the main story arc elsewhere in the city. The finished footage was eventually edited together to create the illusion of a coherent journey. Liman confessed that "anyone who really knows Paris will find it illogical", since few of the locations used in the car chase actually connect to each other.<sup id="cite_ref-Reel_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reel-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> Liman took only a few of the shots himself; his most notable chase sequence shots were those of Matt Damon and Franka Potente while inside the car.<sup id="cite_ref-DVD.com_3-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DVD.com-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film received positive reviews. The film review collection website <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> gave the film an 83% approval rating based on 184 reviews collected, and an average score of 7/10. The site's consensus reads "Expertly blending genre formula with bursts of unexpected wit, <i>The Bourne Identity</i> is an action thriller that deliversand then some."<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Roger_Ebert" title="Roger Ebert">Roger Ebert</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Chicago_Sun-Times" title="Chicago Sun-Times">Chicago Sun-Times</a></i> gave the film three out of four stars and praised it for its ability to absorb the viewer in its "spycraft" and "Damon's ability to be focused and sincere" concluding that the film was "unnecessary, but not unskilled".<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup> Walter Chaw of <i>Film Freak Central</i> praised the film for its pacing and action sequences, describing them as "kinetic, fair, and intelligent, every payoff packaged with a moment's contemplation crucial to the creation of tension" and that the movie could be understood as a clever subversion of the genre.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup> Charles Taylor of <i>Salon.com</i> acclaimed the film as "entertaining, handsome and gripping, <i>The Bourne Identity</i> is something of an anomaly among big-budget summer blockbusters: a thriller with some brains and feeling behind it, more attuned to story and character than to spectacle" and praised Liman for giving the film a "tough mindedness" that never gives way into "cynicism or hopelessness".<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Ed Gonzalez of <a href="/wiki/Slant_Magazine" title="Slant Magazine">Slant Magazine</a> also noted Doug Liman's "restrained approach to the material" as well as Matt Damon and Franka Potente's strong chemistry, but ultimately concluded the film was "smart, but not smart enough".<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup> J. Hoberman of <i>The Village Voice</i> dismissed the film as "banal" and as a disappointment compared against Liman's previous indie releases;<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup> Owen Gleiberman also criticised the film for a "sullen roteness that all of Liman's supple handheld staging can't disguise".<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup> Aaron Beierle of <i>DVDTalk</i> gave particular praise to the film's central car chase which was described as an exciting action highlight and one of the best realized in the genre.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In its opening weekend, <i>The Bourne Identity</i> took in <a href="/wiki/United_States_dollar" title="United States dollar">US$</a>27,118,640 in 2,638 theaters. The film grossed $121,661,683 in North America and $92,263,424 elsewhere for a total worldwide gross of $214,034,224.<sup id="cite_ref-BoxOfficeMojo_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoxOfficeMojo-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><span id="Awards"></span><span id="Accolades"></span></p>
<p>On January 21, 2003, Universal Pictures released <i>The Bourne Identity</i> on <a href="/wiki/VHS" title="VHS">VHS</a>, and on <a href="/wiki/DVD" title="DVD">DVD</a> in the U.S. in two formats; a single-disc widescreen collector's edition and a single-disc full screen collector's edition. Both contain supplemental materials including a making-of documentary, a commentary from director Doug Liman and deleted scenes. On July 13, 2004, Universal released a new DVD of the film in the U.S. in preparation for the sequel's cinema debut.<sup id="cite_ref-DVDSequel_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DVDSequel-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup> This DVD also came in two formats: a single-disc widescreen extended edition and a single-disc full screen extended edition. Both contain supplemental materials including interviews with Matt Damon, deleted scenes, alternative opening and ending, a documentary on the consulate fight and information features on the CIA and amnesia. The alternate ending on the DVD has Bourne collapsing during the search for Marie, waking up with Abbott standing over him, and getting an offer to return to the CIA. Neither contain the commentary or <a href="/wiki/Digital_Theater_System" title="Digital Theater System" class="mw-redirect">DTS</a> tracks present in the collector's edition. The film was also released on <a href="/wiki/Universal_Media_Disc" title="Universal Media Disc">UMD</a> for <a href="/wiki/Sony_Computer_Entertainment" title="Sony Computer Entertainment">Sony</a>'s <a href="/wiki/PlayStation_Portable" title="PlayStation Portable">PlayStation Portable</a> on August 30, 2005 and on <a href="/wiki/HD_DVD" title="HD DVD">HD DVD</a> on July 24, 2007. With the release of <i>The Bourne Ultimatum</i> on DVD, a new DVD of <i>The Bourne Identity</i> was included in a boxed set with <i>The Bourne Supremacy</i> and <i>The Bourne Ultimatum</i>. The boxed set is entitled <i>The Jason Bourne Collection</i>. A trilogy set was released on <a href="/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc" title="Blu-ray Disc" class="mw-redirect">Blu-ray</a> in January 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-Blu-rayTrilogy_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Blu-rayTrilogy-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The score for the Bourne Identity was composed by <a href="/wiki/John_Powell_(composer)" title="John Powell (composer)" class="mw-redirect">John Powell</a>. Powell was bought in to replace Carter Burwell, who had composed and recorded a more traditional orchestral score for the film, which director Doug Liman rejected. Since a lot of the music budget had been spent recording the rejected score, Powell's score was initially conceived to be entirely non-orchestral, making extensive use of percussion, guitars, electronics and studio techniques. However, a string section was later overdubbed onto many of the cues to give them a 'cinematic' quality. <sup id="cite_ref-Empire_magazine_interview_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Empire_magazine_interview-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i><b>The Bourne Identity: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack</b></i> was released on June 11, 2002. In addition to the score, the film also featured the songs "<a href="/wiki/Extreme_Ways" title="Extreme Ways">Extreme Ways</a>" by <a href="/wiki/Moby" title="Moby">Moby</a> and "<a href="/wiki/Southern_Sun_/_Ready_Steady_Go" title="Southern Sun / Ready Steady Go" class="mw-redirect">Southern Sun / Ready Steady Go</a>" by <a href="/wiki/Paul_Oakenfold" title="Paul Oakenfold">Paul Oakenfold</a>. The soundtrack won an <a href="/wiki/ASCAP_Award" title="ASCAP Award" class="mw-redirect">ASCAP Award</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ACAPSound_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ACAPSound-25"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In 2008, <i>The Bourne Identity</i> was adapted into a video game, <i><a href="/wiki/Robert_Ludlum%27s_The_Bourne_Conspiracy" title="Robert Ludlum's The Bourne Conspiracy">The Bourne Conspiracy</a></i>. The game was available for the <a href="/wiki/PlayStation_3" title="PlayStation 3">PlayStation 3</a> and <a href="/wiki/Xbox_360" title="Xbox 360">Xbox 360</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-VideoGame_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VideoGame-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>The Bourne Identity</i> was followed by a 2004 <a href="/wiki/Sequel" title="Sequel">sequel</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Supremacy_(film)" title="The Bourne Supremacy (film)">The Bourne Supremacy</a></i>, which received a similar positive critical and public reception,<sup id="cite_ref-RT2_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RT2-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup> but received some criticism for its hand-held camerawork, which observers argued made action sequences difficult to see.<sup id="cite_ref-HRUltimatum_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HRUltimatum-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>The Bourne Supremacy</i> was directed by <a href="/wiki/Paul_Greengrass" title="Paul Greengrass">Paul Greengrass</a> with Matt Damon reprising his role as Jason Bourne. A third film, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Ultimatum_(film)" title="The Bourne Ultimatum (film)">The Bourne Ultimatum</a></i>, was released in 2007 and again was directed by Paul Greengrass and starred Matt Damon. Like <i>Supremacy</i>, <i>Ultimatum</i> received generally positive critical and public reception, but also received similar criticism for the camera-work.<sup id="cite_ref-TimeCrit_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TimeCrit-29"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The fourth film of the <i>Bourne</i> franchise, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Legacy_(film)" title="The Bourne Legacy (film)">The Bourne Legacy</a></i> was released in 2012. Neither Damon nor Greengrass were involved.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30"><span>[</span>30<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>The Bourne Legacy</i> (film)</h1>
<p><i><b>The Bourne Legacy</b></i> is a 2012 American <a href="/wiki/Action_film" title="Action film">action</a> <a href="/wiki/Spy_film" title="Spy film">spy</a> <a href="/wiki/Thriller_film" title="Thriller film" class="mw-redirect">thriller film</a> directed by <a href="/wiki/Tony_Gilroy" title="Tony Gilroy">Tony Gilroy</a>, and is the fourth installment in the <a href="/wiki/Bourne_(film_series)" title="Bourne (film series)">series of films</a> adapted from the novels originated by <a href="/wiki/Robert_Ludlum" title="Robert Ludlum">Robert Ludlum</a>, and continued by <a href="/wiki/Eric_Van_Lustbader" title="Eric Van Lustbader">Eric Van Lustbader</a>. Although this film has the same title as Van Lustbader's first <i>Bourne</i> novel, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Legacy_(novel)" title="The Bourne Legacy (novel)">The Bourne Legacy</a></i>, the actual screenplay bears little resemblance to the novel. Unlike the novel, which features Jason Bourne as the principal character, the film centers on <a href="/wiki/Black_operation" title="Black operation">Black ops</a> agent Aaron Cross (played by <a href="/wiki/Jeremy_Renner" title="Jeremy Renner">Jeremy Renner</a>), an original character. In addition to Renner, the film stars <a href="/wiki/Rachel_Weisz" title="Rachel Weisz">Rachel Weisz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Edward_Norton" title="Edward Norton">Edward Norton</a>.</p>
<p>The titular character Jason Bourne does not appear in <i>The Bourne Legacy</i>, because actor <a href="/wiki/Matt_Damon" title="Matt Damon">Matt Damon</a>, who played Bourne in the first three films, chose not to return for a fourth film. However, there are various pictures of Damon as Bourne shown throughout the film, and his name is mentioned several times. Tony Gilroy, co-screenwriter of the first three films, sought to continue the story of the film series without changing its key events, and parts of <i>The Bourne Legacy</i> take place at the same time as the previous film, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Ultimatum_(film)" title="The Bourne Ultimatum (film)">The Bourne Ultimatum</a></i> (2007).</p>
<p>In <i>The Bourne Legacy</i>, Aaron Cross is a member of a black ops program called Operation Outcome whose subjects are genetically enhanced. He must run for his life once former CIA Treadstone agent <a href="/wiki/Jason_Bourne" title="Jason Bourne">Jason Bourne</a>'s actions lead to the public exposure of Operation Treadstone and its successor Operation Blackbriar.</p>
<p>Filming was primarily in <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York</a>, with some scenes shot in the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a>. Released on <span class="nowrap">August 10</span>, 2012, the film received mixed reviews, with critics praising the story and Renner's performance, but expressed disappointment in Matt Damon's absence as well as the lack of shaky camera work that the <a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Supremacy_(film)" title="The Bourne Supremacy (film)">second</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Ultimatum_(film)" title="The Bourne Ultimatum (film)">third</a> films had utilized.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">CIA</a> lost track of Jason Bourne's whereabouts in <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">Moscow</a> six weeks ago. Meanwhile, Aaron Cross (<a href="/wiki/Jeremy_Renner" title="Jeremy Renner">Jeremy Renner</a>) is a government operative assigned to Operation Outcome, a <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense" title="United States Department of Defense">Department of Defense</a> <a href="/wiki/Black_operation" title="Black operation">black operation</a> program using experimental pills known as "chems" to enhance the physical and mental abilities of their users. Aaron is assigned to <a href="/wiki/Alaska" title="Alaska">Alaska</a> for a training exercise, where he must survive weather extremes and traverse rugged terrain in order to arrive at a remote cabin. The cabin is operated by an exiled Outcome operative, Number Three (<a href="/wiki/Oscar_Isaac" title="Oscar Isaac">Oscar Isaac</a>), who informs Aaron that he has broken the mission record by two days. <sup id="cite_ref-jeremyleerenner_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jeremyleerenner-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Reporter Simon Ross (<a href="/wiki/Paddy_Considine" title="Paddy Considine">Paddy Considine</a>) of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i>, who has been investigating the CIA programs Treadstone and Blackbriar, is assassinated at <a href="/wiki/London_Waterloo_station" title="London Waterloo station">London Waterloo station</a>. When the illegal adaptation of the programs is exposed by Bourne, the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation" title="Federal Bureau of Investigation">FBI</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Senate_Select_Committee_on_Intelligence" title="United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence">Senate Select Committee on Intelligence</a> investigate <a href="/wiki/Director_of_the_Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Director of the Central Intelligence Agency">CIA Director</a> Ezra Kramer (<a href="/wiki/Scott_Glenn" title="Scott Glenn">Scott Glenn</a>), <a href="/wiki/Deputy_Director_of_the_Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Deputy Director of the Central Intelligence Agency">Deputy Director</a> Pamela Landy (<a href="/wiki/Joan_Allen" title="Joan Allen">Joan Allen</a>), Blackbriar supervisor Noah Vosen (<a href="/wiki/David_Strathairn" title="David Strathairn">David Strathairn</a>) and Treadstone medical director Dr. Albert Hirsch (<a href="/wiki/Albert_Finney" title="Albert Finney">Albert Finney</a>).</p>
<p>After the mayhem in <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York</a> and Jason's escape, Kramer requests help from Mark Turso (<a href="/wiki/Stacy_Keach" title="Stacy Keach">Stacy Keach</a>), a retired <a href="/wiki/United_States_Navy" title="United States Navy">United States Navy</a> admiral, who runs the National Research Assay Group (NRAG). Turso informs Eric Byer (<a href="/wiki/Edward_Norton" title="Edward Norton">Edward Norton</a>), a retired <a href="/wiki/United_States_Air_Force" title="United States Air Force">Air Force</a> colonel overseeing NRAG's research and development of various clandestine enhancement programs used by the CIA and Defense. Byer discovers a potentially scandalous video on the Internet showing Hirsch socializing with Dr. Dan Hillcott (Neil Brooks Cunningham), Outcome's medical director. To prevent the Senate investigation from learning about Outcome, Byer orders that everyone associated with the program to be killed. He sees the sacrifice as acceptable in order to protect NRAG's next-generation "Beta programs", including the <a href="/wiki/Supersoldier" title="Supersoldier">supersoldier</a> program LARX.</p>
<p>Byer deploys a <a href="/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle" title="Unmanned aerial vehicle">drone</a> to eliminate Outcome agents Number Three and Five (Aaron) (<a href="/wiki/Jeremy_Renner" title="Jeremy Renner">Jeremy Renner</a>) in Alaska. Aaron hears the drone's approach and leaves moments before a missile destroys the cabin with Number Three inside. Aaron removes the <a href="/wiki/Radio-frequency_identification" title="Radio-frequency identification">radio-frequency identification</a> implanted in his thigh and force-feeds it to a wolf which is then blown up by a missile, tricking Byer into believing Aaron is dead. Hirsch dies of an apparent heart attack before he can testify before the Senate. Dr. Donald Foite (<a href="/wiki/%C5%BDeljko_Ivanek" title="eljko Ivanek">eljko Ivanek</a>), a researcher at a bio-genetics laboratory, shoots and kills all but one of his top-level colleagues employed by Outcome. When security guards enter his lab and repeatedly shoot him, despite him seemingly not feeling the pain of the gunshots, Foite turns his gun on himself, leaving <a href="/wiki/Biochemist" title="Biochemist">biochemist</a> Dr. Marta Shearing (<a href="/wiki/Rachel_Weisz" title="Rachel Weisz">Rachel Weisz</a>) as the sole survivor.<sup id="cite_ref-jeremyleerenner_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jeremyleerenner-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> Meanwhile, other Outcome agents are eliminated when their handlers give them poisoned chems.</p>
<p>When four elite "D-Track" assassins ambush Marta at her country house. After she states her belief of Foite being brainwashed into an emotionless killer numb of pain with blue chems, the assassins attempt to fake her suicide, but are killed by Aaron. He saves her life as she is his last link to the chems so that he can retain his enhanced capabilities and avoid withdrawal symptoms. Marta reveals that Cross has been <a href="/wiki/Genetic_engineering" title="Genetic engineering">genetically modified</a> by a tailored virus to retain the physical benefits without needing the green chems anymore. He still requires regular doses of blue chems to maintain his intelligence, but he is running out. Aaron confides to her that he is <a href="/wiki/Private_first_class" title="Private first class">Private First Class</a> Kenneth J. Kitsom (reportedly killed by a <a href="/wiki/Improvised_explosive_device" title="Improvised explosive device">roadside bomb</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">Iraq War</a>) and that his recruiter added 12 points to his IQ, enabling Aaron to meet the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army" title="United States Army">United States Army</a>'s requirements. Without his enhanced intelligence, Aaron believes they stand no chance of survival. Aaron and Marta travel to <a href="/wiki/Manila" title="Manila">Manila</a>, where the chems are manufactured, to try to infect him with another virus so he will not need the blue chems.<sup id="cite_ref-jeremyleerenner_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jeremyleerenner-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Aaron and Marta bluff their way into the chem factory. Marta injects Aaron with the live virus stems. Byer alerts the factory security, but Aaron and Marta evade capture. Byer orders LARX-03, a chemically-brainwashed super soldier, the brainwashing being similar to what happened to Foite, to track down and kill them. Aaron recovers from the flu-like symptoms but hallucinates about his Outcome training.<sup id="cite_ref-jeremyleerenner_3-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jeremyleerenner-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> When police surround their shelter while Marta is buying medicine, she warns Aaron by screaming. Aaron rescues her and steals a motorbike. They are pursued by both the police and LARX-03. After a lengthy chase through the streets and marketplaces of Manila to <a href="/wiki/Marikina" title="Marikina">Marikina</a>, they lose the police, but not the assassin. Both Aaron and LARX-03 are wounded by bullets, though LARX-03 is not entirely fazed by the wounds due to pain suppression induced his brainwashing. As Aaron begins losing consciousness, LARX-03 is killed when Marta causes his motorcycle to crash into a pillar. Marta persuades a Filipino boatman to help them escape by sea. They sail away, while back in New York, Vosen lies to the Senate that Landy committed treason by trying to sell Treadstone secrets to the press and by assisting Jason, the only reason why Blackbriar existed.<sup id="cite_ref-jeremyleerenner_3-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jeremyleerenner-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Universal Pictures originally intended <a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Ultimatum_(film)" title="The Bourne Ultimatum (film)"><i>The Bourne Ultimatum</i></a> to be the final film in the series, but development of another film was under way by October 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-MovesAhead_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MovesAhead-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/George_Nolfi" title="George Nolfi">George Nolfi</a>, who co-wrote <i>The Bourne Ultimatum</i>, was to write the script of a fourth film, not to be based on any of the novels by <a href="/wiki/Robert_Ludlum" title="Robert Ludlum">Robert Ludlum</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-MovesAhead_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MovesAhead-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> Joshua Zetumer had been hired to write a parallel scripta draft which could be combined with another (Nolfi's, in this instance)by August 2009 since Nolfi would be directing <i><a href="/wiki/The_Adjustment_Bureau" title="The Adjustment Bureau">The Adjustment Bureau</a></i> that September.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Matt_Damon" title="Matt Damon">Matt Damon</a> stated in November 2009 that no script had been approved and that he hoped that a film would begin shooting in mid-2011.<sup id="cite_ref-JonesTotalFilm_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JonesTotalFilm-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> The next month, he said that he would not do another Bourne film without Paul Greengrass, who announced in late November that he had decided not to return as director.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> In January 2010, Damon said that there would "probably be a prequel of some kind with another actor and another director before we do another one just because I think we're probably another five years away from doing it."<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>However, it was reported in June 2010 that <a href="/wiki/Tony_Gilroy" title="Tony Gilroy">Tony Gilroy</a>, who co-wrote each of the three previous <i>Bourne</i> films, would be writing a script with his brother, screenwriter <a href="/wiki/Dan_Gilroy" title="Dan Gilroy">Dan Gilroy</a>, for a fourth <i>Bourne</i> film to be released sometime in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> That October, Universal set the release date for <i>The Bourne Legacy</i> for August 10, 2012,<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> Tony Gilroy was confirmed as the director of the film, and it was also announced that the Jason Bourne character would not be in <i>The Bourne Legacy</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Gilroy said he did not get involved with the project "until the rules were that Matt [Damon] was gone, Matt and Paul [Greengrass] were gone, there was no Jason Bourne. That was the given when I had the first conversation about this. So it was very important to me, extremely important to me, that everything that had happened before be well preserved and be enhanced if possible by what we're doing now."<sup id="cite_ref-Weintraub_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Weintraub-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup> He also said, "you could never replace Matt [Damon] as Jason Bourne. This isn't <a href="/wiki/James_Bond_in_film" title="James Bond in film">James Bond</a>. You can't do a <a href="/wiki/Prequel" title="Prequel">prequel</a>. You can't do any of those kinds of things, because there was never any cynicism attached to the franchise, and that was the one thing they had to hang on to."<sup id="cite_ref-Hornaday_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hornaday-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Gilroy "never had any intention of ever coming back to this realm at allmuch less write it, much less direct it. Then I started a really casual conversation about what we could do in a post-Jason Bourne setting. I was only supposed to come in for two weeks, but the character we came up with, Aaron Cross, was so compelling."<sup id="cite_ref-Abrahams_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Abrahams-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup> After watching <i>The Bourne Ultimatum</i> again, Gilroy called his brother, screenwriter Dan Gilroy, and said, <span style="padding-right:.2em;">"</span>'The only thing you could do is sort of pull back the curtain and say there's a much bigger conspiracy.' So we had to deal with what happened in <i>Ultimatum</i> as the starting point of this film. <i>Ultimatum</i> plays in the shadows of <i>Legacy</i> for the first 15 minutesthey overlap."<sup id="cite_ref-Abrahams_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Abrahams-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In speaking about the film's storyline, Gilroy drew a distinction between the fictional programs in the <i>Bourne</i> film series:</p>
<p>On a practical level, the Treadstone program was about assassination. They're basically assassins. They live in the worldyou can see Clive Owen [in <i>The Bourne Identity</i>] as a piano teacher, they have coversbut they're essentially assassins. There was nothing that would be described as espionage, [they're] basically a kill squad. The Outcome program that Aaron [played by Jeremy Renner] is part of, [Oscar Isaac's character] is one of them too... The conceit is that [Edward Norton's character] is the mastermind of this entire franchise. We're stepping back a little bit in time here, he's been a developer, he's been at the nexus of the corporate military and intelligence communities. There's a very large corporate element, pharmaceutical corporate element...<sup id="cite_ref-Perez_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Perez-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Although a large part of the film was set in and around Washington, D.C., the real D.C. appears only in aerial <a href="/wiki/Establishing_shot" title="Establishing shot">establishing shots</a>. Most of the film was shot over 12 weeks at the <a href="/wiki/Kaufman_Astoria_Studios" title="Kaufman Astoria Studios">Kaufman Astoria Studios</a> in <a href="/wiki/Queens" title="Queens">Queens</a>, New York, including all interior D.C. scenes.<sup id="cite_ref-prodnotes_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-prodnotes-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup> The old house in <a href="/wiki/Hudson,_New_York" title="Hudson, New York">Hudson, New York</a> used as Shearing's house was unable to accommodate the weight of equipment and crew, so it was used only for exterior shots, and all interior scenes were filmed on a Kaufman Astoria soundstage.<sup id="cite_ref-prodnotes_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-prodnotes-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup> The scenes set in the "SteriPacific" factory in Manila were actually filmed in the <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_Times" title="New York Times" class="mw-redirect">New York Times</a></i> printing plant in Queens.<sup id="cite_ref-lugay_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lugay-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Several scenes were shot overseas, mostly in <a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">Manila</a><sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup> and in the paradise bay of <a href="/wiki/El_Nido,_Palawan" title="El Nido, Palawan">El Nido, Palawan</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> Several train scenes at <a href="/wiki/Garak_Market_Station" title="Garak Market Station">Garak Market Station</a> on <a href="/wiki/Seoul_Subway_Line_3" title="Seoul Subway Line 3">Seoul Subway Line 3</a> and nearby areas in Seocho-daero 77-Gil (1308 Seocho 4-dong), <a href="/wiki/Seocho-gu" title="Seocho-gu" class="mw-redirect">Seocho-gu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gangnam-gu" title="Gangnam-gu" class="mw-redirect">Gangnam-gu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seoul" title="Seoul">Seoul</a>, South Korea were used in some scenes.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kananaskis_Country" title="Kananaskis Country">Kananaskis Country</a> region of <a href="/wiki/Alberta" title="Alberta">Alberta</a>, Canada was used for the scenes set in <a href="/wiki/Alaska" title="Alaska">Alaska</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-prodnotes_16-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-prodnotes-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Gilroy said that "there are three deleted sceneswe just mixed them and color corrected them [...] but what I like about it is all three scenes happen in the movie. One of them's referred to and they're completely legitimate parts of our story, they absolutely happen in our film, we just didn't have time to show them to you so there's nothing off to the side. I think they'll be on the straight-up DVD."<sup id="cite_ref-Weintraub_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Weintraub-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film portrays Cross and Shearing as traveling nonstop from <a href="/wiki/New_York_JFK" title="New York JFK" class="mw-redirect">New York JFK</a> Airport to Manila on board an <a href="/wiki/American_Airlines" title="American Airlines">American Airlines</a> <a href="/wiki/Boeing_747-400" title="Boeing 747-400">Boeing 747-400</a>. That particular 747 model was introduced in 1989; American Airlines has never flown one;<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup> American Airlines has never served Manila as a destination; no commercial airline has ever flown from JFK to Manila nonstop with passenger service; the distance between the two cities exceeds the maximum range of any model 747.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup> In spite of these continuity lapses, American Airlines was actively involved in the production of the film in cooperation with <a href="/wiki/NBCUniversal" title="NBCUniversal">NBCUniversal</a>, and contributed its own airline employees and a <a href="/wiki/Boeing_777-200" title="Boeing 777-200" class="mw-redirect">Boeing 777-200</a> for the interior terminal and cabin shots at Terminal 8 of JFK International Airport.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> The airline also heavily co-marketed the film throughout post-production.</p>
<p><i>The Bourne Legacy</i> received mixed reviews from critics. On <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a>, the film holds a rating of 55%, based on 215 reviews, with an average rating of 5.8/10. The site's consensus reads, "It isn't quite as compelling as the earlier trilogy, but <i>The Bourne Legacy</i> proves the franchise has stories left to telland benefits from Jeremy Renner's magnetic work in the starring role."<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup> On <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>, the film received a score of 61 out of 100, based on 42 critics, which indicates "generally favorable reviews".<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Lisa_Schwarzbaum" title="Lisa Schwarzbaum">Lisa Schwarzbaum</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly" title="Entertainment Weekly">Entertainment Weekly</a></i> gave the film an A-, commenting that "Gilroy, who as a screenwriter has shaped the movie saga from the beginning, trades the wired rhythms established in the past two episodes by Paul Greengrass for something more realistic and closer to the ground. The change is refreshing. Jason Bourne's legacy is in good hands."<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Peter Debruge of <i><a href="/wiki/Variety_(magazine)" title="Variety (magazine)">Variety</a></i> wrote that "the combination of Robert Elswit's elegant widescreen lensing and the measured editing by Tony Gilroy's brother John may be easier to absorb than Greengrass' hyperkinetic docu-based style, but the pic's convoluted script ensures that auds will emerge no less overwhelmed."<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup> Michael Atkinson of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Village_Voice" title="The Village Voice">The Village Voice</a></i> also wrote a scathing review of the film, saying: "The <i>Bourne</i> films have more than just overstayed their welcome and outlasted the Ludlum booksthey've been <a href="/wiki/Van_Halen" title="Van Halen">Van Halenized</a>, with an abrupt change of frontman and a resulting dip in personality."<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Kenneth_Turan" title="Kenneth Turan">Kenneth Turan</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times" title="Los Angeles Times">Los Angeles Times</a></i> gave the film a positive review, called the film "an exemplary espionage thriller that has a strong sense of what it wants to accomplish and how best to get there." He especially commended Gilroy's work on the film: "Gilroy knows the underpinnings of this world inside out and appreciates how essential it is to maintain and extend the house style of cool and credible intelligence that marked the previous films."<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30"><span>[</span>30<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Todd_McCarthy" title="Todd McCarthy">Todd McCarthy</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter" title="The Hollywood Reporter">The Hollywood Reporter</a></i> commented on his review that "the series' legacy is lessened by this capable but uninspired fourth episode."<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In its opening weekend, <i>The Bourne Legacy</i> grossed approximately $38.7 million in the United States and Canada and debuted at #1 of the box office charts, surpassing Universal's expectation of $35 million. It grossed $46.6 million worldwide in its first weekend.<sup id="cite_ref-BOM_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BOM-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> The film sold approximately 400,000 more tickets on its opening weekend than the first film in the series, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Bourne_Identity_(2002_film)" title="The Bourne Identity (2002 film)">The Bourne Identity</a></i>. Studio research reported that audiences were evenly mixed among the sexes.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup> The film grossed $113,203,870 in North America and $162,940,880 in foreign countries, bringing the film's worldwide total to $276,144,750.<sup id="cite_ref-BOM_2-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BOM-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>The Bourne Legacy</i> had its Asian premiere at <a href="/wiki/Resorts_World_Manila" title="Resorts World Manila">Resorts World Manila</a> in <a href="/wiki/Pasay" title="Pasay">Pasay City</a>, <a href="/wiki/Metro_Manila" title="Metro Manila">Metro Manila</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a> on <span class="nowrap">August 5</span>, five days ahead of its opening date in North American theaters.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The soundtrack to <i>The Bourne Legacy</i> as composed by <a href="/wiki/James_Newton_Howard" title="James Newton Howard">James Newton Howard</a> was released digitally on <span class="nowrap">August 7, 2012</span> by <a href="/wiki/Var%C3%A8se_Sarabande_Records" title="Varse Sarabande Records" class="mw-redirect">Varse Sarabande Records</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34"><span>[</span>34<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35"><span>[</span>35<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>The Bourne Legacy</i> was released on DVD and Blu-ray on December 11, 2012 in the United States and Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Universal_Pictures" title="Universal Pictures" class="mw-redirect">Universal Pictures</a> stated at a media conference in <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles,_California" title="Los Angeles, California" class="mw-redirect">Los Angeles, California</a>, that they are likely to release more <i>Bourne</i> films, despite <i>The Bourne Legacy</i> being given mixed reviews by critics.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup> In a December 2012 interview, <a href="/wiki/Matt_Damon" title="Matt Damon">Matt Damon</a> revealed that he and <a href="/wiki/Paul_Greengrass" title="Paul Greengrass">Paul Greengrass</a> were interested in returning for the next film as Jason Bourne and the director respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span>[</span>38<span>]</span></a></sup> Damon is reported saying that although he had not seen <i>Legacy</i>, he intends to do so because not only is he curious to see it, but also because he has enjoyed <a href="/wiki/Jeremy_Renner" title="Jeremy Renner">Jeremy Renner</a> in everything he has seen him in. However, as of June 2014, executive producer Frank Marshall said that Matt Damon will not be returning to the big screen for the next <i>Bourne</i> film, contrary to earlier statements made by Damon and rumors surrounding his return to the franchise.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39"><span>[</span>39<span>]</span></a></sup> On February 21, 2013, it was confirmed that a <i>Bourne 5</i> was being planned.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span>[</span>40<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span>[</span>41<span>]</span></a></sup> On August 2, 2013, Universal hired <a href="/wiki/Tony_Gilroy" title="Tony Gilroy">Tony Gilroy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Peckham" title="Anthony Peckham">Anthony Peckham</a> to write the film's script with Renner returning as Cross.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span>[</span>42<span>]</span></a></sup> On November 8, 2013, <a href="/wiki/The_Fast_and_the_Furious_(film_series)" title="The Fast and the Furious (film series)" class="mw-redirect"><i>The Fast and the Furious</i> film series</a> director <a href="/wiki/Justin_Lin" title="Justin Lin">Justin Lin</a> was announced to direct the film.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span>[</span>43<span>]</span></a></sup> On December 2, 2013, it was announced that Renner will return as Cross, Lin will both direct and produce from his production company <a href="/wiki/Bruno_Wu#Professional_Life" title="Bruno Wu">Perfect Storm Entertainment</a> and the studio announced an August 14, 2015 release date.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44"><span>[</span>44<span>]</span></a></sup> On May 9, 2014, Andrew Baldwin was brought in to re-write the film.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45"><span>[</span>45<span>]</span></a></sup> On June 18, 2014, the studio pushed back the film from August 14, 2015, to July 15, 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46"><span>[</span>46<span>]</span></a></sup> In November 2014, Damon confirmed that he and Greengrass will return.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span>[</span>47<span>]</span></a></sup> On January 6, 2015, the studio pushed back the release date to July 29, 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48"><span>[</span>48<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>In Your Eyes</i> (2014 film)</h1>
<p><i><b>In Your Eyes</b></i> is a 2014 American <a href="/wiki/Paranormal_romance" title="Paranormal romance">paranormal romance</a> film directed by Brin Hill and written by <a href="/wiki/Joss_Whedon" title="Joss Whedon">Joss Whedon</a>, starring <a href="/wiki/Zoe_Kazan" title="Zoe Kazan">Zoe Kazan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michael_Stahl-David" title="Michael Stahl-David">Michael Stahl-David</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nikki_Reed" title="Nikki Reed">Nikki Reed</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steve_Harris_(actor)" title="Steve Harris (actor)">Steve Harris</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mark_Feuerstein" title="Mark Feuerstein">Mark Feuerstein</a>. It is the second feature by <a href="/wiki/Bellwether_Pictures" title="Bellwether Pictures">Bellwether Pictures</a>. <i>In Your Eyes</i>, set in <a href="/wiki/New_Mexico" title="New Mexico">New Mexico</a> and <a href="/wiki/New_Hampshire" title="New Hampshire">New Hampshire</a>, follows Dylan and Rebecca. They live on opposite sides of the country, but are able to sense what the other is feeling - despite being strangers.</p>
<p>The film had its world premiere at the 2014 <a href="/wiki/Tribeca_Film_Festival" title="Tribeca Film Festival">Tribeca Film Festival</a> on April 20. Immediately afterwards, it was <a href="/wiki/Simultaneous_release" title="Simultaneous release">self-distributed</a> online instead of taking on theatrical distribution.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>The film opens with a young Rebecca Porter about to go sledding in New Hampshire, while across the country in New Mexico, a young Dylan Kershaw is at school with a group of his friends. Suddenly, without even knowing what is happening or why, Dylan is able to experience everything that Rebecca experiences, and at the exact moment that Rebecca crashes her sled, rendering her unconscious, Dylan is thrown from his desk and is knocked out cold.</p>
<p>Twenty years later, Rebecca (<a href="/wiki/Zoe_Kazan" title="Zoe Kazan">Zoe Kazan</a>) is married to a successful doctor, Phillip Porter (<a href="/wiki/Mark_Feuerstein" title="Mark Feuerstein">Mark Feuerstein</a>), while Dylan (<a href="/wiki/Michael_Stahl-David" title="Michael Stahl-David">Michael Stahl-David</a>) has just recently gotten out of prison. One night, Rebecca attends a dinner party with her husband, and Dylan is at a local bar trying to stay out of trouble. However, a man who he had been playing pool with earlier hits him on the back with a pool stick. The impact flings Rebecca to the floor, which she cannot explain to the host of the dinner party, and leads to her husband chastising her for her behavior.</p>
<p>The next day, Dylan and Becky connect once more and they learn that if they speak aloud they can hear one another, they can see what the other is looking at, and feel what the other is feeling. They establish that they are not just figments of their respective imaginations, and they are indeed actual people. They set a meeting time to talk later on that night, and they slowly begin to get to know one another through several scenes where they talk, show each other their surroundings, share their dreams and shared experiences, finally stepping in front of mirrors for a visual introduction.</p>
<p>Throughout their experiences (Becky's fundraiser, Dylan's date, etc.) they grow closer. Becky realizes that Dylan is in love with her and she herself is falling in love with him, so she tries to break off their communication, much to their despair. At the same time, circumstances are closing in on the both of them. Becky's husband feels she has grown distant from him, and he is puzzled and disturbed by her odd behavior he has seen when she has been in mental contact with Dylan. One of her friends, thinking that Becky is either having an affair or is cracking up, brings her suspicions to him, and he and a medical colleague have her forcibly institutionalized. Dylan, on the other hand, loses his post-prison job working in a car wash when customers see him seemingly talking to himself as if he were crazy, when in fact, he was speaking to Becky. At the same time, while he is trying to make a clean break from his criminal past, he is menaced by two long-time criminal acquaintances trying to pressure him into using his skills as a burglar to help them commit a big heist.</p>
<p>Later, Dylan feels that Becky is in trouble and he violates his parole by stealing a truck to get to the airport and leaving the state without permission, taking a plane to New Hampshire to rescue Becky from the mental institution. Unable to rent a car at the airport, Dylan steals one. While she telepathically guides him over what are to him unfamiliar roads between the airport and the institution, he uses his criminal smarts to guide Becky through her escape from the facility, including picking a lock on a door. Becky avoids detection until reaching the front door, where she runs into her husband and subsequently punches him in the face before fleeing the facility, while Dylan is being chased by several police cars. They both manage to elude their respective pursuers and end up on foot running through the woods towards a train. They run alongside the moving train from opposite sides of the track and manage to climb into an empty box car, where they finally unite in person.</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Abigail_Spencer" title="Abigail Spencer">Abigail Spencer</a> was originally set to play the lead in the film, but the role was later given to Kazan.<sup id="cite_ref-Next_Movie.3B_cast_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Next_Movie.3B_cast-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Indiewire.3B_cast_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Indiewire.3B_cast-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Principal photography began late February 2012, in <a href="/wiki/New_Hampshire" title="New Hampshire">New Hampshire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NH.3B_production_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NH.3B_production-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup> Producer and co-founder of <a href="/wiki/Bellwether_Pictures" title="Bellwether Pictures">Bellwether Pictures</a> Kai Cole elaborated on the choice, saying, Location is very important to me. I think people can tell when you're tricking them with movie magic. We wanted everything to be authentic, from the architecture to the landscape and New Hampshire is perfect for us".<sup id="cite_ref-NH_Film_Office.3B_production_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NH_Film_Office.3B_production-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup> Director Brin Hill added that resulting from the importance of it in the script, "we were chasing snow. We started out in <a href="/wiki/Connecticut" title="Connecticut">Connecticut</a>, but there was no snow, so we moved to <a href="/wiki/Ohio" title="Ohio">Ohio</a>, but there was no snow [...] and we kept moving north".<sup id="cite_ref-Indiewood_Hollywoodn.27t.3B_production_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Indiewood_Hollywoodn.27t.3B_production-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-studiosystem_news.3B_production_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-studiosystem_news.3B_production-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup> The filming took place in <a href="/wiki/Exeter,_New_Hampshire" title="Exeter, New Hampshire">Exeter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manchester,_New_Hampshire" title="Manchester, New Hampshire">Manchester</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hooksett,_New_Hampshire" title="Hooksett, New Hampshire">Hooksett</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bedford,_New_Hampshire" title="Bedford, New Hampshire">Bedford</a>, <a href="/wiki/Windham,_New_Hampshire" title="Windham, New Hampshire">Windham</a>, <a href="/wiki/Claremont,_New_Hampshire" title="Claremont, New Hampshire">Claremont</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amherst,_New_Hampshire" title="Amherst, New Hampshire">Amherst</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-On_Location_Vacations.3B_production_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-On_Location_Vacations.3B_production-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_Boston_Globe.3B_production_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Boston_Globe.3B_production-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup> The opening sequence at the sledding hill was filmed at <a href="/wiki/McIntyre_Ski_Area" title="McIntyre Ski Area">McIntyre Ski Area</a>, and some footage was also shot in the <a href="/wiki/New_Mexico" title="New Mexico">New Mexico</a> desert.<sup id="cite_ref-Seacoast_Online.3B_production_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Seacoast_Online.3B_production-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup> They wrapped their last day of filming on the East Coast in early March 2012, moving next to <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a> to shoot the other half.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Boston_Globe.3B_production_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Boston_Globe.3B_production-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup> Hill shot the film <a href="/wiki/Digital_video" title="Digital video">digitally</a> with an <a href="/wiki/Arri_Alexa" title="Arri Alexa">Arri Alexa</a>, and said that he enjoyed the "versatility" of it, citing its proximity in look to <a href="/wiki/Film_stock" title="Film stock">film</a> as a satisfying trait for both him and his <a href="/wiki/Cinematographer" title="Cinematographer">DP</a>, Elisha Christian.<sup id="cite_ref-Indiewire.3B_production_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Indiewire.3B_production-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup> The screenplay was written by <a href="/wiki/Joss_Whedon" title="Joss Whedon">Joss Whedon</a> in the early 90s, and went through multiple rewrites over the course of two decades.<sup id="cite_ref-CRAVEONLINE.3B_production_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CRAVEONLINE.3B_production-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> To Hill, "the most interesting aspect of the script was its theme of connectionand what it means to connect in todays society".<sup id="cite_ref-Indiewood_Hollywoodn.27t.3B_production_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Indiewood_Hollywoodn.27t.3B_production-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Tony Morales composed the score for <i>In Your Eyes</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Indiewire.3B_soundtrack_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Indiewire.3B_soundtrack-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup> It was recorded at Emoto Studios in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-ae.3B_soundtrack_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ae.3B_soundtrack-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup> On collaborating with Brin Hill and <a href="/wiki/Joss_Whedon" title="Joss Whedon">Joss Whedon</a>, Morales said, "I primarily worked with Brin on the music for [the film]. Joss had a vision for the score that we were able to run with. As the sound of the score was coming together, Joss and the other producers were all part of the approval process".<sup id="cite_ref-fan_TV.3B_soundtrack_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fan_TV.3B_soundtrack-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup> A hybrid of <a href="/wiki/String_instrument" title="String instrument">string instruments</a>, <a href="/wiki/Piano" title="Piano">piano</a> sounds, and a variety of <a href="/wiki/Electronic_music" title="Electronic music">electronic music</a> were used by Morales to convey a sense of "mystery" that could "weave in and out" of the "romantic energy".<sup id="cite_ref-EVR.3B_soundtrack_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EVR.3B_soundtrack-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup> All music was released by <a href="/wiki/Lakeshore_Records" title="Lakeshore Records">Lakeshore Records</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Lakeshore_Records.3B_soundtrack_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lakeshore_Records.3B_soundtrack-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> The score and soundtrack were digitally available on June 10, 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-FILM_MUSIC_REPORTER.3B_soundtrack_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FILM_MUSIC_REPORTER.3B_soundtrack-25"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Soundtrack.Net.3B_soundtrack_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Soundtrack.Net.3B_soundtrack-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>In Your Eyes</i> premiered on April 20 at the 2014 <a href="/wiki/Tribeca_Film_Festival" title="Tribeca Film Festival">Tribeca Film Festival</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-TRIBECA_FILM_FESTIVAL.3B_infobox_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TRIBECA_FILM_FESTIVAL.3B_infobox-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-THE_WRAP.3B_release_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-THE_WRAP.3B_release-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup> In place of theatrical distribution, the film was put up for <a href="/wiki/Simultaneous_release" title="Simultaneous release">simultaneous release</a>. The venture was announced after its debut screening in a video message from <a href="/wiki/Joss_Whedon" title="Joss Whedon">Joss Whedon</a>, who said that the Tribeca premiere was "not just the premiere of the film. It is the worldwide release date".<sup id="cite_ref-THE_WRAP.3B_release_.232_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-THE_WRAP.3B_release_.232-29"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-USA_TODAY.3B_release_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USA_TODAY.3B_release-30"><span>[</span>30<span>]</span></a></sup> Brin Hill described the experimental method as "bittersweet, because it's uncharted territory. But theres something thrilling about this. [...] Theres something exciting about just making it available everywhere to everyone at once".<sup id="cite_ref-Los_Angeles_Times.3B_release_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Los_Angeles_Times.3B_release-31"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>According to <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a>, 63% of critics have given the film positive feedback (based on 16 reviews).<sup id="cite_ref-Rotten_Tomatoes.3B_critical_reaction_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rotten_Tomatoes.3B_critical_reaction-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Kurt_Loder" title="Kurt Loder">Kurt Loder</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/Reason_(magazine)" title="Reason (magazine)">Reason.com</a></i> complimented the director for making "a lustrous film out of Whedon's ingenious story",<sup id="cite_ref-reason.com.3B_critical_reaction_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reason.com.3B_critical_reaction-33"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup> while Mark Adams of <i><a href="/wiki/Screen_International" title="Screen International">ScreenDaily</a></i> lauded it by saying, "It has the perfect balance of humour and tenderness, with just a dash of danger and even melodrama on the side".<sup id="cite_ref-SCREENDAILY.3B_critical_reaction_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SCREENDAILY.3B_critical_reaction-34"><span>[</span>34<span>]</span></a></sup> John DeFore of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter" title="The Hollywood Reporter">The Hollywood Reporter</a></i> praised Brin Hill's ability to depict "the couple's growing intimacy", but felt that "the forces keeping both from being fulfilled" lacked development.<sup id="cite_ref-THE_Hollywood_REPORTER.3B_critical_reaction_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-THE_Hollywood_REPORTER.3B_critical_reaction-35"><span>[</span>35<span>]</span></a></sup> Eric Kohn of <i><a href="/wiki/Indiewire" title="Indiewire">Indiewire</a></i> wrote that <i>In Your Eyes</i> "successfully offers the lightweight alternative to Whedon's bigger projects: It's cheesy and slight, but persistently smart and entertaining within those narrow parameters".<sup id="cite_ref-Indiewire.3B_critical_reaction_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Indiewire.3B_critical_reaction-36"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i> scored the film two out of five stars, calling it "a rom-com version of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Shining_(film)" title="The Shining (film)">The Shining</a></i>".<sup id="cite_ref-theguardian.3B_critical_reaction_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-theguardian.3B_critical_reaction-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup> Peter Debruge of <i><a href="/wiki/Variety_(magazine)" title="Variety (magazine)">Variety</a></i> said that the film's "setup never really matures beyond a sentimental teenage fantasy".<sup id="cite_ref-VARIETY.3B_critical_reaction_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VARIETY.3B_critical_reaction-38"><span>[</span>38<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>In Your Eyes</i> was released on <a href="/wiki/DVD" title="DVD">DVD</a> on February 10, 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-dvd_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dvd-39"><span>[</span>39<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Melody</i> (1971 film)</h1>
<p><i><b>Melody</b></i> is a 1971 <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">British</a> film directed by <a href="/wiki/Waris_Hussein" title="Waris Hussein">Waris Hussein</a> about "<a href="/wiki/Puppy_love" title="Puppy love">puppy love</a>". It was released as <i><b>S.W.A.L.K.</b></i> in the United Kingdom (S.W.A.L.K. is a message traditionally written on the envelopes of love letters by British schoolchildren, standing for <i>Sealed With A Loving Kiss</i>). The film starred <a href="/wiki/Jack_Wild" title="Jack Wild">Jack Wild</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mark_Lester" title="Mark Lester">Mark Lester</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tracy_Hyde" title="Tracy Hyde">Tracy Hyde</a>. Although the film was a box office disappointment in both the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> and Britain, it turned out to be an enormous hit in <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>, and in some <a href="/wiki/Latin_American" title="Latin American" class="mw-redirect">Latin American</a> countries such as <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>This romantic story is told through the viewpoint of the children in the story, the adults playing only supporting roles. Daniel Latimer (<a href="/wiki/Mark_Lester" title="Mark Lester">Mark Lester</a>) befriends the troublesome Ornshaw (<a href="/wiki/Jack_Wild" title="Jack Wild">Jack Wild</a>). However, when Daniel falls in love with Melody Perkins (<a href="/wiki/Tracy_Hyde" title="Tracy Hyde">Tracy Hyde</a>), the boys' friendship becomes jeopardized as Ornshaw grows jealous of the amount of time that Daniel gives her. Initially embarrassed by the attention, Melody comes to return Daniel's feelings, and the couple announce to their parents that they want to get married. Not sometime in the future, but now. The adults attempt to dissuade them, but Daniel's and Melody's determination leads Ornshaw to have a change of heart. Their classmates gather together at one of the children's hideouts to 'marry' the couple, with their discovery leading to a final showdown between children and teachers.</p>
<p>Film production began in the Spring of 1970 shooting on location in <a href="/wiki/Hammersmith" title="Hammersmith">Hammersmith</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lambeth" title="Lambeth">Lambeth</a> in the greater <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a> area. Post-production was completed at the <a href="/wiki/Twickenham_Film_Studios" title="Twickenham Film Studios">Twickenham Studios</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Melody_DVD.3B_production_notes_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Melody_DVD.3B_production_notes-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> The graveyard scenes of the film were shot on location at <a href="/wiki/Brompton_Cemetery" title="Brompton Cemetery">Brompton Cemetery</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nunhead_Cemetery" title="Nunhead Cemetery">Nunhead Cemetery</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2010)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>. The seaside scenes in the latter part of the film were shot in <a href="/wiki/Weymouth,_Dorset" title="Weymouth, Dorset">Weymouth, Dorset</a>.</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Mark_Lester" title="Mark Lester">Mark Lester</a> (Daniel Latimer) and <a href="/wiki/Jack_Wild" title="Jack Wild">Jack Wild</a> (Ornshaw) had previously appeared together in the 1968 musical film adaptation of <i><a href="/wiki/Oliver!_(film)" title="Oliver! (film)">Oliver!</a></i>. They were joined by the child model <a href="/wiki/Tracy_Hyde" title="Tracy Hyde">Tracy Hyde</a> in the title role. Other cast members included <a href="/wiki/Kate_Williams_(actress)" title="Kate Williams (actress)">Kate Williams</a> as Melody's mother, <a href="/wiki/Roy_Kinnear" title="Roy Kinnear">Roy Kinnear</a> as her father, <a href="/wiki/Sheila_Steafel" title="Sheila Steafel">Sheila Steafel</a> as Daniel's mother, with <a href="/wiki/Ken_Jones_(actor)" title="Ken Jones (actor)">Ken Jones</a>, and <a href="/wiki/James_Cossins" title="James Cossins">James Cossins</a>.</p>
<p>The film's musical soundtrack included songs by the <a href="/wiki/Bee_Gees" title="Bee Gees">Bee Gees</a> ("<a href="/wiki/In_the_Morning_(Bee_Gees_song)" title="In the Morning (Bee Gees song)" class="mw-redirect">In the Morning</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Melody_Fair" title="Melody Fair">Melody Fair</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Give_Your_Best" title="Give Your Best" class="mw-redirect">Give Your Best</a>", and the hit singles "<a href="/wiki/To_Love_Somebody_(song)" title="To Love Somebody (song)">To Love Somebody</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/First_of_May_(Bee_Gees_song)" title="First of May (Bee Gees song)">First of May</a>"), and the <a href="/wiki/Crosby,_Stills,_Nash_%26_Young" title="Crosby, Stills, Nash &amp; Young">Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young</a> hit "<a href="/wiki/Teach_Your_Children" title="Teach Your Children">Teach Your Children</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>This was the first screenplay by film director <a href="/wiki/Alan_Parker" title="Alan Parker">Alan Parker</a>. Parker did some second-unit direction for the film, shooting the montage sequences of the school children at break-time and at the track meet.<sup id="cite_ref-Melody_DVD.3B_production_notes_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Melody_DVD.3B_production_notes-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> Because of its enormous success in Japan, the film has been mastered in <a href="/wiki/DVD_region_code" title="DVD region code">Region 2</a> format on <a href="/wiki/DVD" title="DVD">DVD</a> by Kadokawa Herald Pictures in Japan. This was the feature film debut of then child model and commercial actress <a href="/wiki/Tracy_Hyde" title="Tracy Hyde">Tracy Hyde</a> at the age of 11. Writer/Director <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Birkin" title="Andrew Birkin">Andrew Birkin</a> recommended Tracy Hyde for the title role of Melody Perkins to director <a href="/wiki/Waris_Hussein" title="Waris Hussein">Waris Hussein</a>, after screening and auditioning over 100 girls.<sup id="cite_ref-Melody_DVD.3B_production_notes_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Melody_DVD.3B_production_notes-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> Actor <a href="/wiki/Jack_Wild" title="Jack Wild">Jack Wild</a>, who played Ornshaw, was actually 17 at the time of the production.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources"><span title="The material near this tag may rely on an unreliable source. (December 2010)">unreliable source?</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>One Day</i> (2011 film)</h1>
<p><i><b>One Day</b></i> is a 2011 romance drama film directed by <a href="/wiki/Lone_Scherfig" title="Lone Scherfig">Lone Scherfig</a>. It was adapted by <a href="/wiki/David_Nicholls_(writer)" title="David Nicholls (writer)">David Nicholls</a> from his 2009 <a href="/wiki/One_Day_(novel)" title="One Day (novel)">novel of the same name</a>. It stars <a href="/wiki/Anne_Hathaway" title="Anne Hathaway">Anne Hathaway</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jim_Sturgess" title="Jim Sturgess">Jim Sturgess</a>. <a href="/wiki/Focus_Features" title="Focus Features">Focus Features</a> released the film theatrically in August 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-fif_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fif-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>The film opens with a short scene from the "current" day in 2006, which appears later on, before going back 18 years.</p>
<p>Dexter Mayhew (<a href="/wiki/Jim_Sturgess" title="Jim Sturgess">Jim Sturgess</a>) and Emma Morley (<a href="/wiki/Anne_Hathaway" title="Anne Hathaway">Anne Hathaway</a>) meet on 14 July 1988 after their graduation from the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Edinburgh" title="University of Edinburgh">University of Edinburgh</a>. They spend the night together but agree to be just friends, and plan to spend the following day together, the 15th, St. <a href="/wiki/Swithun" title="Swithun">Swithun</a>'s day. The film chronologically reconnects Dexter, Emma or both of them on that one day over the next 18 years after they go their separate ways.</p>
<p>One year later in 1989, Dexter helps Emma move into a flat in London where she plans to pursue a career as a writer. However, after little success, she ends up working as a waitress in a Mexican restaurant by 1990, and meets Ian (<a href="/wiki/Rafe_Spall" title="Rafe Spall">Rafe Spall</a>), an aspiring comedian who is hired soon after. Dexter is travelling the world while drinking and having sex promiscuously with a succession of girlfriends, but they keep in contact via phonecalls and letters. He then visits Emma on 15 July 1991 and, to get her out of her rut, suggests they go away for the weekend.
