They flirt back and forth and it's made clear that Emma may have deeper feelings for him, but since she knows that Dexter is not boyfriend material, nothing comes of it and two more years fly by. Dexter is now a wealthy and successful television presenter on a raucous late-night television show, where he meets Sylvie (<a href="/wiki/Romola_Garai" title="Romola Garai">Romola Garai</a>), who later becomes his new girlfriend.</p>
<p>Dexter visits his parents on 15 July 1994 after his mother (<a href="/wiki/Patricia_Clarkson" title="Patricia Clarkson">Patricia Clarkson</a>) has been diagnosed with cancer and is terminally ill. He arrives at the family home still under the influence of drugs and alcohol from heavy partying the night before, which his father (<a href="/wiki/Ken_Stott" title="Ken Stott">Ken Stott</a>) notices and is furious about, telling Dexter he will ban him from visiting again if he keeps it up. Also, his mother appears very unimpressed with the nature of his television show and reveals that she no longer believes he is a nice man. On the same day, Emma goes out on a date with Ian. Although there appears to be no romantic spark between them, she knows he means well and so they continue to date anyway.</p>
<p>By 1995, Emma is now a school teacher and has moved in with Ian. However, she grows more and more irritated with him because of his lack of ambition and failure to contribute to maintaining their household. Dexter is the presenter of another television show, which isn't doing so well, making him "the most annoying man on telly". On 15 July 1996, he and Emma meet for dinner. He turns up high on <a href="/wiki/Cocaine" title="Cocaine">cocaine</a>, leaves the table every thirty minutes, flirts with another woman down the hall, and insults Emma. She storms off and, out in the street, decides that they must break off their friendship due to them outgrowing each other. She tells him that although she loves him, she no longer likes him anymore.</p>
<p>Two years later, Dexter's television career has gone into a steep decline because he is 32 years old and television executives prefer presenters in their early 20s. Meanwhile, Emma and Ian have split up and she becomes a published author of children's books. By 1999, Dexter is in a long-term relationship with Sylvie. On 15 July 2000, Emma's former university roommate and Dexter's old best friend get married, and both Emma and Dexter are invited to the wedding. There, Dexter receives a job offer from Calum, his old roommate who has since become a multimillionaire from owning a chain of <a href="/wiki/Organic_food" title="Organic food">organic food</a> restaurants. Dexter and Emma leave the party to talk on the rooftop, where he tells her about Sylvie, who is now his fiance, and is on his way to becoming a father. Emma tries to hide the fact that she is upset and they share a very brief but meaningful kiss.</p>
<p>By 2001, Dexter is a father but later learns that Sylvie is having an affair with Calum and they divorce. Two years pass and Emma has moved to Paris, where Dexter visits her on 15 July in the hope that they will get together again, this time for good. It is revealed that they had a one-night stand after his marriage to Sylvie broke down. However, Emma reveals that she has a new boyfriend (<a href="/w/index.php?title=S%C3%A9bastien_Dupuis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sbastien Dupuis (page does not exist)">Sbastien Dupuis</a>), a French musician who plays piano in a jazz band. Smitten with Emma but taken aback by the revelation that she has moved on, Dexter decides to leave. Suddenly, she has second thoughts and chases after him, exclaiming that she thought she had gotten rid of him. He promises to never hurt, lie to or cheat on her, and they share a passionate kiss and finally start a full relationship together.</p>
<p>Emma and Dexter become engaged in 2004 and eventually marry. Parlaying his restaurant experience into a new career, Dexter opens his own cafe in England, which proves to be very lucrative, and he and Emma start trying to have their own baby. However, they are unsuccessful and become frustrated with one another. On 15 July 2006 (the scene from the very beginning of the movie), Emma is hit by a truck while riding her bicycle out of a blind alley, and she dies. Dexter becomes inconsolable and self-destructive, and is particularly desolate each year on their day. Over the years, he gets support from his ex-wife, their daughter Jasmine, his widowed father, and even Ian, who also mourns Emma every year. Ian has since married and had children, but he visits Dexter and tells him that Emma was never the same with him as she was with Dexter, that she "lit up" whenever Dexter was around, and that "she made you decent and you made her so happy".</p>
<p>On 15 July 2011, Dexter visits <a href="/wiki/Arthur%27s_Seat" title="Arthur's Seat">Arthur's Seat</a> in <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a> with Jasmine. The movie flashbacks to 1988 when they met and reveals they spent their day together at the same place. At the top, Dexter and Emma promise to always be best friends.</p>
<p>The film is a co-production between <a href="/wiki/Random_House" title="Random House">Random House Films</a> and <a href="/wiki/Focus_Features" title="Focus Features">Focus Features</a>. <a href="/wiki/Film4_Productions" title="Film4 Productions">Film4 Productions</a> is co-financing.<sup id="cite_ref-fif_2-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fif-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Actress Anne Hathaway said she was clandestinely given the script as the film was set in the United Kingdom and director Scherfig wasn't looking for any American actresses for the part. Hathaway flew to London for a meeting with Scherfig to explain why she should get the part. Hathaway later said it was "the worst meeting of my life... I was just inarticulate", but on leaving Hathaway wrote out a list of songs for Scherfig to listen to, saying, "I clearly didn't communicate to you what I needed to today. But I think these songs can do it for me." Scherfig did listen to them, which led to Hathaway getting the part.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Principal photography commenced in July 2010. Filming took place on location in Scotland, England and France.<sup id="cite_ref-fif_2-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fif-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> The production filmed in <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh" title="Edinburgh">Edinburgh</a>, the city where Dexter and Emma first meet, in August 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> Various landmark locations, including <a href="/wiki/Arthur%27s_Seat" title="Arthur's Seat">Arthur's Seat</a>, were used.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> Production then moved to London. <a href="/wiki/Parliament_Hill_Lido" title="Parliament Hill Lido">Parliament Hill Lido</a> in <a href="/wiki/North_London" title="North London">north London</a> was used for scenes in which Emma, of varying ages, swims.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup> Filming took place inside a house in Granville Road in <a href="/wiki/Stroud_Green" title="Stroud Green">Stroud Green</a> for scenes involving Jim Sturgess and Romola Garai.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> Scenes in the shop and cafe were filmed at Leila's shop and cafe on Arnold Circus, close to Brick Lane in the East End.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> UK railway Station filming took place at Ridgmont Station on the Bedford to Bletchley <a href="/wiki/Marston_Vale_Line" title="Marston Vale Line">Marston Vale Line</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup> Filming in France took place in <a href="/wiki/Dinard" title="Dinard">Dinard</a>, a town close by to St. Malo, in the Brittany region. A seaside club was turned into the Caf Paradis, designed to ape Greek themes.</p>
<p>The film is ranked as "rotten" on <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> with a 36% positive approval rating (only 51 out of 140 critics gave positive reviews), with the consensus stating "Despite some fresh narrative twists, <i>One Day</i> lacks the emotion, depth, or insight of its bestselling source material".<sup id="cite_ref-rotom_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rotom-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/CinemaScore" title="CinemaScore">CinemaScore</a> polls reported that the average grade moviegoers gave the film was a "B-minus" on an A+ to F scale.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Betsey Sharkey of the <i><a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times" title="Los Angeles Times">Los Angeles Times</a></i> called it a "heartbreaking disappointment of a film"<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup> while Peter Howell of the <i><a href="/wiki/Toronto_Star" title="Toronto Star">Toronto Star</a></i> said "Long before the credits roll, you may find yourself wishing your life could flash before your eyes, to end the monotony of this relentless turning of calendar pages."<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup> In contrast, <a href="/wiki/Roger_Ebert" title="Roger Ebert">Roger Ebert</a> said "<i>One Day</i> has style, freshness, and witty bantering dialogue."<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup> Anne Hathaway's Yorkshire accent in the role of Emma has been widely regarded as subpar. Newspaper columnist Suzanne Moore, reviewing the film on <a href="/wiki/BBC_Radio_4" title="BBC Radio 4">BBC Radio 4</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Front_Row_(radio)" title="Front Row (radio)">Front Row</a></i>, said the accents were "all over the shop". Moore went on to say, "Sometimes she's from Scotland, sometimes she's from New York, you just can't tell".<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>I Origins</i></h1>
<p><i><b>I Origins</b></i> is a 2014 American <a href="/wiki/Science_fiction_film" title="Science fiction film">science fiction</a> <a href="/wiki/Drama_film" title="Drama film" class="mw-redirect">drama</a> written and directed by <a href="/wiki/Mike_Cahill_(director)" title="Mike Cahill (director)">Mike Cahill</a>. The independent production premiered at the <a href="/wiki/2014_Sundance_Film_Festival" title="2014 Sundance Film Festival">2014 Sundance Film Festival</a> on <span class="nowrap">January 18</span>, 2014. It is distributed by <a href="/wiki/Fox_Searchlight_Pictures" title="Fox Searchlight Pictures">Fox Searchlight Pictures</a>, and opened in limited release on <span class="nowrap">July 18</span>, 2014. It won the Best Feature Length Film Award at the <a href="/wiki/Sitges_Film_Festival" title="Sitges Film Festival">Festival Internacional de Cinema Fantstic de Catalunya</a> on October 11, 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>A graduate student, Ian Gray, is researching the evolution of human eyes with Karen, his first year lab assistant, and Kenny. He has a particular hostility to superstition and "<a href="/wiki/Intelligent_design" title="Intelligent design">intelligent design</a>", which he hopes to discredit by filling in the steps of <a href="/wiki/Evolution_of_the_eye" title="Evolution of the eye">the evolution of the eye</a>. At a Halloween party he has an encounter with Sofi, who is wearing a mask. He photographs her eyes and they go into the washroom to have sex. Abruptly she leaves.</p>
<p>Ian continues thinking about her. One day coincidences seem to mysteriously guide him to a billboard displaying what he recognizes to be Sofi's eyes. Eventually he sees her on a train. They begin a relationship, although his rationalism clashes with her fey spirituality. One day they agree to marry. They are told they need to wait a day for a licence, and Ian gets a call from Karen at the lab. There has been a breakthrough in their research. She's found a blind worm  <i><a href="/wiki/Eisenia_fetida" title="Eisenia fetida">Eisenia fetida</a></i>  with the DNA to develop an eye. Ian takes Sofi to the lab with him.</p>
<p>Sofi is upset by the research they're doing and Karen leaves. Sofi kisses Ian and knocks over a bottle of formaldehyde, splashing his eyes. They call Karen, who helps him to the eyewash station and bandages his eyes, and Sofi takes him home. Then the elevator in Sofi's apartment building stops between floors. As they try to climb out the elevator starts to move again and Sofi is killed. Ian goes into a depression, and Karen continues their research. One night Karen brings him a meal at his home. He begins to cry and she hugs him. They begin to kiss.</p>
<p>The film flashes forward seven years. Ian has written a book on the evolution of the eye that he claims further debunks creationism. Ian and Karen are now married and Karen is pregnant. When their baby is born, the hospital takes an <a href="/wiki/Iris_scan" title="Iris scan" class="mw-redirect">iris scan</a> of him. The results are entered in the database and the program identifies the baby as a certain Paul Edgar Dairy. The nurse re-enters the results and the problem disappears.</p>
<p>A few months later, a Doctor Simmons calls, claiming that a test of the baby's urine may indicate an elevated risk of <a href="/wiki/Autism" title="Autism">autism</a> and recommending a further test. But Ian and Karen become suspicious during this test and decide to investigate Doctor Simmons. They find that she is in fact one of a few people with full access to the iris scan database. Ian tracks some pictures from this test to Idaho where he stumbles on the family of Paul Edgar Dairy, who apparently died just before their baby was conceived.</p>
<p>Ian's former research partner, Kenny, is the creator of the iris database. He helps Ian and Karen run some photos of deceased people's eyes through the database to see if there are any recent matches. They get a hit for Sofi, whose iris scan matches one made in India just three months prior, years after Sofi's death.</p>
<p>Ian goes to India to find the subject of this scan. There he finds Priya, the head of the community centre where the iris scan was made. Priya recognizes Sofi's eyes as those of a girl she knows, named Salomina, and agrees to help. Ian and Priya begin searching for Salomina, who is an orphan and seems to have disappeared into the crowds of the city. Ian tries putting up a billboard showing Sofi's eyes and offering a cash reward. He is besieged with calls but none are credible. Weeks later he comes across a little girl staring at the billboard. It is Salomina. He takes her back to his hotel and contacts Karen over <a href="/wiki/Skype" title="Skype">Skype</a>. The two of them conduct a simple test designed to reveal if Salomina might be somehow linked with Sofi. At first Salomina is uncannily accurate, but in the end her results are within the probable range of random chance. Karen asks him how he feels about this and he says he feels foolish. Ian then leaves the hotel room with Salomina to take her to Priya but when they reach the elevator, Salomina panics and throws herself into his arms. They cling to each other, crying, and he picks her up and takes her down the stairs instead.</p>
<p>A <a href="/wiki/Post-credits_scene" title="Post-credits scene">post-credits scene</a> shows Dr. Simmons scanning the irises of famous deceased figures, apparently finding matches.</p>
<p><i>I Origins</i> was the second feature film by writer-director <a href="/wiki/Mike_Cahill_(director)" title="Mike Cahill (director)">Mike Cahill</a> after his earlier independent science fiction-drama, <i><a href="/wiki/Another_Earth" title="Another Earth">Another Earth</a></i> (2011), also with actress <a href="/wiki/Brit_Marling" title="Brit Marling">Brit Marling</a>. Cahill sold the film rights to <i>Another Earth</i> to <a href="/wiki/Fox_Searchlight_Pictures" title="Fox Searchlight Pictures">Fox Searchlight Pictures</a> at the <a href="/wiki/2011_Sundance_Film_Festival" title="2011 Sundance Film Festival">2011 Sundance Film Festival</a>. At that time he also sold a screenplay to what would be his next feature film titled <i>I</i>. Though during the development of <i>I</i>, after failing to "crack" some aspects of the story, Cahill instead decided to make an origin story for the film, in which he had a "rich back story for".<sup id="cite_ref-slashfilm_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-slashfilm-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Although Fox Searchlight owned the rights to any prequels or sequels to the <i>I</i> script, Cahill decided to make <i>I Origins</i> independently. He intended to sell the film at the <a href="/wiki/Sundance_Film_Festival" title="Sundance Film Festival">Sundance Film Festival</a>, like he did for <i>Another Earth</i>. Fox Searchlight agreed and the film was produced by Verisimilitude and WeWork Studios in association with Bersin Pictures and Penny Jane Films. After the premiere of <i>I Origins</i> at the <a href="/wiki/2014_Sundance_Film_Festival" title="2014 Sundance Film Festival">2014 Sundance Film Festival</a>, Fox Searchlight ended up buying the rights to the film.<sup id="cite_ref-slashfilm_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-slashfilm-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>I Origins</i> <a href="/wiki/Film_premiere" title="Film premiere" class="mw-redirect">premiered</a> at the <a href="/wiki/2014_Sundance_Film_Festival" title="2014 Sundance Film Festival">2014 Sundance Film Festival</a> on <span class="nowrap">January 18</span>, 2014. After its premiere, <a href="/wiki/Fox_Searchlight_Pictures" title="Fox Searchlight Pictures">Fox Searchlight Pictures</a> bought rights to worldwide distribution of the film.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> The film won the festival's <a href="/wiki/Alfred_P._Sloan_Prize" title="Alfred P. Sloan Prize">Alfred P. Sloan Prize</a>, which recognizes films that depict science and technology. The win was Cahill's second; his film <i><a href="/wiki/Another_Earth" title="Another Earth">Another Earth</a></i> also won the prize in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>I Origins</i> also screened at the <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a>-based BAMcinemaFest and at the <a href="/wiki/Nantucket_Film_Festival" title="Nantucket Film Festival">Nantucket Film Festival</a>, both in late June 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>I Origins</i> began its <a href="/wiki/Limited_release" title="Limited release">limited theatrical release</a> on <span class="nowrap">July 18</span>, 2014 in just four theaters.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> The following week, it expanded to 76 theaters.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>I Origins</i> received mixed reviews from critics. <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> gave the film a rating of 52%, based on 96 reviews. The site's consensus states: "Writer-director Mike Cahill remains an intriguingly ambitious talent, but with the uneven sci-fi drama <i>I Origins</i>, his reach exceeds his grasp".<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup> On <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>, the film has a score of 57 out of 100, based on 36 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".<sup id="cite_ref-Metacritic_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Metacritic-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup> Jordan Zakarin, of entertainment and media news website <a href="/wiki/TheWrap" title="TheWrap">TheWrap</a>, said that "The movie starts as a love story and then morphs into a thriller, propelled always by the push and pull of faith and logic, with tragedy shifting world views over time". He continued, saying that "The message is both micro and macro, aimed at the renewed war in the United States over issues like science education and contraception, as well as Cahills way of working out his own mixed emotions".<sup id="cite_ref-thewrap_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thewrap-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>I Origins</i> was developed as a prequel of <i>I</i>, a screenplay which Cahill sold to <a href="/wiki/Fox_Searchlight_Pictures" title="Fox Searchlight Pictures">Fox Searchlight Pictures</a> in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-thewrap_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thewrap-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup> Cahill intended for <i>I</i> to take place twenty years after the event of <i>I Origins</i>, after the repercussions of Dr. Ian Grays discoveries take hold, as teased in the post-credits of the film.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>During press interviews for the film, Cahill spoke of plans to go ahead with a sequel to <i>I Origins</i>, saying "There's a sequel in the works. It's not scripted. We're not in production yet, but we set up at Fox Searchlight".<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Hitman: Agent 47</i></h1>
<p><i><b>Hitman: Agent 47</b></i> is a 2015 German-American-British<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Action_film" title="Action film">action</a> <a href="/wiki/Thriller_(genre)" title="Thriller (genre)">thriller film</a> directed by <a href="/wiki/Aleksander_Bach" title="Aleksander Bach">Aleksander Bach</a> in his directorial debut and written by <a href="/wiki/Skip_Woods" title="Skip Woods">Skip Woods</a> (who also wrote the <a href="/wiki/Hitman_(2007_film)" title="Hitman (2007 film)">original <i>Hitman</i> film</a>) and Michael Finch. It is based on the <a href="/wiki/Hitman_(video_game_series)" title="Hitman (video game series)"><i>Hitman</i> video game series</a>, developed by <a href="/wiki/IO_Interactive" title="IO Interactive">IO Interactive</a>, and its main character, a mysterious assassin known only as <a href="/wiki/Agent_47" title="Agent 47">Agent 47</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Fox_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fox-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> The film stars <a href="/wiki/Rupert_Friend" title="Rupert Friend">Rupert Friend</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hannah_Ware" title="Hannah Ware">Hannah Ware</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zachary_Quinto" title="Zachary Quinto">Zachary Quinto</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ciar%C3%A1n_Hinds" title="Ciarn Hinds">Ciarn Hinds</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Kretschmann" title="Thomas Kretschmann">Thomas Kretschmann</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Angelababy" title="Angelababy">Angelababy</a>. It was released on August 21, 2015. It is also the first ever Hollywood movie to be filmed in <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>47 (<a href="/wiki/Rupert_Friend" title="Rupert Friend">Rupert Friend</a>) is an "Agent," a genetically-enhanced supersoldier created decades ago by Doctor Pitor Litvenko (<a href="/wiki/Ciaran_Hinds" title="Ciaran Hinds" class="mw-redirect">Ciaran Hinds</a>), a skilled Russian geneticist who had a crisis of conscience and disappeared before the Agent project's completion, leaving behind his daughter Katia (<a href="/wiki/Hannah_Ware" title="Hannah Ware">Hannah Ware</a>). 47 works as a hitman for the ICA (International Contracts Agency) and has spent the last few years tracking down Katia as a means to find her father. His most recent targets were mercenaries led by Delriego (<a href="/wiki/Rolf_Kanies" title="Rolf Kanies">Rolf Kanies</a>) who have been trying to find Litvenko in order to recreate the Agent program for their own means.</p>
<p>Katia, living in Berlin, has worked tirelessly to find her father, and is plagued by overwhelming anxiety and an acute awareness of everything around her, being able to see and hear things well outside a person's normal sensory radius. Katia is approached at a subway station by a man calling himself John Smith (<a href="/wiki/Zachary_Quinto" title="Zachary Quinto">Zachary Quinto</a>). He tells her that 47 is on his way to kill her, and offers her protection, while alluding that he has information about her father. 47 finds and attacks the pair, who are able to escape, but not before 47 grazes Katia's arm with a sniper bullet. Smith and Katia hide out in a hotel room where the former explains that he is an operative for a corporation known as Syndicate International, and Katia shows him her map of clues to finding her father. Katia asks John to tell her whatever he knows about her father. John responds with Litvenko's age, medical condition (<a href="/wiki/Rheumatoid_arthritis" title="Rheumatoid arthritis">rheumatoid arthritis</a>) and that he speaks several different languages - including <a href="/wiki/Tamil_language" title="Tamil language">Tamil</a> which is quite uncommon. He also says that he has stage 3 lung cancer. With these facts, Katia figures out that her dad would be living in a country which has a warm climate where orchids can grow, has Tamil as one of its official languages and where advanced medical treatments are available. Just as she is about to determine the country, 47 bursts through the door, shoots Smith in the chest, and knocks Katia unconscious. Elsewhere, 47's handler Diana (<a href="/wiki/Angelababy" title="Angelababy">Angelababy</a>) contacts another Agent with a contract.</p>
<p>Once Katia awakens, 47 explains to her that she too, is an Agent, only Katia is more advanced than even 47 himself (he even explains that her real name is "quatre-vingt-dix"; which is French for "90"). He shows her how to use her heightened senses in combat, as the two fight against Syndicate forces. They are confronted by Smith, who reveals to have a genetically engineered subdermal body armor, leaving him impervious to gunshots. Despite all these, Katia is not all pleased for being chosen to be a killing machine. Smith demands to know Litvenko's location. After a brief fight, 47 and Katia manage to escape. Katia makes 47 promise that he won't harm her father and finally reveal's Litvenko's location: Singapore.</p>
<p>Once there, they find Litvenko, who frequently needs an inhaler to breathe. He apologizes to Katia for abandoning her, saying that he only wanted to keep her safe. He refers to 47 as her "brother", saying that he had left her with family after all. Just then, Syndicate soldiers attack the group and they are forced to flee. During the escape, Litvenko is captured by the Syndicate but not before being slipped an explosive-rigged inhaler by 47.</p>
<p>At Syndicate International headquarters, Smith tortures Litvenko under the supervision of Syndicate director Antoine LeClerq (<a href="/wiki/Thomas_Kretschmann" title="Thomas Kretschmann">Thomas Kretschmann</a>). Litvenko still refuses to reopen the Agent program. While Katia crashes a helicopter into the building, 47 infiltrates the headquarters disguised as a firefighter. The two fight their way through Syndicate security forces, and 47 is once again confronted by Smith. With Smith being impervious to bullets, 47 defeats Smith by electrocuting him. On the rooftop, 47 and Katia fight their way through the last of the Syndicate's security, but not before LeClerq escapes in a helicopter with Litvenko. In mid-air, Litvenko detonates the inhaler given to him by 47, ensuring that the Syndicate will not come after Katia. 47 then calls Diana and confirms his first target (LeClerq) has been eliminated. When Diana asks about the second target (Katia), 47 drops his phone off the side of the building. As the two prepare to leave, they are confronted by Agent 48, an exact look-alike of Agent 47, who tells them "Diana says 'Hello'" before a gun battle begins between them.</p>
<p>A mid-credits scene shows the electrocuted body of Smith, now with white hair and a ghostly pale complexion, as he jolts awake.</p>
<p>On February 5, 2013, it was reported that <a href="/wiki/20th_Century_Fox" title="20th Century Fox">20th Century Fox</a> was developing a new film based on the <a href="/wiki/Hitman_(video_game_series)" title="Hitman (video game series)"><i>Hitman</i></a> video games, with the title <i>Agent 47</i> derived from the lead character <a href="/wiki/Agent_47" title="Agent 47">Agent 47</a>. <a href="/wiki/Skip_Woods" title="Skip Woods">Skip Woods</a> wrote the screenplay with Michael Finch, and commercial director <a href="/wiki/Aleksander_Bach" title="Aleksander Bach">Aleksander Bach</a> directed as his feature film debut.</p>
<p>On February 5, 2013, <a href="/wiki/Paul_Walker" title="Paul Walker">Paul Walker</a> was attached to play the title role as <a href="/wiki/Agent_47" title="Agent 47">Agent 47</a>, but on November 30, 2013, he died in a car accident, before filming had begun.<sup id="cite_ref-Fox_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fox-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> On January 9, 2014, <a href="/wiki/Rupert_Friend" title="Rupert Friend">Rupert Friend</a> was in talks to replace Walker. On January 31, 2014, <a href="/wiki/Zachary_Quinto" title="Zachary Quinto">Zachary Quinto</a> joined the film in a supporting role.<sup id="cite_ref-Zachary_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zachary-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> On February 5, 2014, <a href="/wiki/Hannah_Ware" title="Hannah Ware">Hannah Ware</a> also joined the film to play the female lead. On March 6, 2014, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Kretschmann" title="Thomas Kretschmann">Thomas Kretschmann</a> signed on to play the high-profile villain, Le Clerq.<sup id="cite_ref-Thomas_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thomas-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> On March 13, 2014 <a href="/wiki/Dan_Bakkedahl" title="Dan Bakkedahl">Dan Bakkedahl</a> joined the cast of the film.<sup id="cite_ref-Bakkedahl_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bakkedahl-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup> On March 14, 2014, <a href="/wiki/Ciar%C3%A1n_Hinds" title="Ciarn Hinds">Ciarn Hinds</a> signed on to star in the film as a scientist.</p>
<p>Filming was originally set to take place in <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a> in summer 2013,<sup id="cite_ref-Fox_6-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fox-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> but was later postponed to March 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-Zachary_9-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zachary-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Principal_photography" title="Principal photography">Principal photography</a> began on February 18, 2014; an image from the European set was released that week.<sup id="cite_ref-Thomas_10-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thomas-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The official soundtrack was composed by Marco Beltrami.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Two images and footage from the film were revealed at the <a href="/wiki/San_Diego_Comic-Con_International" title="San Diego Comic-Con International">San Diego Comic-Con International</a> on July 25, 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup> The first official trailer was released online on February 11, 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Hitman: Agent 47</i> grossed $22.5 million in North America and $59.4 million in other territories for a worldwide total of $81.9 million, against a budget of $35 million.<sup id="cite_ref-BOM_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BOM-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In its opening weekend, the film grossed $8.3 million, finishing 4th at the box office.</p>
<p>The film opened in 60 markets internationally.<sup id="cite_ref-5thOverseasOpening_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5thOverseasOpening-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup> It opened in France at number 2 with $1.9 million, third in the United Kingdom with $1.4 million, and first in Colombia.<sup id="cite_ref-5thOverseasOpening_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5thOverseasOpening-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Hitman: Agent 47</i> has received negative reviews from critics. Review aggregation website <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> gives the film a rating of 8%, based on 108 reviews, with an average rating of 3.7/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "<i>Hitman: Agent 47</i> fails to clear the low bar set by its predecessor, forsaking thrilling action in favor of a sleekly hollow mlange of dull violence and product placement."<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a> gives the film a score of 28 out of 100, based on reviews from 27 critics, indicating "generally unfavorable reviews".<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup> Audiences surveyed by <a href="/wiki/CinemaScore" title="CinemaScore">CinemaScore</a> gave the film an average grade of "B" on an A+ to F scale.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/IGN" title="IGN">IGN</a> gave the film a score of 6.0/10, saying, "<i>Hitman: Agent 47</i> is almost certainly going to be too much of a generic action film for those heavily invested in the game franchise, and too video game-like for those who aren't."<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> IrishFilmCritic gave the film 3.5/5 stars, describing the target audience as "those of us who grew up in the 70s and 80s and thrived on overly exaggerated action films with anything that starred Arnold Schwarzenegger, Sylvester Stallone and Bruce Willis...Go to this movie and just have fun, its that simple."<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup> Kotaku also gave the film a positive review.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Tech-savvy site <a href="/wiki/Geek.com" title="Geek.com">Geek.com</a> awarded the film a decent review. Critic Will Greenwald commented that "It isnt a must-watch, and doesnt stand out as memorable or terrible, but its enjoyable enough to at least feel like <i>Hitman</i>... The premise feels like <i><a href="/wiki/L%C3%A9on:_The_Professional" title="Lon: The Professional">The Professional</a></i>... And, as stupid as that all sounds, its actually very loosely the plot of the first Hitman game, <i><a href="/wiki/Hitman:_Codename_47" title="Hitman: Codename 47">Hitman: Codename 47</a></i>... the first hour the film feels like a bizarre take on <i><a href="/wiki/The_Terminator" title="The Terminator">The Terminator</a></i>. The action is frantic and creative. Gunplay feels a bit like <i><a href="/wiki/Equilibrium_(film)" title="Equilibrium (film)">Equilibrium</a></i>, which means its eye-catching, brutal, and incredibly unrealistic... and its entertaining despite not feeling as genuine and harsh as the action in <i><a href="/wiki/Dredd" title="Dredd">Dredd</a></i> or <i><a href="/wiki/John_Wick_(film)" title="John Wick (film)" class="mw-redirect">John Wick</a></i>... I liked <i>Hitman: Agent 47</i>, but its not a very good movie. Its uneven and weird, and while its much more enjoyable than the previous <i>Hitman</i> film, it doesnt leave a very lasting impression. Its not <i><a href="/wiki/Hitman_(2007_film)" title="Hitman (2007 film)">Hitman</a></i> boring and its not <i><a href="/wiki/Street_Fighter:_The_Legend_of_Chun-Li" title="Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li">Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li</a></i> bad or faithless to the source material, but it isnt consistently as strong as it could have been with a bit more logic in the writing and much less reliance on CG and film speed trickery to make the fights seem flashier (and faker). There are just too many little things that feel off for the big, eye-catching things to really stay with you." <sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The Sci-Fi Movie page awarded the film just two stars out of five. Film critic Tim Janson stated: "First time Director Aleksander Bach makes the mistake in thinking that more characters with special abilities makes for a better film. Unfortunately this is not the case. Theres little attempt at developing any of the characters as more than one-dimensional cutouts." <sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Adrian Askarieh told IGN in an interview that he may oversee a film universe with <i>Just Cause</i>, <i>Hitman</i>, <i>Tomb Raider</i>, <i>Deus Ex</i> and <i>Thief</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>About Time</i> (2013 film)</h1>
<p><i><b>About Time</b></i> is a 2013 British <a href="/wiki/Romantic_film" title="Romantic film" class="mw-redirect">romantic</a> <a href="/wiki/Comedy-drama" title="Comedy-drama">comedy-drama</a> film about a young man with the special ability to <a href="/wiki/Time_travel" title="Time travel">time travel</a> who tries to change his past in order to improve his future.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> The film was written and directed by <a href="/wiki/Richard_Curtis" title="Richard Curtis">Richard Curtis</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> and stars <a href="/wiki/Domhnall_Gleeson" title="Domhnall Gleeson">Domhnall Gleeson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rachel_McAdams" title="Rachel McAdams">Rachel McAdams</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bill_Nighy" title="Bill Nighy">Bill Nighy</a>. It was released in the United Kingdom on 4 September 2013 and in the United States on 1 November 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-release-date_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-release-date-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>Tim Lake (<a href="/wiki/Domhnall_Gleeson" title="Domhnall Gleeson">Domhnall Gleeson</a>) is a young man from <a href="/wiki/Cornwall" title="Cornwall">Cornwall</a>, <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a>. He grows up in a house by the sea with his father (<a href="/wiki/Bill_Nighy" title="Bill Nighy">Bill Nighy</a>), his mother (<a href="/wiki/Lindsay_Duncan" title="Lindsay Duncan">Lindsay Duncan</a>), his absent-minded uncle (<a href="/wiki/Richard_Cordery" title="Richard Cordery">Richard Cordery</a>), and his free-spirited sister, Katherine (<a href="/wiki/Lydia_Wilson" title="Lydia Wilson">Lydia Wilson</a>), who is known to family and friends as Kit Kat. At the age of 21, Tim is told by his father that the men of his family have a special gift: the ability to travel in time. This supernatural ability is subject to one constraint: they can only travel to places and times they have been before. After his father discourages Tim from using his gift to acquire money or fame, he decides that he will use it to improve his love life.</p>
<p>The following summer, Kit Kat's friend Charlotte (<a href="/wiki/Margot_Robbie" title="Margot Robbie">Margot Robbie</a>) comes to the house in order to spend her holiday with Tim's family. Tim is instantly attracted to her and at the end of her stay decides to tell her how he feels. She tells him that he should not have waited until the last day, that perhaps if he had told her earlier, something could have happened between them. Tim travels back in time and, the second time around, tells Charlotte in the middle of the holiday how he feels. In this instance, Charlotte uses the exact opposite excuse, saying that it would be better if they waited until the last day of the holiday, and then something could potentially happen between them. Heartbroken, Tim realizes that Charlotte is not attracted to him and that time travel will not make it possible for him to change her mind.</p>
<p>After the summer, Tim moves to London to pursue a career as a barrister. He is put up by his father's old acquaintance, Harry (<a href="/wiki/Tom_Hollander" title="Tom Hollander">Tom Hollander</a>), a misanthropic playwright. After some months, Tim visits a <a href="/wiki/Dans_le_Noir" title="Dans le Noir">Dans le Noir</a> restaurant, where he meets Mary (<a href="/wiki/Rachel_McAdams" title="Rachel McAdams">Rachel McAdams</a>), a young American woman who works for a publishing house. The two flirt in the darkness of the restaurant, and afterward, Mary gives Tim her phone number. Tim returns home to find a distraught Harry. It turns out that the same night as he met Mary, the opening night of Harry's new play had been ruined by one of the actors forgetting his lines at a crucial point. Tim goes back in time to put things right and the play is a triumph.</p>
<p>Having saved Harry's opening night, Tim tries to call Mary, but discovers that her number is no longer in his mobile phone. By going back in time to help Harry, Tim chose a path in which the evening with Mary never happened. However, he recalls that Mary was obsessed with <a href="/wiki/Kate_Moss" title="Kate Moss">Kate Moss</a>. By attending a Kate Moss exhibition in town, he is able to run into Mary again. He strikes up an acquaintance with her but discovers she now has a boyfriend. Tim finds out when and where they met, turns up early and persuades her to leave the party before she can meet her future boyfriend. Their relationship develops and Tim moves in with Mary. He encounters Charlotte again by accident, and this time she tells him that she would be interested in pursuing a romantic liaison with him. Tim turns her down, realising that he is truly in love with Mary. He proposes marriage; she accepts and is welcomed into his family. Their first child, Posy, is born. Tim's sister, Kit, has not been so lucky and her unhappy relationship, failure to find a career, and drinking lead her to crash her car on the same day as Posy's first birthday.</p>
<p>Kit is seriously hurt but begins to make a good recovery. Tim decides to intervene in her life and does so by preventing her from meeting her boyfriend, Jimmy (<a href="/wiki/Tom_Hughes_(actor)" title="Tom Hughes (actor)">Tom Hughes</a>). When he returns to the present time, he finds Posy has never been born and that he has a son instead. His father explains that travelling back to change things before his children were born would mean those children would not be born. Thus, any events that occurred before Posy's birth cannot be changed, and Tim must accept the consequences as a normal person would. Tim accepts he cannot change Kit's life by changing her past but he and Mary help her to change her life in the present. She settles down with an old friend of Tim's and has a child of her own. Tim and Mary have another child, a boy named Jeff.</p>
<p>Tim learns that his father has terminal cancer and that time travel cannot change it. His father has known for quite some time, but kept travelling back in time to effectively extend his life and spend more time with his family. He tells Tim to live each day twice in order to be truly happy: the first time, live it as normal, and the second time, live every day again almost exactly the same. The first time with all the tensions and worries that stop us noticing how sweet the world can be, but the second time noticing. Tim follows this advice and also travels back into the past to visit his father whenever he misses him.</p>
<p>Mary tells Tim she wants a third child. He is reluctant at first because he will not be able to visit his father after the baby is born but agrees. After visiting his father for the following nine months, Tim tells his father that he cannot visit any more. They travel back to when Tim was a small boy, reliving a fond memory of them playing on the beach, and after have a heartfelt, tearful goodbye. Mary gives birth to another baby girl, Jo, and Tim knows he can never see his father again. After reliving each day, Tim comes to realise that it is better to live each day once, and appreciate everything as if he is living it for the second time. The film ends with Tim leaving Mary in bed and getting his three children ready for school.</p>
<p><span id="Casting"></span> <a href="/wiki/Zooey_Deschanel" title="Zooey Deschanel">Zooey Deschanel</a> had been in talks for the role of Mary but ultimately the role went to McAdams.<sup id="cite_ref-g2012_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-g2012-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Richard_Griffiths" title="Richard Griffiths">Richard Griffiths</a> also plays a brief part in what would be his final film appearance, with the film being released months after his death in March of 2013.</p>
<p>Curtis has said this is likely to be his last film as director, but that he will continue in the film industry.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><span id="Release"></span> The film was initially scheduled to be released on 10 May 2013, release was pushed back to 1 November 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-release-date_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-release-date-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> The film premiered on 8 August 2013 as part of the Film4 Summer Screen outdoor cinema series at London's historic <a href="/wiki/Somerset_House" title="Somerset House">Somerset House</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup> It was released in the UK on 4 September 2013 and in the US in limited release on 1 November 2013 and in wide release on 8 November 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>"About Time" received mixed to positive reviews from critics. Review aggregation website <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> gives the film a score of 70% based on reviews from 138 critics, with an average rating of 6.4/10. The site's Audience Score is 4/5, based upon 54,832 ratings with 81% of the raters liking the film. <sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>, which uses a <a href="/wiki/Weighted_mean" title="Weighted mean" class="mw-redirect">weighted mean</a>, assigned a score of 55/100, based on reviews from 34 film critics.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup> Based on responses from 78,018 users, <i>About Time</i> received a rating of 7.8/10 on the <a href="/wiki/Internet_Movie_Database" title="Internet Movie Database">Internet Movie Database</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Catherine Shoard of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i> compares the film to <a href="/wiki/Groundhog_Day_(film)" title="Groundhog Day (film)"><i>Groundhog Day</i></a> noting it "is about as close to home as a homage can get without calling in the copyright team" and describes Domhnall Gleeson as a "ginger <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Grant" title="Hugh Grant">Hugh Grant</a>", which "at first, is unnerving; as <i>About Time</i> marches on, Gleeson's innate charm gleams through and this weird disconnection becomes quite compelling." Shoard gives the film 2 stars out of 5.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup> Robbie Collin of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph" title="The Daily Telegraph">The Daily Telegraph</a></i> praises the comic timing of McAdams and Gleeson, but criticises the film, comparing it to a quilt, calling it "soft, frayed at the edges, and oh so comfortable" and gives it a score of 3 stars out of 5.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Leslie Felperin of <i>Variety</i> magazine calls the film "reassuringly bland" and says there is sense of <a href="/wiki/D%C3%A9j%C3%A0_vu" title="Dj vu">dj vu</a> especially for anyone who has seen <i><a href="/wiki/The_Time_Traveler%27s_Wife_(film)" title="The Time Traveler's Wife (film)">The Time Traveler's Wife</a></i> also co-starring McAdams. Unlike that film she has no knowledge of his powers, resulting in a "fundamental lack of honesty in their relationship". Felperin notes British reverse snobbery would put many off this and other Curtis films but that is less of a problem among American Anglophiles and those willing to suspend disbelief, taking the characters as British "versions of <a href="/wiki/Woody_Allen" title="Woody Allen">Woody Allen</a>s Manhattanites (but with less angst)". Felperin praises the chemistry of the leading couple "that keeps the film aloft" and the supporting cast, while also criticising the stock characters as being too familiar.<sup id="cite_ref-variety-review_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-variety-review-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film became a surprise hit in <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a>, where it was watched by more than 3 million people, one of the highest numbers among the foreign romantic comedy movies released in Korea.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> It grossed the total of $23,434,443, which is the highest figure compared to the other countries.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Critic <a href="/wiki/Mark_Kermode" title="Mark Kermode">Mark Kermode</a> observes that writer Curtis "sets up his rules of temporal engagement, only to break them willy-nilly whenever the prospect of an extra hug rears its head".<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Critic Megan Gibson writes that the main rules as explained to Tim by his father are violated:<sup id="cite_ref-entertainment.time.com_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-entertainment.time.com-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film's internal logic about time travel was also criticised in other reviews:</p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Life Is Beautiful</i></h1>
<p><i><b>Life Is Beautiful</b></i> (<a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">Italian</a>: <span lang="it"><i>La vita  bella</i></span> <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA_for_Italian" title="Help:IPA for Italian">[la vita  bblla]</a></span>) is a 1997 Italian <a href="/wiki/Tragicomedy" title="Tragicomedy">tragicomic</a> <a href="/wiki/Comedy-drama" title="Comedy-drama">comedy-drama</a> film directed by and starring <a href="/wiki/Roberto_Benigni" title="Roberto Benigni">Roberto Benigni</a>, who co-wrote the film with <a href="/wiki/Vincenzo_Cerami" title="Vincenzo Cerami">Vincenzo Cerami</a>. Benigni plays Guido Orefice, a <a href="/wiki/Italian_Jews" title="Italian Jews">Jewish Italian</a> book shop owner, who must employ his fertile imagination to shield his son from the horrors of internment in a <a href="/wiki/Nazi_concentration_camp" title="Nazi concentration camp" class="mw-redirect">Nazi concentration camp</a>. Part of the film came from Benigni's own family history; before Roberto's birth, his father had survived three years of internment at the <a href="/wiki/Bergen-Belsen_concentration_camp" title="Bergen-Belsen concentration camp">Bergen-Belsen concentration camp</a>.</p>
<p>The film was a critical and financial success, winning Benigni the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Actor" title="Academy Award for Best Actor">Academy Award for Best Actor</a> at the <a href="/wiki/71st_Academy_Awards" title="71st Academy Awards">71st Academy Awards</a> as well as the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Score" title="Academy Award for Best Original Score">Academy Award for Best Original Dramatic Score</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Foreign_Language_Film" title="Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film">Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film</a>.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>In 1939 <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">Italy</a>, Guido Orefice is a young Jewish man who is leaving his old life and going to work in the city where his uncle lives. Guido is comical and sharp, making the best from each situation he encounters. From the start he falls in love with a girl Dora. Later he sees her again in the city where she is a teacher. Dora is set to be engaged to a rich but arrogant man. He is a local government official with whom Guido has run-ins from the beginning. Guido is still in love with Dora and performs many stunts in order to see her. Guido sets up many "coincidental" incidents to show his interest. Finally Dora sees Guido's affection and promise and gives in against her better judgement. He steals her from her engagement party on a horse, humiliating her fianc and mother. Soon they are married and have a son, Giosu.</p>
<p>Through the first part, the film depicts the changing political climate in Italy: Guido frequently imitates members of the <a href="/wiki/National_Fascist_Party" title="National Fascist Party">National Fascist Party</a>, skewering their racist logic and pseudoscientific reasoning (at one point, jumping onto a table to demonstrate his "perfect Aryan bellybutton"). However, the growing Fascist wave is also evident: the horse Guido steals Dora away on has been painted green and covered in <a href="/wiki/Antisemitism" title="Antisemitism">antisemitic</a> insults. Later during World War II, after Dora and her mother have reconciled, Guido, his Uncle Eliseo and Giosu are seized on Giosu's birthday. They and many other Jews are forced onto a train and taken to a <a href="/wiki/Concentration_camp" title="Concentration camp" class="mw-redirect">concentration camp</a>. After confronting a guard about her husband and son and being told there is no mistake, Dora volunteers to get on the train in order to be close to her family. However, as men and women are separated in the camp, Dora and Guido never see each other during the internment. Thus, Guido pulls off stunts, such as using the camp's loudspeaker, to send messages, symbolic or literal, to Dora to assure her that he and their son are safe. Eliseo is executed in a gas chamber shortly after their arrival. Giosu barely avoids being gassed himself as he hates to take baths and showers, and did not follow the other children when they had been ordered to enter the gas chambers.</p>
<p>In the camp, Guido hides their true situation from his son. Guido explains to Giosu that the camp is a complicated game in which he must perform the tasks Guido gives him. Giosu is at times reluctant to go along with the game, but Guido convinces him each time to continue on. Guido sets up the concentration camp as a game for Giosu. Each of the tasks will earn them points and whoever gets to one thousand points first will win a tank. He tells him that if he cries, complains that he wants his mother, or says that he is hungry, he will lose points, while quiet boys who hide from the camp guards earn extra points. Guido uses this game to explain features of the concentration camp that would otherwise be frightening for a young child: the guards are mean only because they want the tank for themselves; the dwindling numbers of children (who are being killed in gas chambers) are only hiding in order to score more points than Giosu so they can win the game. He puts off Giosu's requests to end the game and return home by convincing him that they are in the lead for the tank, and need only wait a short while before they can return home with their tank. Guido eventually buys additional time by intentionally getting Giosu mixed in with nearby German schoolchildren, and briefly working as a servant for the same kids in order to help keep the other officials from noticing that Giosu is actually Italian.</p>
<p>Despite being surrounded by the misery, sickness, and death at the camp, Giosu does not question this fiction because of his father's convincing performance and his own innocence. Guido maintains this story right until the end when, in the chaos of shutting down the camp as the Allied forces approach, he tells his son to stay in a box until everybody has left, this being the final competition before the tank is his. As the camp is in chaos Guido goes off to find Dora, but while he is out he is caught by a German soldier. An officer makes the decision to execute Guido. Guido is led off by the soldier to be executed. While he is walking to his death, Guido passes by Giosu one last time, still in character and playing the game. The next morning, Giosu emerges from the sweatbox, just as a U.S. Army unit led by a Sherman tank arrives and the camp is liberated. Giosu is elated and is convinced he has won the game and the prize. The captives in the concentration camp also emerge from hiding. The prisoners travel to safety, accompanied by the Americans. While they are traveling, the soldiers allow Giosu to ride on the tank with them. Giosu soon spots Dora in the procession leaving the camp. Giosu and Dora are reunited and are extremely happy to see each other. In the film, Giosu is a young boy; however, both the beginning and ending of the film are narrated by an older Giosu recalling his father's story of sacrifice for his family.</p>
<p><i>Life is Beautiful</i> was shown at the <a href="/wiki/1998_Cannes_Film_Festival" title="1998 Cannes Film Festival">1998 Cannes Film Festival</a>, and went on to win the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Prix_(Cannes_Film_Festival)" title="Grand Prix (Cannes Film Festival)">Grand Prix</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-festival-cannes.com_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-festival-cannes.com-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/71st_Academy_Awards" title="71st Academy Awards">71st Academy Awards</a>, the film won awards for <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Original_Music_Score" title="Academy Award for Original Music Score" class="mw-redirect">Best Music, Original Dramatic Score</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Foreign_Language_Film" title="Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film">Best Foreign Language Film</a>, with Benigni winning <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Actor" title="Academy Award for Best Actor">Best Actor</a> for his role. The film also received Academy Award nominations for <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Directing" title="Academy Award for Directing" class="mw-redirect">Directing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Film_Editing" title="Academy Award for Film Editing" class="mw-redirect">Film Editing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Writing_Original_Screenplay" title="Academy Award for Writing Original Screenplay" class="mw-redirect">Best Original Screenplay</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Best Picture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Life is Beautiful</i> became commercially successful. After Miramax Films released the film on 23 October 1998 in the United States, the film went on to gross $57,563,264 in North America, and $171,600,000 internationally, with a worldwide gross of $229,163,264.<sup id="cite_ref-mojo_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mojo-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> It is the highest grossing movie to be made in Italy, and the second highest grossing foreign language film in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film also received mostly positive reviews, with the film aggregator website <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> giving the film a "Fresh" 80% rating.<sup id="cite_ref-Life_is_Beautiful_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Life_is_Beautiful-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> Despite its acclaim, actor-director Roberto Benigni received criticism for its comedic elements incorporated into the backdrop of the Holocaust. <a href="/wiki/Roger_Ebert" title="Roger Ebert">Roger Ebert</a> gave the film 3 1/2 stars, stating, "At Cannes, it offended some left-wing critics with its use of humor in connection with the Holocaust. What may be most offensive to both wings is its sidestepping of politics in favor of simple human ingenuity. The film finds the right notes to negotiate its delicate subject matter."<sup id="cite_ref-Roger_Ebert_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Roger_Ebert-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The original <a href="/wiki/Film_score" title="Film score">score</a> to the film was composed by <a href="/wiki/Nicola_Piovani" title="Nicola Piovani">Nicola Piovani</a>, with the exception of a classical piece which figures prominently: the "<a href="/wiki/Belle_nuit,_%C3%B4_nuit_d%27amour" title="Belle nuit,  nuit d'amour">Barcarolle</a>" by <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Offenbach" title="Jacques Offenbach">Jacques Offenbach</a>. The soundtrack album won the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Score" title="Academy Award for Best Original Score">Academy Award for Best Original Dramatic Score</a> and was nominated for a <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award" title="Grammy Award">Grammy Award</a>: "Best Instrumental Composition Written for a Motion Picture, Television or Other Visual Media", but lost to the score of <i><a href="/wiki/A_Bug%27s_Life" title="A Bug's Life">A Bug's Life</a></i>.</p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Up</i> (2009 film)</h1>
<p><i><b>Up</b></i> is a 2009 American <a href="/wiki/3D_film" title="3D film">3D</a> <a href="/wiki/Computer-animated" title="Computer-animated" class="mw-redirect">computer-animated</a> comedy adventure<sup id="cite_ref-Cannes2009_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cannes2009-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> film produced by <a href="/wiki/Pixar" title="Pixar">Pixar</a> and released by <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_Pictures" title="Walt Disney Pictures">Walt Disney Pictures</a>. Directed by <a href="/wiki/Pete_Docter" title="Pete Docter">Pete Docter</a>, the film centers on an elderly widower named Carl Fredricksen (<a href="/wiki/Ed_Asner" title="Ed Asner">Ed Asner</a>) and an earnest young <a href="/wiki/Scouting_in_popular_culture" title="Scouting in popular culture">Wilderness Explorer</a> named Russell (<a href="/wiki/Jordan_Nagai" title="Jordan Nagai">Jordan Nagai</a>). By tying thousands of balloons to his home, 78-year-old Carl sets out to fulfill his dream to see the wilds of <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a> and to complete a promise made to his late wife, Ellie. The film was co-directed by <a href="/wiki/Bob_Peterson_(filmmaker)" title="Bob Peterson (filmmaker)">Bob Peterson</a>, with music composed by <a href="/wiki/Michael_Giacchino" title="Michael Giacchino">Michael Giacchino</a>.</p>
<p>Docter began working on the story in 2004, which was based on fantasies of escaping from life when it becomes too irritating. He and eleven other Pixar artists spent three days in <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a> gathering research and inspiration. The designs of the characters were caricatured and stylized considerably, and animators were challenged with creating realistic cloth. The floating house is attached by a varying number between 10,000 and 20,000 balloons in the film's sequences. <i>Up</i> was Pixar's first film to be presented in <a href="/wiki/Disney_Digital_3-D" title="Disney Digital 3-D">Disney Digital 3-D</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Up</i> was released on May 29, 2009 and opened the <a href="/wiki/2009_Cannes_Film_Festival" title="2009 Cannes Film Festival">2009 Cannes Film Festival</a>, becoming the first animated and 3D film to do so.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> The film became a great financial success, accumulating over $731 million in its theatrical release. <i>Up</i> received universal acclaim, with most reviewers commending the humor and heart of the film. Edward Asner was praised for his portrayal of Carl, and a montage of Carl and his wife Ellie aging together was widely lauded. The film received five <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award" title="Academy Award" class="mw-redirect">Academy Award</a> nominations, including <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Best Picture</a>, making it the second animated film in history to receive such a nomination (and Pixar's first Best Picture nomination), following <i><a href="/wiki/Beauty_and_the_Beast_(1991_film)" title="Beauty and the Beast (1991 film)">Beauty and the Beast</a></i> (1991).<sup id="cite_ref-oscar_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oscar-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>Carl Fredricksen is a young 8-year-old boy who idolizes famous explorer Charles Muntz. Muntz has been accused of fabricating the skeleton of a giant exotic bird he says he discovered at <a href="/wiki/Angel_Falls" title="Angel Falls">Paradise Falls</a>, and vows to return there to catch one alive. One day Carl befriends a girl named Ellie, who is also a fan of Muntz. She confides to Carl her desire to move her "clubhouse"an abandoned house in the neighborhoodto a cliff overlooking Paradise Falls. Carl and Ellie eventually get married and live together in the restored house. After suffering a <a href="/wiki/Miscarriage" title="Miscarriage">miscarriage</a><sup id="cite_ref-miscarriage_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-miscarriage-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> and being told they cannot have a child, the two decide to realize their dream of visiting Paradise Falls. They try to save for the trip, but repeatedly end up spending the money on more pressing needs. Finally, an elderly Carl arranges for the trip, but Ellie suddenly becomes ill and dies.</p>
<p>Years later, Carl still lives in the house, stubbornly <a href="/wiki/Holdout_(real_estate)" title="Holdout (real estate)">holding out</a> as the surrounding neighborhood is torn down for new construction, but when he accidentally injures a construction worker over damage to his mailbox, a court orders him to move to a <a href="/wiki/Retirement_home" title="Retirement home">retirement home</a>. However, Carl comes up with a scheme to keep his promise to Ellie, and turns his house into a makeshift <a href="/wiki/Airship" title="Airship">airship</a>, using thousands of helium balloons. Russell, a young Wilderness Explorer, becomes an accidental stowaway in his effort to earn his final <a href="/wiki/Scout_badge" title="Scout badge">merit badge</a> for assisting the elderly.</p>
<p>After surviving a <a href="/wiki/Thunderstorm" title="Thunderstorm">thunderstorm</a>, the flying house lands on a <a href="/wiki/Tepui" title="Tepui">tepui</a> opposite Paradise Falls. Carl and Russell harness themselves to the still-buoyant house and begin to walk it across the mesa, hoping to reach the falls before the balloons deflate. Russell encounters a tall, colorful <a href="/wiki/Flightless_bird" title="Flightless bird">flightless bird</a>, whom he names "Kevin". They then meet a friendly dog named Dug, who wears a special collar that allows him to speak, and who vows to take the bird to his master.</p>
<p>The group is set upon by a <a href="/wiki/Pack_(canine)" title="Pack (canine)">pack</a> of aggressive dogs led by Alphaalso seeking the birdand are taken to their master, who turns out to be an elderly Charles Muntz. Muntz invites Carl and Russell aboard his <a href="/wiki/Dirigible" title="Dirigible" class="mw-redirect">dirigible</a>, where he explains that he has spent years since his disgrace searching for the giant bird. When Russell notes the bird's similarity to Kevin, Muntz becomes hostile, believing they have been attempting to steal the bird. The pair flees with Kevin and Dug, but Muntz catches up with them, captures Kevin and starts a fire beneath Carl's house, forcing him to choose between saving it or Kevin. Carl rushes to put out the fire, allowing Muntz to take the bird. He and Russell eventually reach the falls, though Russell is disappointed in Carl over his decision to abandon Kevin.</p>
<p>Settling into his home, Carl looks through Ellie's childhood scrapbook, and is surprised to find that she has filled in the blank pages with photos of their marriage, along with a note thanking him for the "adventure" and encouraging him to go have a new one. Reinvigorated, he goes to find Russell, only to see him sailing off with some balloons to save Kevin on his own. Carl empties the house of furniture and possessions, lightening it, and pursues him.</p>
<p>Russell is captured by Muntz, but Carl manages to board the dirigible in flight and free both Russell and Kevin. Dug accidentally defeats Alpha and becomes the dogs' new leader. Muntz pursues them around the airship, finally cornering Dug, Kevin, and Russell inside Carl's tethered house. Carl lures Kevin back onto the airship with Dug and Russell clinging to her back, but when Muntz leaps after them, he snags his foot on some balloon lines and falls to his death. The house then descends out of sight through the clouds.</p>
<p>Carl and Russell reunite Kevin with her chicks, then fly the dirigible back to the city. Carl presents Russell with his final badge: a grape soda cap that Ellie gave to Carl when they first met and made their promise. The two then enjoy some ice cream together. Meanwhile, Carl's house has landed on the cliff beside Paradise Falls, fulfilling his promise to Ellie.</p>
<p>Director <a href="/wiki/Pete_Docter" title="Pete Docter">Pete Docter</a> first began writing <i>Up</i> in 2004. The fantasy of a flying house was developed on the idea of escaping from life when it becomes too irritating,<sup id="cite_ref-empire_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-empire-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-scifiwirewondercon_15-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scifiwirewondercon-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup> which stemmed from his difficulty with social situations growing up.<sup id="cite_ref-zone_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zone-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> Actor and writer <a href="/wiki/Tom_McCarthy_(director)" title="Tom McCarthy (director)">Tom McCarthy</a> aided Docter and <a href="/wiki/Bob_Peterson_(filmmaker)" title="Bob Peterson (filmmaker)">Bob Peterson</a> in shaping the story for about three months.<sup id="cite_ref-moviehole_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-moviehole-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup> Docter selected an old man for the main character after drawing a picture of a grumpy old man with smiling balloons.<sup id="cite_ref-moviehole_17-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-moviehole-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup> The two men thought that an old man was a good idea for a protagonist because they felt that their experiences and the way that they affect their view of the world was a rich source of humor. Docter was not concerned with an elderly protagonist, stating that children would relate to Carl in the way that they relate to their grandparents.<sup id="cite_ref-empire_21-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-empire-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Early concepts were very different from the final film. The initial version featured a floating castle with two brothers vying to inherit their father's kingdom, and featured a tall bird similar to the final film, but little else. Docter's next idea introduced many of the elements that eventually made their way into the film, but had Carl and Russell landing the house on a Soviet-era spy airship camouflaged as a giant cloud rather than on a tepui. This concept was rewritten due to its similarity to another idea Pixar was developing. Another idea Docter added, then removed, was magic fountain-of-youth eggs laid by the bird, in order to explain the age discrepancy between Muntz and Carl, but it was decided that this subplot was too distracting, and that people would forgive the minor inconsistency.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Docter noted that the film reflects his friendships with Disney veterans <a href="/wiki/Frank_Thomas_(animator)" title="Frank Thomas (animator)">Frank Thomas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ollie_Johnston" title="Ollie Johnston">Ollie Johnston</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Joe_Grant" title="Joe Grant">Joe Grant</a> (who all died before the film's release and thus the film was dedicated to them). Grant gave the script his approval as well as some advice before his death in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-awn_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-awn-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup> Docter recalled that Grant would remind him that the audience needed an "emotional bedrock" because of how wacky the adventure would become; here it is Carl mourning for his wife.<sup id="cite_ref-moviehole_17-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-moviehole-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup> Docter felt that Grant's personality influenced Carl's deceased wife Ellie more than the grouchy main character,<sup id="cite_ref-awn_26-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-awn-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup> and Carl was primarily based on <a href="/wiki/Spencer_Tracy" title="Spencer Tracy">Spencer Tracy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Walter_Matthau" title="Walter Matthau">Walter Matthau</a>, <a href="/wiki/James_Whitmore" title="James Whitmore">James Whitmore</a>, and their own grandparents, because there was "something sweet about these grumpy old guys".<sup id="cite_ref-exclaim_9-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-exclaim-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-THRQ.26APeteDocter_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-THRQ.26APeteDocter-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup> Docter and Jonas Rivera noted Carl's charming nature in spite of his grumpiness derives from the elderly "hav[ing] this charm and almost this 'old man license' to say things that other people couldn't get away with [...] It's like how we would go to eat with Joe Grant and he would call the waitresses 'honey'. I wish I could call a waitress 'honey'."<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Docter revealed that the filmmakers' first story outline had Carl "just want[ing] to join his wife up in the sky. It was almost a kind of strange suicide mission or something. And obviously that's [a problem]. Once he gets airborne, then what? So we had to have some goal for him to achieve that he had not yet gotten."<sup id="cite_ref-ambitious_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ambitious-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup> As a result, they added the plot of going to South America. The location was chosen due to both Docter's love of tropical locations, but also in wanting a location that Carl could be stuck with a kid due to the inability to leave him with an authority such as a police officer or <a href="/wiki/Social_worker" title="Social worker" class="mw-redirect">social worker</a>. They implemented a child character as a way to help Carl stop being "stuck in his ways".<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Docter created Dug as he felt it would be refreshing to show what a dog thinks, rather than what people assume it thinks.<sup id="cite_ref-dogthoughts_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dogthoughts-30"><span>[</span>30<span>]</span></a></sup> Knowledge of canine communication, body language and pack behaviors for the artists and animators to portray such thoughts came from consultant Dr. <a href="/wiki/Ian_Dunbar" title="Ian Dunbar">Ian Dunbar</a>, veterinarian, dog behaviorist and trainer.<sup id="cite_ref-dogcommunications_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dogcommunications-31"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup> The idea for Alpha's voice derived from thinking about what would happen if someone broke a record player and it always played at a high pitch.<sup id="cite_ref-moviehole_17-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-moviehole-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup> Russell was added to the story at a later date than Dug and Kevin;<sup id="cite_ref-moviehole_17-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-moviehole-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup> his presence, as well as the construction workers, helped to make the story feel less "episodic".<sup id="cite_ref-ambitious_22-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ambitious-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
