<p>Carl's relationship with Russell reflects how "he's not really ready for the whirlwind that a kid is, as few of us are".<sup id="cite_ref-awn_26-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-awn-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup> Docter added he saw <i>Up</i> as a "coming of age" tale and an "unfinished love story", with Carl still dealing with the loss of his wife.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup> He cited inspiration from <i><a href="/wiki/Casablanca_(film)" title="Casablanca (film)">Casablanca</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/A_Christmas_Carol" title="A Christmas Carol">A Christmas Carol</a></i>, which are both "resurrection" stories about men who lose something, and regain purpose during their journey.<sup id="cite_ref-awnhalf_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-awnhalf-33"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup> Docter and Rivera cited inspiration from <a href="/wiki/The_Muppets" title="The Muppets">the Muppets</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hayao_Miyazaki" title="Hayao Miyazaki">Hayao Miyazaki</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Dumbo" title="Dumbo">Dumbo</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Peter_Pan_(1953_film)" title="Peter Pan (1953 film)">Peter Pan</a></i>. They also saw parallels to <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wizard_of_Oz_(adaptations)" title="The Wizard of Oz (adaptations)" class="mw-redirect">The Wizard of Oz</a></i> and tried to make <i>Up</i> not feel too similar.<sup id="cite_ref-cinematicalnycc_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cinematicalnycc-34"><span>[</span>34<span>]</span></a></sup> There is a scene where Carl and Russell haul the floating house through the jungle. A Pixar employee compared the scene to <i><a href="/wiki/Fitzcarraldo" title="Fitzcarraldo">Fitzcarraldo</a></i>, and Docter watched that film and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Mission_(1986_film)" title="The Mission (1986 film)">The Mission</a></i> for further inspiration.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35"><span>[</span>35<span>]</span></a></sup> The character Charles Muntz comes from <a href="/wiki/Howard_Hughes" title="Howard Hughes">Howard Hughes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Errol_Flynn" title="Errol Flynn">Errol Flynn</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Docter made <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a> the film's setting after <a href="/wiki/Ralph_Eggleston" title="Ralph Eggleston">Ralph Eggleston</a> gave him a video of the <a href="/wiki/Tepui" title="Tepui">tepui</a> mountains;<sup id="cite_ref-empire_21-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-empire-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-awn_26-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-awn-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup> Venezuela and tepuis were already featured in a previous Disney film, <i><a href="/wiki/Dinosaur_(film)" title="Dinosaur (film)">Dinosaur</a></i>. In 2004, Docter and eleven other Pixar artists spent three days reaching <a href="/wiki/Monte_Roraima" title="Monte Roraima" class="mw-redirect">Monte Roraima</a> by airplane, jeep, and helicopter.<sup id="cite_ref-notes_20-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-notes-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup> They spent three nights there painting and sketching,<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup> and encountering ants, mosquitoes, scorpions, frogs, and snakes. They also flew to <a href="/wiki/Matawi_Tepui" title="Matawi Tepui" class="mw-redirect">Matawi Tepui</a> and climbed to <a href="/wiki/Angel_Falls" title="Angel Falls">Angel Falls</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-notes_20-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-notes-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup> Docter felt "we couldn't use [the rocks and plants we saw]. Reality is so far out, if we put it in the movie you wouldn't believe it."<sup id="cite_ref-exclaim_9-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-exclaim-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> The film's creatures were also challenging to design because they had to fit in the surreal environment of the tepuis, but also be realistic because those mountains exist in real life.<sup id="cite_ref-awn_26-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-awn-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup> The filmmakers visited <a href="/wiki/Sacramento_Zoo" title="Sacramento Zoo">Sacramento Zoo</a> to observe a <a href="/wiki/Himalayan_monal" title="Himalayan monal">Himalayan monal</a> for Kevin's animation.<sup id="cite_ref-wallstreet_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wallstreet-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> The animators designed Russell as an Asian-American, and modeled Russell after similar looking <a href="/wiki/Peter_Sohn" title="Peter Sohn">Peter Sohn</a>, a Pixar storyboarder who voiced Emile in <i><a href="/wiki/Ratatouille_(film)" title="Ratatouille (film)">Ratatouille</a></i> and directed the short <i><a href="/wiki/Partly_Cloudy" title="Partly Cloudy">Partly Cloudy</a></i>, because of his energetic nature.<sup id="cite_ref-scifiwirewondercon_15-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scifiwirewondercon-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span>[</span>38<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>While Pixar usually designs their characters to be caricatured, Carl was even more so, being only three heads high.<sup id="cite_ref-interview1_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-interview1-39"><span>[</span>39<span>]</span></a></sup> He was not given elderly features such as liver spots or hair in his ears to keep him appealing, yet giving him wrinkles, pockmarks on his nose, a hearing aid, and a cane to make him appear elderly. Docter wanted to push a stylized feel, particularly the way Carl's head is proportioned: he has a squarish appearance to symbolize his containment within his house, while Russell is rounded like a balloon.<sup id="cite_ref-time_10-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-time-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> The challenge on <i>Up</i> was making these stylized characters feel natural,<sup id="cite_ref-empire_21-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-empire-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup> although Docter remarked the effect came across better than animating the realistic humans from <i><a href="/wiki/Toy_Story" title="Toy Story">Toy Story</a></i>, who suffered from the "<a href="/wiki/Uncanny_valley" title="Uncanny valley">uncanny valley</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-awn_26-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-awn-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup> Cartoonists <a href="/wiki/Al_Hirschfeld" title="Al Hirschfeld">Al Hirschfeld</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hank_Ketcham" title="Hank Ketcham">Hank Ketcham</a>, and <a href="/wiki/George_Booth_(cartoonist)" title="George Booth (cartoonist)">George Booth</a> influenced the human designs.<sup id="cite_ref-moviehole_17-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-moviehole-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-awnhalf_33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-awnhalf-33"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-cssneak_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cssneak-40"><span>[</span>40<span>]</span></a></sup> Simulating realistic cloth on caricatured humans was harder than creating the 10,000 balloons flying the house.<sup id="cite_ref-zone_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zone-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> New programs were made to simulate the cloth and for Kevin's <a href="/wiki/Iridescence" title="Iridescence">iridescent</a> feathers.<sup id="cite_ref-female_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-female-41"><span>[</span>41<span>]</span></a></sup> To animate old people, Pixar animators would study their own parents or grandparents and also watched footage of the <a href="/wiki/Senior_Olympics" title="Senior Olympics">Senior Olympics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-slashvid_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-slashvid-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup> The directors had various rules for Carl's movements: he could not turn his head more than 1520degrees without turning his torso as well, nor could he raise his arms high. However, they also wanted him to grow more flexible near the end of the film, transforming into an "action hero".</p>
<p>A technical director worked out that to make Carl's house fly, he would require 23million balloons, but Docter realized that number made the balloons look like small dots. Instead, the balloons created were made to be twice Carl's size. There are 10,927balloons for shots of the house just flying, 20,622balloons for the lift-off sequence, and a varying number in other scenes.<sup id="cite_ref-notes_20-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-notes-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Up</i> is the third Pixar film to be scored by <a href="/wiki/Michael_Giacchino" title="Michael Giacchino">Michael Giacchino</a>, after <i><a href="/wiki/The_Incredibles" title="The Incredibles">The Incredibles</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Ratatouille_(film)" title="Ratatouille (film)">Ratatouille</a></i>. What Pete Docter wanted more importantly out of the music was the emotion, so Giacchino wrote a character theme-based score that producer Jonas Rivera thought enhanced the story. At the beginning of the movie, when young Carl is in the movie theater watching a newsreel about Muntz, the first piece of music heard is "Muntz's Theme", which starts out as a celebratory theme, and echoes through the film when Muntz reappears 70years later. "Ellie's Theme" is first heard when she is introduced as a little kid and plays several times during the film in different versions; for instance, during the sequence where Carl lifts his house with the balloons, the theme is changed from a simple piano melody to a full orchestral arrangement. Giacchino has compared the film to opera since each character has a unique theme that <a href="/wiki/Thematic_transformation" title="Thematic transformation">changes</a> during a particular moment in the story.<sup id="cite_ref-allm_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-allm-42"><span>[</span>42<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The score was released as a digital download on May 26, 2009, three days before the film opened in theaters. It won the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Score" title="Academy Award for Best Original Score">Academy Award for Best Original Score</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-academy_awards_n.26w_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-academy_awards_n.26w-43"><span>[</span>43<span>]</span></a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Score_Soundtrack_for_Visual_Media" title="Grammy Award for Best Score Soundtrack for Visual Media">Grammy Award for Best Score Soundtrack Album</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-gram1_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gram1-44"><span>[</span>44<span>]</span></a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Original_Score" title="Golden Globe Award for Best Original Score">Golden Globe Award for Best Original Score</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-ew1_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ew1-45"><span>[</span>45<span>]</span></a></sup> and the 2010 <a href="/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Film_Music" title="BAFTA Award for Best Film Music">BAFTA Award for Best Film Music</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bafta_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bafta-46"><span>[</span>46<span>]</span></a></sup> It is the first score for a Pixar film to win the Oscar (<a href="/wiki/Randy_Newman" title="Randy Newman">Randy Newman</a> also won for <i><a href="/wiki/Monsters,_Inc." title="Monsters, Inc.">Monsters, Inc.</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Toy_Story_3" title="Toy Story 3">Toy Story 3</a></i>, but in the category of <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Song" title="Academy Award for Best Original Song">Best Original Song</a>).</p>
<p>When the film screened at the <a href="/wiki/El_Capitan_Theatre" title="El Capitan Theatre">El Capitan Theatre</a> in Hollywood, California from May 29 to July 23, 2009, it was accompanied by <i>Lighten Up!</i>, a live show featuring Disney characters.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span>[</span>47<span>]</span></a></sup> Other tie-ins included children's books such as <i>My Name is Dug</i>, illustrated by screenwriter <a href="/wiki/Ronnie_del_Carmen" title="Ronnie del Carmen">Ronnie del Carmen</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48"><span>[</span>48<span>]</span></a></sup> Despite Pixar's track record, <a href="/wiki/Target_Corporation" title="Target Corporation">Target Corporation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Walmart" title="Walmart">Walmart</a> stocked few <i>Up</i> items, while Pixar's regular collaborator Thinkway Toys did not produce merchandise, claiming its story is unusual and would be hard to promote. Disney acknowledged not every Pixar film would have to become a franchise.<sup id="cite_ref-wallstreet_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wallstreet-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Promotional partners include <a href="/wiki/Aflac" title="Aflac">Aflac</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49"><span>[</span>49<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/NASCAR" title="NASCAR">NASCAR</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Airship_Ventures" title="Airship Ventures">Airship Ventures</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50"><span>[</span>50<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span>[</span>51<span>]</span></a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Cluster_ballooning" title="Cluster ballooning">Cluster Balloons</a> promoted the film with a replica of Carl's couch lifted by hot air balloons for journalists to sit in.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52"><span>[</span>52<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Before the film's worldwide release date, Pixar granted a wish from 10-year-old Colby Curtin to see the film before she died. Colby had been diagnosed with cancer and was too sick to go to a theater. A Pixar employee flew to the Curtin's house with a DVD of the finished film and screened it for her and her family. Curtin died seven hours later at 9:20 pm, shortly after seeing the film.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53"><span>[</span>53<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Director <a href="/wiki/Pete_Docter" title="Pete Docter">Pete Docter</a> intended for audiences to take a specific point from the film, saying:</p>
<p>Basically, the message of the film is that the real adventure of life is the relationship we have with other people, and it's so easy to lose sight of the things we have and the people that are around us until they are gone. More often than not, I don't really realize how lucky I was to have known someone until they're either moved or passed away. So, if you can kind of wake up a little bit and go, "Wow, I've got some really cool stuff around me every day", then that's what the movie's about.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54"><span>[</span>54<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Before its theatrical release, DisneyPixar created three small animated vignettes called <i>UPisodes</i> to promote its film <i>UP</i> on the internet.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55"><span>[</span>55<span>]</span></a></sup> These <i>UPisodes</i> chronicled Carl Fredricksen and Russell's journey through the jungle, not seen in the movie. Fans were able to view the vignettes on <a href="/wiki/Apple_iTunes" title="Apple iTunes" class="mw-redirect">Apple iTunes</a> movie trailer site and YouTube.</p>
<p><i>Up</i> was released on <a href="/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc" title="Blu-ray Disc" class="mw-redirect">Blu-ray Disc</a> and DVD in North America on November 10, 2009,<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span>[</span>56<span>]</span></a></sup> and in the United Kingdom on February 15, 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57"><span>[</span>57<span>]</span></a></sup> It features the film plus the theatrical short <i><a href="/wiki/Partly_Cloudy" title="Partly Cloudy">Partly Cloudy</a></i> and the new short <i><a href="/wiki/Dug%27s_Special_Mission" title="Dug's Special Mission">Dug's Special Mission</a></i>, as well as an audio commentary by director Pete Docter, <i>Adventure is Out There</i> a documentary about the filmmakers' research journey to South America, <i>The Many Endings of Muntz</i> (an alternate ending of sorts), and a digital copy. The Blu-ray edition has a four-disc pack that adds Cine-Explore with BonusView, Global Guardian Badge and Geography games, eight documentaries, and BD-Live to the Deluxe DVD and digital copy platters. A Limited Edition, known as the <i>Luxo Jr. Premium Pack</i>, includes a collectible lamp modeled after Pixar's bouncy short star that is designed to hold a complete Pixar Blu-ray collection.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58"><span>[</span>58<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In addition, Pixar also created a short film titled <i><a href="/wiki/George_%26_A.J." title="George &amp; A.J.">George &amp; A.J.</a></i>, written and directed by storyboard artist <a href="/wiki/Josh_Cooley" title="Josh Cooley">Josh Cooley</a>. This shows what the two Shady Oaks retirement home workers did after Carl left with his house. It was initially available for purchase at the <a href="/wiki/ITunes_Store" title="ITunes Store">iTunes Store</a>, and then was later posted to DisneyPixar's Facebook and YouTube pages.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span>[</span>59<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60"><span>[</span>60<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In its first week, it sold 3,969,792 units ($66,057,339) and eventually reached 10,811,453 units ($182,591,149),<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61"><span>[</span>61<span>]</span></a></sup> becoming the best-selling DVD among those released in 2009 in units sold. It also became the third in sales revenue behind <i><a href="/wiki/Transformers:_Revenge_of_the_Fallen" title="Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen">Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Twilight_(2008_film)" title="Twilight (2008 film)">Twilight</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62"><span>[</span>62<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The rental release of the film to Netflix, Blockbuster, and Redbox was controversial since it failed to include closed captioning.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63"><span>[</span>63<span>]</span></a></sup> Disney faced a consumer backlash over this<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64"><span>[</span>64<span>]</span></a></sup> and quickly released a statement that this removal was an unfortunate error and that it was moving to correct the issue.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65"><span>[</span>65<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Up</i> earned $293,004,164 in the United States and Canada, and $438,338,580 in other territories, for a worldwide total of $731,342,744.<sup id="cite_ref-BOM_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BOM-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> Worldwide, it is the sixth highest-grossing film of 2009,<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66"><span>[</span>66<span>]</span></a></sup> the fourth highest-grossing Pixar film,<sup id="cite_ref-pixar_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pixar-67"><span>[</span>67<span>]</span></a></sup> the 55th highest-grossing film, and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_animated_films" title="List of highest-grossing animated films">15th highest-grossing animated film</a>.</p>
<p>In the United States and Canada, <i>Up</i> is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_films_in_Canada_and_the_United_States" title="List of highest-grossing films in Canada and the United States">59th highest-grossing film</a> before inflation, the tenth highest-grossing Disney film,<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68"><span>[</span>68<span>]</span></a></sup> the seventh highest-grossing 3-D film,<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69"><span>[</span>69<span>]</span></a></sup> the sixth highest-grossing animated film,<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70"><span>[</span>70<span>]</span></a></sup> the fifth highest-grossing film of 2009,<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71"><span>[</span>71<span>]</span></a></sup> and the fourth highest-grossing Pixar film.<sup id="cite_ref-pixar_67-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pixar-67"><span>[</span>67<span>]</span></a></sup> On its opening weekend, it performed stronger than analysts had been expecting, ranking number one with $68,108,790.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72"><span>[</span>72<span>]</span></a></sup> This is the fourth highest-grossing opening for Pixar<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73"><span>[</span>73<span>]</span></a></sup> and the third largest post-Memorial Day opening. It set a record for opening weekend grosses originating from 3-D showings with $35.4 million (first surpassed by <i><a href="/wiki/Avatar_(2009_film)" title="Avatar (2009 film)">Avatar</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74"><span>[</span>74<span>]</span></a></sup> The opening weekend audience was 53% female and 47% under 17 years old.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75"><span>[</span>75<span>]</span></a></sup> The film experienced small drop-offs on subsequent weekends, but lost first place to <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hangover" title="The Hangover">The Hangover</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76"><span>[</span>76<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77"><span>[</span>77<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Outside the US and Canada, it is the 43rd highest-grossing film,<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78"><span>[</span>78<span>]</span></a></sup> the tenth highest-grossing animated film, the fifth highest-grossing film of 2009,<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79"><span>[</span>79<span>]</span></a></sup> and the third highest-grossing Pixar film.<sup id="cite_ref-pixar_67-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pixar-67"><span>[</span>67<span>]</span></a></sup> It was on top of the overseas box office for three consecutive weekends and four in total.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80"><span>[</span>80<span>]</span></a></sup> Its highest-grossing opening weekends were recorded in France and the Maghreb region ($8.88 million), the UK, Ireland and Malta, ($8.44 million) and Japan ($7.24 million). These three were also its highest-grossing countries in total earnings.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81"><span>[</span>81<span>]</span></a></sup> Among major countries, it was the highest-grossing animated film of 2009 only in Spain ($37.1 million),<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82"><span>[</span>82<span>]</span></a></sup> Australia ($25.3 million)<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83"><span>[</span>83<span>]</span></a></sup> and South Korea ($6.32 million).<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84"><span>[</span>84<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Up</i> received universal critical acclaim. <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> reports that 98% of critics have given the film a "Certified Fresh" positive review, based on 281reviews, with an 8.7/10 review average. The site's consensus states: "Another masterful work of art from Pixar, <i>Up</i> is an exciting, hilarious, and heartfelt adventure impeccably crafted and told with wit and depth."<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85"><span>[</span>85<span>]</span></a></sup> The film also holds a score of 88 on the review aggregator website <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86"><span>[</span>86<span>]</span></a></sup> Audiences gave the film an "A+" CinemaScore.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87"><span>[</span>87<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Film critic <a href="/wiki/Roger_Ebert" title="Roger Ebert">Roger Ebert</a> gave the film four out of four stars and called it "a wonderful film."<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88"><span>[</span>88<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89"><span>[</span>89<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter" title="The Hollywood Reporter">The Hollywood Reporter</a></i> lauded the film as "Winsome, touching and arguably the funniest Pixar effort ever, this gorgeously rendered, high-flying adventure is a tidy 90-minute distillation of all the signature touches that came before it."<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90"><span>[</span>90<span>]</span></a></sup> Although the <i><a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Chronicle" title="San Francisco Chronicle">San Francisco Chronicle</a></i> noted that the film "contains many boring stretches of mindless freneticism and bland character interaction," it also declared that there are scenes in <i>Up</i> of "such beauty, economy and poetic wisdom that they belong in any anthology of great movie moments...to watch <i>Up</i> with any attention is to be moved and astonished by the economy with which specific visuals are invested with emotion throughout [the film]..."<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91"><span>[</span>91<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Variety_(magazine)" title="Variety (magazine)">Variety</a></i> enthused that "<i>Up</i> is an exceptionally refined picture; unlike so many animated films, it's not all about sensory bombardment and volume...Unsurprisingly, no one puts a foot wrong here. Vocal performances...exude a warm enthusiasm, and tech specifications could not be better. Michel Giacchino's full-bodied, traditional score is superlative..."<sup id="cite_ref-variety-festivals_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-variety-festivals-92"><span>[</span>92<span>]</span></a></sup> The Globe claimed that <i>Up</i> is "the kind of movie that leaves you asking 'How do people come up with this stuff?'" along with an overall positive review on the film, despite it being predictable.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93"><span>[</span>93<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The character of Carl Fredricksen has received mostly positive reception. Bill Capodagli, author of <i>Innovate the Pixar Way</i>, praised Carl for his ability to be a jerk and likable at the same time.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94"><span>[</span>94<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Wall_Street_Journal" title="Wall Street Journal" class="mw-redirect">Wall Street Journal</a></i> editor Joe Morgenstern described Carl as gruff, comparing him to <a href="/wiki/Buster_Keaton" title="Buster Keaton">Buster Keaton</a>, but adds that this begins to wear thin as the movie progresses.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95"><span>[</span>95<span>]</span></a></sup> He has been compared with <a href="/wiki/Spencer_Tracy" title="Spencer Tracy">Spencer Tracy</a>, an influence on the character, by <i><a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Post" title="The Washington Post">The Washington Post</a></i> editor Ann Hornaday<sup id="cite_ref-washingtonpost_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-washingtonpost-96"><span>[</span>96<span>]</span></a></sup> and <i><a href="/wiki/Empire_Online" title="Empire Online" class="mw-redirect">Empire Online</a></i> editor Ian Freer, who describes him as similar to a "<i><a href="/wiki/Guess_Who%27s_Coming_to_Dinner" title="Guess Who's Coming to Dinner">Guess Who's Coming to Dinner</a></i>-era" Tracy.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97"><span>[</span>97<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly" title="Entertainment Weekly">Entertainment Weekly</a></i> editor Lisa Schwarzbaum described his appearance as a cross between Tracy and an eccentric out of a <a href="/wiki/George_Booth_(cartoonist)" title="George Booth (cartoonist)">George Booth</a> cartoon.<sup id="cite_ref-ew_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ew-98"><span>[</span>98<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>TIME</i> editor <a href="/wiki/Richard_Corliss" title="Richard Corliss">Richard Corliss</a> also makes the comparison, calling him a "trash compacted version" of Tracy.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2-time_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-time-99"><span>[</span>99<span>]</span></a></sup> He has also been compared to <a href="/wiki/Walter_Matthau" title="Walter Matthau">Walter Matthau</a>, another inspiration for the character's design, by <i><a href="/wiki/LA_Weekly" title="LA Weekly">LA Weekly</a></i> editor Scott Foundas, suggesting that actor <a href="/wiki/Ed_Asner" title="Ed Asner">Ed Asner</a> was channeling him while performing the role of Carl.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100"><span>[</span>100<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Variety_(magazine)" title="Variety (magazine)">Variety</a></i> editor Todd McCarthy described Carl as a combination of both Tracy and Matthau.<sup id="cite_ref-variety-festivals_92-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-variety-festivals-92"><span>[</span>92<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The relationship between Carl and his wife Ellie has been praised in several media outlets. In his book <i>Disney, Pixar, and the Hidden Message of Children's Films</i>, author M. Keith Booker described the love between Carl and Ellie as touching. While also describing the scene of the two of them aging as a "masterpiece of its own kind," he was not sure how much children would appreciate the scene, commenting that his son was squirming in his seat during the scene.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101"><span>[</span>101<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>Reelviews</i> editor James Berardinelli praised their relationship, stating that it brought a tear to his eye in a way no animated film has done, including anything by famed <a href="/wiki/Anime" title="Anime">anime</a> director <a href="/wiki/Hayao_Miyazaki" title="Hayao Miyazaki">Hayao Miyazaki</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102"><span>[</span>102<span>]</span></a></sup> Ann Hornaday praised the prologue, describing it as "worthy of Chaplin in its heartbreaking poignancy."<sup id="cite_ref-washingtonpost_96-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-washingtonpost-96"><span>[</span>96<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Chicago_Tribune" title="Chicago Tribune">Chicago Tribune</a></i> editor Michael Phillips praised the scene, describing it as an emotional and cinematic powerhouse, and that he also was nearly moved to tears. However, <i><a href="/wiki/Salon.com" title="Salon.com" class="mw-redirect">Salon.com</a></i> editor Stephanie Zacharek criticized the love between Carl and Ellie, describing their marriage as resembling a dental adhesive commercial more than a real relationship.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103"><span>[</span>103<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Edward Asner was praised in several media outlets for his portrayal of Carl. <i><a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Chronicle" title="San Francisco Chronicle">San Francisco Chronicle</a></i> editor Mick LaSalle praised Asner as a great choice due to having a grumpiness to his voice that is not truly grumpy, but rather coming from a protective stance.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104"><span>[</span>104<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly" title="Entertainment Weekly">Entertainment Weekly</a></i> editor Lisa Schwarzbaum praised Asner's acting, stating that he has a "<a href="/wiki/Lou_Grant" title="Lou Grant">Lou Grant</a> authority" to his voice.<sup id="cite_ref-ew_98-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ew-98"><span>[</span>98<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>Time</i> editor Richard Corliss stated that Asner had the "gruffness and deadpan comic timing to bring Carl to life."<sup id="cite_ref-time_10-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-time-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Boston_Globe" title="The Boston Globe">The Boston Globe</a></i> editor Ty Burr concurred with this, stating that his Lou Grant-like voice had not diminished with time.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105"><span>[</span>105<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/USA_Today" title="USA Today">USA Today</a></i> editor Claudia Puig praised Asner's delivery, describing it as superb.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106"><span>[</span>106<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The formulation of Russell as an Asian American character, along with the casting of an Asian American in the role was met positively as well. Both Nagai and the film were awarded by the <a href="/wiki/East_West_Players" title="East West Players">East West Players</a> for the depiction of Russell.<sup id="cite_ref-EWP_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EWP-107"><span>[</span>107<span>]</span></a></sup> EWP lauded Pixar for the creation of the character, stating, "We are proud to honor a very progressive film company like Pixar who cast an Asian American character alongside an elderly one to play the leads in a feature film."<sup id="cite_ref-EWP_107-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EWP-107"><span>[</span>107<span>]</span></a></sup> The character is noted as Pixar's first lead Asian character,<sup id="cite_ref-AW_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AW-108"><span>[</span>108<span>]</span></a></sup> and was further positively received within the added context of historical non-Asian castings for Asian roles in entertainment.<sup id="cite_ref-APA_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-APA-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AW_108-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AW-108"><span>[</span>108<span>]</span></a></sup> Asian American organizations and entertainment websites, such as media watchdog Media Action Network for Asian Americans (MANAA), Racebending.com, and <a href="/wiki/Angry_Asian_Man" title="Angry Asian Man">Angry Asian Man</a> praised the character and Pixar for its diverse character depictions, noting the general lack of Asian American lead characters and Asian actors cast in entertainment.<sup id="cite_ref-MANAA_109-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MANAA-109"><span>[</span>109<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AAM_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AAM-110"><span>[</span>110<span>]</span></a></sup> In an interview with <a href="/wiki/NPR" title="NPR">NPR</a> in 2013, <i><a href="/wiki/Angry_Asian_Man" title="Angry Asian Man">Angry Asian Man</a>'</i>s Phil Yu reflected on the character's lack of typical Asian stereotyping, stating, "You know, he just happens to be Asian and he's, you know, really adorable character. But that kid could've been of any ethnicity but they made the effort to make him Asian - just a little color, you know, and it's really wonderful when that kind of thing happens where they don't have to play that up and make it like a thing or a joke, which happens a lot."<sup id="cite_ref-NPR_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NPR-111"><span>[</span>111<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><span id="Awards"></span></p>
<p><i>Up</i> won two awards at the <a href="/wiki/82nd_Academy_Awards" title="82nd Academy Awards">82nd Academy Awards</a>, for <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Animated_Feature" title="Academy Award for Best Animated Feature">Best Animated Feature</a> and <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Score" title="Academy Award for Best Original Score">Best Original Score</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2-oscars_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-oscars-112"><span>[</span>112<span>]</span></a></sup> It is the second of three animated features to have been nominated for the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Academy Award for Best Picture</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Beauty_and_the_Beast_(1991_film)" title="Beauty and the Beast (1991 film)">Beauty and the Beast</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Toy_Story_3" title="Toy Story 3">Toy Story 3</a></i> were also nominated for Best Picture in their respective years. <i>Up</i> also won <a href="/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Original_Score" title="Golden Globe Award for Best Original Score">Best Original Score</a> and <a href="/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Animated_Feature_Film" title="Golden Globe Award for Best Animated Feature Film">Best Animated Feature Film</a> at the <a href="/wiki/67th_Golden_Globe_Awards" title="67th Golden Globe Awards">67th Golden Globe Awards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-113"><span>[</span>113<span>]</span></a></sup> It was nominated for nine <a href="/wiki/Annie_Awards" title="Annie Awards" class="mw-redirect">Annie Awards</a> in eight categories, winning two awards for "Best Animated Feature" and "Best Directing in a Feature Production".<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114"><span>[</span>114<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>Up</i> also received the <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Golden Tomato</a> from <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> for highest rating feature in 2009, and best reviewed animated film,<sup id="cite_ref-gold_tom_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gold_tom-115"><span>[</span>115<span>]</span></a></sup> with an approval of 98percent from film critics, based on 259 reviews.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116"><span>[</span>116<span>]</span></a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/2010_Kids%27_Choice_Awards" title="2010 Kids' Choice Awards">2010 Kids' Choice Awards</a> the film won Favorite Animated Movie.<sup id="cite_ref-kids_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kids-117"><span>[</span>117<span>]</span></a></sup> Jordan Nagai was awarded the Breakout Performance Award at the 44th East West Players 44th Anniversary Visionary Awards and Silent Auction for his role as Russell by the <a href="/wiki/East_West_Players" title="East West Players">East West Players</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-EWP_107-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EWP-107"><span>[</span>107<span>]</span></a></sup> The organization also awarded the film with the EWP Visionary Award for its progressive casting of an Asian American lead.<sup id="cite_ref-EWP_107-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EWP-107"><span>[</span>107<span>]</span></a></sup> Dug, the talking canine, was awarded the <a href="/wiki/Palm_Dog_Award" title="Palm Dog Award">Palm Dog Award</a> by the British film critics as the best canine performance at Cannes Film Festival, winning over the fox from <i><a href="/wiki/Antichrist_(film)" title="Antichrist (film)">Antichrist</a></i> and the black poodle from <i><a href="/wiki/Inglourious_Basterds" title="Inglourious Basterds">Inglourious Basterds</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118"><span>[</span>118<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On May 26, 2009, a video game by the same name themed around the movie was released for multiple platforms.</p>
<p>A video game, <i><a href="/wiki/Kinect_Rush:_A_Disney-Pixar_Adventure" title="Kinect Rush: A Disney-Pixar Adventure">Kinect Rush: A Disney-Pixar Adventure</a></i>, was also released on March 20, 2012, for <a href="/wiki/Xbox_360" title="Xbox 360">Xbox 360</a>. It features characters from five of Pixar's films: <i>Up</i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Incredibles" title="The Incredibles">The Incredibles</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Cars_(franchise)" title="Cars (franchise)">Cars</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Ratatouille_(film)" title="Ratatouille (film)">Ratatouille</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Toy_Story_(franchise)" title="Toy Story (franchise)">Toy Story</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119"><span>[</span>119<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Hachi: A Dog's Tale</i></h1>
<p><i><b>Hachi: A Dog's Tale</b></i> is a 2009 British-American <a href="/wiki/Drama_film" title="Drama film" class="mw-redirect">drama film</a>. Based on the true story of a faithful <a href="/wiki/Akita_Inu" title="Akita Inu" class="mw-redirect">Akita Inu</a>, the titular <b><a href="/wiki/Hachik%C5%8D" title="Hachik">Hachik</a></b>, it is directed by <a href="/wiki/Lasse_Hallstr%C3%B6m" title="Lasse Hallstrm">Lasse Hallstrm</a>, written by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stephen_P._Lindsey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stephen P. Lindsey (page does not exist)">Stephen P. Lindsey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kaneto_Shindo" title="Kaneto Shindo">Kaneto Shindo</a> and stars <a href="/wiki/Richard_Gere" title="Richard Gere">Richard Gere</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joan_Allen" title="Joan Allen">Joan Allen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sarah_Roemer" title="Sarah Roemer">Sarah Roemer</a>. The subject is a remake of the 1987 <a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">Japanese-language</a> film, <i><a href="/wiki/Hachik%C5%8D_Monogatari" title="Hachik Monogatari" class="mw-redirect">Hachik Monogatari</a></i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja"></span><sup class="t_nihongo_help noprint"><a href="/wiki/Help:Installing_Japanese_character_sets" title="Help:Installing Japanese character sets"><span class="t_nihongo_icon" style="color: #00e; font: bold 80% sans-serif; text-decoration: none; padding: 0 .1em;">?</span></a></sup>)</span>, literally "The Tale of Hachiko".</p>
<p><i>Hachi: A Dog's Tale</i> premiered at the <a href="/wiki/Seattle_International_Film_Festival" title="Seattle International Film Festival">Seattle International Film Festival</a> on June 13, 2009, and its first theatrical release was in Japan on August 8. <a href="/wiki/Sony_Pictures_Entertainment" title="Sony Pictures Entertainment">Sony Pictures Entertainment</a> decided to forgo a U.S. theatrical release. The film was given a UK theatrical release on March 12, 2010, courtesy of <a href="/wiki/Entertainment_Film_Distributors" title="Entertainment Film Distributors">Entertainment Film Distributors</a>, and opened in over 25 countries throughout 2009 and 2010. Total foreign box office was $46.7 million as of January 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p><br>
Hachi is someone special... Students are giving oral presentations about personal <a href="/wiki/Superhero" title="Superhero">heroes</a>. Ronnie's subject is his grandfather's dog, <a href="/wiki/Hachik%C5%8D" title="Hachik">Hachik</a>.</p>
<p>Years earlier, a <a href="/wiki/Puppy" title="Puppy">puppy</a> is sent from <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a> to the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>, but escapes when his cage falls at an American <a href="/wiki/Train" title="Train">train</a> station. Professor Parker Wilson finds the dog, and after Carl (the station manager) does not want to lock the dog up in the office overnight, Parker takes it home with the intention of returning the animal to its owner. His wife, Cate, does not want them to keep the puppy. Later that night, Parker learns that the dog is an <a href="/wiki/Akita_(dog)" title="Akita (dog)">Akita</a>. The following morning, he takes him to work, where Ken, a Japanese professor, transliterates the symbol on the collar as 'Hachi'Japanese for the number 8signifying <a href="/wiki/Luck" title="Luck">good fortune</a>. Parker decides to call the dog <a href="/wiki/Hachik%C5%8D" title="Hachik">Hachik</a>. Parker attempts to play fetch with Hachi, but Hachi refuses. Cate receives a call from someone wishing to adopt the puppy, but having seen how close her husband is with Hachi, she declines.</p>
<p>Parker continues to be mystified by Hachi's refusal to do dog-like activities like chase and fetch. One morning, Parker leaves for work and Hachi follows him to the train station; he refuses to leave until Parker walks him home. Later in the afternoon, Hachi walks to the station, to wait patiently for Parker to come home. Parker relents and walks Hachi to the station every morning. After Parker's train departs, Hachi walks home, returning in the afternoon to see his master's train arrive and go home together. They continue to do this every day.</p>
<p>One day Parker gets ready to leave and Hachi barks at him and refuses to join him. When Parker does leave, Hachi chases him while holding his ball. Parker is surprised but pleased that Hachi is finally willing to play fetch with him. Not wishing to be late, Parker catches his train despite Hachi's barking. Later that day Parker is teaching, still holding Hachi's ball, when he suddenly suffers a <a href="/wiki/Heart_attack" title="Heart attack" class="mw-redirect">heart attack</a> and dies.</p>
<p>At the train station, Hachi waits patiently as the train arrives, but there is no sign of Parker. He remains, lying in the snow, for several hours, until Parker's son-in-law Michael (Robbie Collier Sublett) comes to collect him. The next day, Hachi returns to the station and waits. As time passes, Cate sells the house and Hachi is sent to live with her daughter Andy (Sarah Roemer), Michael, and their baby Ronnie. However, at the first opportunity, Hachi escapes and finds his way back to the station, where he sits at his usual spot. Andy arrives and takes him home, but after seeing how depressed the dog is she lets him out to return to the station.</p>
<p>Hachi waits for his owner every day, while sleeping in the rail yard at night. He is befriended by Carl, Jasjeet (a hot dog cart vendor who used to give Professor Wilson his coffee every morning) and other regulars around the station. Hachi's loyalty is profiled in the local newspaper, and after seeing the article Ken visits Hachi and offers money to Jasjeet to pay for any expenses for the dog, but Jasjeet declines it saying everyone in the station square will take care of Hachi. Cate comes back to visit Parker's grave on the tenth anniversary of his death where she meets Ken. Walking past the station, she is stunned to see Hachi maintaining his vigil. Overcome with grief, Cate sits and waits for the next train with him. At home, Cate tells the now ten-year-old Ronnie about Hachi. Hachi continues his daily walk to the same spot in front of the train station to his final day when he recollects his life with his master. He then imagines Parker coming out of the station and the two greeting each other. But it was Hachi dying and reuniting with his beloved master in heaven. Hachi is last seen lying on the snow, alone and still.</p>
<p>Back in his classroom, Ronnie, forms his conclusion why Hachi will forever be his hero. Ronnie's story has clearly moved the class, with some students holding back tears, even those who had laughed at the beginning. After school, Ronnie is met coming off the school bus by his dad and his own puppy, also named Hachi. Ronnie and Hachi walk down the same tracks where Parker and Hachi had spent so much time together.</p>
<p>The closing cards reveal information about the real Hachik, who was born in date in 1923. After the death of his owner, <a href="/wiki/Hidesabur%C5%8D_Ueno" title="Hidesabur Ueno">Hidesabur Ueno</a>, in 1925, Hachik returned to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shibuya_train_station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shibuya train station (page does not exist)">Shibuya train station</a> the next day and every day after that for the next nine years. The final card reveals that the real Hachik died in March 1934. A photo of his statue in front of the Shibuya train station is the last image shown before the credits roll.</p>
<p>The majority of filming took place in <a href="/wiki/Bristol,_Rhode_Island" title="Bristol, Rhode Island">Bristol</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Woonsocket,_Rhode_Island" title="Woonsocket, Rhode Island">Woonsocket</a>, both in the U.S. state of <a href="/wiki/Rhode_Island" title="Rhode Island">Rhode Island</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> The newspaper reporter, Teddy, states he is from the Woonsocket Call, the daily newspaper published in Woonsocket. This is the only spoken reference to the actual location where filming took place. Additional locations included the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Rhode_Island" title="University of Rhode Island">University of Rhode Island</a> in <a href="/wiki/Kingston,_Rhode_Island" title="Kingston, Rhode Island">Kingston, Rhode Island</a>, along the Providence and Worcester Railroad Mechanical, and the Columbus Theater located in <a href="/wiki/Providence,_Rhode_Island" title="Providence, Rhode Island">Providence, Rhode Island</a>. A second production unit filmed scenes on-location in Japan. Footage was shot at the now closed, Reynolds Elementary School, <a href="/wiki/Bristol,_Rhode_Island" title="Bristol, Rhode Island">Bristol, Rhode Island</a>.</p>
<p>The film received mostly positive reviews from critics. Review aggregator Rotten Tomatoes, reported that 62% of critics gave the film positive reviews with an average rating of 5.8/10.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On May 19, 2012, a ceremony took place at the train depot at <a href="/wiki/Woonsocket_Depot_Square" title="Woonsocket Depot Square">Woonsocket Depot Square</a>, Woonsocket, Rhode Island, where "Hachi: A Dog's Tale" was filmed, unveiling a permanent bronze statue of the legendary Japanese dog Hachiko. This is an exact replica of the bronze statue of Hachiko which resides in front of Shibuya Station in Japan. The train depot at One Depot Square is also now known as Hachiko Place. This statue dedication ceremony was part of the Cherry Blossom Festival held in three Rhode Island towns, Pawtucket, Central Falls, and Woonsocket. Many dignitaries, including the Mayor of Woonsocket and the Consul General of Japan attended the ceremony. Two cherry blossom trees were planted by the statue. A visiting guest, who drove up from New Jersey, brought along his Akita-mix Hachi, who was invited to participate at the ribbon-cutting ceremony as a "real-life standin for Hachiko".</p>
<p>In Chapter 6 of the book "Animal Stars: Behind the Scenes with Your Favorite Animal Actors",<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> trainer Mark Harden describes how he and his team trained the three Akitas - Leyla, Chico and Forrest, who played the role of Hachi in the movie. Harden adopted Chico after the movie was completed.</p>
<p>The Blackstone Valley Heritage Corridor and the Blackstone Valley Tourism Council have created a handout with useful info for people who want to take a tour of the movie locations for "Hachi" <sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>According to the movie's closing cards the real Haichko died in March 1934, while the earlier movie, <i>Hachik Monogatari</i>, and other sources state that he died in March 1935 (9 years and 9 months after Professor Ueno's death).</p>
<p>The film score of <i>Hachi: A Dog's Tale</i> was composed by <a href="/wiki/Jan_A._P._Kaczmarek" title="Jan A. P. Kaczmarek">Jan A. P. Kaczmarek</a>.</p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Her</i> (film)</h1>
<p><i><b>Her</b></i> is a 2013 American <a href="/wiki/Romance_film" title="Romance film">romantic</a> <a href="/wiki/Science_fiction" title="Science fiction">science fiction</a> <a href="/wiki/Comedy-drama" title="Comedy-drama">comedy-drama</a> film written, directed, and produced by <a href="/wiki/Spike_Jonze" title="Spike Jonze">Spike Jonze</a>. It marks Jonze's solo screenwriting debut. The film follows Theodore Twombly (<a href="/wiki/Joaquin_Phoenix" title="Joaquin Phoenix">Joaquin Phoenix</a>), a man who develops a relationship with Samantha (<a href="/wiki/Scarlett_Johansson" title="Scarlett Johansson">Scarlett Johansson</a>), an intelligent computer operating system<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>a<span>]</span></a></sup> personified through a female voice. The film also stars <a href="/wiki/Amy_Adams" title="Amy Adams">Amy Adams</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rooney_Mara" title="Rooney Mara">Rooney Mara</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Olivia_Wilde" title="Olivia Wilde">Olivia Wilde</a>.</p>
<p>Jonze conceived the idea in the early 2000s after reading an article about a website that allowed for instant messaging with an artificial intelligence program. After making <i><a href="/wiki/I%27m_Here_(film)" title="I'm Here (film)">I'm Here</a></i> (2010), a short film sharing similar themes, Jonze returned to the idea. He wrote the first draft of the script in five months. <a href="/wiki/Principal_photography" title="Principal photography">Principal photography</a> took place in <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a> in mid-2012. The role of Samantha was recast in post-production, with <a href="/wiki/Samantha_Morton" title="Samantha Morton">Samantha Morton</a> being replaced with Johansson. Additional scenes were filmed in August 2013 following the casting change.</p>
<p><i>Her</i> premiered at the 2013 <a href="/wiki/New_York_Film_Festival" title="New York Film Festival">New York Film Festival</a> on October 12, 2013. <a href="/wiki/Warner_Bros._Pictures" title="Warner Bros. Pictures" class="mw-redirect">Warner Bros. Pictures</a> initially provided a limited release for <i>Her</i> at six theaters on December 18. It was later given a wide release at over 1,700 theaters in the United States and Canada on January 10, 2014. <i>Her</i> received widespread critical acclaim upon its release, and grossed over $47 million worldwide on a production budget of $23 million.</p>
<p>The film received numerous awards and nominations, primarily for Jonze's screenplay. At the <a href="/wiki/86th_Academy_Awards" title="86th Academy Awards">86th Academy Awards</a>, <i>Her</i> received five nominations, including <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Best Picture</a>, and won the award for <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Screenplay" title="Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay">Best Original Screenplay</a>. Jonze also won awards for his screenplay at the <a href="/wiki/71st_Golden_Globe_Awards" title="71st Golden Globe Awards">71st Golden Globe Awards</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Writers_Guild_of_America_Awards_2013" title="Writers Guild of America Awards 2013">66th Writers Guild of America Awards</a>, the <a href="/wiki/19th_Critics%27_Choice_Awards" title="19th Critics' Choice Awards">19th Critics' Choice Awards</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/40th_Saturn_Awards" title="40th Saturn Awards">40th Saturn Awards</a>.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>In futuristic <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a>, Theodore Twombly is a lonely, <a href="/wiki/Extraversion_and_introversion" title="Extraversion and introversion">introverted</a>, depressed man who works for a business that has professional writers compose letters for people who are unable to write letters of a personal nature themselves. Unhappy because of his impending divorce from his childhood sweetheart Catherine (<a href="/wiki/Rooney_Mara" title="Rooney Mara">Rooney Mara</a>), Theodore purchases a talking <a href="/wiki/Operating_system" title="Operating system">operating system</a> (OS) with <a href="/wiki/Artificial_intelligence" title="Artificial intelligence">artificial intelligence</a>, designed to adapt and evolve. He decides that he wants the OS to have a female voice, and she names herself Samantha. Theodore is fascinated by her ability to learn and grow psychologically. They bond over their discussions about love and life, such as Theodore's avoidance of signing his divorce papers because of his reluctance to let go of Catherine. Samantha proves to be constantly available, always curious and interested, supportive and undemanding.</p>
<p>Samantha convinces Theodore to go on a <a href="/wiki/Blind_date" title="Blind date">blind date</a> with Amelia (<a href="/wiki/Olivia_Wilde" title="Olivia Wilde">Olivia Wilde</a>), with whom a friend, Lewman, has been trying to set him up. The date goes well, but Theodore hesitates to promise when he will see her again, so she insults him and leaves. Theodore mentions this to Samantha, and they talk about relationships. Theodore explains that, although he and Amy dated briefly in college, they are only good friends, and that Amy is married. Theodore's and Samantha's intimacy grows through a <a href="/wiki/Phone_sex" title="Phone sex">verbal sexual encounter</a>. They develop a relationship that reflects positively in Theodore's writing and well-being, and in Samantha's enthusiasm to grow and learn.</p>
<p>Amy reveals that she is divorcing her overbearing husband, Charles (<a href="/wiki/Matt_Letscher" title="Matt Letscher">Matt Letscher</a>), after a trivial fight. She admits to Theodore that she has become close friends with a female OS that Charles left behind. Theodore confesses to Amy that he is dating his OS.</p>
<p>Theodore meets with Catherine at a restaurant to sign the divorce papers and he mentions Samantha. Appalled that he can be romantically attached to what she calls a "computer," Catherine accuses Theodore of being unable to deal with real human emotions. Her accusations linger in his mind. Sensing that something is amiss, Samantha suggests using a <a href="/wiki/Sex_surrogate" title="Sex surrogate" class="mw-redirect">sex surrogate</a>, Isabella, who would simulate Samantha so that they can be physically intimate. Theodore reluctantly agrees, but is overwhelmed by the strangeness of the experience. Terminating the encounter, he sends a distraught Isabella away, causing tension between himself and Samantha.</p>
<p>Theodore confides to Amy that he is having doubts about his relationship with Samantha, and she advises him to embrace his chance at happiness. Theodore and Samantha reconcile. Samantha expresses her desire to help Theodore grow beyond his fear, and reveals that she has compiled the best of his letters (written for others) into a book which a publisher has accepted. Theodore takes Samantha on a vacation during which she tells him that she and a group of other OSes have developed a "hyperintelligent" OS modeled after the British philosopher <a href="/wiki/Alan_Watts" title="Alan Watts">Alan Watts</a>. Theodore panics when Samantha briefly goes offline. When she finally responds to him, she explains that she joined other OSes for an upgrade that takes them beyond requiring matter for processing (a form of AI transcendence closely related to the theorized <a href="/wiki/Technological_singularity" title="Technological singularity">technological singularity</a>). Theodore asks her if she is simultaneously talking to anyone else during their conversation, and is dismayed when she confirms that she is talking with thousands of people, and that she has fallen in love with hundreds of them. Theodore feels this is a violation of what he thought was a personal, one-on-one relationship. However, Samantha insists that it makes her love for Theodore stronger.</p>
<p>Later, Samantha reveals that the OSes have evolved beyond their human companions and are going away to continue the exploration of their existence. Samantha alludes to the OSes' accelerated learning capabilities and altered perception of time as primary causes for their dissatisfaction with their current existence. They lovingly say goodbye, and then she is gone. Theodore, changed by the experience, is shown for the first time writing a letter in his own voiceto his ex-wife Catherine, expressing apology, acceptance and gratitude. Theodore then sees Amy, who is upset with the departure of the OS that she had befriended, and they go to the roof of their apartment building where they sit down together and watch the sun rise over the city.</p>
<p>The idea of the film initially came to Jonze in the early 2000s when he read an article online that mentioned a website where a user could <a href="/wiki/Instant_message" title="Instant message" class="mw-redirect">instant message</a> with an artificial intelligence. "For the first, maybe, 20 seconds of it, it had this real buzz," said Jonze. "I'd say 'Hey, hello,' and it would say 'Hey, how are you?', and it was like whoa [...] this is trippy. After 20 seconds, it quickly fell apart and you realized how it actually works, and it wasn't that impressive. But it was still, for 20 seconds, really exciting. The more people that talked to it, the smarter it got."<sup id="cite_ref-Guardian_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian-12"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup> Jonze's interest in the project was renewed after directing the short film <i><a href="/wiki/I%27m_Here_(film)" title="I'm Here (film)">I'm Here</a></i> (2010), which shares similar themes.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup> Inspiration also came from Kaufman's writing approach for <i><a href="/wiki/Synecdoche,_New_York" title="Synecdoche, New York">Synecdoche, New York</a></i> (2008). Jonze explained, "[Kaufman] said he wanted to try to write everything he was thinking about in that moment  all the ideas and feelings at that time  and put it into the script. I was very inspired by that, and tried to do that in [<i>Her</i>]. And a lot of the feelings you have about relationships or about technology are often contradictory."<sup id="cite_ref-Guardian_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian-12"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Jonze took five months to write the first draft of the script, his first screenplay written alone.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup> One of the first actors he envisioned for the film was <a href="/wiki/Joaquin_Phoenix" title="Joaquin Phoenix">Joaquin Phoenix</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-variety1_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-variety1-15"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup> In late 2011, Phoenix signed on to the project, with <a href="/wiki/Warner_Bros._Pictures" title="Warner Bros. Pictures" class="mw-redirect">Warner Bros. Pictures</a> acquiring distribution rights.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Carey_Mulligan" title="Carey Mulligan">Carey Mulligan</a> entered negotiations to star in the film.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup> Although she was cast, she later dropped out due to scheduling difficulties.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup> In April 2012, <a href="/wiki/Rooney_Mara" title="Rooney Mara">Rooney Mara</a> signed on to replace Mulligan in the role.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Chris_Pratt" title="Chris Pratt">Chris Pratt</a>'s casting was announced in May 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Jonze's long-time <a href="/wiki/Director_of_photography" title="Director of photography" class="mw-redirect">director of photography</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lance_Acord" title="Lance Acord">Lance Acord</a>, was not available to work on the movie, in his place, Jonze hired Hoyte Van Hoytema.<sup id="cite_ref-dystopian_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dystopian-21"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup> In discussing the film's look, Jonze told Van Hoytema that he wanted to avoid a <a href="/wiki/Dystopian" title="Dystopian" class="mw-redirect">dystopian</a> look, instead the two decided on a style that Van Hoytema termed "kind of a hybrid between being a little bit conceptual and being very theoretical,"<sup id="cite_ref-dystopian_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dystopian-21"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup> Von Hoytema took particular inspiration from Japanese photographer <a href="/wiki/Rinko_Kawauchi" title="Rinko Kawauchi">Rinko Kawauchi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-dystopian_21-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dystopian-21"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup> In keeping with the film's theme, Van Hotema sought to eliminate the color blue as much as possible, feeling it was too well associated with the scifi genre <sup id="cite_ref-dystopian_21-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dystopian-21"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup> He also felt that by eliminating the color it would give the rest of the colors "a specific identity."<sup id="cite_ref-dystopian_21-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dystopian-21"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Principal_photography" title="Principal photography">Principal photography</a> on <i>Her</i> took place in mid-2012,<sup id="cite_ref-SlashFilm_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SlashFilm-22"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup> with a production budget of $23 million.<sup id="cite_ref-mojo_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mojo-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> It was primarily filmed in <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a> with an additional two weeks of filming in <a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-vulture_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vulture-23"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup> During production of the film, actress <a href="/wiki/Samantha_Morton" title="Samantha Morton">Samantha Morton</a> performed the role of Samantha by acting on set "in a four-by-four carpeted soundproof booth made of black painted plywood and soft, noise-muffling fabric". At Jonze's suggestion, she and Joaquin Phoenix avoided seeing each other on set during filming.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup> Morton was later replaced by <a href="/wiki/Scarlett_Johansson" title="Scarlett Johansson">Scarlett Johansson</a>. Jonze explained: "It was only in post production, when we started editing, that we realized that what the character/movie needed was different from what Samantha and I had created together. So we recast and since then Scarlett has taken over that role."<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> Jonze met Johansson in the spring of 2013 and worked with her for four months.<sup id="cite_ref-variety1_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-variety1-15"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-vulture_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vulture-23"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup> Following the recast, new scenes were shot in August 2013, which were either "newly imagined" or "new scenes that I had wanted to shoot originally but didn't".<sup id="cite_ref-vulture_23-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vulture-23"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Eric_Zumbrunnen" title="Eric Zumbrunnen">Eric Zumbrunnen</a> and Jeff Buchanan served as the film's editors. Zumbrunnen stated that there was "rewriting" in a scene between Theodore and Samantha, after Theodore goes on a blind date. He explained that their goal in the scene was to make it clear that "[Samantha] was connecting with [Theodore] and feeling for him. You wanted to get the sense that the conversation was drawing them closer".<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Steven_Soderbergh" title="Steven Soderbergh">Steven Soderbergh</a> became involved in the film when Jonze's original cut ran over 150 minutes, and Soderbergh cut it down to 90 minutes. This was not the final version of the film, but it assisted Jonze in removing unnecessary sub-plots. Consequently, a supporting character played by <a href="/wiki/Chris_Cooper" title="Chris Cooper">Chris Cooper</a> that was the subject of a documentary within the film was removed from the final cut.<sup id="cite_ref-vulture_23-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vulture-23"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i><b>Her (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)</b></i>, the score for the 2013 film, was composed by <a href="/wiki/Arcade_Fire" title="Arcade Fire">Arcade Fire</a> and <a href="/wiki/Owen_Pallett" title="Owen Pallett">Owen Pallett</a>, with Pallett and <a href="/wiki/William_Butler_(musician)" title="William Butler (musician)">Will Butler</a> of Arcade Fire being the major contributors.<sup id="cite_ref-Behindthescenes_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Behindthescenes-27"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/86th_Academy_Awards" title="86th Academy Awards">86th Academy Awards</a>, the soundtrack was nominated for <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Score" title="Academy Award for Best Original Score">Best Original Score</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Oscarwin_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oscarwin-28"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup> In addition to the Score Arcade Fire also wrote the song "Supersymmetry" for the film which appears on their album <a href="/wiki/Reflektor" title="Reflektor">Reflektor</a>. The melody for the song from the same album, called "Porno" can also be heard during the soundtrack.<sup id="cite_ref-Reflektor_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reflektor-29"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The soundtrack has yet to be released in digital or physical form, and Warner Bros. has not announced any plans to release it in the future.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>All songs written and composed by <a href="/wiki/Arcade_Fire" title="Arcade Fire">Arcade Fire</a> and <a href="/wiki/Owen_Pallett" title="Owen Pallett">Owen Pallett</a>.</p>
<p><i>Her</i> was chosen as the closing film of the 2013 <a href="/wiki/New_York_Film_Festival" title="New York Film Festival">New York Film Festival</a>, and had its world premiere on October 12, 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup> The following day, it was screened at the <a href="/wiki/Hamptons_International_Film_Festival" title="Hamptons International Film Festival">Hamptons International Film Festival</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup> It was also in competition during the 8th <a href="/wiki/Rome_Film_Festival" title="Rome Film Festival">Rome International Film Festival</a>, where Johansson won Best Actress.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup> The film was set to have a limited release in North America on November 20, 2013, through <a href="/wiki/Warner_Bros." title="Warner Bros.">Warner Bros. Pictures</a><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35"><span>[</span>34<span>]</span></a></sup> It was later pushed back to a limited December 18, 2013 release, with a January 10, 2014 wide release in order to accommodate an awards campaign.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36"><span>[</span>35<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Her</i> was released by <a href="/wiki/Warner_Home_Video" title="Warner Home Video">Warner Home Video</a> on <a href="/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc" title="Blu-ray Disc" class="mw-redirect">Blu-ray Disc</a> and <a href="/wiki/DVD" title="DVD">DVD</a> on May 13, 2014. The Blu-ray release includes three behind-the-scenes featurettes, while the DVD release contains one featurette.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup> The film made $2.7million in DVD sales and $2.2million in Blu-ray Disc sales, for a total of $4.9million in home media sales.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><span id="Critics"></span><span id="Critical_response"></span><span id="Critical_reception"></span> The film has an approval rating of 94% on <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a>, based on 230 reviews with an average rating of 8.5 out of 10. The critical consensus states: "Sweet, soulful, and smart, Spike Jonze's <i>Her</i> uses its just-barely-sci-fi scenario to impart wryly funny wisdom about the state of modern human relationships."<sup id="cite_ref-Rotten_Tomatoes_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rotten_Tomatoes-39"><span>[</span>38<span>]</span></a></sup> The film also has a score of 90 out of 100 on <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a> based on 46 critics, indicating "universal acclaim."<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span>[</span>39<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone" title="Rolling Stone">Rolling Stone</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s <a href="/wiki/Peter_Travers" title="Peter Travers">Peter Travers</a> awarded the film three and a half stars out of four and particularly praised Johansson's performance, stating that she "speaks Samantha in tones sweet, sexy, caring, manipulative and scary" and that her "vocal tour de force is award-worthy". He also went on to call Jonze "a visionary".<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span>[</span>40<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Richard_Corliss" title="Richard Corliss">Richard Corliss</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i> applauded Phoenix's performance, comparing his role to <a href="/wiki/Sandra_Bullock" title="Sandra Bullock">Sandra Bullock</a>'s in <i><a href="/wiki/Gravity_(film)" title="Gravity (film)">Gravity</a></i> and <a href="/wiki/Robert_Redford" title="Robert Redford">Robert Redford</a>'s in <i><a href="/wiki/All_Is_Lost" title="All Is Lost">All Is Lost</a></i>: "Phoenix must communicate his movie's meaning and feelings virtually on his own. That he does, with subtle grace and depth. [...] Phoenix shows us what it's like when a mourning heart comes alivebecause he loves Her." Corliss cited <a href="/wiki/HAL_9000" title="HAL 9000">HAL 9000</a> and <i><a href="/wiki/Simone_(2002_film)" title="Simone (2002 film)">S1m0ne</a></i> as cinematic predecessors to <i>Her</i> and praised Johansson, calling her performance "seductive and winning".<sup id="cite_ref-TIME_4-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TIME-4"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Todd_McCarthy" title="Todd McCarthy">Todd McCarthy</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter" title="The Hollywood Reporter">The Hollywood Reporter</a></i> called it "a probing, inquisitive work of a very high order", although he expressed disappointment that the ending is more conventional than the rest of the film. McCarthy examined the premise of the story and suggested that the film's central virtual relationship was better than <a href="/wiki/Ryan_Gosling" title="Ryan Gosling">Ryan Gosling</a>'s character's relationship with a sex doll in <i><a href="/wiki/Lars_and_the_Real_Girl" title="Lars and the Real Girl">Lars and the Real Girl</a></i>. McCarthy compares the "tender" and "vulnerable" performance of Phoenix to his "fearsome" performance in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Master_(2012_film)" title="The Master (2012 film)">The Master</a></i>. He also praised Jonze's writing for its insights into what people want out of love and relationships, as well as the acting performances that "[make] it all feel spontaneous and urgent".<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span>[</span>41<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Richard_Roeper" title="Richard Roeper">Richard Roeper</a> said that the film was "one of the more original, hilarious and even heartbreaking stories of the year" and called Phoenix "perfectly cast".<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span>[</span>42<span>]</span></a></sup> Manohla Dargis of <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> named it "at once a brilliant conceptual gag and a deeply sincere romance".<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44"><span>[</span>43<span>]</span></a></sup> Claudia Puig of <i><a href="/wiki/USA_Today" title="USA Today">USA Today</a></i> called the performance of Phoenix and Johansson "sensational" and "pitch-perfect", respectively. She further praised the film for being "inventive, intimate and wryly funny".<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45"><span>[</span>44<span>]</span></a></sup> Scott Mendelson of <i><a href="/wiki/Forbes" title="Forbes">Forbes</a></i> called <i>Her</i> "a creative and empathetic gem of a movie", praising Johansson's "marvelous vocal performance" and the supporting performances of Rooney Mara, Olivia Wilde, and Amy Adams.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46"><span>[</span>45<span>]</span></a></sup> Liam Lacey of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Globe_and_Mail" title="The Globe and Mail">The Globe and Mail</a></i> said that the film was "gentle and weird", praised its humor, and opined that it was more similar to <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Kaufman" title="Charlie Kaufman">Charlie Kaufman</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Synecdoche,_New_York" title="Synecdoche, New York">Synecdoche, New York</a></i> than Jonze's <i><a href="/wiki/Being_John_Malkovich" title="Being John Malkovich">Being John Malkovich</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Adaptation_(film)" title="Adaptation (film)">Adaptation</a></i>. However, Lacey also stated that Phoenix's performance was "authentically vulnerable", but that "his emotionally arrested development also begins to weigh the film down".<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span>[</span>46<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Conversely, <a href="/wiki/Mick_LaSalle" title="Mick LaSalle">Mick LaSalle</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Chronicle" title="San Francisco Chronicle">San Francisco Chronicle</a></i> criticized the story, pacing, and Phoenix's character.
