He also opined that the film was "a lot more interesting to think about than watch".<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48"><span>[</span>47<span>]</span></a></sup> J. R. Jones of the <i><a href="/wiki/Chicago_Reader" title="Chicago Reader">Chicago Reader</a></i> gave the film 2 out of 4 stars, praising the performances of Phoenix and Johansson, but also criticizing Phoenix's character, calling him an "idiot". He also criticized the lack of realism in the relationship between Phoenix and Johansson's characters.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49"><span>[</span>48<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Stephanie_Zacharek" title="Stephanie Zacharek">Stephanie Zacharek</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Village_Voice" title="The Village Voice">The Village Voice</a></i> opined that Jonze was "so entranced with his central conceit that he can barely move beyond it", and criticized the dialogue as being "premeditated." However, she also praised Johannson's performance, calling it "the movie's saving grace" and stating that <i>Her</i> "isn't just unimaginable without Johanssonit might have been unbearable without her".<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50"><span>[</span>49<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Her</i> grossed $258,000 in six theaters during its opening weekend, averaging $43,000 per theater.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span>[</span>50<span>]</span></a></sup> The film earned over $3 million while on limited release, before expanding to a wide release of 1,729 theaters on January 10, 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52"><span>[</span>51<span>]</span></a></sup> On its first weekend of wide release the film took in $5.35million.<sup id="cite_ref-mojo3771_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mojo3771-53"><span>[</span>52<span>]</span></a></sup> The film grossed $25.6million in the United States and Canada and $21.8million in other territories for a worldwide gross of $47.4million.<sup id="cite_ref-mojo_2-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mojo-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> Audiences surveyed by <a href="/wiki/CinemaScore" title="CinemaScore">CinemaScore</a> gave <i>Her</i> a B- grade.<sup id="cite_ref-mojo3771_53-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mojo3771-53"><span>[</span>52<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Her</i> has earned various awards and nominations, with particular praise for Jonze's screenplay. At the <a href="/wiki/86th_Academy_Awards" title="86th Academy Awards">86th Academy Awards</a>, the film was nominated in five categories, including <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Best Picture</a>, with Jonze winning for <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Screenplay" title="Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay">Best Original Screenplay</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54"><span>[</span>53<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55"><span>[</span>54<span>]</span></a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/71st_Golden_Globe_Awards" title="71st Golden Globe Awards">71st Golden Globe Awards</a>, the film garnered three nominations, going on to win <a href="/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Screenplay" title="Golden Globe Award for Best Screenplay">Best Screenplay</a> for Jonze.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span>[</span>55<span>]</span></a></sup> Jonze was also awarded the Best Original Screenplay Award from the <a href="/wiki/Writers_Guild_of_America" title="Writers Guild of America">Writers Guild of America</a><sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57"><span>[</span>56<span>]</span></a></sup> and at the <a href="/wiki/19th_Critics%27_Choice_Awards" title="19th Critics' Choice Awards">19th Critics' Choice Awards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58"><span>[</span>57<span>]</span></a></sup> The film also won <a href="/wiki/Saturn_Award_for_Best_Fantasy_Film" title="Saturn Award for Best Fantasy Film">Best Fantasy Film</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saturn_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actress" title="Saturn Award for Best Supporting Actress">Best Supporting Actress</a> for Johansson, and <a href="/wiki/Saturn_Award_for_Best_Writing" title="Saturn Award for Best Writing">Best Writing</a> for Jonze at the <a href="/wiki/40th_Saturn_Awards" title="40th Saturn Awards">40th Saturn Awards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span>[</span>58<span>]</span></a></sup> The film was nominated for <a href="/wiki/Producers_Guild_of_America_Award_for_Best_Theatrical_Motion_Picture" title="Producers Guild of America Award for Best Theatrical Motion Picture">Best Theatrical Motion Picture</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Producers_Guild_of_America_Awards_2013" title="Producers Guild of America Awards 2013">25th Producers Guild of America Awards</a>, but lost to <i><a href="/wiki/12_Years_a_Slave_(film)" title="12 Years a Slave (film)">12 Years a Slave</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Gravity_(film)" title="Gravity (film)">Gravity</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60"><span>[</span>59<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>Her</i> also won <a href="/wiki/National_Board_of_Review_Award_for_Best_Film" title="National Board of Review Award for Best Film">Best Film</a> and <a href="/wiki/National_Board_of_Review_Award_for_Best_Director" title="National Board of Review Award for Best Director">Best Director</a> for Jonze at the <a href="/wiki/National_Board_of_Review_Awards" title="National Board of Review Awards" class="mw-redirect">National Board of Review Awards</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61"><span>[</span>60<span>]</span></a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/American_Film_Institute" title="American Film Institute">American Film Institute</a> included the film in its list of the top ten films of 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62"><span>[</span>61<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>August Rush</i></h1>
<p><i><b>August Rush</b></i> is a 2007 <a href="/wiki/Drama_film" title="Drama film" class="mw-redirect">drama film</a> directed by <a href="/wiki/Kirsten_Sheridan" title="Kirsten Sheridan">Kirsten Sheridan</a> and written by <a href="/wiki/Nick_Castle" title="Nick Castle">Nick Castle</a>, <a href="/wiki/James_V._Hart" title="James V. Hart">James V. Hart</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Paul_Castro" title="Paul Castro">Paul Castro</a>, and produced by Richard Barton Lewis.</p>
<p>Deciding to run away to <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>, musical prodigy Evan Taylor begins to unravel the mystery of who he is, all while Evan's mother is searching for him while his father is searching for her.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>In 1995, Lyla Novacek (<a href="/wiki/Keri_Russell" title="Keri Russell">Keri Russell</a>) is a cellist living under strict rule of her father (<a href="/wiki/William_Sadler_(actor)" title="William Sadler (actor)">William Sadler</a>). Louis Connelly (<a href="/wiki/Jonathan_Rhys_Meyers" title="Jonathan Rhys Meyers">Jonathan Rhys Meyers</a>) is the lead singer of "The Connelly Brothers", an <a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Irish</a> rock band. Lyla and Louis meet and sleep together. The day after, they separate in a hurry, and are unable to maintain contact as Lyla leaves for <a href="/wiki/Chicago" title="Chicago">Chicago</a>. Lyla realizes she is pregnant. After an argument with her father, she is struck by a car. Due to the accident trauma, she gives birth prematurely, and her father secretly puts her son up for adoption, allowing her to believe that the baby died.</p>
<p>Eleven years later, Evan Taylor (<a href="/wiki/Freddie_Highmore" title="Freddie Highmore">Freddie Highmore</a>) is living in a boys' <a href="/wiki/Orphanage" title="Orphanage">orphanage</a> outside <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>, where he meets Richard Jeffries (<a href="/wiki/Terrence_Howard" title="Terrence Howard">Terrence Howard</a>), a <a href="/wiki/Social_worker" title="Social worker" class="mw-redirect">social worker</a>. Evan has the savant-like ability to hear music wherever he is. Convinced that his parents will find him, Evan runs away to New York City, "following the music" in the hope it will lead him to his family. He finds a boy named Arthur (<a href="/wiki/Leon_Thomas_III" title="Leon Thomas III">Leon Thomas III</a>) performing in <a href="/wiki/Washington_Square_Park" title="Washington Square Park">Washington Square Park</a>.</p>
<p>Louis lives in <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco" title="San Francisco">San Francisco</a>, having left his band, while Lyla gave up performing and lives in Chicago. She is called to her father's deathbed and he admits that her child survived and is alive in New York. Lyla decides to abandon her father to his fate and moves to New York. Evan follows Arthur to his home in a condemned theater and is taken in by Maxwell "Wizard" Wallace (<a href="/wiki/Robin_Williams" title="Robin Williams">Robin Williams</a>), a vagrant musician who teaches homeless children music and employs them as <a href="/wiki/Street_performer" title="Street performer" class="mw-redirect">street performers</a>. Evan tries playing Wizard's prize guitar and is so good that Wizard gives him the guitar and his old spot in Washington Square Park. He gives Evan the <a href="/wiki/Stage_name" title="Stage name">stage name</a> "August Rush" and tries to market him to clubs. Seeing the posters that Jeffries has posted for the runaway Evan, Wizard destroys all the ones he finds, hoping to keep Evan and his gift for his own gain.</p>
<p>Louis decides to reconnect with Lyla and flies to Chicago to find her. Due to a misunderstanding, he ends up in New York, where he gets his band back together. The derelict theatre Wizard and his "children" are living in is raided by the police. After evading them, Evan (now "August") takes refuge in a church where a young girl, Hope (<a href="/wiki/Jamia_Simone_Nash" title="Jamia Simone Nash">Jamia Simone Nash</a>), introduces him to the piano and written music. He picks up this skill so quickly that Hope gets the attention of the parish pastor (<a href="/wiki/Mykelti_Williamson" title="Mykelti Williamson">Mykelti Williamson</a>), who enrolls August at the <a href="/wiki/Juilliard_School" title="Juilliard School">Juilliard School</a>. A rhapsody takes shape from August's notes and homework.</p>
<p>In New York, Lyla goes to Jeffries' office and Jeffries identifies Evan as her son. She takes up the cello again and accepts an offer to perform with the Philharmonic at a series of concerts in <a href="/wiki/Central_Park" title="Central Park">Central Park</a>. August is selected to perform the rhapsody he's been composing at the same concert. Wizard intrudes during a rehearsal and, claiming to be his father, pulls August out of the school threatening August to tell the authorities about his true identity. On the day of the outdoor concert, August is forbidden by Wizard to attend. August meets Louis in the park, not knowing Louis was his father and tells him of his dilemma and Louis encourages him to go. August leaves Wizard with help from Arthur, who also rebels, and flees to the concert.</p>
<p>Jeffries identifies August as Evan and heads for the concert. August arrives in time to conduct his <a href="/wiki/Rhapsody_(music)" title="Rhapsody (music)">rhapsody</a>. Louis also arrives and reunites with Lyla, realizing she was playing at the concert. August finishes his rhapsody and as he turns to discover his parents, smiles knowing that he was always right about knowing they loved him and gratified that his faith in fate has proven itself.</p>
<p>The final number with Lyla and Louis begins with Lyla playing the Adagio-Moderato from Edward Elgar's <a href="/wiki/Cello_Concerto_(Elgar)" title="Cello Concerto (Elgar)">Cello Concerto in E Minor</a>.</p>
<p>Except for "Dueling Guitars", all of August's guitar pieces were played by American guitarist-composer <a href="/wiki/Kaki_King" title="Kaki King">Kaki King</a>. King's hands are used in close-ups for August Rush.</p>
<p>Composer Mark Mancina spent over a year and a half composing the score of <i>August Rush</i>. "The heart of the story is how we respond and connect through music. It's about this young boy who believes that he's going to find his parents through his music. That's what drives him."<sup id="cite_ref-BillBoard.com_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BillBoard.com-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> The final theme of the movie was composed first. "That way I could take bits and pieces of the ending piece and relate it to the things that are happening in (August's) life. All of the themes are pieces of the puzzle, so at the end it means something because you've been subliminally hearing it throughout the film."<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> The score was recorded at the Todd-AO Scoring Stage and the Eastwood Scoring Stage at Warner Brothers.<sup id="cite_ref-scoring_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scoring-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>August Rush</i> received mixed to negative reviews from film critics,<sup id="cite_ref-Rotten_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rotten-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Meta_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Meta-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> although it has earned mostly positive reception from the general public.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> On the review aggregator <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a>, 37% of critics gave the film positive reviews, based on 110 reviews. The site's consensus reads: "Though featuring a talented cast, <i>August Rush</i> cannot overcome the flimsy direction and schmaltzy plot."<sup id="cite_ref-Rotten_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rotten-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> On <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>, the film had an average score of 38 out of 100, based on 27 critics, indicating "generally negative reviews".<sup id="cite_ref-Meta_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Meta-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In a review by <i><a href="/wiki/USA_Today" title="USA Today">USA Today</a></i>, Claudia Puig commented that "<i>August Rush</i> will not be for everyone, but it works if you surrender to its lilting and unabashedly sentimental tale of evocative music and visual poetry."<sup id="cite_ref-USA-today_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USA-today-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter" title="The Hollywood Reporter">The Hollywood Reporter</a></i> reviewed the film positively, writing "the story is about musicians and how music connects people, so the movie's score and songs, created by composers Mark Mancina and Hans Zimmer, give poetic whimsy to an implausible tale."<sup id="cite_ref-HollywoodReporter_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HollywoodReporter-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Pam Grady of the <i><a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Chronicle" title="San Francisco Chronicle">San Francisco Chronicle</a></i> called the film "an inane musical melodrama." Grady said "the entire story is ridiculous" and "Coincidences pile on, behavior and motivations defy logic, and the characters are so thinly drawn that most of the cast is at a loss."<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> Edward Douglas of comingsoon.net said it "does not take long for the movie to reveal itself as an extremely contrived and predictable movie that tries too hard to tug on the heartstrings."<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Roger_Ebert" title="Roger Ebert">Roger Ebert</a> gave the movie three stars, calling it "a movie drenched in sentimentality, but it's supposed to be. The movie also came to a very sudden end leaving it unfinished."<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Jamila_Gavin" title="Jamila Gavin">Jamila Gavin</a> compared the film to <a href="/wiki/Charles_Dickens" title="Charles Dickens">Dickens'</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Oliver_Twist" title="Oliver Twist">Oliver Twist</a></i> and <a href="/wiki/Coram_Boy" title="Coram Boy">Coram Boy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Shawn_Johnson" title="Shawn Johnson">Shawn Johnson</a> used Bari Improv and August's Rhapsody for her floor exercise music in 2008, notably featured at the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">Beijing Olympics</a>.</p>
<p>Despite the mixed reception, <i>August Rush</i> was praised for its music. The song "Raise It Up" was nominated for <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Song" title="Academy Award for Best Original Song">Best Original Song</a> at the <a href="/wiki/80th_Academy_Awards" title="80th Academy Awards">80th Academy Awards</a>, but lost to <i><a href="/wiki/Once_(film)" title="Once (film)">Once</a></i>.</p>
<p>It was announced in November, 2014 that <a href="/wiki/Mark_Mancina" title="Mark Mancina">Mark Mancina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Glen_Berger" title="Glen Berger">Glen Berger</a> were bringing the film to Broadway.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>V for Vendetta</i> (film)</h1>
<p><i><b>V for Vendetta</b></i> is a 2006 <a href="/wiki/List_of_dystopian_films" title="List of dystopian films">dystopian</a> <a href="/wiki/Political_thriller" title="Political thriller">political thriller</a> film directed by <a href="/wiki/James_McTeigue" title="James McTeigue">James McTeigue</a> and written by the The Wachowski Brothers, based on the 1988 <a href="/wiki/Vertigo_Comics" title="Vertigo Comics" class="mw-redirect">Vertigo Comics</a> <a href="/wiki/Limited_series" title="Limited series" class="mw-redirect">limited series</a> of the <a href="/wiki/V_for_Vendetta" title="V for Vendetta">same name</a> by <a href="/wiki/Alan_Moore" title="Alan Moore">Alan Moore</a> and <a href="/wiki/David_Lloyd_(comics)" title="David Lloyd (comics)">David Lloyd</a>. The film is set in an <a href="/wiki/Alternate_future" title="Alternate future" class="mw-redirect">alternate future</a> where a <a href="/wiki/Neo-fascism" title="Neo-fascism">neo-fascist</a> regime has subjugated the United Kingdom. <a href="/wiki/Hugo_Weaving" title="Hugo Weaving">Hugo Weaving</a> portrays <a href="/wiki/V_(comics)" title="V (comics)">V</a>, an anarchist freedom fighter who attempts to ignite a revolution through elaborate terrorist acts and <a href="/wiki/Natalie_Portman" title="Natalie Portman">Natalie Portman</a> plays <a href="/wiki/Evey_Hammond" title="Evey Hammond">Evey</a>, a working-class girl caught up in V's mission, while <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Rea" title="Stephen Rea">Stephen Rea</a> portrays the detective leading a desperate quest to stop V.</p>
<p>The film was originally scheduled for release by <a href="/wiki/Warner_Bros." title="Warner Bros.">Warner Bros.</a> on Friday, November 4, 2005 (a day before the 400th <a href="/wiki/Guy_Fawkes_Night" title="Guy Fawkes Night">Guy Fawkes Night</a>), but was delayed; it opened on March 17, 2006, to positive reviews. Alan Moore, having been dissatisfied with the film adaptations of his other works <i><a href="/wiki/From_Hell_(film)" title="From Hell (film)">From Hell</a></i> (2001) and <i><a href="/wiki/The_League_of_Extraordinary_Gentlemen_(film)" title="The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen (film)">The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen</a></i> (2003), declined to watch the film and asked not to be credited or paid royalties.</p>
<p><i>V for Vendetta</i> has been seen by many political groups as an allegory of oppression by government; <a href="/wiki/Libertarianism" title="Libertarianism">libertarians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anarchism" title="Anarchism">anarchists</a> have used it to promote their beliefs. David Lloyd stated: "The <a href="/wiki/Guy_Fawkes_mask" title="Guy Fawkes mask">Guy Fawkes mask</a> has now become a common brand and a convenient placard to use in protest against tyranny  and I'm happy with people using it, it seems quite unique, an icon of popular culture being used this way."<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>In the late 2020s the world is in turmoil, with the United States fractured as a result of prolonged conflict and a <a href="/wiki/Pandemic" title="Pandemic">pandemic</a> of the "St. Mary's Virus" ravaging Europe. The <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> is ruled as a <a href="/wiki/Neo-fascism" title="Neo-fascism">fascist</a> police state by the <a href="/wiki/Norsefire" title="Norsefire">Norsefire</a> Party. <a href="/wiki/Political_dissent" title="Political dissent">Political opponents</a>, <a href="/wiki/Immigrants" title="Immigrants" class="mw-redirect">immigrants</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muslims" title="Muslims" class="mw-redirect">muslims</a>, <a href="/wiki/Homosexuals" title="Homosexuals" class="mw-redirect">homosexuals</a> and other "undesirables" are imprisoned in <a href="/wiki/Concentration_camp" title="Concentration camp" class="mw-redirect">concentration camps</a>. On November 4, a <a href="/wiki/Guy_Fawkes_mask" title="Guy Fawkes mask">Guy Fawkes-masked</a> vigilante identifying himself as "<a href="/wiki/V_(comics)" title="V (comics)">V</a>" (<a href="/wiki/Hugo_Weaving" title="Hugo Weaving">Hugo Weaving</a>) rescues <a href="/wiki/Evey_Hammond" title="Evey Hammond">Evey Hammond</a> (<a href="/wiki/Natalie_Portman" title="Natalie Portman">Natalie Portman</a>), an employee of the state-run British Television Network (BTN), from members of the "Fingermen" <a href="/wiki/Secret_police" title="Secret police">secret police</a> while she is out past <a href="/wiki/Curfew" title="Curfew">curfew</a>. From a rooftop, they watch his demolition of the <a href="/wiki/Old_Bailey" title="Old Bailey">Old Bailey</a> criminal court building, accompanied by fireworks and the <i><a href="/wiki/1812_Overture" title="1812 Overture">1812 Overture</a></i>. Inspector Finch (<a href="/wiki/Stephen_Rea" title="Stephen Rea">Stephen Rea</a>), <a href="/wiki/Scotland_Yard" title="Scotland Yard">Scotland Yard</a>'s Chief of Police, is tasked with investigating V's activities while BTN declares the incident an "emergency demolition". V interrupts the broadcast to claim responsibility and urges the people of <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">Britain</a> to rise up against their government. He asks them to meet him exactly one year later, on November 5, <a href="/wiki/Guy_Fawkes_Night" title="Guy Fawkes Night">Guy Fawkes Night</a>, outside the <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Westminster" title="Palace of Westminster">Houses of Parliament</a>, which he promises to destroy. During the broadcast, the police attempt to capture V. Evey helps him escape but is knocked unconscious.</p>
<p>V takes Evey to his home, where she is told she must remain for one year. After learning V is killing government officials, she offers to help and uses the opportunity to escape to the home of her boss, comedian and talk show host Gordon Deitrich (<a href="/wiki/Stephen_Fry" title="Stephen Fry">Stephen Fry</a>). In return for Evey trusting him with her safety, Gordon reveals prohibited materials including <a href="/wiki/Subversive" title="Subversive" class="mw-redirect">subversive</a> paintings, an antique <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Homoerotic" title="Homoerotic" class="mw-redirect">homoerotic</a> photographs. After Gordon performs a <a href="/wiki/Satire" title="Satire">satire</a> of the government on his show, his home is raided and Evey is captured. She is imprisoned and tortured for information about V, with her only solace being a note written by actress Valerie Page (<a href="/wiki/Natasha_Wightman" title="Natasha Wightman">Natasha Wightman</a>), who occupies a nearby cell.</p>
<p>Evey is told she will be executed unless she reveals V's location. When she says she would rather die, she is released and finds herself in V's home. It turns out that V was the one who had "captured" her at Gordon's home, and staged her imprisonment and torture to free her from her fears. The note was real, passed from Valerie to V when he was imprisoned. He also informs her that Deitrich had been executed when the Quran was found in his home. While Evey initially hates V for what he did to her, she realises she has become a stronger person. She leaves him, promising to return before November 5.</p>
<p>Finch learns V is the result of human experimentation and is murdering the people who detained him. Finch searches for the true identity of V, tracing him to a <a href="/wiki/Biological_warfare" title="Biological warfare">bioweapons</a> program at a detention centre for "social deviants" and <a href="/wiki/Political_dissident" title="Political dissident" class="mw-redirect">political dissidents</a> in <a href="/wiki/Larkhill" title="Larkhill">Larkhill</a> <a href="/wiki/Concentration_camp" title="Concentration camp" class="mw-redirect">concentration camp</a>. Finch meets William Rookwood, who tells him that the program, directed by then-<a href="/wiki/Undersecretary" title="Undersecretary">Undersecretary</a> <a href="/wiki/Adam_Susan" title="Adam Susan">Adam Sutler</a> (<a href="/wiki/John_Hurt" title="John Hurt">John Hurt</a>), resulted in the creation of the "St. Mary's Virus" and its release in a <a href="/wiki/False_flag" title="False flag">false flag</a> terrorist attack. The deaths of over 100,000 people and the resulting fear enabled the Norsefire Party to win the next election and turn the country into a <a href="/wiki/Totalitarian" title="Totalitarian" class="mw-redirect">totalitarian state</a> under Sutler's rule as High Chancellor. Finch later discovers the man he met was V in disguise, and Finch initially disbelieves his story.</p>
<p>As November 5 nears, V distributes thousands of Guy Fawkes masks and the population questions Party rule. On the eve of November 5, Evey visits V, who shows her an explosive-laden train in the abandoned <a href="/wiki/London_Underground" title="London Underground">London Underground</a>, set to destroy Parliament. He leaves it to Evey to decide whether to use it. V meets Party Leader Creedy (<a href="/wiki/Tim_Pigott-Smith" title="Tim Pigott-Smith">Tim Pigott-Smith</a>), with whom he made a deal to surrender in exchange for Sutler's execution. After Creedy executes Sutler, V reneges on his deal and kills Creedy and his men. Mortally wounded, he returns to Evey to thank her and tell her he loves her before dying.</p>
<p>As Evey places V's body aboard the train she is found by Finch. Disillusioned by the Party's regime, Finch allows Evey to send the train. Thousands of unarmed Londoners wearing Guy Fawkes masks march towards Parliament. Without orders, the military allows the crowd to pass. Parliament is destroyed as Finch asks Evey for V's identity, to which she replies, "He was all of us."</p>
<p><i>V for Vendetta</i> sets the <a href="/wiki/Gunpowder_Plot" title="Gunpowder Plot">Gunpowder Plot</a> as V's historical inspiration, contributing to his choice of timing, language and appearance.<sup id="cite_ref-official_production_6-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-official_production-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> For example, the names <a href="/wiki/Ambrose_Rookwood" title="Ambrose Rookwood">Rookwood</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Percy_(plotter)" title="Thomas Percy (plotter)" class="mw-redirect">Percy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Robert_Keyes" title="Robert Keyes">Keyes</a> are used in the film, which are also the names of three of the Gunpowder conspirators. The film creates parallels to <a href="/wiki/Alexandre_Dumas,_p%C3%A8re" title="Alexandre Dumas, pre" class="mw-redirect">Alexandre Dumas'</a> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Count_of_Monte_Cristo" title="The Count of Monte Cristo">The Count of Monte Cristo</a></i>, by drawing direct comparisons between V and <a href="/wiki/Edmond_Dant%C3%A8s" title="Edmond Dants">Edmond Dants</a>. (In both stories, the hero escapes an unjust and traumatic imprisonment and spends decades preparing to take vengeance on his oppressors under a new <a href="/wiki/Persona" title="Persona">persona</a>.)<sup id="cite_ref-Chum_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chum-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ReviewJournal_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReviewJournal-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BoxOfficeCritic_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoxOfficeCritic-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup> The film is also explicit in portraying V as the embodiment of an idea rather than an individual through V's dialogue and by depicting him without a past, identity or face. According to the official website, "V's use of the Guy Fawkes mask and persona functions as both practical and symbolic elements of the story. He wears the mask to hide his physical scars, and in obscuring his identity he becomes the idea itself."<sup id="cite_ref-official_production_6-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-official_production-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>As noted by several critics and commentators, the film's story and style mirror elements from <a href="/wiki/Gaston_Leroux" title="Gaston Leroux">Gaston Leroux</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_Phantom_of_the_Opera" title="The Phantom of the Opera">The Phantom of the Opera</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ebert_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ebert-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-sfgate_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sfgate-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup> V and the Phantom both wear masks to hide their disfigurements, control others through the leverage of their imaginations, have tragic pasts, and are motivated by revenge. V and Evey's relationship also parallels many of the romantic elements of <i>The Phantom of the Opera</i>, where the masked Phantom takes <a href="/wiki/Christine_Daa%C3%A9" title="Christine Daa">Christine Daa</a> to his subterranean lair to re-educate her.<sup id="cite_ref-Ebert_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ebert-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-sfgate_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sfgate-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Rolllingstones_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rolllingstones-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>As a film about the struggle between freedom and the state, <i>V for Vendetta</i> takes imagery from many classic totalitarian icons both real and fictional, including the <a href="/wiki/Third_Reich" title="Third Reich" class="mw-redirect">Third Reich</a> and <a href="/wiki/George_Orwell" title="George Orwell">George Orwell</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Nineteen_Eighty-Four" title="Nineteen Eighty-Four">Nineteen Eighty-Four</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-official_production_6-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-official_production-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-v_for_vendetta_interviews_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-v_for_vendetta_interviews-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> For example, Adam Sutler<sup id="cite_ref-v_for_vendetta_interviews_10-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-v_for_vendetta_interviews-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> primarily appears on large video screens and on portraits in people's homes, both common features among modern totalitarian regimes and reminiscent of the image of <a href="/wiki/Big_Brother_(Nineteen_Eighty-Four)" title="Big Brother (Nineteen Eighty-Four)">Big Brother</a>. The slogan "Strength through Unity. Unity through Faith" is displayed prominently across London, similar in cadence to "<a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Truth" title="Ministry of Truth" class="mw-redirect">War is Peace. Freedom is Slavery. Ignorance is Strength</a>" in Orwell's book.<sup id="cite_ref-LaTimes_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LaTimes-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> There is also the state's use of <a href="/wiki/Mass_surveillance" title="Mass surveillance">mass surveillance</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Closed-circuit_television" title="Closed-circuit television">closed-circuit television</a>, on its citizens. Valerie was sent to a detention facility for being a lesbian and then had medical experiments performed on her, reminiscent of the <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_homosexuals_in_Nazi_Germany_and_the_Holocaust" title="Persecution of homosexuals in Nazi Germany and the Holocaust">persecution of homosexuals in Nazi Germany and the Holocaust</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sfgate_17-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sfgate-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup> The name "Adam Sutler" and his hysterical style of speech are inspired by <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Hitler" title="Adolf Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a> although Jews appear to have been replaced by Muslims as a target for persecution. Norsefire has replaced <a href="/wiki/St_George%27s_Cross" title="St George's Cross">St George's Cross</a> with a national symbol similar to the modern <a href="/wiki/Cross_of_Lorraine" title="Cross of Lorraine">Cross of Lorraine</a> (both crossbars near the top). This was a symbol used by <a href="/wiki/Free_French_Forces" title="Free French Forces" class="mw-redirect">Free French Forces</a> during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, as it was a traditional symbol of French patriotism that could be used as an answer to the <a href="/wiki/Swastika#Nazi_Germany" title="Swastika">Nazis' swastika</a>.</p>
<p>"We felt the novel was very prescient to how the political climate is at the moment. It really showed what can happen when society is ruled by government, rather than the government being run as a voice of the people. I don't think it's such a big leap to say that things like that can happen when leaders stop listening to the people."</p>
<p>The filmmakers added topical references relevant to a 2006 audience. According to the <i><a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times" title="Los Angeles Times">Los Angeles Times</a></i>, "With a wealth of new, real-life parallels to draw from in the areas of government surveillance, torture, <a href="/wiki/Fear_mongering" title="Fear mongering">fear mongering</a> and <a href="/wiki/Media_manipulation" title="Media manipulation">media manipulation</a>, not to mention <a href="/wiki/Corporate_crime" title="Corporate crime">corporate corruption</a> and religious hypocrisy, you can't really blame the filmmakers for having a field day referencing current events." There are also references to an <a href="/wiki/Global_spread_of_H5N1" title="Global spread of H5N1">avian flu</a> pandemic,<sup id="cite_ref-LaTimes_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LaTimes-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> as well as pervasive use of <a href="/wiki/Biometrics" title="Biometrics">biometric identification</a> and <a href="/wiki/ECHELON" title="ECHELON">signal-intelligence gathering</a> and analysis by the regime.</p>
<p>Film critics, political commentators and other members of the media have also noted the film's numerous references to events surrounding the <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_George_W._Bush" title="Presidency of George W. Bush">George W. Bush administration</a> in the United States. These include the hoods and sacks worn by the prisoners in Larkhill that have been seen as a reference to the <a href="/wiki/Abu_Ghraib_torture_and_prisoner_abuse" title="Abu Ghraib torture and prisoner abuse">Abu Ghraib torture and prisoner abuse</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Age_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Age-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_New_Yorker_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_New_Yorker-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Homeland_Security_Advisory_System" title="Homeland Security Advisory System">Homeland Security Advisory System</a> and <a href="/wiki/Extraordinary_rendition_by_the_United_States" title="Extraordinary rendition by the United States" class="mw-redirect">rendition</a> are also referenced.<sup id="cite_ref-Christianity_Today_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Christianity_Today-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup> One of the forbidden items in Gordon's secret basement is a protest poster with a mixed U.S.U.K. flag with a <a href="/wiki/Swastika" title="Swastika">swastika</a> and the title "Coalition of the Willing, To Power" which combines the "<a href="/wiki/Multinational_force_in_Iraq" title="Multinational force in Iraq" class="mw-redirect">Coalition of the Willing</a>" with <a href="/wiki/Friedrich_Nietzsche" title="Friedrich Nietzsche">Friedrich Nietzsche's</a> concept of <a href="/wiki/Will_to_Power" title="Will to Power" class="mw-redirect">Will to Power</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-From_Script_to_Film_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-From_Script_to_Film-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Despite the America-specific references, the filmmakers have always referred to the film as adding dialogue to a set of issues much broader than the U.S. administration.<sup id="cite_ref-v_for_vendetta_interviews_10-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-v_for_vendetta_interviews-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> When James McTeigue was asked whether or not BTN was based on <a href="/wiki/Fox_News_Channel" title="Fox News Channel">Fox News Channel</a>, McTeigue replied, "Yes. But not just <a href="/wiki/Fox_News_Channel" title="Fox News Channel">Fox</a>. Everyone is complicit in this kind of stuff. It could just as well been the Britain's <a href="/wiki/Sky_News" title="Sky News">Sky News</a> Channel, also a part of <a href="/wiki/News_Corporation" title="News Corporation">News Corp</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-v_for_vendetta_interviews_10-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-v_for_vendetta_interviews-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film was made by many of the same filmmakers involved in <a href="/wiki/The_Matrix_series" title="The Matrix series" class="mw-redirect"><i>The Matrix</i> series</a>. In 1988, producer Joel Silver acquired the rights to two of <a href="/wiki/Alan_Moore" title="Alan Moore">Alan Moore</a>'s works: <i><a href="/wiki/V_for_Vendetta" title="V for Vendetta">V for Vendetta</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Watchmen" title="Watchmen">Watchmen</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-vendettasite_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vendettasite-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> After the release and relative success of <a href="/wiki/Road_House_(1989_film)" title="Road House (1989 film)"><i>Road House</i></a>, writer <a href="/wiki/Hilary_Henkin" title="Hilary Henkin">Hilary Henkin</a> was brought on to flesh out the project with an initial draft  one that bears little, if any, relation to the finished product, with the inclusion of overtly satirical and surrealistic elements not present in the graphic novel, as well as the removal of much of the novel's ambiguity, especially in regard to V's identity.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup> The Wachowskis were fans of <i>V for Vendetta</i> and in the mid-1990s, before working on <i><a href="/wiki/The_Matrix" title="The Matrix">The Matrix</a></i>, wrote a draft screenplay that closely followed the graphic novel. During the post-production of the second and third <i>The Matrix</i> films, they revisited the screenplay and offered the director's role to <a href="/wiki/James_McTeigue" title="James McTeigue">James McTeigue</a>. All three were intrigued by the original story's themes and found them to be relevant to the current political landscape. Upon revisiting the screenplay, the Wachowskis set about making revisions to condense and modernise the story, while at the same time attempting to preserve its integrity and themes. James McTeigue cites the film <i><a href="/wiki/The_Battle_of_Algiers_(film)" title="The Battle of Algiers (film)" class="mw-redirect">The Battle of Algiers</a></i> as his principal influence in preparing to film <i>V for Vendetta</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-official_production_6-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-official_production-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Moore explicitly disassociated himself from the film due to his lack of involvement in its writing or directing, as well as due to a continuing series of disputes over film adaptations of his work.<sup id="cite_ref-IGN_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IGN-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> He ended cooperation with his publisher, <a href="/wiki/DC_Comics" title="DC Comics">DC Comics</a>, after its corporate parent, <a href="/wiki/Warner_Bros." title="Warner Bros.">Warner Bros.</a>, failed to retract statements about Moore's supposed endorsement of the film. Moore said that the script contained plot holes<sup id="cite_ref-comicbookresource_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-comicbookresource-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup> and that it ran contrary to the theme of his original work, which was to place two political extremes (fascism and <a href="/wiki/Anarchism" title="Anarchism">anarchism</a>) against one another. He argues his work had been recast as a story about "current <a href="/wiki/Neoconservatism" title="Neoconservatism">American neo-conservatism</a> vs. current <a href="/wiki/Liberalism_in_the_United_States" title="Liberalism in the United States">American liberalism</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-mooreinterview_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mooreinterview-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup> Per his wishes, Moore's name does not appear in the film's closing credits. Co-creator and illustrator <a href="/wiki/David_Lloyd_(comics)" title="David Lloyd (comics)">David Lloyd</a> supports the film adaptation, commenting that the script is very good but that Moore would only ever be truly happy with a complete book-to-screen adaptation.<sup id="cite_ref-vendettasite_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vendettasite-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>V for Vendetta</i> was filmed in <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>, United Kingdom, and in <a href="/wiki/Potsdam" title="Potsdam">Potsdam</a>, Germany, at <a href="/wiki/Babelsberg_Studios" title="Babelsberg Studios" class="mw-redirect">Babelsberg Studios</a>. Much of the film was shot on <a href="/wiki/Sound_stage" title="Sound stage">sound stages</a> and indoor sets, with location work done in <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a> for three scenes: the Norsefire rally flashback, Larkhill, and Bishop Lilliman's bedroom. The scenes that took place in the abandoned <a href="/wiki/London_Underground" title="London Underground">London Underground</a> were filmed at the disused <a href="/wiki/Aldwych_tube_station" title="Aldwych tube station">Aldwych tube station</a>. Filming began in early March 2005 and principal photography officially wrapped in early June 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-vendettasite_24-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vendettasite-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>V for Vendetta</i> is the final film shot by <a href="/wiki/Cinematographer" title="Cinematographer">cinematographer</a> <a href="/wiki/Adrian_Biddle" title="Adrian Biddle">Adrian Biddle</a>, who died of a heart attack on December 7, 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>To film the final scene at <a href="/wiki/Westminster" title="Westminster">Westminster</a>, the area from <a href="/wiki/Trafalgar_Square" title="Trafalgar Square">Trafalgar Square</a> and <a href="/wiki/Whitehall" title="Whitehall">Whitehall</a> up to Parliament and <a href="/wiki/Clock_Tower,_Palace_of_Westminster" title="Clock Tower, Palace of Westminster" class="mw-redirect">Big Ben</a> had to be closed for three nights from midnight until 5am. This was the first time the security-sensitive area (home to <a href="/wiki/10_Downing_Street" title="10 Downing Street">10 Downing Street</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(United_Kingdom)" title="Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)">Ministry of Defence</a>) had ever been closed to accommodate filming.<sup id="cite_ref-About_the_Production_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-About_the_Production-29"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup> Prime Minister (at the time of filming) <a href="/wiki/Tony_Blair" title="Tony Blair">Tony Blair</a>'s son, Euan, worked on the film's production and is said (according to an interview with Stephen Fry) to have helped the filmmakers obtain the unparalleled filming access. This drew criticism of Blair from <a href="/wiki/Member_of_Parliament" title="Member of Parliament" class="mw-redirect">MP</a> <a href="/wiki/David_Davis_(British_politician)" title="David Davis (British politician)">David Davis</a> due to the film's content. However, the filmmakers denied Euan Blair's involvement in the deal,<sup id="cite_ref-tony_blair.27s_son_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tony_blair.27s_son-30"><span>[</span>30<span>]</span></a></sup> stating that access was acquired through nine months of negotiations with fourteen different government departments and agencies.<sup id="cite_ref-About_the_Production_29-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-About_the_Production-29"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film was designed to have a future-retro look, with heavy use of grey tones to give a dreary, stagnant feel to totalitarian London. The largest set created for the film was the Shadow Gallery, which was made to feel like a cross between a crypt and an <a href="/wiki/Undercroft" title="Undercroft">undercroft</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Unmasked_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Unmasked-31"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup> The Gallery is V's home as well as the place where he stores various artefacts forbidden by the government. Some of the works of art displayed in the gallery include <i><a href="/wiki/The_Arnolfini_Portrait" title="The Arnolfini Portrait" class="mw-redirect">The Arnolfini Portrait</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Jan_van_Eyck" title="Jan van Eyck">Jan van Eyck</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Bacchus_and_Ariadne" title="Bacchus and Ariadne">Bacchus and Ariadne</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Titian" title="Titian">Titian</a>, a <i><a href="/wiki/Mildred_Pierce_(film)" title="Mildred Pierce (film)">Mildred Pierce</a></i> poster, <i><a href="/wiki/St._Sebastian_(Mantegna)" title="St. Sebastian (Mantegna)">St. Sebastian</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Andrea_Mantegna" title="Andrea Mantegna">Andrea Mantegna</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lady_of_Shalott_(painting)" title="The Lady of Shalott (painting)">The Lady of Shalott</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/John_William_Waterhouse" title="John William Waterhouse">John William Waterhouse</a> and statues by <a href="/wiki/Giacometti" title="Giacometti" class="mw-redirect">Giacometti</a>. One of the major challenges in the film was how to bring V to life from under an expressionless mask. Thus, considerable effort was made to bring together lighting, acting, and Weaving's voice to create the proper mood for the situation. Since the mask muffled Weaving's voice, his entire dialogue was re-recorded in post-production.<sup id="cite_ref-About_the_Production_29-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-About_the_Production-29"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The cast and filmmakers attended several press conferences that allowed them to address issues surrounding the film, including its authenticity, Alan Moore's reaction to it and its intended political message. The film was intended to be a departure from some of Moore's original themes. In the words of Hugo Weaving: "Alan Moore was writing about something which happened some time ago. It was a response to living in <a href="/wiki/Thatcherite" title="Thatcherite" class="mw-redirect">Thatcherite</a> Britain... This is a response to the world in which we live today. So I think that the film and the graphic novel are two separate entities." Regarding the film's controversial political content, the filmmakers have said that the film is intended more to raise questions and add to a dialogue already present in society, rather than provide answers or tell viewers what to think.<sup id="cite_ref-v_for_vendetta_interviews_10-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-v_for_vendetta_interviews-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film adopts extensive imagery from the 1605 Gunpowder Plot, in which a group of Catholic conspirators plotted to destroy the then Houses of Parliament in order to spark a revolution in England.<sup id="cite_ref-vendettasite_24-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vendettasite-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> The film was originally scheduled for release on the weekend of November 5, 2005, the Plot's 400th anniversary, with the tag line "Remember, remember the 5th of November", taken from a traditional British rhyme memorialising the event. However, the marketing angle lost much of its value when the release date was pushed back to March 17, 2006. Many have speculated that the delay was caused by the London tube bombing on the <a href="/wiki/7_July_2005_London_bombings" title="7 July 2005 London bombings">July 7</a> and the failed <a href="/wiki/21_July_2005_London_bombings" title="21 July 2005 London bombings">July 21 bombing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup> The filmmakers have denied this, saying that the delays were due to the need for more time to finish the visual effects production.<sup id="cite_ref-Postponed_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Postponed-33"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>V for Vendetta</i> had its first major premiere on February 13 at the <a href="/wiki/Berlin_Film_Festival" title="Berlin Film Festival" class="mw-redirect">Berlin Film Festival</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-v_for_vendetta_interviews_10-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-v_for_vendetta_interviews-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> It opened for general release on March 17, 2006 in 3,365 cinemas in the United States, the United Kingdom and six other countries.<sup id="cite_ref-boxofficemojo_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-boxofficemojo-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>By December 2006, <i>V for Vendetta</i> had grossed $132,511,035, of which $70,511,035 was from the United States. The film led the U.S. box office on its opening day, taking in an estimated $8,742,504, and remained the number one film for the remainder of the weekend, taking in an estimated $25,642,340. Its closest rival, <i><a href="/wiki/Failure_to_Launch" title="Failure to Launch">Failure to Launch</a></i>, took in $15,604,892.<sup id="cite_ref-boxofficemojo_3-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-boxofficemojo-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> The film debuted at number one in the Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sweden and Taiwan. <i>V for Vendetta</i> also opened in 56 <a href="/wiki/IMAX" title="IMAX">IMAX</a> cinemas in North America, grossing $1.36 million during the opening three days.<sup id="cite_ref-imax_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imax-34"><span>[</span>34<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/At_the_Movies_with_Ebert_%26_Roeper" title="At the Movies with Ebert &amp; Roeper" class="mw-redirect">Ebert and Roeper</a> gave the film a "two thumbs up" rating. <a href="/wiki/Roger_Ebert" title="Roger Ebert">Roger Ebert</a> stated that <i>V for Vendetta</i> "almost always has something going on that is actually interesting, inviting us to decode the character and plot and apply the message where we will". <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Pomeranz" title="Margaret Pomeranz">Margaret Pomeranz</a> and <a href="/wiki/David_Stratton" title="David Stratton">David Stratton</a> from <a href="/wiki/At_the_Movies_(Australian_TV_series)" title="At the Movies (Australian TV series)"><i>At the Movies</i></a> stated that despite the problem of never seeing Weaving's face, there was good acting and an interesting plot, adding that the film is also disturbing, with scenes reminiscent of Nazi Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-at_the_movies_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-at_the_movies-35"><span>[</span>35<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jonathan_Ross_(television_presenter)" title="Jonathan Ross (television presenter)" class="mw-redirect">Jonathan Ross</a> from the BBC blasted the film, calling it a "woeful, depressing failure" and stating that the "cast of notable and familiar talents such as John Hurt and Stephen Rea stand little chance amid the wreckage of the Wachowski siblings' dismal script and its particularly poor dialogue."<sup id="cite_ref-jonathan_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jonathan-36"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup> Sean Burns of <i><a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_Weekly" title="Philadelphia Weekly">Philadelphia Weekly</a></i> gave the film a 'D', criticizing the film's treatment of its political message as being "fairly dim, adolescent stuff,"<sup id="cite_ref-seanburns_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-seanburns-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup> as well as expressing dislike for the "barely decorated sets with television-standard overlit shadow-free cinematography by the late Adrian Biddle. The film is a visual insult."<sup id="cite_ref-seanburns_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-seanburns-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup> On Alan Moore removing his name from the project, Burns says "it's not hard to see why,"<sup id="cite_ref-seanburns_37-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-seanburns-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup> as well as criticising Portman's performance: "Portman still seems to believe that standing around with your mouth hanging open constitutes a performance."<sup id="cite_ref-seanburns_37-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-seanburns-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup> Harry Guerin from the Irish TV network <a href="/wiki/Radio_Telef%C3%ADs_%C3%89ireann" title="Radio Telefs ireann" class="mw-redirect">RT</a> states the film "works as a political thriller, adventure and social commentary and it deserves to be seen by audiences who would otherwise avoid any/all of the three". He added that the film will become "a cult favourite whose reputation will only be enhanced with age."<sup id="cite_ref-rte_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rte-38"><span>[</span>38<span>]</span></a></sup> Andy Jacobs for the BBC gave the film two stars out of five, remarking that it is "a bit of a mess... it rarely thrills or engages as a story."<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39"><span>[</span>39<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>V for Vendetta</i> received few awards, although at the 2007 <a href="/wiki/Saturn_Awards" title="Saturn Awards" class="mw-redirect">Saturn Awards</a> Natalie Portman won the <a href="/wiki/Saturn_Award_for_Best_Actress" title="Saturn Award for Best Actress">Best Actress</a> award.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span>[</span>40<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> gives the film a 73% "Certified Fresh" approval rating.<sup id="cite_ref-rt_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rt-41"><span>[</span>41<span>]</span></a></sup> The film was nominated for the <a href="/wiki/Hugo_Award_for_Best_Dramatic_Presentation,_Long_Form" title="Hugo Award for Best Dramatic Presentation, Long Form" class="mw-redirect">Hugo Award for Best Dramatic Presentation, Long Form</a> in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span>[</span>42<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>V</i> was included on <i>Fandomania</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'s</span> list of <i>The 100 Greatest Fictional Characters</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span>[</span>43<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Empire_(film_magazine)" title="Empire (film magazine)">Empire</a></i> magazine (in 2008) named the film the 418th greatest movie of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44"><span>[</span>44<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>V for Vendetta</i> deals with issues of homosexuality, <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_religion" title="Criticism of religion">criticism of religion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Totalitarianism" title="Totalitarianism">totalitarianism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islamophobia" title="Islamophobia">Islamophobia</a> and terrorism. Its controversial story line and themes have been the target of both criticism and praise from <a href="/wiki/Sociopolitical" title="Sociopolitical" class="mw-redirect">sociopolitical</a> groups.</p>
<p>On April 17, 2006 the New York Metro Alliance of Anarchists organised a protest against DC Comics and <a href="/wiki/Time_Warner" title="Time Warner">Time Warner</a>, accusing it of watering down the story's original message in favour of violence and special effects.<sup id="cite_ref-Columbia_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Columbia-45"><span>[</span>45<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NYMAA_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYMAA-46"><span>[</span>46<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/David_Graeber" title="David Graeber">David Graeber</a>, an anarchist scholar and former professor at <a href="/wiki/Yale_University" title="Yale University">Yale University</a>, was not upset by the film. "I thought the message of anarchy got out in spite of Hollywood." However, Graeber went on to state: "Anarchy is about creating communities and democratic decision making. That's what is absent from Hollywood's interpretation."<sup id="cite_ref-Columbia_45-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Columbia-45"><span>[</span>45<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Film critic <a href="/wiki/Richard_Roeper" title="Richard Roeper">Richard Roeper</a> dismissed right-wing Christian criticism of the film on the television show <i>Ebert and Roeper</i>, saying that V's terrorist label is applied in the film "by someone who's essentially Hitler, a dictator."<sup id="cite_ref-ROTTEN_.26_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ROTTEN_.26-47"><span>[</span>47<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/LGBT" title="LGBT">LGBT</a> commentators have praised the film for its positive depiction of homosexuals. <a href="/wiki/Sarah_Warn" title="Sarah Warn">Sarah Warn</a> of <a href="/wiki/AfterEllen.com" title="AfterEllen.com" class="mw-redirect">AfterEllen.com</a> called the film "one of the most pro-gay ever". Warn went on to praise the central role of the character Valerie "not just because it is beautifully acted and well-written, but because it is so utterly unexpected [in a Hollywood film]."<sup id="cite_ref-afterellen_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-afterellen-48"><span>[</span>48<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/David_Walsh_(film_critic)" title="David Walsh (film critic)" class="mw-redirect">David Walsh</a> from the <a href="/wiki/World_Socialist_Web_Site" title="World Socialist Web Site">World Socialist Web Site</a> criticises V's actions as "antidemocratic," calling the film an example of "the bankruptcy of <a href="/wiki/Propaganda_of_the_deed" title="Propaganda of the deed">anarcho-terrorist</a> ideology;" Walsh writes that because the people have not played any part in the revolution, they will be unable to produce a "new, liberated society."<sup id="cite_ref-socialist_criticism_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-socialist_criticism-49"><span>[</span>49<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Clay_Duke" title="Clay Duke" class="mw-redirect">Clay Duke</a>, the perpetrator of the <a href="/wiki/2010_Panama_City_school_board_shootings" title="2010 Panama City school board shootings">2010 Panama City school board shootings</a>, was reportedly obsessed with the film <i>V for Vendetta.</i> Prior to the shootings and his eventual suicide, Duke spray-painted a red <i>V</i> inside a red circle, a supposed allusion to his fascination with the graphic novel.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50"><span>[</span>50<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film was broadcast on China's national TV station, <a href="/wiki/China_Central_Television" title="China Central Television">China Central Television</a> (CCTV) on December 16, 2012 completely uncensored,<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span>[</span>51<span>]</span></a></sup> surprising many viewers. While many believed that the government had banned the film, the <a href="/wiki/State_Administration_of_Radio,_Film_and_Television" title="State Administration of Radio, Film and Television" class="mw-redirect">State Administration of Radio, Film and Television</a> stated that it was not aware of a ban; CCTV makes its own decisions on whether to censor foreign films. Liu Shanying, a political scientist at the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Academy_of_Social_Sciences" title="Chinese Academy of Social Sciences">Chinese Academy of Social Sciences</a> who used to work for CCTV, speculated that the showing indicated that <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_China" title="Censorship in China">Chinese film censorship</a> might be loosened.<sup id="cite_ref-watt20121220_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-watt20121220-52"><span>[</span>52<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film's story was adapted from Alan Moore and David Lloyd's graphic novel <i>V for Vendetta</i>; this was originally published between 1982 and 1985 in the British comic anthology <i><a href="/wiki/Warrior_(comics)" title="Warrior (comics)">Warrior</a></i>, and then reprinted and completed by DC. Moore's comics were later compiled into a graphic novel and published again in the United States under DC's <a href="/wiki/Vertigo_Comics" title="Vertigo Comics" class="mw-redirect">Vertigo</a> imprint and in the United Kingdom under <a href="/wiki/Titan_Books" title="Titan Books">Titan Books</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53"><span>[</span>53<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>There are several fundamental differences between the film and the original source material. For example, the comic is set in the 1990s, while the film is set sometime between 2028 and 2038: Alan Moore's original story was created as a response to British Thatcherism in the early '80s and was set as a conflict between a fascist state and anarchism, while the film's story has been changed by the Wachowski Brothers to fit a modern political context. Alan Moore, however, charged that, in doing so, the story has turned into an American-centric conflict between <a href="/wiki/Liberalism_(US)" title="Liberalism (US)" class="mw-redirect">liberalism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neo-conservatism" title="Neo-conservatism" class="mw-redirect">neo-conservatism</a>, and abandons the original anarchist-fascist themes. Moore states "There wasn't a mention of anarchy as far as I could see. The fascism had been completely defanged. I mean, I think that any references to <a href="/wiki/Racial_policy_of_Nazi_Germany" title="Racial policy of Nazi Germany">racial purity</a> had been excised, whereas actually, fascists are quite big on racial purity." Furthermore, in the original story, Moore attempted to maintain moral ambiguity, and not to portray the fascists as caricatures, but as realistic, rounded characters. The time limitations of a film meant that the story had to omit or streamline some of the characters, details, and plotlines from the original story.<sup id="cite_ref-official_production_6-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-official_production-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> Chiefly, the original graphic novel has the fascists elected legally and kept in power through the general apathy of the public, whereas the film introduces the "St. Mary's virus", a biological weapon engineered and released by the Norsefire Party as a means of clandestinely gaining control over their own country.</p>
<p>Many of the characters from the graphic novel underwent significant changes for the film. V is characterized in the film as a romantic freedom fighter who shows concern over the loss of innocent life.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54"><span>[</span>54<span>]</span></a></sup> However, in the graphic novel, he is portrayed as ruthless, willing to kill anyone who gets in his way. Evey Hammond's transformation as V's <a href="/wiki/Mentorship" title="Mentorship">protge</a> is also much more drastic in the novel than in the film. At the beginning of the film, she is already a confident woman with a hint of rebellion in her; in the graphic novel, she starts off as an insecure, desperate young woman forced into prostitution. V and Evey's relationship, though not as obvious in the book, ends in the film with pledges of love. In the graphic novel's finale, she not only carries out V's plans as she does in the film, but also clearly takes on V's identity.<sup id="cite_ref-IGN_7-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IGN-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> In the film, Inspector Finch sympathizes with V, but, in the graphic novel, he is determined to stop V and goes as far as taking <a href="/wiki/Lysergic_acid_diethylamide" title="Lysergic acid diethylamide">LSD</a> to enter into a criminal's state of mind. Gordon, a very minor character in both adaptations, is also drastically changed. In the novel, Gordon is a small-time criminal who takes Evey into his home after V abandons her on the street. The two share a brief romance before Gordon is killed by a Scottish gang. In the film, however, Gordon is a well-mannered colleague of Evey's, and is later revealed to be gay. He is arrested by fingermen for broadcasting a political parody on his TV program, and is later executed when a <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a> is found in his possession.<sup id="cite_ref-IGN_7-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IGN-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>V for Vendetta</i> was released on DVD in the US on August 1, 2006<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55"><span>[</span>55<span>]</span></a></sup> in three formats: a single-disc wide-screen version, a single-disc full-screen version, and a two-disc <a href="/wiki/Widescreen" title="Widescreen">wide-screen</a> special edition.<sup id="cite_ref-DVD_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DVD-56"><span>[</span>56<span>]</span></a></sup> DVD sales were successful, selling 1,412,865 DVD units in the first week of release which translated to $27,683,818 in revenue. By the end of 2006, 3,086,073 DVD units had been sold, bringing in slightly more than its production cost of $58,342,597.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57"><span>[</span>57<span>]</span></a></sup> The single disc versions contain a short (15:56) behind-the-scenes <a href="/wiki/Featurette" title="Featurette">featurette</a> titled "Freedom! Forever!<sup id="cite_ref-Widescreen_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Widescreen-58"><span>[</span>58<span>]</span></a></sup> Making V for Vendetta" and the film's <a href="/wiki/Theatrical_trailer" title="Theatrical trailer" class="mw-redirect">theatrical trailer</a>, whereas the two-disc special edition contains three additional documentaries, and several extra features for collectors. On the second disc of the special edition, a short <a href="/wiki/Easter_egg_(media)" title="Easter egg (media)">Easter egg</a> clip of Natalie Portman on <i><a href="/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live" title="Saturday Night Live">Saturday Night Live</a></i> can be viewed by selecting the picture of wings on the second page of the menu. The film has also been released on the <a href="/wiki/HD_DVD" title="HD DVD">HD DVD</a> <a href="/wiki/High-definition_video" title="High-definition video">high definition</a> format, which features a unique 'in-film experience' created exclusively for the disc. Warner Bros. later released the video on <a href="/wiki/Blu-Ray" title="Blu-Ray" class="mw-redirect">Blu-Ray</a>, on May 20, 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span>[</span>59<span>]</span></a></sup> The film also saw release on Sony's PSP UMD format.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60"><span>[</span>60<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The <i>V for Vendetta</i> <a href="/wiki/Film_soundtrack" title="Film soundtrack" class="mw-redirect">soundtrack</a> was released by <a href="/wiki/Astralwerks" title="Astralwerks">Astralwerks Records</a> on March 21, 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61"><span>[</span>61<span>]</span></a></sup> The original scores from the film's composer, <a href="/wiki/Dario_Marianelli" title="Dario Marianelli">Dario Marianelli</a>, make up most of the tracks on the album.<sup id="cite_ref-tillnes2006_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tillnes2006-62"><span>[</span>62<span>]</span></a></sup> The soundtrack also features three vocals played during the film: "<a href="/wiki/Cry_Me_a_River" title="Cry Me a River">Cry Me a River</a>" by <a href="/wiki/Julie_London" title="Julie London">Julie London</a>, a cover of <a href="/wiki/The_Velvet_Underground" title="The Velvet Underground">The Velvet Underground</a> song, "<a href="/wiki/I_Found_a_Reason" title="I Found a Reason">I Found a Reason</a>" by <a href="/wiki/Cat_Power" title="Cat Power">Cat Power</a> and "Bird Gerhl" by <a href="/wiki/Antony_and_the_Johnsons" title="Antony and the Johnsons">Antony and the Johnsons</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-tillnes2006_62-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tillnes2006-62"><span>[</span>62<span>]</span></a></sup> As mentioned in the film, these songs are samples of the 872 <a href="/wiki/Blacklisted#Political_context" title="Blacklisted" class="mw-redirect">blacklisted</a> tracks on V's <a href="/wiki/Wurlitzer" title="Wurlitzer">Wurlitzer jukebox</a> that V "reclaimed" from the Ministry of Objectionable Materials. The climax of <a href="/wiki/Tchaikovsky" title="Tchaikovsky" class="mw-redirect">Tchaikovsky</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/1812_Overture" title="1812 Overture">1812 Overture</a></i> appears at the end of the track "Knives and Bullets (and Cannons too)". The Overture's <i><a href="/wiki/Finale_(music)" title="Finale (music)">finale</a></i> is played at key parts at the beginning and end of the film.</p>
<p>Three songs were played during the ending credits which were not included on the <i>V for Vendetta</i> soundtrack.<sup id="cite_ref-tillnes2006_62-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tillnes2006-62"><span>[</span>62<span>]</span></a></sup> The first was "<a href="/wiki/Street_Fighting_Man" title="Street Fighting Man">Street Fighting Man</a>" by the <a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stones" title="Rolling Stones" class="mw-redirect">Rolling Stones</a>. The second was a special version of <a href="/wiki/Ethan_Stoller" title="Ethan Stoller">Ethan Stoller</a>'s "BKAB". In keeping with revolutionary tone of the film, excerpts from "On Black Power" (also in "A Declaration of Independence") by <a href="/wiki/Black_nationalism" title="Black nationalism">black nationalist</a> leader <a href="/wiki/Malcolm_X" title="Malcolm X">Malcolm X</a>, and from "Address to the Women of America" by feminist writer <a href="/wiki/Gloria_Steinem" title="Gloria Steinem">Gloria Steinem</a> were added to the song. Gloria Steinem can be heard saying: "This is no simple reform... It really is a revolution. Sex and race, because they are easy and visible differences, have been the primary ways of organising human beings into superior and inferior groups and into the cheap labour on which this system still depends." The final song was "<a href="/wiki/Let_It_Come_Down_(Spiritualized_album)" title="Let It Come Down (Spiritualized album)">Out of Sight</a>" by <a href="/wiki/Spiritualized" title="Spiritualized">Spiritualized</a>.</p>
<p>Also in the film were segments from two of <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Carlos_Jobim" title="Antonio Carlos Jobim" class="mw-redirect">Antonio Carlos Jobim</a>'s classic <a href="/wiki/Bossa_nova" title="Bossa nova">bossa nova</a> songs, "<a href="/wiki/The_Girl_from_Ipanema" title="The Girl from Ipanema">The Girl From Ipanema</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Corcovado_(song)" title="Corcovado (song)">Quiet Nights of Quiet Stars</a>". These songs were played during the "breakfast scenes" with V and Deitrich and were one of the ways used to tie the two characters together. <a href="/wiki/Symphony_No._5_(Beethoven)" title="Symphony No. 5 (Beethoven)">Beethoven's <i>Symphony No.5</i></a> also plays an important role in the film, with the first four notes of the first movement signifying the letter "V" in <a href="/wiki/Morse_code" title="Morse code">Morse code</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-graphic_novel_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-graphic_novel-63"><span>[</span>63<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BBC_News_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_News-64"><span>[</span>64<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon Deitrich's <a href="/wiki/Benny_Hill" title="Benny Hill">Benny Hill</a>-styled comedy sketch of Chancellor Sutler includes the "<a href="/wiki/Yakety_Sax" title="Yakety Sax">Yakety Sax</a>" theme. Inspector Finch's alarm clock begins the morning of November 4 with the song "Long Black Train" by <a href="/wiki/Richard_Hawley" title="Richard Hawley">Richard Hawley</a>, which contains the <a href="/wiki/Foreshadowing" title="Foreshadowing">foreshadowing</a> lyrics "Ride the long black train... take me home black train."</p>
<p>The original graphic novel by Moore and Lloyd was re-released as a hardback collection in October 2005 to tie into the film's original release date of November 5, 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65"><span>[</span>65<span>]</span></a></sup> The film renewed interest in Alan Moore's original story, and sales of the original graphic novel rose dramatically in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-Televisionpoint_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Televisionpoint-66"><span>[</span>66<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>A novelisation of the film, written by <a href="/wiki/Steve_Moore_(comics)" title="Steve Moore (comics)">Steve Moore</a> and based on the Wachowski Brothers' script, was published by <a href="/wiki/Pocket_Star" title="Pocket Star" class="mw-redirect">Pocket Star</a> on January 31, 2006. Spencer Lamm, who has worked with the Wachowskis, created a "<a href="/wiki/Making-of" title="Making-of">behind-the-scenes</a>" book. Titled <i>V for Vendetta: From Script to Film</i>, it was published by Universe on August 22, 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67"><span>[</span>67<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>As well as promotional items created to publicise the film (which included a shoulder bag and bust of "V"'s Guy Fawkes mask), replicas of the mask and action figures were released.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68"><span>[</span>68<span>]</span></a></sup> Figures released by NECA include a 12-inch (30cm) action figure which speaks phrases from the film, a 12-inch resin statue and a seven-inch (17cm) figure.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69"><span>[</span>69<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Good Will Hunting</i></h1>
<p><i><b>Good Will Hunting</b></i> is a 1997 American <a href="/wiki/Drama_film" title="Drama film" class="mw-redirect">drama film</a> directed by <a href="/wiki/Gus_Van_Sant" title="Gus Van Sant">Gus Van Sant</a>, and stars <a href="/wiki/Matt_Damon" title="Matt Damon">Matt Damon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robin_Williams" title="Robin Williams">Robin Williams</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ben_Affleck" title="Ben Affleck">Ben Affleck</a>, <a href="/wiki/Minnie_Driver" title="Minnie Driver">Minnie Driver</a> and <a href="/wiki/Stellan_Skarsg%C3%A5rd" title="Stellan Skarsgrd">Stellan Skarsgrd</a>. Written by Affleck and Damon, and with Damon in the title role, the film follows 20-year-old <a href="/wiki/South_Boston" title="South Boston">South Boston</a> laborer Will Hunting, an unrecognized genius who, as part of a <a href="/wiki/Deferred_prosecution" title="Deferred prosecution">deferred prosecution</a> agreement after assaulting a police officer, becomes a client of a therapist (Williams) and studies advanced mathematics with a renowned professor (Skarsgrd). Through his therapy sessions, Will re-evaluates his relationships with his best friend (Affleck), his girlfriend (Driver) and himself, facing the significant task of thinking about his future.</p>
<p>The film received universal critical acclaim and was a financial success. It grossed over US$225 million during its theatrical run with only a modest $10 million budget. It was nominated for nine <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award" title="Academy Award" class="mw-redirect">Academy Awards</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Academy Award for Best Picture</a>, and won two: <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actor" title="Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor">Best Supporting Actor</a> for Williams and <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Writing_(Original_Screenplay)" title="Academy Award for Best Writing (Original Screenplay)" class="mw-redirect">Best Original Screenplay</a> for Damon and Affleck.</p>
<p>After Williams' death in 2014, it was ranked at number 53 in <i>The Hollywood Reporter</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s 100 Favorite Films list.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
