<p>Twenty-year-old Will Hunting (Damon) of <a href="/wiki/South_Boston" title="South Boston">South Boston</a> is a self-taught, genius-level intellect with an <a href="/wiki/Eidetic_memory" title="Eidetic memory">eidetic memory</a>, though he works simply as a janitor at the <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology" title="Massachusetts Institute of Technology">Massachusetts Institute of Technology</a>, and spends his free time drinking with his friends, Chuckie (Affleck), Billy (<a href="/wiki/Cole_Hauser" title="Cole Hauser">Cole Hauser</a>) and Morgan (<a href="/wiki/Casey_Affleck" title="Casey Affleck">Casey Affleck</a>). When Professor Gerald Lambeau (Skarsgrd) posts a difficult problem taken from <a href="/wiki/Algebraic_graph_theory" title="Algebraic graph theory">algebraic graph theory</a> as a challenge for his graduate students, Will solves the problem anonymously, stunning both the graduate students and Lambeau himself. As a challenge to the unknown genius, Lambeau posts an even more difficult problem and chances upon Will solving it. Fearing he will lose his sole means of (a meager) income, Will flees and skips going into work the next day. That night, Will meets Skylar (Driver), a British orphan about to graduate from <a href="/wiki/Harvard" title="Harvard" class="mw-redirect">Harvard</a>, who plans on attending medical school at <a href="/wiki/Stanford_University_School_of_Medicine" title="Stanford University School of Medicine">Stanford</a>.</p>
<p>Assaulting both a man who bullied him as a child and a police officer who attempts to break up the fight, Will faces incarceration, but Lambeau arranges for him to forgo jail time if he agrees to study mathematics under Lambeau's supervision while simultaneously seeking <a href="/wiki/Psychotherapy" title="Psychotherapy">psychotherapy</a>. Will tentatively agrees but treats his first few therapists with contempt; his refusal to open up is met with staunch defiance by the <a href="/wiki/Bourgeois" title="Bourgeois" class="mw-redirect">bourgeois</a> mentality of the therapists, who each refuse to treat Will further. In desperation, Lambeau calls on Dr. Sean Maguire (Williams), his estranged and much more grounded college roommate, who now teaches psychology at <a href="/wiki/Bunker_Hill_Community_College" title="Bunker Hill Community College">Bunker Hill Community College</a>. Unlike the other therapists, Sean actually challenges Will's weak defense mechanisms, and after a few unproductive sessions, Will begins to open up.</p>
<p>Will is particularly struck by Sean's story of how he met his wife by giving up his ticket to the historic sixth game of the <a href="/wiki/1975_World_Series" title="1975 World Series">1975 World Series</a>, after falling in love at first sight. Sean neither regrets his decision, nor does he regret the final years of his marriage, when his wife was dying of cancer. This encourages Will to build a relationship with Skylar, though he lies to her about his past and is reluctant to introduce her to his friends or show her his rundown neighborhood. Will also challenges Sean to take an objective look at his own life, since Sean has been unable to move on from his wife's death.</p>
<p>Chafing under Lambeau's high expectations, Will makes a mockery of job interviews that Lambeau arranges for him. He turns down a position for the <a href="/wiki/National_Security_Agency" title="National Security Agency">National Security Agency</a>, offering a scathing critique of the agency's actions to his interviewer. When Skylar asks Will to move to California with her, he panics and pushes her away, revealing that he is an orphan and that his foster father physically abused him. Skylar tells Will that she loves him, but he refuses and leaves her room. Will next storms out on Lambeau, dismissing the mathematical research he has been doing. Sean points out that Will is so adept at anticipating future failure in his interpersonal relationships that he deliberately sabotages them in order to avoid emotional pain. When Will refuses to give an honest reply about what he wants to do with his life, Sean shows him the door. Will tells Chuckie he wants to be a laborer for the rest of his life, Chuckie responds that it would be an insult to his friends for Will to waste his potential and that his fondest wish is that Will should leave to pursue something greater.</p>
<p>Will walks in on a heated argument between Sean and Lambeau over his future. Sean and Will share that they were both victims of child abuse. Sean helps Will to see that he is a victim of his own inner demons and to accept that it is not his fault. Sean comforts Will as he cries over the 20 years of trauma. Will decides to accept one of the job offers arranged by Lambeau. Having helped Will overcome his problems, Sean reconciles with Lambeau and decides to take a sabbatical to travel the world. When Will's friends present him with a rebuilt <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Nova" title="Chevrolet Nova" class="mw-redirect">Chevrolet Nova</a> for his twenty-first birthday, he decides to pass on his job offers and drive to California to reunite with Skylar. Sometime later, Chuckie goes to Will's house to pick him up, only to find that he is not there. Sean comes out of his house and finds a letter from Will in his mailbox, which tells him he is going to see Skylar, much to his pleasure. The credits roll as Will's car is shown driving on the highway to California.</p>
<p>Originally, <a href="/wiki/Matt_Damon" title="Matt Damon">Matt Damon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ben_Affleck" title="Ben Affleck">Ben Affleck</a> wrote the <a href="/wiki/Screenplay#Spec_scripts" title="Screenplay">screenplay</a> as a thriller about a young man in the rough-and-tumble streets of <a href="/wiki/South_Boston" title="South Boston">South Boston</a> who possesses a superior intelligence and is targeted by the FBI to become a <a href="/wiki/G-Man_(slang)" title="G-Man (slang)">G-Man</a>. <a href="/wiki/Castle_Rock_Entertainment" title="Castle Rock Entertainment">Castle Rock Entertainment</a> president <a href="/wiki/Rob_Reiner" title="Rob Reiner">Rob Reiner</a> later urged them to drop the thriller aspect of the story and to focus on the relationship between Will Hunting (Damon) and his psychologist (Williams). At Reiner's request, screenwriter <a href="/wiki/William_Goldman" title="William Goldman">William Goldman</a> read the script and further suggested that the film's climax ought to be Will's decision to follow his girlfriend Skylar to California. Goldman has consistently denied the persistent rumor that he wrote <i>Good Will Hunting</i> or acted as a <a href="/wiki/Script_doctor" title="Script doctor">script doctor</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> In his book <i><a href="/wiki/Which_Lie_Did_I_Tell%3F" title="Which Lie Did I Tell?">Which Lie Did I Tell?</a></i>, Goldman jokingly writes, "I did not just doctor it. I wrote the whole thing from scratch." before dismissing the rumour as false.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Castle Rock bought the script for $675,000 against $775,000, meaning that Damon and Affleck would stand to earn an additional $100,000 if the film was produced and they retained sole writing credit. However, studios balked at the idea of Affleck and Damon in the lead roles, with many studio executives stating that they wanted <a href="/wiki/Brad_Pitt" title="Brad Pitt">Brad Pitt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_DiCaprio" title="Leonardo DiCaprio">Leonardo DiCaprio</a>. At the time Damon and Affleck were meeting at Castle Rock, <a href="/wiki/Kevin_Smith" title="Kevin Smith">Kevin Smith</a> was working with Affleck on <i><a href="/wiki/Mallrats" title="Mallrats">Mallrats</a></i> and with both Damon and Affleck on <i><a href="/wiki/Chasing_Amy" title="Chasing Amy">Chasing Amy</a>.</i><sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> Castle Rock put the script in turnaround, and gave Damon and Affleck 30 days to find another buyer for the script who would reimburse Castle Rock the money paid, otherwise the script reverted to the studio, and Damon and Affleck would be out. All the studios that were involved in the original bidding war for the screenplay now each turned the pair down, taking meetings with Affleck and Damon only to tell them this to their face. As a last resort, Affleck passed the script to his <i>Chasing Amy</i> director Kevin Smith, who read it and promised to walk the script directly into Harvey Weinstein's office at Miramax. Weinstein read the script, loved it, and paid Castle Rock their due, while also agreeing to let Damon and Affleck star in the movie. In his recollection of the meeting, Weinstein asked about an out-of-place, mid-script <a href="/wiki/Oral_sex" title="Oral sex">oral sex</a> scene, which Damon and Affleck explained was a test to see which studio executives had actually read the script.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>After buying the rights from Castle Rock, Miramax gave the green light to put the film into production. Several well-known filmmakers were originally considered to direct, including <a href="/wiki/Mel_Gibson" title="Mel Gibson">Mel Gibson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michael_Mann_(film_director)" title="Michael Mann (film director)" class="mw-redirect">Michael Mann</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Steven_Soderbergh" title="Steven Soderbergh">Steven Soderbergh</a>. Originally, Affleck asked Kevin Smith if he was interested in directing. He declined, saying they needed a "good director" and that he only directs things he writes and is not much of a visual director. Damon and Affleck later chose <a href="/wiki/Gus_Van_Sant" title="Gus Van Sant">Gus Van Sant</a> for the job, whose work on previous films like <i><a href="/wiki/Drugstore_Cowboy" title="Drugstore Cowboy">Drugstore Cowboy</a></i> (1989) had left a favorable impression on the fledgling screenwriters. Miramax was persuaded and hired Van Sant to direct the film.</p>
<p>Much of the filming was done on location in the Greater <a href="/wiki/Boston" title="Boston">Boston</a> area and <a href="/wiki/Toronto" title="Toronto">Toronto</a> between April and June 1997. Although the story is set in Boston, much of the film was shot at locations in Canada, with the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Toronto" title="University of Toronto">University of Toronto</a> standing in for the interiors of <a href="/wiki/MIT" title="MIT" class="mw-redirect">MIT</a> and <a href="/wiki/Harvard_University" title="Harvard University">Harvard University</a>. The classroom scenes were filmed at McLennan Physical Laboratories (of the University of Toronto) and <a href="/wiki/Central_Technical_School" title="Central Technical School">Central Technical School</a>. Harvard normally disallows filming on its property, but permitted limited filming by the project after intervention by Harvard alumnus <a href="/wiki/John_Lithgow" title="John Lithgow">John Lithgow</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup> Likewise, only the exterior shots of <a href="/wiki/Bunker_Hill_Community_College" title="Bunker Hill Community College">Bunker Hill Community College</a> were filmed in Boston; however, Sean's office was built in Toronto as an exact replica of one at the college.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The restaurant to which Lambeau took Sean was <a href="/wiki/Locke-Ober" title="Locke-Ober">Locke-Ober</a> on Winter Place. It closed in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The interior bar scenes set in "<a href="/wiki/South_Boston" title="South Boston">Southie</a>" were shot on location at Woody's L St. Tavern.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup> Meanwhile, the homes of Will (fronting at 190 West 6th Street) and Sean (Joe Keating's three-decker apartment at 259 E Street, which was two-way at time of filming), while some distance apart in the movie, actually back up to each other on Bowen Street, the narrow street Chuckie drives down on a couple of occasions to walk up to Will's back door.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-scenery_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scenery-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The Bow and Arrow Pub, which was located at the corner of Bow Street and <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts_Avenue_(Boston)" title="Massachusetts Avenue (Boston)" class="mw-redirect">Massachusetts Avenue</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cambridge,_Massachusetts" title="Cambridge, Massachusetts">Cambridge</a>, doubled as the Harvard bar in which Will met Skylar for the first time. The <a href="/wiki/Baskin-Robbins" title="Baskin-Robbins">Baskin-Robbins</a>/<a href="/wiki/Dunkin%27_Donuts" title="Dunkin' Donuts">Dunkin' Donuts</a> featured in the "<a href="/wiki/How_do_you_like_them_apples" title="How do you like them apples">How'd you like <i>them</i> apples?</a>" scene was next door to the pub (now Grafton Street) at the time of the film's release, but it later moved two doors down, after One Bow Street opened up between the two the following year.<sup id="cite_ref-scenery_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scenery-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Tasty_Sandwich_Shop" title="Tasty Sandwich Shop">The Tasty</a>, which is the present-day <a href="/wiki/Citizens_Financial_Group" title="Citizens Financial Group">Citizens Bank</a> at the corner of JFK and Brattle Streets, was the scene of Will and Skylar's first kiss.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Au_Bon_Pain" title="Au Bon Pain">Au Bon Pain</a>, where Will and Skylar discuss the former's <a href="/wiki/Photographic_memory" title="Photographic memory" class="mw-redirect">photographic memory</a>, is at the corner of Dunster Street and Mass Ave.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Boston_Public_Garden" title="Boston Public Garden" class="mw-redirect">Boston Public Garden</a> bench on which Will and Sean sat for a scene in the film became a temporary shrine after Williams' death in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Director Gus Van Sant says in the <a href="/wiki/DVD_commentary" title="DVD commentary" class="mw-redirect">DVD commentary</a> that, had he known just how successful the film was going to be, he would have left at least a couple of edited scenes intact that were cut purely for considerations of length. One of these involves Skylar's visit to Chuckie in hopes of shedding light on some of Will's eccentricities that Will himself is unwilling to discuss.</p>
<p>The film is dedicated to the memory of poet <a href="/wiki/Allen_Ginsberg" title="Allen Ginsberg">Allen Ginsberg</a> and writer <a href="/wiki/William_S._Burroughs" title="William S. Burroughs">William S. Burroughs</a>, both of whom died in 1997.</p>
<p>In the film's opening weekend in limited release, it earned $272,912. In its January 1998 wide-release opening weekend, it earned $10,261,471. It went on to gross $138,433,435 in <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a> for a total worldwide gross of $225,900,000.</p>
<p><i>Good Will Hunting</i> received critical acclaim. Review aggregation website <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> gives the film a rating of 97%, based on 70 reviews, with an average rating of 8/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "It follows a predictable narrative arc, but <i>Good Will Hunting</i> adds enough quirks to the journey -- and is loaded with enough powerful performances -- that it remains an entertaining, emotionally rich drama."<sup id="cite_ref-RottenTomatoes_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RottenTomatoes-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> At <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>, the film has a score of 70 out of 100, based on 28 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".<sup id="cite_ref-Metacritic_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Metacritic-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Roger_Ebert" title="Roger Ebert">Roger Ebert</a> gave the film three out of four stars, writing that while the story is "predictable", it is "the individual moments, not the payoff, that make it so effective."<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Several scholars have examined the film as a portrayal of <a href="/wiki/Anti-Catholicism_in_the_United_States" title="Anti-Catholicism in the United States">residual CatholicProtestant tensions in Boston</a>, as <a href="/wiki/Irish_Catholic" title="Irish Catholic">Irish Catholics</a> from <a href="/wiki/South_Boston" title="South Boston">Southie</a> are aligned against ostensibly <a href="/wiki/White_Anglo-Saxon_Protestant" title="White Anglo-Saxon Protestant">Protestant</a> characters who are affiliated with <a href="/wiki/Harvard_University" title="Harvard University">Harvard</a> and <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology" title="Massachusetts Institute of Technology">MIT</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Herlihy-Mera_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Herlihy-Mera-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The musical score for <i>Good Will Hunting</i> was composed by <a href="/wiki/Danny_Elfman" title="Danny Elfman">Danny Elfman</a>, who had previously collaborated with <a href="/wiki/Gus_Van_Sant" title="Gus Van Sant">Gus Van Sant</a> on <i><a href="/wiki/To_Die_For" title="To Die For">To Die For</a></i> and would go on to score many of the director's other films. The film also features many songs written and recorded by singer-songwriter <a href="/wiki/Elliott_Smith" title="Elliott Smith">Elliott Smith</a>. His song "<a href="/wiki/Miss_Misery" title="Miss Misery">Miss Misery</a>" was nominated for the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Song" title="Academy Award for Best Original Song">Academy Award for Best Original Song</a>, but lost to "<a href="/wiki/My_Heart_Will_Go_On" title="My Heart Will Go On">My Heart Will Go On</a>" from <i><a href="/wiki/Titanic_(1997_film)" title="Titanic (1997 film)">Titanic</a></i>. Elfman's score was also nominated for an <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award" title="Academy Award" class="mw-redirect">Oscar</a>, but lost to <i>Titanic</i> as well. On September 11, 2006, NBC's <i><a href="/wiki/Today_(NBC_program)" title="Today (NBC program)" class="mw-redirect">The Today Show</a></i> used Elfman's song "Weepy Donuts" while <a href="/wiki/Matt_Lauer" title="Matt Lauer">Matt Lauer</a> spoke during the opening credits.</p>
<p>A soundtrack album for the film was released by <a href="/wiki/Capitol_Records" title="Capitol Records">Capitol Records</a> on November 18, 1997, though only two of Elfman's cues appear on the release.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>"<a href="/wiki/Afternoon_Delight" title="Afternoon Delight">Afternoon Delight</a>" by the <a href="/wiki/Starland_Vocal_Band" title="Starland Vocal Band">Starland Vocal Band</a> was featured in the film, but did not appear on the soundtrack album.</p>
<p>A limited edition soundtrack album featuring Elfman's complete score from the film was released by Music Box Records on March 3, 2014. The soundtrack, issued in 1500 copies, includes all of Elfman's cues (including music not featured on the rare Miramax Academy promo) and also contains the songs by Elliott Smith. One of the tracks is Smith's songs with Elfman's arrangements added into the mix.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Mary and Max</i></h1>
<p><i><b>Mary and Max</b></i> is a 2009 Australian <a href="/wiki/Stop_motion" title="Stop motion">stop motion animated</a> <a href="/wiki/Black_comedy" title="Black comedy">dark comedy</a>-<a href="/wiki/Drama_film" title="Drama film" class="mw-redirect">drama film</a> written and directed by <a href="/wiki/Adam_Elliot" title="Adam Elliot">Adam Elliot</a> as his first animated feature film with music by Dale Cornelius and produced by Melanie Coombs and Melodrama Pictures. The voice cast included <a href="/wiki/Philip_Seymour_Hoffman" title="Philip Seymour Hoffman">Philip Seymour Hoffman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toni_Collette" title="Toni Collette">Toni Collette</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eric_Bana" title="Eric Bana">Eric Bana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bethany_Whitmore" title="Bethany Whitmore">Bethany Whitmore</a> with narration by <a href="/wiki/Barry_Humphries" title="Barry Humphries">Barry Humphries</a>. The film premiered on the opening night of the <a href="/wiki/2009_Sundance_Film_Festival" title="2009 Sundance Film Festival">2009 Sundance Film Festival</a> on January 15, 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> The film won the Annecy Cristal in June 2009 from the <a href="/wiki/Annecy_International_Animated_Film_Festival" title="Annecy International Animated Film Festival">Annecy International Animated Film Festival</a>, and Best Animated Feature Film at the <a href="/wiki/Asia_Pacific_Screen_Awards" title="Asia Pacific Screen Awards">Asia Pacific Screen Awards</a> in November 2009. The film was theatrically released on April 9, 2009 by <a href="/wiki/Icon_Productions" title="Icon Productions">Icon Entertainment International</a>. <i>Mary and Max</i> received generally very positive reviews from critics and it earned $1.7 million USD on a $8.2 million AUD budget.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>In 1976, eight-year-old Mary Daisy Dinkle (<a href="/wiki/Bethany_Whitmore" title="Bethany Whitmore">Bethany Whitmore</a>) lives a lonely life in <a href="/wiki/Mount_Waverley,_Victoria" title="Mount Waverley, Victoria">Mount Waverley</a>, Australia. At school, she is teased by her classmates because of an unfortunate birthmark on her forehead; while at home, her distant father, Noel, and alcoholic, <a href="/wiki/Kleptomaniac" title="Kleptomaniac" class="mw-redirect">kleptomaniac</a> mother, Vera, provide little support. Her only comforts are her pet rooster, Ethel; her favourite food, sweetened <a href="/wiki/Condensed_milk" title="Condensed milk">condensed milk</a>; and a <a href="/wiki/The_Smurfs" title="The Smurfs">Smurfs</a>-like cartoon show called <i>The Noblets</i>. One day, while at the post office with her mother, Mary spots a <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a> telephone book and, becoming curious about Americans, decides to write to one. She randomly chooses Max Jerry Horowitz's name from the phone book and writes him a letter telling him about herself, sending it off in the hope that he will become her <a href="/wiki/Pen_pal" title="Pen pal">pen friend</a>.</p>
<p>Max Jerry Horowitz (<a href="/wiki/Philip_Seymour_Hoffman" title="Philip Seymour Hoffman">Philip Seymour Hoffman</a>) is a <a href="/wiki/Obesity-associated_morbidity" title="Obesity-associated morbidity">morbidly obese</a> 44-year-old ex-<a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">Jewish</a> <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheist</a> who has trouble forming close bonds with other people, due to various mental and social problems. Though Mary's letter initially gives him an <a href="/wiki/Anxiety_attack" title="Anxiety attack" class="mw-redirect">anxiety attack</a>, he decides to write back to her, and the two quickly become friends (partly due to their shared love of chocolate and <i>The Noblets</i>). Due to Vera's disapproval of Max, Mary tells him to send his letters to her <a href="/wiki/Agoraphobia" title="Agoraphobia">agoraphobic</a> neighbour, Len Hislop, whose mail she collects regularly. When Mary later asks Max about <a href="/wiki/Romance_(love)" title="Romance (love)">love</a>, he suffers a severe anxiety attack and is institutionalized for eight months. After his release, he is hesitant to write to Mary again for some time. On his 48th birthday, he wins the New York lottery, using his winnings to buy a lifetime supply of chocolate and an entire collection of Noblet figurines. He gives the rest of his money to his elderly neighbour Ivy, who uses most of it to pamper herself before dying in an accident with a malfunctioning <a href="/wiki/Jet_pack" title="Jet pack">jet pack</a>. Meanwhile, Mary becomes despondent, thinking Max has abandoned her.</p>
<p>On the advice of his therapist, Max finally writes back to Mary and explains he has been diagnosed with <a href="/wiki/Asperger_syndrome" title="Asperger syndrome">Asperger syndrome</a>. Mary is thrilled to hear from him again, and the two continue their correspondence for the next several years. When Noel retires from his job at a tea bag factory, he takes up <a href="/wiki/Metal_detector" title="Metal detector">metal detecting</a>, but is soon swept away (and presumably killed) by a big <a href="/wiki/Tidal_bore" title="Tidal bore">tidal bore</a> while on a beach. Mary (<a href="/wiki/Toni_Colette" title="Toni Colette" class="mw-redirect">Toni Colette</a>) goes to university and has her birthmark surgically removed, and develops a crush on her <a href="/wiki/Greek_Australians" title="Greek Australians">Greek Australian</a> neighbour, Damien Popodopoulos (<a href="/wiki/Eric_Bana" title="Eric Bana">Eric Bana</a>). Drunk and guilt-ridden over her husband's death, Vera accidentally kills herself after she drinks <a href="/wiki/Embalming_chemicals" title="Embalming chemicals">embalming fluid</a> (which she mistook for <a href="/wiki/Classification_of_wine#Other_styles" title="Classification of wine">cooking sherry</a>). Mary and Damien grow closer following Vera's death and are later married.</p>
<p>Inspired by her friendship with Max, Mary studies <a href="/wiki/Psychology" title="Psychology">psychology</a> at university, writing her doctoral dissertation on Asperger syndrome with Max as her test subject. She plans to have her dissertation published as a book; but when Max receives a copy from her, he is infuriated that she has taken advantage of his condition, which he sees as an integral part of his personality and not a disability that needs to be cured. He breaks off communication with Mary (by removing the letter "M" from his typewriter), who, heartbroken, has the entire run of her book <a href="/wiki/Pulped" title="Pulped" class="mw-redirect">pulped</a>, effectively ending her budding career. She sinks into <a href="/wiki/Major_depressive_disorder" title="Major depressive disorder">depression</a> and begins drinking cooking sherry, as her mother had done. While searching through a cabinet, she finds a can of condensed milk, and sends it to Max as an apology. She checks the post daily for a response and one day finds a note from Damien, informing her that he has left her for his own pen friend, Desmond, a sheep farmer in New Zealand.</p>
<p>Meanwhile, after an incident in which he nearly chokes a homeless man (<a href="/wiki/Ian_%22Molly%22_Meldrum" title='Ian "Molly" Meldrum' class="mw-redirect">Ian "Molly" Meldrum</a>) in anger, after throwing a used cigarette, Max realizes Mary is an imperfect human being, like himself, and sends her a package containing his Noblet figurine collection as a sign of forgiveness. Mary, however, has sunken into despair after Damien's departure, and fails to find the package on her doorstep for several days. Finding some <a href="/wiki/Diazepam" title="Diazepam">Valium</a> that had belonged to her mother, and unaware that she is pregnant with Damien's child, Mary decides to commit <a href="/wiki/Suicide" title="Suicide">suicide</a>. As she takes the Valium and is on the verge of hanging herself, Len knocks on her door, having conquered his <a href="/wiki/Agoraphobia" title="Agoraphobia">agoraphobia</a> to alert her of Max's package. Inside, she finds the Noblet figurines and a letter from Max, in which he tells her of his realization that they are not perfect and expresses his forgiveness. He also states how much their friendship means to him, and that he hopes their paths will cross one day.</p>
<p>One year later, Mary travels to New York with her infant child to finally visit Max. Entering his apartment, Mary discovers Max on his couch, gazing upward with a smile on his face, having died earlier that morning. Looking around the apartment, Mary is awestruck to find all the letters she had sent to Max over the years, laminated and taped to the ceiling. Realizing Max had been gazing at the letters when he died, and seeing how much he had valued their friendship, Mary cries tears of joy and joins him on the couch.</p>
<p>The film deals with themes including <a href="/wiki/Child_neglect" title="Child neglect">childhood neglect</a>, <a href="/wiki/Friendship" title="Friendship">friendship</a>, the obscurity of life, <a href="/wiki/Teasing" title="Teasing">teasing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Loneliness" title="Loneliness">loneliness</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mental_illness" title="Mental illness" class="mw-redirect">mental illness</a>, <a href="/wiki/Autism" title="Autism">autism</a> (<a href="/wiki/Asperger_syndrome" title="Asperger syndrome">Asperger syndrome</a> in particular), <a href="/wiki/Obesity" title="Obesity">obesity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suicide" title="Suicide">suicide</a>, <a href="/wiki/Major_depressive_disorder" title="Major depressive disorder">depression</a>, <a href="/wiki/Solitude" title="Solitude">isolation</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Anxiety" title="Anxiety">anxiety</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>According to the opening credits, the film is based on a true story. In an interview given in April 2009, writer-director Elliot clarified that the character of Max was inspired by "a pen-friend in New York who I've been writing to for over twenty years."<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Principal_photography" title="Principal photography">Principal photography</a> lasted over 57 weeks, using 133 separate sets, 212 puppets, and 475 miniature <a href="/wiki/Theatrical_property" title="Theatrical property">props</a>, "including a fully functioning <a href="/wiki/Underwood_Typewriter_Company" title="Underwood Typewriter Company">Underwood typewriter</a> which apparently took 9 weeks to design and build."<sup id="cite_ref-infilmaus_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-infilmaus-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The music in the film features <a href="/wiki/Simon_Jeffes" title="Simon Jeffes">Simon Jeffes</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Penguin_Cafe_Orchestra" title="Penguin Cafe Orchestra">Penguin Cafe Orchestra</a>'s "Perpetuum Mobile" (the opening theme) and "Prelude and Yodel", as well as "Russian Rag" by <a href="/wiki/Elena_Kats-Chernin" title="Elena Kats-Chernin">Elena Kats-Chernin</a>. The closing-credits music is "<a href="/wiki/A_Swingin%27_Safari" title="A Swingin' Safari">A Swingin' Safari</a>" by <a href="/wiki/Bert_Kaempfert" title="Bert Kaempfert">Bert Kaempfert</a> and his Orchestra. Other artists include <a href="/wiki/Nana_Mouskouri" title="Nana Mouskouri">Nana Mouskouri</a>, Dale Cornelius, <a href="/wiki/Leroy_Anderson" title="Leroy Anderson">Leroy Anderson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pink_Martini" title="Pink Martini">Pink Martini</a>, London Pops Orchestra, <a href="/wiki/James_Last" title="James Last">James Last</a> and his Orchestra, <a href="/wiki/The_King%27s_Consort" title="The King's Consort">The King's Consort</a> and Choir, the Sydney Alpha Ensemble, and the <a href="/wiki/Symphony_Australia" title="Symphony Australia" class="mw-redirect">ABC Radio Orchestra</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>This film also includes the <a href="/wiki/Pink_Martini" title="Pink Martini">Pink Martini</a> version of <a href="/wiki/Doris_Day" title="Doris Day">Doris Day</a>'s most well-known song, "<a href="/wiki/Que_Sera,_Sera_(Whatever_Will_Be,_Will_Be)" title="Que Sera, Sera (Whatever Will Be, Will Be)">Que Sera Sera</a>", which is played over Mary's attempted suicide scene.</p>
<p><i>Mary and Max</i> received generally very positive reviews.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup> As of August 2014, 95% (57 of 60) of the critics at the film review aggregator <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> rate <i>Mary and Max</i> fresh, with eleven of the fourteen "Top Critic" reviews agreeing.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup> Matt Ravier, writing for <i>In Film Australia</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-infilmaus_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-infilmaus-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup> said the "story is paper-thin and some stretches of it are simply too long, yet whenever the narrative thread threatens to tear the sheer authenticity and bold honesty of the characters save the day". The <i><a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times" title="Los Angeles Times">Los Angeles Times</a></i> called it a "remarkable and poignant" film depicting a "<a href="/wiki/Film_noir" title="Film noir">film noir</a> world of blacks, whites and grays for Max and a <a href="/wiki/Photographic_print_toning#Sepia_tone" title="Photographic print toning">sepia</a> <a href="/wiki/Suburb" title="Suburb">suburbia</a> for Mary".<sup id="cite_ref-latimes_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-latimes-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup> After the film was released on DVD in the United States, <i><a href="/wiki/Slant_Magazine" title="Slant Magazine">Slant</a></i> said "Adam Elliot's dry wit is pervasive throughout <i>Mary and Max</i> and it's nice to see that this unique sense of humor extends to the extras. The writer-director gives a funny and informative <a href="/wiki/Audio_commentary" title="Audio commentary">audio commentary</a> and a set of hilarious making-of episodes reflects the sardonic tone of the production. The big prize here, however, is the addition of Elliot's Oscar-winning short <i><a href="/wiki/Harvie_Krumpet" title="Harvie Krumpet">Harvie Krumpet</a></i>. This Geoffrey Rush-narrated tale of the titular Tourette syndrome sufferer is a wonderful introduction both to Elliot's sensibilities and to <i>Mary and Max</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s specific tone."<sup id="cite_ref-slantmag_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-slantmag-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Mary and Max</i> grossed $1,444,617 at the Australian box office.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup> The film received no general theatrical release in the United States, though it was showcased at several American film festivals,<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup> and was briefly shown at one of the <a href="/wiki/Laemmle_Theatres" title="Laemmle Theatres">Laemmle Theatres</a> in the Los Angeles area.<sup id="cite_ref-latimes_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-latimes-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup> The film's U.S. distributor (<a href="/wiki/IFC_Films" title="IFC Films">IFC Films</a>) made the film available through <a href="/wiki/Video_on_demand" title="Video on demand">video on demand</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-slantmag_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-slantmag-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup> The film was released in France by Gaumont<sup id="cite_ref-maryetmax.gaumont.fr_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-maryetmax.gaumont.fr-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup> and in Germany by MFA<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> to significant critical and box office success.</p>
<p>This film was also short listed for the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Animated_Feature" title="Academy Award for Best Animated Feature">Academy Award for Best Animated Feature</a>, but was ultimately not nominated.</p>
<p><i>Mary and Max</i> was released on DVD on January 26, 2010 by <a href="/wiki/Icon_Entertainment_International" title="Icon Entertainment International" class="mw-redirect">Icon Entertainment International</a>.</p>
<p>An exhibit of artefacts and clips from the film were presented in France and Australia. In France the exhibition was hosted by Gaumont as part of the release.<sup id="cite_ref-maryetmax.gaumont.fr_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-maryetmax.gaumont.fr-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup> In Australia initially at the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Centre_for_the_Moving_Image" title="Australian Centre for the Moving Image">Australian Centre for the Moving Image</a> for three months starting in March 2010<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup> and then touring around Australia throughout 2010/2011.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Lon: The Professional</i></h1>
<p><i><b>Lon: The Professional</b></i> (<a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a>: <span lang="fr"><i><b>Lon</b></i></span>; also known as <i><b>The Professional</b></i>) is a 1994 English-language French <a href="/wiki/Thriller_(genre)" title="Thriller (genre)">crime thriller film</a><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> written and directed by <a href="/wiki/Luc_Besson" title="Luc Besson">Luc Besson</a>. It stars <a href="/wiki/Jean_Reno" title="Jean Reno">Jean Reno</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gary_Oldman" title="Gary Oldman">Gary Oldman</a>, and features the motion picture debut of <a href="/wiki/Natalie_Portman" title="Natalie Portman">Natalie Portman</a>. In the film Leon (Reno), a professional hitman, reluctantly takes in 12-year-old girl Mathilda (Portman), after her family is murdered by corrupt <a href="/wiki/Drug_Enforcement_Administration" title="Drug Enforcement Administration">Drug Enforcement Administration</a> agent <a href="/wiki/Norman_Stansfield" title="Norman Stansfield">Norman Stansfield</a> (Oldman). Lon and Mathilda form an unusual relationship, as she becomes his <a href="/wiki/Mentorship" title="Mentorship">protge</a> and learns the hitman's trade.</p>
<p><i>Lon: The Professional</i> was a commercial success, grossing over $45 million worldwide on a $16 million budget.<sup id="cite_ref-the-numbers_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-the-numbers-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>Lon Montana (<a href="/wiki/Jean_Reno" title="Jean Reno">Jean Reno</a>) is a Franco-Italian <a href="/wiki/Hitman" title="Hitman" class="mw-redirect">hitman</a> (or "cleaner", as he refers to himself) living a solitary life in New York City's <a href="/wiki/Little_Italy,_Manhattan" title="Little Italy, Manhattan">Little Italy</a>. His work comes from a <a href="/wiki/Mafia" title="Mafia">mafioso</a> named Tony (<a href="/wiki/Danny_Aiello" title="Danny Aiello">Danny Aiello</a>). Lon spends his idle time engaging in calisthenics, nurturing a houseplant, and watching old films.</p>
<p>One day, Lon sees Mathilda Lando (<a href="/wiki/Natalie_Portman" title="Natalie Portman">Natalie Portman</a>), a twelve-year-old girl who is smoking a cigarette and sporting a black eye. Mathilda lives with her dysfunctional family in an apartment down the hall. Her abusive father and self-absorbed stepmother have not noticed that Mathilda stopped attending class at her school for troubled girls. Mathilda's father (<a href="/wiki/Michael_Badalucco" title="Michael Badalucco">Michael Badalucco</a>) attracts the ire of corrupt <a href="/wiki/Drug_Enforcement_Administration" title="Drug Enforcement Administration">DEA</a> agents, who have been paying him to stash <a href="/wiki/Cocaine" title="Cocaine">cocaine</a> in his apartment. After they discover he has been cutting the cocaine to keep some for himself, DEAagents storm the building, led by sharply dressed drug addict <a href="/wiki/Norman_Stansfield" title="Norman Stansfield">Norman Stansfield</a> (<a href="/wiki/Gary_Oldman" title="Gary Oldman">Gary Oldman</a>). During the raid, Stansfield quickly becomes unhinged and murders Mathilda's entire family one by one while Mathilda is out shopping. When Mathilda returns, she realizes what has happened just in time to continue down the hall, where she desperately knocks on her neighbour's door. A hesitant Lon gives her shelter.</p>
<p>Mathilda quickly discovers that Lon is a hitman. She begs him to take care of her and to teach her his skills, as she wants to avenge the murder of her four-year-old brother. At first, Lon is unsettled by her presence. He even almost kills her in her sleep, possibly out of mercy, but can't bring himself to do it. The next morning, Lon tries to throw Mathilda out, but she claims that, because he saved her life the previous day, he is now responsible for her, stating that she would be dead by the end of the day if he threw her out and it would be like he had never opened the door for her. She begs him to train her as a "cleaner," demonstrating her willingness to learn by taking Lon's gun and firing randomly onto the street outside his open window. Reluctantly, Lon trains Mathilda and shows her how to use various weapons. In return, she runs his errands, cleans his apartment, and teaches him how to read. Mathilda tells Lon she loves him several times, but he offers no response.</p>
<p>One day after Mathilda has learned how to shoot, she fills a bag with guns from Lon's collection and sets out to kill Stansfield. She bluffs her way into the DEA office by posing as a delivery girl, only to be ambushed by Stansfield in a bathroom. Mathilda learns from Stansfield that Lon killed one of the corrupt DEA agents in Chinatown that morning. Lon, after discovering her plan in a note left for him, rescues Mathilda, shooting two more of Stansfield's men in the process. A now enraged Stansfield goes to find Tony, and assaults him in order to find out where Lon is.</p>
<p>When Mathilda returns home from grocery shopping, an <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Police_Department_Emergency_Service_Unit" title="New York City Police Department Emergency Service Unit">NYPD ESU</a> team sent by Stansfield captures her and attempts to infiltrate Lon's apartment. Lon ambushes the ESU team and grabs Mathilda. Back in his apartment, Lon creates a quick escape for Mathilda by smashing a hole in an air shaft. He reassures her and tells her that he loves her and that she has given him "a taste for life", moments before the police come for him. In the chaos that follows, Lon sneaks out of the building disguised as a wounded ESU officer. He goes unnoticed save for Stansfield, who recognizes him, follows him downstairs and shoots him in the back. As he is dying, Lon places an object in Stansfield's hands that he says is "from Mathilda". Opening his hands, Stansfield discovers that it is the pin from a grenade. He then opens Lon's vest to find a cluster of active grenades, which detonate moments later, killing them both.</p>
<p>Mathilda heads to see Tony, as Lon had instructed her to do before he died. Tony reveals to Mathilda that Lon instructed him to give his money to her if anything happened to him. He offers to hold the money and provide it to her on an allowance basis, on account of her youth. Mathilda asks Tony to give her a job as a hitman; Tony angrily declines, telling Mathilda to forget about her ordeal and return to school. Mathilda meets with the school headmistress, who readmits her after Mathilda tells her what had happened in the past several days and if the headmistress doesn't help her now, Mathilda would be dead by the end of the day. She then walks into a field near the school to plant Lon's houseplant, as she had told Lon he should, to give it roots.</p>
<p><i>Lon: The Professional</i> is to some extent an expansion of an idea in Besson's earlier 1990 film, <i><a href="/wiki/Nikita_(film)" title="Nikita (film)">La Femme Nikita</a></i> (in some countries <i>Nikita</i>). In <i>La Femme Nikita</i> <a href="/wiki/Jean_Reno" title="Jean Reno">Jean Reno</a> plays a similar character named Victor. Besson described Lon as "Now maybe Jean is playing the American cousin of Victor. This time he's more human."<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>While most of the interior footage was shot in France, the rest of the film was shot on location in New York. The final scene at the school was filmed at the <a href="/wiki/Stevens_Institute_of_Technology" title="Stevens Institute of Technology">Stevens Institute of Technology</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hoboken,_New_Jersey" title="Hoboken, New Jersey">Hoboken</a>, New Jersey.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>A soundtrack for the film was released in October 1994. It was commercially successful in Japan, being certified gold for 100,000 copies shipped in December 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-RIAJ-feb2000_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RIAJ-feb2000-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Lon: The Professional</i> received favorable reviews from critics. The film holds a "Certified Fresh" rating on <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a>, with an aggregate rating of 72% based on 57 critical reviews. The site's consensus states, "Pivoting on the unusual relationship between seasoned hitman and his 12-year-old apprenticea breakout turn by young Natalie PortmanLuc Besson's <i>Lon</i> is a stylish and oddly affecting thriller".<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> At <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>, the film received an average score of 64 based on 12 reviews, indicating "Generally favorable reviews".<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Mark Salisbury of <a href="/wiki/Empire_(film_magazine)" title="Empire (film magazine)"><i>Empire</i> magazine</a> awarded the film a full five stars. He said, "Oozing style, wit and confidence from every sprocket, and offering a dizzyingly, fresh perspective on the Big Apple that only Besson could bring, this is, in a word, wonderful".<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup> Mark Deming at <a href="/wiki/AllMovie" title="AllMovie">AllMovie</a> awarded the film four stars out of five, describing it as "As visually stylish as it is graphically violent", and featuring "a strong performance from Jean Reno, a striking debut by Natalie Portman, and a love-it-or-hate-it, over-the-top turn by Gary Oldman".<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Richard_Schickel" title="Richard Schickel">Richard Schickel</a> of <a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)"><i>Time</i> magazine</a> lauded the film, writing, "this is a Cuisinart of a movie, mixing familiar yet disparate ingredients, making something odd, possibly distasteful, undeniably arresting out of them". He praised Oldman's performance as "divinely psychotic".<sup id="cite_ref-schickel_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-schickel-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Roger_Ebert" title="Roger Ebert">Roger Ebert</a> awarded the film two-and-a-half stars out of four, writing: "It is a well-directed film, because Besson has a natural gift for plunging into drama with a charged-up visual style. And it is well acted." However, he was not entirely complimentary: "Always at the back of my mind was the troubled thought that there was something wrong about placing a 12-year-old character in the middle of this action. ... In what is essentially an exercisea slick urban thrillerit seems to exploit the youth of the girl without really dealing with it."<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span> <a href="/wiki/Janet_Maslin" title="Janet Maslin">Janet Maslin</a> wrote, "<i>The Professional</i> is much too sentimental to sound shockingly amoral in the least. Even in a finale of extravagant violence, it manages to be maudlin  Mr. Oldman expresses most of the film's sadism as well as many of its misguidedly poetic sentiments."<sup id="cite_ref-nyt_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Lon: The Professional</i> was a commercial success, grossing over $45 million worldwide on a $16 million budget.<sup id="cite_ref-the-numbers_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-the-numbers-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Lon: The Professional</i> won the <a href="/wiki/Czech_Lion_Awards" title="Czech Lion Awards">Czech Lion Award</a> for Best Foreign Language Film and the <a href="/wiki/Motion_Picture_Sound_Editors" title="Motion Picture Sound Editors">Golden Reel Award</a> for Best Sound Editing  Foreign Feature. The film was also nominated for seven <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Award" title="Csar Award">Csar Awards</a> in <a href="/wiki/20th_C%C3%A9sar_Awards" title="20th Csar Awards">1995</a>, namely <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Award_for_Best_Film" title="Csar Award for Best Film">Best Film</a>, <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Award_for_Best_Actor" title="Csar Award for Best Actor">Best Actor</a> (Jean Reno), <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Award_for_Best_Director" title="Csar Award for Best Director">Best Director</a>, <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Award_for_Best_Cinematography" title="Csar Award for Best Cinematography">Best Cinematography</a>, <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Award_for_Best_Editing" title="Csar Award for Best Editing">Best Editing</a>, <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Award_for_Best_Music_Written_for_a_Film" title="Csar Award for Best Music Written for a Film" class="mw-redirect">Best Music</a>, and <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Award_for_Best_Sound" title="Csar Award for Best Sound">Best Sound</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In the 2013 book, <i>Poseur: A Memoir of Downtown New York City in the '90s</i>, <a href="/wiki/Marc_Spitz" title="Marc Spitz">Marc Spitz</a> describes the film as a "<a href="/wiki/Cult_film" title="Cult film">cult classic</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup> In 2014, <i><a href="/wiki/Time_Out_(magazine)" title="Time Out (magazine)">Time Out</a></i> polled several film critics, directors, actors and stunt actors to list their top action films; <i>Lon: The Professional</i> was listed at No. 42.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup> The character <a href="/wiki/Norman_Stansfield" title="Norman Stansfield">Norman Stansfield</a> has since been named by several publications as one of cinema's greatest villains.</p>
<p>The British band <a href="/wiki/Alt-J" title="Alt-J">Alt-J</a> released a song about the film, titled '<a href="/wiki/Matilda_(alt-J_song)" title="Matilda (alt-J song)">Matilda</a>' [sic]. The first line in the lyrics, "this is from Matilda", refer to Leon's last words to Norman Stansfield, shortly before the grenades detonate and take their lives.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Bollywood" title="Bollywood">Bollywood</a> film <i><a href="/wiki/Bichhoo" title="Bichhoo">Bichhoo</a></i> was inspired by <i>Lon: The Professional</i>.</p>
<p>South Korean comedian <a href="/wiki/Park_Myeong-su" title="Park Myeong-su">Park Myeong-su</a> and singer-songwriter <a href="/wiki/IU_(singer)" title="IU (singer)">IU</a> released and performed a song inspired by the film, "Leon", for a bi-annual music festival of South Korea's highly popular variety show, <i><a href="/wiki/Infinite_Challenge" title="Infinite Challenge">Infinite Challenge</a></i>, in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>It has been claimed that Besson has written the script for a sequel, which director <a href="/wiki/Olivier_Megaton" title="Olivier Megaton">Olivier Megaton</a> was to direct and in which Portman would reprise the Mathilda role. Filming was to be delayed until Portman was a bit older. However, in the meantime, Besson left <a href="/wiki/Gaumont_Film_Company" title="Gaumont Film Company">Gaumont Film Company</a> to start his own movie studio, <a href="/wiki/EuropaCorp" title="EuropaCorp">EuropaCorp</a>. Unhappy at Besson's departure, Gaumont Film Company "has held <i>The Professional</i> rights close to the vest  and will not budge". According to Megaton, the sequel will more than likely never happen.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>There is also an extended version of the film, referred to as "international version," "<i>version longue</i>," or "<i>version intgrale</i>". Containing 25minutes of additional footage, it is sometimes called the "<a href="/wiki/Director%27s_Cut" title="Director's Cut" class="mw-redirect">Director's Cut</a>" but Besson refers to the original version as the Director's Cut and the new version as "The Long Version".<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup> According to Luc Besson, this is the version he wanted to release, but for the fact that the extra scenes tested poorly with <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a> preview audiences. The additional material is found in the film's second act, and it depicts more of the interactions and relationship between Lon and Mathilda, as well as explicitly demonstrating how Mathilda accompanies Lon on several of his hits as "a full co-conspirator", to further her training as a contracted killer.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Lon: Version Intgrale</i> was released in France in 1996; in the United States, where the film was originally released as <i>The Professional</i>, it was released on DVD as <i>Lon: The Professional</i> in 2000. Both versions contain the additional footage.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Spirited Away</i></h1>
<p><a href="/wiki/Japanese_yen" title="Japanese yen"></a>30.4 billion<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i><b>Spirited Away</b></i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">Japanese</a>: <span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja"></span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <a href="/wiki/Hepburn_romanization" title="Hepburn romanization">Hepburn</a>: <i>Sen to Chihiro no <a href="/wiki/Spirit_away" title="Spirit away">Kamikakushi</a></i><sup class="t_nihongo_help noprint"><a href="/wiki/Help:Installing_Japanese_character_sets" title="Help:Installing Japanese character sets"><span class="t_nihongo_icon" style="color: #00e; font: bold 80% sans-serif; text-decoration: none; padding: 0 .1em;">?</span></a></sup>, "Sen and Chihiro's Spiriting Away")</span> is a 2001 Japanese <a href="/wiki/Anime" title="Anime">animated</a> <a href="/wiki/Fantasy_film" title="Fantasy film">fantasy film</a> written and directed by <a href="/wiki/Hayao_Miyazaki" title="Hayao Miyazaki">Hayao Miyazaki</a> and produced by <a href="/wiki/Studio_Ghibli" title="Studio Ghibli">Studio Ghibli</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bcdb_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bcdb-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> The film stars <a href="/wiki/Rumi_Hiiragi" title="Rumi Hiiragi">Rumi Hiiragi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Miyu_Irino" title="Miyu Irino">Miyu Irino</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mari_Natsuki" title="Mari Natsuki">Mari Natsuki</a>, Takeshi Naito, <a href="/wiki/Yasuko_Sawaguchi" title="Yasuko Sawaguchi">Yasuko Sawaguchi</a>, Tsunehiko Kamij, Takehiko Ono and <a href="/wiki/Bunta_Sugawara" title="Bunta Sugawara">Bunta Sugawara</a>, and tells the story of Chihiro Ogino (Hiiragi), a sullen ten-year-old girl who, while moving to a new neighborhood, enters the spirit world. After her parents are transformed into pigs by the witch Yubaba (Natsuki), Chihiro takes a job working in Yubaba's <a href="/wiki/Sent%C5%8D" title="Sent">bathhouse</a> to find a way to free herself and her parents and return to the human world.</p>
<p>Miyazaki wrote the script after he decided the film would be based on his friend, associate producer Seiji Okuda's ten-year-old daughter, who came to visit his house each summer.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> At the time, Miyazaki was developing two personal projects, but they were rejected. With a budget of <a href="/wiki/United_States_dollar" title="United States dollar">US$</a>19 million, production of <i>Spirited Away</i> began in 2000. During production, Miyazaki realized the film would be over three hours long and decided to cut out several parts of the story. <a href="/wiki/Pixar" title="Pixar">Pixar</a> director <a href="/wiki/John_Lasseter" title="John Lasseter">John Lasseter</a>, a fan of Miyazaki, was approached by <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_Pictures" title="Walt Disney Pictures">Walt Disney Pictures</a> to supervise an English-language translation for the film's North American release. Lasseter hired <a href="/wiki/Kirk_Wise" title="Kirk Wise">Kirk Wise</a> as director and <a href="/wiki/Donald_W._Ernst" title="Donald W. Ernst">Donald W. Ernst</a> as producer of the adaptation. Screenwriters Cindy Davis Hewitt and Donald H. Hewitt wrote the <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English-language</a> dialogue, which they wrote to match the characters' original <a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">Japanese-language</a> lip movements.<sup id="cite_ref-latimes_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-latimes-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film was released on 20 July 2001, and became the most successful film in Japanese history, grossing about $289 million worldwide and receiving widespread critical acclaim. The film overtook <i><a href="/wiki/Titanic_(1997_film)" title="Titanic (1997 film)">Titanic</a></i> (at the time the top grossing film worldwide) in the Japanese box office to become the <a href="/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_films_in_Japan" title="List of highest-grossing films in Japan">highest-grossing film in Japanese history</a> with a 30.4 billion total. <i>Spirited Away</i> frequently ranks among the <a href="/wiki/Films_considered_the_greatest_ever" title="Films considered the greatest ever" class="mw-redirect">greatest animated films</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Paste_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Paste-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Metadecade_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Metadecade-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> It won the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Animated_Feature" title="Academy Award for Best Animated Feature">Academy Award for Best Animated Feature</a> at the <a href="/wiki/75th_Academy_Awards" title="75th Academy Awards">75th Academy Awards</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Bear" title="Golden Bear">Golden Bear</a> at the 2002 <a href="/wiki/Berlin_International_Film_Festival" title="Berlin International Film Festival">Berlin International Film Festival</a> (tied with <i><a href="/wiki/Bloody_Sunday_(TV_film)" title="Bloody Sunday (TV film)" class="mw-redirect">Bloody Sunday</a></i>) and is among the top ten in the <a href="/wiki/BFI_list_of_the_50_films_you_should_see_by_the_age_of_14" title="BFI list of the 50 films you should see by the age of 14">BFI list of the 50 films you should see by the age of 14</a>.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>Ten-year-old Chihiro Ogino and her parents are traveling to their new home when her father takes a wrong turn. They enter what appears to be an abandoned amusement park, which Chihiro's father insists on exploring. Chihiro's parents sit at an empty but seemingly operational restaurant and begin to devour the fresh food in a piggish manner; meanwhile, Chihiro discovers an exquisite <a href="/wiki/Sent%C5%8D" title="Sent">bathhouse</a> across a bridge, where a young boy named Haku warns her to get out before the impending sunset. Frantically, Chihiro returns to her parents, only to discover that they have transformed into pigs. She attempts to escape, but the way by which they came has since become submerged. Frightened and alone, she observes as the world she ventured into reveals itself as a luxurious retreat for spirits to revitalize themselves.</p>
<p>Haku finds Chihiro and advises her to demand a job from the bathhouse's boiler-man, Kamaji, a <a href="/wiki/Y%C5%8Dkai" title="Ykai">spider-like being</a> who prepares requested treatments for guests. Kamaji and Lin, one of the employees there, send Chihiro to Yubaba, the cruel and tyrannical owner of the bathhouse. While she initially refuses Chihiro's service, Yubaba reluctantly hires her in exchange for her identity, renaming her Sen <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja"></span><sup class="t_nihongo_help noprint"><a href="/wiki/Help:Installing_Japanese_character_sets" title="Help:Installing Japanese character sets"><span class="t_nihongo_icon" style="color: #00e; font: bold 80% sans-serif; text-decoration: none; padding: 0 .1em;">?</span></a></sup>)</span>. Haku takes Sen to visit her parents' pigpen and returns her clothes. Within, Sen finds a goodbye card from a friend with her real name written on it. Haku tells her that Yubaba controls people by taking their names and that she will become trapped in the spirit world if she forgets her name, as he has.</p>
<p>While working, Sen invites a silent, masked creature named No-Face inside the bathhouse, believing him to be a customer. A "stink spirit" subsequently arrives, and Sen is quickly assigned to tend to the guest by her nauseated superiors. She discovers he is actually the powerful guardian spirit of a polluted river. In gratitude for cleaning him, he gives Sen a magic <a href="/wiki/Emetic" title="Emetic" class="mw-redirect">emetic</a> <a href="/wiki/Dumpling" title="Dumpling">dumpling</a>. Sen is congratulated by her gleeful coworkers, who had shunned her as an outsider. Later, while most of the staff sleep, No-Face tempts a worker with gold. The greedy employee takes the bait only to be swallowed whole. No-Face begins demanding food, producing gold to tempt the naive staff. As the workers swarm him, hoping to be tipped, he devours two of them and grows larger.</p>
<p>Sen discovers paper <a href="/wiki/Shikigami" title="Shikigami">shikigami</a> attacking a dragon and recognizes the dragon as Haku transformed. When a grievously-injured Haku crashes into Yubaba's penthouse, Sen follows him upstairs. When she reaches Haku, a shikigami that stowed away on her back transforms into Zeniba, Yubaba's twin sister. She transforms Yubaba's baby son Boh into a mouse, creates a decoy baby, and turns Yubaba's pet bird creature into a tiny, fly-like bird. Zeniba tells Sen that Haku has stolen a magic golden <a href="/wiki/Seal_(emblem)" title="Seal (emblem)">seal</a> from her and warns Sen that it carries a deadly curse. After Haku dives to the boiler room with Sen and Boh on his back, she feeds him part of the dumpling, causing him to vomit both the seal and a black slug, which Sen crushes with her foot.</p>
<p>With Haku unconscious, Sen resolves to return the seal and apologize for Haku. Before she leaves the bathhouse, Sen confronts the now-massive No-Face and feeds him the rest of the dumpling. No-Face chases Sen out of the bathhouse, steadily vomiting out those he has eaten and thus gradually returning to his former self. Sen, No-Face, Boh, and the bird creature travel to see Zeniba. Enraged at the damage caused by No-Face, Yubaba blames Sen for inviting him in and orders that her parents be slaughtered. After Haku reveals that Boh is missing, he promises to retrieve Boh in exchange for Yubaba freeing Sen and her parents.</p>
<p>Sen, No-Face, Boh, and the bird creature arrive at Zeniba's house. Zeniba, now the benevolent "Granny," reveals that Sen's love for Haku broke her curse and that Yubaba had used the black slug to control him. Haku appears in his dragon form and flies both Sen and Boh back to the bathhouse. No-Face unexpectedly shows itself as a very good <a href="/wiki/Spinning_(textiles)" title="Spinning (textiles)">spinner</a> for Zeniba and accepts her proposal to stay as a helper.</p>
<p>On the way back, Sen recalls a memory from her youth in which she had fallen into the Kohaku River while trying to retrieve her fallen shoe but was swept safely ashore. After correctly guessing that Haku is the spirit of the Kohaku River (and thus revealing his real name), Haku is freed from Yubaba's control. When they arrive at the bathhouse, Yubaba tells Sen that in order to break the curse on her parents, she must identify them from among a group of pigs. Sen correctly states that none of the pigs are her parents, releasing her parents from the curse and herself from her contract with Yubaba. Haku takes her to the entrance to the spirit world and promises to see her again in the future. Chihiro reunites with her restored parents, who do not remember what happened. They walk back to their car, which has become covered in fallen leaves and dust after days passed in their absence, and drive away.</p>
<p>Every summer, <a href="/wiki/Hayao_Miyazaki" title="Hayao Miyazaki">Hayao Miyazaki</a> spent his vacation at a mountain cabin with his family and five girls who were friends of the family. The idea for <i>Spirited Away</i> came about when he wanted to make a film for these friends. Miyazaki had previously directed films such as <i><a href="/wiki/My_Neighbor_Totoro" title="My Neighbor Totoro">My Neighbor Totoro</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Kiki%27s_Delivery_Service" title="Kiki's Delivery Service">Kiki's Delivery Service</a></i>, which were for small children and teenagers, but he had not created a film for ten-year-old girls. For inspiration, he read <a href="/wiki/Sh%C5%8Djo_manga" title="Shjo manga">shjo manga</a> magazines like <i><a href="/wiki/Nakayoshi" title="Nakayoshi">Nakayoshi</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Ribon" title="Ribon">Ribon</a></i> the girls had left at the cabin, but felt they only offered subjects on "crushes" and romance. When looking at his young friends, Miyazaki felt this was not what they "held dear in their hearts" and decided to produce the film about a girl heroine whom they could look up to instead.<sup id="cite_ref-nausicaa_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nausicaa-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Miyazaki wanted to produce a new film for years, he previously wrote two project proposals, but they were rejected. The first one was based on the Japanese book <i>Kirino Mukouno Fushigina Machi</i>, and the second one was about a teenage heroine. Miyazaki's third proposal, which ended up becoming <i>Sen and Chihiro Spirited Away</i>, was more successful. The three stories revolved around a bathhouse that was based on a bathhouse in Miyazaki's hometown. Miyazaki thought the bathhouse was a mysterious place, and there was a small door next to one of the bathtubs in the bathhouse. Miyazaki was always curious to what was behind it, and he made up several stories about it; one of which was the inspiration for the bathhouse in <i>Spirited Away</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-nausicaa_11-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nausicaa-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Production of <i>Spirited Away</i> commenced in 2000 on a budget of <a href="/wiki/Japanese_yen" title="Japanese yen"></a>1.9 billion (US$19 million).<sup id="cite_ref-howe_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-howe-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup> Disney invested 10% of the cost for the <a href="/wiki/Right_of_first_refusal" title="Right of first refusal">right of first refusal</a> for American distribution.<sup id="cite_ref-fps_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fps-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup> As with <i><a href="/wiki/Princess_Mononoke" title="Princess Mononoke">Princess Mononoke</a></i>, Miyazaki and the <a href="/wiki/Studio_Ghibli" title="Studio Ghibli">Studio Ghibli</a> staff experimented with computer animation. With the use of more computers and programs such as <a href="/wiki/Autodesk_Softimage" title="Autodesk Softimage">Softimage</a>, the staff learned the software, but kept the technology at a level to enhance the story, not to "steal the show". Each character was mostly hand-drawn, with Miyazaki working alongside his animators to see they were getting it just right.<sup id="cite_ref-howe_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-howe-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup> The biggest difficulty in making the film was to reduce its length. When production started, Miyazaki realized it would be more than three hours long if he made it according to his plot. He had to delete many scenes from the story, and tried to reduce the "eye-candy" in the film because he wanted it to be simple. Miyazaki did not want to make the hero a "pretty girl." At the beginning, he was frustrated at how she looked "dull" and thought, "She isn't cute. Isn't there something we can do?" As the film neared the end, however, he was relieved to feel "she will be a charming woman."<sup id="cite_ref-nausicaa_11-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nausicaa-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Miyazaki based some of the buildings in the spirit world on the buildings in the real-life <a href="/wiki/Edo-Tokyo_Open_Air_Architectural_Museum" title="Edo-Tokyo Open Air Architectural Museum">Edo-Tokyo Open Air Architectural Museum</a> in <a href="/wiki/Koganei,_Tokyo" title="Koganei, Tokyo">Koganei, Tokyo</a>, Japan. He often visited the museum for inspiration while working on the film. Miyazaki had always been interested in the Pseudo-Western style buildings from the <a href="/wiki/Meiji_period" title="Meiji period">Meiji period</a> that were available there. The museum made Miyazaki feel nostalgic, "especially when I stand here alone in the evening, near closing time, and the sun is setting tears well up in my eyes."<sup id="cite_ref-nausicaa_11-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nausicaa-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup> Another major inspiration was the Notoyaryokan, a <a href="/wiki/Ryokan_(Japanese_inn)" title="Ryokan (Japanese inn)" class="mw-redirect">traditional Japanese inn</a> located in <a href="/wiki/Yamagata_Prefecture" title="Yamagata Prefecture">Yamagata Prefecture</a>, famous for its exquisite architecture and ornamental features.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup> The old gold town of <a href="/wiki/Jiufen" title="Jiufen">Jiufen</a> in <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a> also served as an inspirational model for Miyazaki's film.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/D%C5%8Dgo_Onsen" title="Dgo Onsen">Dgo Onsen</a> is also often said to be a key inspiration for the Spirited Away onsen/bathhouse.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Film_score" title="Film score">film score</a> of <i>Spirited Away</i> was composed and conducted by Miyazaki's regular collaborator <a href="/wiki/Joe_Hisaishi" title="Joe Hisaishi">Joe Hisaishi</a>, and performed by the <a href="/wiki/New_Japan_Philharmonic" title="New Japan Philharmonic">New Japan Philharmonic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Record_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Record-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup> The soundtrack received awards at the 56th Mainichi Film Competition Award for Best Music, the <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_International_Anime_Fair" title="Tokyo International Anime Fair">Tokyo International Anime Fair</a> 2001 Best Music Award in the Theater Movie category, and the 17th Japan Gold Disk Award for Animation Album of the Year.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup> Later, Hisaishi added lyrics to "One Summer's Day" and named the new version "The Name of Life" <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja"></span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>"Inochi no Namae"</i><sup class="t_nihongo_help noprint"><a href="/wiki/Help:Installing_Japanese_character_sets" title="Help:Installing Japanese character sets"><span class="t_nihongo_icon" style="color: #00e; font: bold 80% sans-serif; text-decoration: none; padding: 0 .1em;">?</span></a></sup>)</span> which was performed by <a href="/wiki/Ayaka_Hirahara" title="Ayaka Hirahara">Ayaka Hirahara</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The closing song, "Always With Me" <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja"></span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Itsumo Nandodemo</i><sup class="t_nihongo_help noprint"><a href="/wiki/Help:Installing_Japanese_character_sets" title="Help:Installing Japanese character sets"><span class="t_nihongo_icon" style="color: #00e; font: bold 80% sans-serif; text-decoration: none; padding: 0 .1em;">?</span></a></sup>, literally, "Always, No Matter How Many Times")</span> was written and performed by <a href="/wiki/Youmi_Kimura" title="Youmi Kimura">Youmi Kimura</a>, a composer and <a href="/wiki/Lyre" title="Lyre">lyre</a>-player from <a href="/wiki/Osaka" title="Osaka">Osaka</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-yumi_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yumi-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup> The lyrics were written by Kimura's friend Wakako Kaku. The song was intended to be used for <i>Rin the Chimney Painter</i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja"></span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Entotsu-kaki no Rin</i><sup class="t_nihongo_help noprint"><a href="/wiki/Help:Installing_Japanese_character_sets" title="Help:Installing Japanese character sets"><span class="t_nihongo_icon" style="color: #00e; font: bold 80% sans-serif; text-decoration: none; padding: 0 .1em;">?</span></a></sup>)</span>, a different Miyazaki film which was never released.<sup id="cite_ref-yumi_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yumi-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup> In the special features of Japanese DVD, Hayao Miyazaki explains how the song in fact inspired him to create <i>Spirited Away</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-yumi_23-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yumi-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup> The song itself would be recognized as Gold at the <a href="/wiki/43rd_Japan_Record_Awards" title="43rd Japan Record Awards">43rd Japan Record Awards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Besides the original soundtrack, there is also an <a href="/wiki/Image_song" title="Image song">image album</a>, titled <i>Spirited Away Image Album</i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja"></span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Sen to Chihiro no Kamikakushi Imji Arubamu</i><sup class="t_nihongo_help noprint"><a href="/wiki/Help:Installing_Japanese_character_sets" title="Help:Installing Japanese character sets"><span class="t_nihongo_icon" style="color: #00e; font: bold 80% sans-serif; text-decoration: none; padding: 0 .1em;">?</span></a></sup>)</span>, that contains 10 tracks.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Both <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_Pictures" title="Walt Disney Pictures">Walt Disney Pictures</a> and <a href="/wiki/DreamWorks" title="DreamWorks">DreamWorks</a> bid for the US distribution rights.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup> Eventually, <a href="/wiki/Disney" title="Disney" class="mw-redirect">Disney</a> won the rights to dub the English adaptation of <i>Spirited Away</i>, under the supervision of <a href="/wiki/Pixar" title="Pixar">Pixar</a> animator <a href="/wiki/John_Lasseter" title="John Lasseter">John Lasseter</a>.
