A Miyazaki fan, Lasseter would sit with his staff and watch Miyazaki's work when encountering story problems, and at one point they did so with <i>Spirited Away</i>, which impressed Lasseter.<sup id="cite_ref-howe3_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-howe3-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup> Upon hearing his reaction to the film, people at Disney asked Lasseter if he would be interested in trying to bring <i>Spirited Away</i> to an American audience. Lasseter agreed to be executive producer for English adaptation. Soon, several others began to join the project: <i><a href="/wiki/Beauty_and_the_Beast_(1991_film)" title="Beauty and the Beast (1991 film)">Beauty and the Beast</a></i> co-director <a href="/wiki/Kirk_Wise" title="Kirk Wise">Kirk Wise</a> and <i><a href="/wiki/Aladdin_(1992_Disney_film)" title="Aladdin (1992 Disney film)">Aladdin</a></i> co-producer <a href="/wiki/Donald_W._Ernst" title="Donald W. Ernst">Donald W. Ernst</a> joined Lasseter as director and producer of <i>Spirited Away</i> respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-howe3_27-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-howe3-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup> Cindy Davis Hewitt and Donald H. Hewitt penned the <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English-language</a> dialogue, which they wrote to match the characters' original <a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">Japanese-language</a> lip movements.<sup id="cite_ref-latimes_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-latimes-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The cast of the film consisted of <a href="/wiki/Daveigh_Chase" title="Daveigh Chase">Daveigh Chase</a>, <a href="/wiki/Susan_Egan" title="Susan Egan">Susan Egan</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Ogden_Stiers" title="David Ogden Stiers">David Ogden Stiers</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Ratzenberger" title="John Ratzenberger">John Ratzenberger</a>. Advertising was limited, and <i>Spirited Away</i> was only mentioned in a small scrolling section of their film page on Disney's official website. Disney had sidelined their official website for <i>Spirited Away</i> and it remained hidden.<sup id="cite_ref-howe3_27-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-howe3-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup> The promotion of the film was given a worse treatment than Disney's own <a href="/wiki/B-movie" title="B-movie" class="mw-redirect">B-movies</a> by comparison.<sup id="cite_ref-fps_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fps-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup> Marc Hairston argues this was a justified response to Ghibli's retention of the merchandising rights to the film and characters, which imposed a limitation on Disney that did not validate the marketing costs.<sup id="cite_ref-fps_14-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fps-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The major <a href="/wiki/Theme_(arts)" title="Theme (arts)">themes</a> of <i>Spirited Away</i> center on the protagonist Chihiro and her <a href="/wiki/Liminality" title="Liminality">liminal</a> journey through the realm of spirits, wherein Chihiro becomes separated from everything she has known. Chihiro's experience in the alternate world, which may be compared to <a href="/wiki/Lewis_Carroll" title="Lewis Carroll">Lewis Carroll</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland" title="Alice's Adventures in Wonderland">Alice's Adventures in Wonderland</a></i>, represents her passage from childhood to adulthood.<sup id="cite_ref-satoshi3_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-satoshi3-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Archetype" title="Archetype">archetypal</a> entrance into another world demarcates Chihiro's status as one somewhere between child and adult. Chihiro also stands outside societal boundaries in the supernatural setting. The use of the word <a href="/wiki/Kamikakushi" title="Kamikakushi" class="mw-redirect">kamikakushi</a> (literally "hidden by gods") within the Japanese title, and its associated folklore, reinforces this liminal passage: "Kamikakushi is a verdict of 'social death' in this world, and coming back to this world from Kamikakushi meant 'social resurrection.'"<sup id="cite_ref-reider_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reider-29"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Yubaba has many similarities to <a href="/wiki/The_Coachman" title="The Coachman">The Coachman</a> from <i><a href="/wiki/Pinocchio_(1940_film)" title="Pinocchio (1940 film)">Pinocchio</a></i>, in the sense that she transforms humans into pigs in a similar way that the boys of <a href="/wiki/Pleasure_Island_(Pinocchio)" title="Pleasure Island (Pinocchio)" class="mw-redirect">Pleasure Island</a> were transformed into donkeys. Upon gaining employment at the bathhouse, Yubaba's seizure of Chihiro's <a href="/wiki/True_name" title="True name">true name</a> symbolically kills the child,<sup id="cite_ref-satoshi3_28-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-satoshi3-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup> who must then assume adulthood. She then undergoes a <a href="/wiki/Rite_of_passage" title="Rite of passage">rite of passage</a> according to the <a href="/wiki/Monomyth" title="Monomyth">monomyth</a> format; to recover continuity with her past, Chihiro must create a new identity.<sup id="cite_ref-satoshi3_28-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-satoshi3-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Along with its function within the ostensible <a href="/wiki/Coming_of_age" title="Coming of age">coming of age</a> theme, Yubaba's act of taking Chihiro's name and replacing it with Sen (literally, "one thousand"), is symbolic of capitalism's single-minded concern with value, illustrative of the film's exploration of capitalism and its effect on traditional Japanese culture.<sup id="cite_ref-napier_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-napier-30"><span>[</span>30<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Yubaba is stylistically unique within the bathhouse, wearing Western dress and living among European dcor and furnishings, in contrast with the minimalist Japanese style of her employee's quarters, representing the Western capitalist influence over Japan in its <a href="/wiki/Meiji_period" title="Meiji period">meiji period</a> and beyond. The meiji design of the abandoned theme park is the setting for Chihiro's parents' transformation, the father reassuring Chihiro that he has "credit cards and cash", before their morphing into literal consumerist pigs.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Spirited Away</i> contains critical commentary on modern Japanese society concerning generational conflicts and environmental pollution.<sup id="cite_ref-napier_30-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-napier-30"><span>[</span>30<span>]</span></a></sup> Chihiro has been seen as a representation of the <a href="/wiki/Sh%C5%8Djo" title="Shjo">shjo</a>, whose roles and ideology had changed dramatically since post-war Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-napier3_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-napier3-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Just as Chihiro seeks her past identity, Japan, in its anxiety over the economic downturn occurring during the release of the film in 2001, sought to reconnect to past values.<sup id="cite_ref-satoshi3_28-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-satoshi3-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup> In an interview, Miyazaki has commented on this nostalgic element for an old Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-midnight-eye_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-midnight-eye-33"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup> Initially, Chihiro travels past the abandoned fairground, a symbol for Japan's burst <a href="/wiki/Economic_bubble" title="Economic bubble">economic bubble</a>, to reach the fantasy world replete with <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Japan" title="Culture of Japan">Japanese culture</a> and fable in the amalgam of the bathhouse.</p>
<p>However, the bathhouse of the spirits cannot be seen as a place free of ambiguity and darkness.<sup id="cite_ref-thrupkaew_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thrupkaew-34"><span>[</span>34<span>]</span></a></sup> Many of the employees are rude to Chihiro because she is human, and corruption is ever-present;<sup id="cite_ref-napier3_32-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-napier3-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup> it is a place of excess and greed, as depicted in the initial appearance of the No-Face.<sup id="cite_ref-harris_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-harris-35"><span>[</span>35<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In stark contrast to the simplicity of Chihiro's journey and transformation is the constant chaotic carnival in the background.<sup id="cite_ref-napier3_32-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-napier3-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup> The environmental comments concerning the trash deforming the River God and Haku losing his river to apartment complex construction further indicate the sources of pollution within the bathhouse, a place of ritual purity, come from within the <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Japan" title="Culture of Japan">Japanese society</a>.</p>
<p>Additional themes are expressed through the No-Face, who reflects the characters which surround him, learning by example and taking the traits of whomever he consumes. This nature results in No-Face's monstrous rampage through the bath house. After Chihiro saves No-Face with the emetic dumpling, he becomes timid once more. At the end of the film, Zeniba decides to take care of No-Face so it can develop without the negative influence of the bathhouse.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Spirited Away</i> was released theatrically in Japan on 20 July 2001 by distributor <a href="/wiki/Toho" title="Toho">Toho</a>, grossing 30.4 billion to become the <a href="/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_films_in_Japan" title="List of highest-grossing films in Japan">highest-grossing film in Japanese history</a>, according to the Motion Picture Producers Association of Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-WSJ_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WSJ-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup> It was also the first film to earn $200 million at the worldwide box office before opening in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span>[</span>38<span>]</span></a></sup> The film was dubbed into English by <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_Pictures" title="Walt Disney Pictures">Walt Disney Pictures</a>, under the supervision of <a href="/wiki/Pixar" title="Pixar">Pixar</a>'s <a href="/wiki/John_Lasseter" title="John Lasseter">John Lasseter</a>. The dubbed version premiered at the <a href="/wiki/Toronto_International_Film_Festival" title="Toronto International Film Festival">Toronto International Film Festival</a> on 7 September 2002<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39"><span>[</span>39<span>]</span></a></sup> and was later released in North America on 20 September 2002. <i>Spirited Away</i> had very little marketing, less than Disney's other B-films, with at most, 151 theaters showing the film in 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-fps_14-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fps-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup> After the 2003 Oscars, it expanded to as many as 714 theaters. The film grossed US$449,839 in its opening weekend and ultimately grossed around $10 million by September 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-box_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-box-40"><span>[</span>40<span>]</span></a></sup> In addition to its North American earnings of $10 million and Japanese earnings of $250 million, it grossed a further $29 million from other countries for a worldwide total of about $289 million.<sup id="cite_ref-gross_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gross-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> In Argentina, it's in the Top 10 of the anime films with more sold tickets ever.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span>[</span>41<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Spirited Away</i> received widespread critical acclaim from film critics. The film holds a 97% approval rating on the <a href="/wiki/Review_aggregator" title="Review aggregator">review aggregator</a> website <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> based on 178 reviews, with an average rating of 8.6/10, and the consensus: "<i>Spirited Away</i> is a dazzling, enchanting, and gorgeously drawn fairy tale that will leave viewers a little more curious and fascinated by our world."<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span>[</span>42<span>]</span></a></sup> On <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>, the film achieved a weighted average score of 94 out of 100 based on 37 reviews, signifying "universal acclaim".<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span>[</span>43<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Roger_Ebert" title="Roger Ebert">Roger Ebert</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Chicago_Sun-Times" title="Chicago Sun-Times">Chicago Sun-Times</a></i> gave the film a full four stars, praising the film and Miyazaki's direction. Ebert also said that <i>Spirited Away</i> was one of "the year's best films."<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44"><span>[</span>44<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Elvis_Mitchell" title="Elvis Mitchell">Elvis Mitchell</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> positively reviewed the film and praised the animation sequences. Mitchell also drew a favorable comparison to Lewis Carroll's <i><a href="/wiki/Through_the_Looking-Glass" title="Through the Looking-Glass">Through the Looking-Glass</a></i> and also said that his movies are about "moodiness as mood" and the characters "heightens the [film's] tension."<sup id="cite_ref-NYT_review_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT_review-45"><span>[</span>45<span>]</span></a></sup> Derek Elley of <i><a href="/wiki/Variety_(magazine)" title="Variety (magazine)">Variety</a></i> said that <i>Spirited Away</i> "can be enjoyed by sprigs and adults alike" and praised the animation and music.<sup id="cite_ref-variety_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-variety-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kenneth_Turan" title="Kenneth Turan">Kenneth Turan</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times" title="Los Angeles Times">Los Angeles Times</a></i> praised the voice acting and said the film is the "product of a fierce and fearless imagination whose creations are unlike anything a person has seen before". Turan also praised Miyazaki's direction.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46"><span>[</span>46<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Orlando_Sentinel" title="Orlando Sentinel">Orlando Sentinel</a>'</i>s critic Jay Boyar also praised Miyazaki's direction and said the film is "the perfect choice for a child who has moved into a new home."<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span>[</span>47<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In 2010, <i>Rotten Tomatoes</i> ranked <i>Spirited Away</i> as the thirteenth-best animated film on the site.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48"><span>[</span>48<span>]</span></a></sup> In 2005, it was ranked as the twelfth-best animated film of all time by <a href="/wiki/IGN" title="IGN">IGN</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49"><span>[</span>49<span>]</span></a></sup> The film is also ranked No. 9 of the highest-rated movies of all time on <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>, being the highest rated traditionally animated film on the site. The film ranked number 10 in <i><a href="/wiki/Empire_(film_magazine)" title="Empire (film magazine)"><i>Empire</i> magazine</a>'s "The 100 Best Films Of World Cinema"</i> in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50"><span>[</span>50<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In his book <i>Otaku</i>, <a href="/wiki/Hiroki_Azuma" title="Hiroki Azuma">Hiroki Azuma</a> observed: "Between 2001 and 2007, the <a href="/wiki/Otaku" title="Otaku">otaku</a> forms and markets quite rapidly won social recognition in Japan", and cites Miyazaki's win at the Academy Awards for <i>Spirited Away</i> among his examples.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span>[</span>51<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Spirited Away</i> was first released on VHS and DVD format on 19 July 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-JPNreleases_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JPNreleases-57"><span>[</span>57<span>]</span></a></sup> The Japanese DVD releases includes storyboards for the film and the special edition includes a Ghibli <a href="/wiki/DVD_player" title="DVD player">DVD player</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58"><span>[</span>58<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>Spirited Away</i> currently holds the record for most home video copies sold of all-time in Japan with 2,403,000.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span>[</span>59<span>]</span></a></sup> In North America, the film was released on DVD and VHS formats by <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_Studios_Home_Entertainment" title="Walt Disney Studios Home Entertainment">Buena Vista Home Entertainment</a> on 15 April 2003. The attention brought by the Oscar win resulted in the film becoming a strong seller.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60"><span>[</span>60<span>]</span></a></sup> The bonus features include Japanese trailers, a making-of documentary which originally aired on <a href="/wiki/Nippon_Television" title="Nippon Television" class="mw-redirect">Nippon Television</a>, interviews with the North American voice actors, a select storyboard-to-scene comparison and <i>The Art of Spirited Away</i>, a documentary narrated by actor <a href="/wiki/Jason_Marsden" title="Jason Marsden">Jason Marsden</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61"><span>[</span>61<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film was released nationwide in the UK on 12 September 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62"><span>[</span>62<span>]</span></a></sup> It was released on DVD in the UK on 29 March 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63"><span>[</span>63<span>]</span></a></sup> In 2005, it was re-released by <a href="/wiki/Optimum_Releasing" title="Optimum Releasing" class="mw-redirect">Optimum Releasing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64"><span>[</span>64<span>]</span></a></sup> The film was released on Blu-ray format in Japan and the UK in 2014, and was released in North America on 16 June 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65"><span>[</span>65<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66"><span>[</span>66<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>The Curious Case of Benjamin Button</i> (film)</h1>
<p><i><b>The Curious Case of Benjamin Button</b></i> is a 2008 American <a href="/wiki/Romance_film" title="Romance film">romantic</a> <a href="/wiki/Fantasy" title="Fantasy">fantasy</a> <a href="/wiki/Drama_film" title="Drama film" class="mw-redirect">drama film</a> directed by <a href="/wiki/David_Fincher" title="David Fincher">David Fincher</a>. The storyline by <a href="/wiki/Eric_Roth" title="Eric Roth">Eric Roth</a> and <a href="/wiki/Robin_Swicord" title="Robin Swicord">Robin Swicord</a> is loosely based on the 1922 <a href="/wiki/The_Curious_Case_of_Benjamin_Button_(short_story)" title="The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (short story)">short story of the same name</a> by <a href="/wiki/F._Scott_Fitzgerald" title="F. Scott Fitzgerald">F. Scott Fitzgerald</a>. The film stars <a href="/wiki/Brad_Pitt" title="Brad Pitt">Brad Pitt</a> as a man who ages in reverse and <a href="/wiki/Cate_Blanchett" title="Cate Blanchett">Cate Blanchett</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Romantic_interest" title="Romantic interest" class="mw-redirect">love interest</a> throughout his life.</p>
<p>The film was released in North America on December 25, 2008, and on February 6, 2009 in the United Kingdom, to positive reviews. The film went on to receive thirteen <a href="/wiki/81st_Academy_Awards" title="81st Academy Awards">Academy Award</a> nominations, including <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Best Picture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Director" title="Academy Award for Best Director">Best Director</a> for Fincher, <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Actor" title="Academy Award for Best Actor">Best Actor</a> for Pitt and <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actress" title="Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress">Best Supporting Actress</a> for <a href="/wiki/Taraji_P._Henson" title="Taraji P. Henson">Taraji P. Henson</a>, and won three, for <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Art_Direction" title="Academy Award for Best Art Direction" class="mw-redirect">Best Art Direction</a>, <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Makeup" title="Academy Award for Best Makeup" class="mw-redirect">Best Makeup</a> and <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Visual_Effects" title="Academy Award for Best Visual Effects">Best Visual Effects</a>.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>In 2005, elderly Daisy Fuller is on her deathbed in a <a href="/wiki/New_Orleans" title="New Orleans">New Orleans</a> hospital as <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina" title="Hurricane Katrina">Hurricane Katrina</a> approaches; she asks her daughter, Caroline, to read aloud from the diary of Benjamin Button.</p>
<p>From the reading, it is revealed that on the evening of <a href="/wiki/Armistice_Day" title="Armistice Day">November 11, 1918</a>, a boy is born with the appearance and physical maladies of an elderly man. The baby's mother died after giving birth, and the father, Thomas Button, abandons the infant on the porch of a nursing home. Queenie and Mr. "Tizzy" Weathers, workers at the nursing home, find the baby, and Queenie decides to care for him as her own.</p>
<p>Benjamin learns to walk in 1925; he declares it a miracle, after which he uses crutches in place of a wheelchair. On Thanksgiving 1930, Benjamin meets seven-year-old Daisy, whose grandmother lives in the nursing home. He and Daisy become good friends. Later, he accepts work on a <a href="/wiki/Tugboat" title="Tugboat">tugboat</a> captained by Mike Clark. Benjamin also meets Thomas Button, who does not reveal that he is Benjamin's father. In Autumn 1936, Benjamin leaves New Orleans for a long-term work engagement with the tugboat crew; Daisy later is accepted into a dance company in <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a> under choreographer George Balanchine.</p>
<p>In 1941, Benjamin is in <a href="/wiki/Murmansk" title="Murmansk">Murmansk</a>, where he begins having an affair with Elizabeth Abbott, wife of the British Trade Minister. That December, Japan <a href="/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor" title="Attack on Pearl Harbor">attacks Pearl Harbor</a>, thrusting the United States into <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>. Mike volunteers the boat for the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Navy" title="U.S. Navy" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Navy</a>; the crew is assigned to salvage duties. During a patrol, the tugboat finds a sunken U.S. transport and the bodies of many American troops. A German submarine surfaces; Mike steers the tugboat full speed towards it while a German gunner fires on the tugboat, killing most of the crew, including Mike. The tugboat rams the submarine, causing it to explode, sinking both vessels. Benjamin and another crewman are rescued by U.S. Navy ships the next day.</p>
<p>In May 1945, Benjamin returns to New Orleans and reunites with Queenie. A few weeks later, he reunites with Daisy; they go out for dinner. Upon failing to seduce him afterward, she departs. Benjamin later reunites with Thomas Button, who, terminally ill, reveals he is Benjamin's father and wills Benjamin his button company and his estate.</p>
<p>In 1947, Benjamin visits Daisy in New York unannounced but departs upon seeing that she has fallen in love with someone else. In 1954, Daisy's dancing career ends when her leg is crushed in an automobile accident in <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">Paris</a>. When Benjamin visits her, Daisy is amazed by his youthful appearance, but, frustrated by her injuries, she tells him to stay out of her life.</p>
<p>In spring 1962, Daisy returns to New Orleans and reunites with Benjamin. Now of comparable physical age, they fall in love and go sailing together. They return to learn that Queenie has died, then move in together. In 1967, Daisy, who has opened a ballet studio, tells Benjamin that she is pregnant; she gives birth to a girl, Caroline, in the spring of 1968. Believing he can not be a proper father to his daughter due to his reverse aging, Benjamin departs after selling his belongings, leaving a bank account book holding the proceeds behind for Daisy and Caroline; he travels alone during the 1970s.</p>
<p>Benjamin returns to Daisy in 1980. Now married, Daisy introduces him, as a family friend, to her husband and daughter. Daisy admits that he was right to leave; she could not have coped otherwise. She later visits Benjamin at his hotel, where they again share their passion for each other, then part once more.</p>
<p>In 1990, widowed Daisy is contacted by social workers who have found Benjaminnow physically a pre-teen. When she arrives, they explain that he was living in a condemned building and was taken to the hospital in poor physical condition, and that they found her name in his diary. The bewildered social workers also say he is displaying early signs of <a href="/wiki/Dementia" title="Dementia">dementia</a>. Daisy moves into the nursing home in 1997 and cares for Benjamin for the rest of his life. In the spring of 2003, Benjamin dies in Daisy's arms, physically an infant but chronologically 84 years of age. Having finally revealed the story of Caroline's father to her, Daisy dies as <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina" title="Hurricane Katrina">Hurricane Katrina</a> approaches.</p>
<p>Producer <a href="/wiki/Ray_Stark" title="Ray Stark">Ray Stark</a> bought the film rights to do <i><a href="/wiki/The_Curious_Case_of_Benjamin_Button_(short_story)" title="The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (short story)">The Curious Case of Benjamin Button</a></i> in the mid-1980s, and it was optioned by <a href="/wiki/Universal_Pictures" title="Universal Pictures" class="mw-redirect">Universal Pictures</a>. The first choice to direct it was <a href="/wiki/Frank_Oz" title="Frank Oz">Frank Oz</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Martin_Short" title="Martin Short">Martin Short</a> attached for the title role, but Oz could not work out how to make the story work. The film was optioned in 1991 by <a href="/wiki/Steven_Spielberg" title="Steven Spielberg">Steven Spielberg</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Tom_Cruise" title="Tom Cruise">Tom Cruise</a> attached for the lead role, but Spielberg left the project to direct <i><a href="/wiki/Jurassic_Park_(film)" title="Jurassic Park (film)">Jurassic Park</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Schindler%27s_List" title="Schindler's List">Schindler's List</a></i>. Other directors attached were <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Read_Johnson" title="Patrick Read Johnson">Patrick Read Johnson</a> and <a href="/wiki/Agnieszka_Holland" title="Agnieszka Holland">Agnieszka Holland</a>. Stark eventually sold the rights to producers <a href="/wiki/Kathleen_Kennedy_(film_producer)" title="Kathleen Kennedy (film producer)" class="mw-redirect">Kathleen Kennedy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Frank_Marshall_(film_producer)" title="Frank Marshall (film producer)" class="mw-redirect">Frank Marshall</a>, who took the film to <a href="/wiki/Paramount_Pictures" title="Paramount Pictures">Paramount Pictures</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Universal_Pictures" title="Universal Pictures" class="mw-redirect">Universal Pictures</a> still on as a co-production partner. By summer 1994, Maryland Film Office chief Jack Gerbes was approached with the possibility of making the film in <a href="/wiki/Baltimore" title="Baltimore">Baltimore</a>. In October 1998, screenwriter <a href="/wiki/Robin_Swicord" title="Robin Swicord">Robin Swicord</a> wrote for director <a href="/wiki/Ron_Howard" title="Ron Howard">Ron Howard</a> an adapted screenplay of the short story, a project which would potentially star actor <a href="/wiki/John_Travolta" title="John Travolta">John Travolta</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> In May 2000, <a href="/wiki/Paramount_Pictures" title="Paramount Pictures">Paramount Pictures</a> hired screenwriter <a href="/wiki/Jim_Taylor_(writer)" title="Jim Taylor (writer)">Jim Taylor</a> to adapt a screenplay from the short story. The studio also attached director <a href="/wiki/Spike_Jonze" title="Spike Jonze">Spike Jonze</a> to helm the project.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> Screenwriter <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Kaufman" title="Charlie Kaufman">Charlie Kaufman</a> had also written a draft of the adapted screenplay at one point.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> In June 2003, director <a href="/wiki/Gary_Ross" title="Gary Ross">Gary Ross</a> entered final negotiations to helm the project based on a new draft penned by screenwriter <a href="/wiki/Eric_Roth" title="Eric Roth">Eric Roth</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> In May 2004, director <a href="/wiki/David_Fincher" title="David Fincher">David Fincher</a> entered negotiations to replace Ross in directing the film.<sup id="cite_ref-Coin_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Coin-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In May 2005, actors <a href="/wiki/Brad_Pitt" title="Brad Pitt">Brad Pitt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cate_Blanchett" title="Cate Blanchett">Cate Blanchett</a> entered negotiations to star in the film.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> In September 2006, actors <a href="/wiki/Tilda_Swinton" title="Tilda Swinton">Tilda Swinton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jason_Flemyng" title="Jason Flemyng">Jason Flemyng</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taraji_P._Henson" title="Taraji P. Henson">Taraji P. Henson</a> entered negotiations to be cast into the film.<sup id="cite_ref-Swinton_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Swinton-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> The following October, with production yet to begin, actress <a href="/wiki/Julia_Ormond" title="Julia Ormond">Julia Ormond</a> was cast as Daisy's daughter, to whom Blanchett's character tells the story of her love for Benjamin Button.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup> Brad Pitt had collaborated with many of his co-stars in previous films. He co-starred with Ormond in <i><a href="/wiki/Legends_of_the_Fall" title="Legends of the Fall">Legends of the Fall</a></i>, with Flemyng in <i><a href="/wiki/Snatch_(film)" title="Snatch (film)">Snatch</a></i>, with Harris in <i><a href="/wiki/Ocean%27s_Twelve" title="Ocean's Twelve">Ocean's Twelve</a></i>, with Blanchett in <i><a href="/wiki/Babel_(film)" title="Babel (film)">Babel</a></i> and with Swinton in <i><a href="/wiki/Burn_After_Reading" title="Burn After Reading">Burn After Reading</a></i>.</p>
<p>For <i>Benjamin Button</i>, <a href="/wiki/New_Orleans" title="New Orleans">New Orleans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Louisiana" title="Louisiana">Louisiana</a> and the surrounding area was chosen as the filming location for the story to take advantage of the state's production incentives, and shooting was slated to begin in October 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup> Filming of <i>Benjamin Button</i> began on November 6, 2006 in New Orleans. In January 2007, Blanchett joined the shoot.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup> Fincher praised the ease of accessibility to rural and urban sets in New Orleans and said that the recovery from <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina" title="Hurricane Katrina">Hurricane Katrina</a> did not serve as an atypical hindrance to production.<sup id="cite_ref-Ready_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ready-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In March 2007, production moved to <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a> for two more months of filming. <a href="/wiki/Principal_photography" title="Principal photography">Principal photography</a> was targeted to last a total of 150 days. Additional time was needed at visual effects house <a href="/wiki/Digital_Domain" title="Digital Domain">Digital Domain</a> to make the visual effects for the metamorphosis of Brad Pitt's character to the infant stage.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup> The director used a camera system called <a href="/wiki/Mova_(camera_system)" title="Mova (camera system)">Contour</a>, developed by <a href="/wiki/Steve_Perlman" title="Steve Perlman">Steve Perlman</a>, to capture facial deformation data from live-action performances.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Several digital environments for the film were created by Matte World Digital, including multiple shots of the interior of the New Orleans train station, to show architectural alterations and deterioration throughout different eras. The train station was built as a 3D model and lighting and aging effects were added, using Next Limit's Maxwell rendering softwarean architectural visualization tool.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup> Overall production was finished in September 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-Mandeville_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mandeville-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The score to <i>The Curious Case of Benjamin Button</i> was written by French composer <a href="/wiki/Alexandre_Desplat" title="Alexandre Desplat">Alexandre Desplat</a>, who recorded his score with an 87-piece ensemble of the <a href="/wiki/Hollywood_Studio_Symphony" title="Hollywood Studio Symphony">Hollywood Studio Symphony</a> at the Sony Scoring Stage.<sup id="cite_ref-Scoring_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Scoring-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>The Curious Case of Benjamin Button</i> was originally slated for theatrical release in May 2008,<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup> but it was pushed back to November 26, 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup> The release date was moved again to December 25 in the United States, January 16, 2009 in Mexico, February 6 in the United Kingdom, February 13 in Italy<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup> and February 27 in South Africa.</p>
<p>On its opening day, the film opened in the number two position behind <i><a href="/wiki/Marley_%26_Me_(film)" title="Marley &amp; Me (film)">Marley &amp; Me</a></i>, in North America with $11,871,831 in 2,988 theaters with a $3,973 average.<sup id="cite_ref-BoxOfficeMojo_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoxOfficeMojo-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> However, during its opening weekend, the film dropped to the third position behind <i>Marley &amp; Me</i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Bedtime_Stories_(film)" title="Bedtime Stories (film)">Bedtime Stories</a></i> with $26,853,816 in 2,988 theaters with an $8,987 average. The film has come to gross $127.5 million domestically and $206.4 million in foreign markets, with a total gross of $333.9 million.<sup id="cite_ref-BoxOfficeMojo_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoxOfficeMojo-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film has received positive reviews, with Pitt's performance receiving praise. The review aggregator <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> reports that 73% of critics gave the film positive reviews based on 235 reviews.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>, the film received an average score of 70 out of 100, based on 37 reviews.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Yahoo!_Movies" title="Yahoo! Movies">Yahoo! Movies</a> reported the film received a B+ average score from critical consensus, based on 12 reviews.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Todd McCarthy of <i><a href="/wiki/Variety_(magazine)" title="Variety (magazine)">Variety</a></i> magazine gave the film a positive review, calling it a "richly satisfying serving of deep-dish Hollywood storytelling."<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup> Peter Howell of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Toronto_Star" title="The Toronto Star" class="mw-redirect">The Toronto Star</a></i> says: "It's been said that the unexamined life is not worth living. <i>The Curious Case of Benjamin Button</i> suggests an addendum: a life lived backwards can be far more enriching" and describes the film as "a magical and moving account of a man living his life resoundingly in reverse" and "moviemaking at its best."<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup> Rod Yates of <i><a href="/wiki/Empire_(magazine)" title="Empire (magazine)" class="mw-redirect">Empire</a></i> awarded it five out of a possible five stars.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup> Kirk Honeycutt of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter" title="The Hollywood Reporter">The Hollywood Reporter</a></i> felt the film was "superbly made and winningly acted by Brad Pitt in his most impressive outing to date." Honeycutt praised Fincher's directing of the film and noted that the "cinematography wonderfully marries a palette of subdued earthen colors with the necessary CGI and other visual effects that place one in a magical past." Honeycutt states the bottom line about <i>Benjamin Button</i> is that it is "an intimate epic about love and loss that is <a href="/wiki/Cin%C3%A9ma_pur" title="Cinma pur">pure cinema</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-THR_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-THR-29"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/A._O._Scott" title="A. O. Scott">A. O. Scott</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> states: "<i>The Curious Case of Benjamin Button</i>, more than two and a half hours long, sighs with longing and simmers with intrigue while investigating the philosophical conundrums and emotional paradoxes of its protagonists condition in a spirit that owes more to <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Luis_Borges" title="Jorge Luis Borges">Jorge Luis Borges</a> than to <a href="/wiki/F._Scott_Fitzgerald" title="F. Scott Fitzgerald">Fitzgerald</a>." Scott praised director David Fincher and writes "Building on the advances of pioneers like <a href="/wiki/Steven_Spielberg" title="Steven Spielberg">Steven Spielberg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Jackson" title="Peter Jackson">Peter Jackson</a> and <a href="/wiki/Robert_Zemeckis" title="Robert Zemeckis">Robert Zemeckis</a>, Mr. Fincher has added a dimension of delicacy and grace to digital filmmaking" and further states: "While it stands on the shoulders of breakthroughs like <i><a href="/wiki/Minority_Report_(film)" title="Minority Report (film)">Minority Report</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings_(film_series)" title="The Lord of the Rings (film series)">The Lord of the Rings</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Forrest_Gump" title="Forrest Gump">Forrest Gump</a></i>, <i>Benjamin Button</i> may be the most dazzling such hybrid yet, precisely because it is the subtlest." He also stated: "At the same time, like any other lovelike any movieit is shadowed by disappointment and fated to end."<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30"><span>[</span>30<span>]</span></a></sup> On the other hand, Anne Hornaday of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Post" title="The Washington Post">The Washington Post</a></i> states: "There's no denying the sheer ambition and technical prowess of <i>The Curious Case of Benjamin Button</i>. What's less clear is whether it entirely earns its own inflated sense of self-importance" and further says, "It plays too safe when it should be letting its freak flag fly."<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup> Kimberley Jones of the <i><a href="/wiki/Austin_Chronicle" title="Austin Chronicle" class="mw-redirect">Austin Chronicle</a></i> panned the film and states, "Fincher's selling us cheekboned movie stars frolicking in bedsheets and calling it a great love. I didn't buy it for a second."<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Roger_Ebert" title="Roger Ebert">Roger Ebert</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Chicago_Sun-Times" title="Chicago Sun-Times">Chicago Sun-Times</a></i> gave the film two and a half stars out of four, saying that it is "a splendidly made film based on a profoundly mistaken premise." He goes on to elaborate that "the movie's premise devalues any relationship, makes futile any friendship or romance, and spits, not into the face of destiny, but backward into the maw of time."<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup> Peter Bradshaw in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i> called it "166 minutes of twee tedium", giving it one star out of a possible five.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34"><span>[</span>34<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Cosmo Landesman of the <i><a href="/wiki/Sunday_Times" title="Sunday Times" class="mw-redirect">Sunday Times</a></i> wrote: "The film's premise serves no purpose. It's a gimmick that goes on for nearly three hours," concluding "<i>The Curious Case of Benjamin Button</i> is an <a href="/wiki/Anodyne" title="Anodyne">anodyne</a> Hollywood film that offers a safe and sanitised view of life and death. It's <i>Forrest Gump</i> goes backwards," while awarding the film two out of five stars.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35"><span>[</span>35<span>]</span></a></sup> James Christopher in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Times" title="The Times">The Times</a></i> called it "a tedious marathon of smoke and mirrors. In terms of the basic requirements of three-reel drama the film lacks substance, credibility, a decent script and characters you might actually care for"<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup> while Derek Malcolm of London's <i><a href="/wiki/Evening_Standard" title="Evening Standard" class="mw-redirect">Evening Standard</a></i> notes that "never at any point do you feel that there's anything more to it than a very strange story traversed by a film-maker who knows what he is doing but not always why he is doing it."<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film was released on DVD on May 5, 2009 by <a href="/wiki/Paramount_Pictures" title="Paramount Pictures">Paramount</a>, and on Blu-ray and 2-Disc DVD by <a href="/wiki/The_Criterion_Collection" title="The Criterion Collection">The Criterion Collection</a>. The Criterion release includes over three hours of special features, and a documentary about the making of the film.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span>[</span>38<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>As of November 1, 2009 the DVD has sold 2,515,722 DVD copies and has generated $41,196,515 in sales revenue.<sup id="cite_ref-Test_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Test-39"><span>[</span>39<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>The Pursuit of Happyness</i></h1>
<p><i><b>The Pursuit of Happyness</b></i> is a 2006 American <a href="/wiki/Biographical_film" title="Biographical film">biographical</a> <a href="/wiki/Drama_film" title="Drama film" class="mw-redirect">drama film</a> based on <a href="/wiki/Chris_Gardner" title="Chris Gardner">Chris Gardner</a>'s nearly one-year struggle being homeless. Directed by <a href="/wiki/Gabriele_Muccino" title="Gabriele Muccino">Gabriele Muccino</a>, the film features <a href="/wiki/Will_Smith" title="Will Smith">Will Smith</a> as Gardner, a homeless salesman. Smith's son <a href="/wiki/Jaden_Smith" title="Jaden Smith">Jaden Smith</a> co-stars, making his film debut as Gardner's son, Christopher Jr.</p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Screenplay" title="Screenplay">screenplay</a> by <a href="/wiki/Steven_Conrad" title="Steven Conrad">Steven Conrad</a> is based on the best-selling <a href="/wiki/Memoir" title="Memoir">memoir</a> written by Gardner with Quincy Troupe. The film was released on December 15, 2006, by <a href="/wiki/Columbia_Pictures" title="Columbia Pictures">Columbia Pictures</a>. For his performance, Smith was nominated for an <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award" title="Academy Award" class="mw-redirect">Academy Award</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Golden_Globe" title="Golden Globe" class="mw-redirect">Golden Globe</a> for Best Actor.</p>
<p>The unusual spelling of the film's title comes from a <a href="/wiki/Mural" title="Mural">mural</a> that Gardner sees on the wall outside the daycare facility his son attends. He complains to the owner of the daycare that "happiness" is incorrectly spelled as "happyness" and needs to be changed.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>In 1981, <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco" title="San Francisco">San Francisco</a> salesman Chris Gardner (<a href="/wiki/Will_Smith" title="Will Smith">Will Smith</a>) invests his entire life savings in portable <a href="/wiki/Bone_density" title="Bone density">bone density</a> scanners, which he demonstrates to doctors and pitches as a handy quantum leap over standard X-rays. The scanners play a vital role in Chris' life. While he is able to sell most of them, the time lag between the sales and his growing financial demands enrage his already bitter and alienated wife Linda (<a href="/wiki/Thandie_Newton" title="Thandie Newton">Thandie Newton</a>), who works as a hotel maid. The financial instability increasingly erodes their marriage, in spite of them caring for their five-year-old son, Christopher (<a href="/wiki/Jaden_Smith" title="Jaden Smith">Jaden Smith</a>).</p>
<p>While downtown trying to sell one of the scanners, Gardner meets Jay Twistle (Brian Howe), a manager for <a href="/wiki/Dean_Witter_Reynolds" title="Dean Witter Reynolds">Dean Witter Reynolds</a> and impresses him by solving a <a href="/wiki/Rubik%27s_Cube" title="Rubik's Cube">Rubik's Cube</a> during a short taxi ride. After Jay leaves, Gardner lacks money to pay the fare, and chooses to run, resulting in the driver chasing him into a <a href="/wiki/Bay_Area_Rapid_Transit" title="Bay Area Rapid Transit">BART</a> station. Gardner boards a train but loses one of his scanners in the process. His new relationship with Jay earns him the chance to become an intern stockbroker. The day before the interview, Gardner grudgingly agrees to paint his apartment so as to postpone being evicted due to his difficulty in paying the rent. While painting, Gardner is greeted by two policemen at his doorstep, who take him to the station, stating he has to pay for his numerous parking tickets he has accumulated. As part of the sanction, Gardner is ordered to spend the night in jail, complicating his schedule for the interview the next morning. He manages to arrive at Dean Witter's office on time, albeit still in his shabby clothes. Despite his appearance, he impresses the interviewers, and lands an internship. He will be amongst 20 interns competing for a paid position as a <a href="/wiki/Broker" title="Broker">broker</a>.</p>
<p>Gardner's unpaid internship does not please Linda, who eventually leaves for New York. After Gardner bluntly says she is incapable of being a single mother, she agrees that Christopher will remain with his father. Gardner is further set back when his bank account is garnished by the IRS for unpaid income taxes, and he and his young son are evicted. He ends up with less than twenty-two dollars, resulting in them being homeless, and are forced at one point to stay in a restroom at a BART station. Other days, he and Christopher spend nights at a homeless shelter, in BART, or, if he manages to procure cash, at a hotel. Later, Gardner finds the bone scanner that he lost in the station and, after repairing it, sells it to a physician, thus completing all his sales of his scanners.</p>
<p>Disadvantaged by his limited work hours, and knowing that maximizing his client contacts and profits is the only way to earn the broker position, Gardner develops a number of ways to make phone sales calls more efficiently, including reaching out to potential high value customers, defying protocol. One sympathetic prospect who is a top-level pension fund manager even takes him and his son to a <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers" title="San Francisco 49ers">San Francisco 49ers</a> game. Regardless of his challenges, he never reveals his lowly circumstances to his colleagues, even going so far as to lend one of his bosses five dollars for cab fare, a sum that he cannot afford. Concluding his internship, Gardner is called into a meeting with his managers. One of them notes he is wearing a new shirt. Gardner explains it is his last day and thought to dress for the occasion. The manager smiles and says he should wear it again tomorrow, letting him know he has won the coveted full-time position. Fighting back tears, Gardner shakes hands with them, then rushes to his son's daycare to embrace Christopher. They walk down the street, joking with each other and are passed by a man in a business suit (the real Chris Gardner in a cameo appearance). The epilogue reveals that Gardner went on to form his own multimillion-dollar brokerage firm.</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Chris_Gardner" title="Chris Gardner">Chris Gardner</a> realized his story had <a href="/wiki/Hollywood" title="Hollywood">Hollywood</a> potential after an overwhelming national response to an interview he did with <i><a href="/wiki/20/20_(US_television_series)" title="20/20 (US television series)" class="mw-redirect">20/20</a></i> in January 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> He published his autobiography on May 23, 2006, and later became an associate producer for the film. The movie took some liberties with Gardner's true life story. Certain details and events that actually took place over the span of several years were compressed into a relatively short time and although eight-year-old Jaden portrayed Chris as a five-year-old, Gardner's son was just a toddler at the time.</p>
<p>Chris Gardner reportedly thought Smith, an actor best known for his performances in action movies, was miscast to play him. However, he said his daughter Jacintha "set him straight" by saying, "If Smith can <a href="/wiki/Ali_(film)" title="Ali (film)">play Muhammad Ali</a>, he can play you!"<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Var%C3%A8se_Sarabande" title="Varse Sarabande">Varse Sarabande</a> released a soundtrack album with the score composed by <a href="/wiki/Andrea_Guerra_(composer)" title="Andrea Guerra (composer)">Andrea Guerra</a> on January 9, 2007.</p>
<p>Also in the film are brief portions of "<a href="/wiki/Higher_Ground_(Stevie_Wonder_song)" title="Higher Ground (Stevie Wonder song)">Higher Ground</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Jesus_Children_of_America&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jesus Children of America (page does not exist)">Jesus Children of America</a>", both sung by <a href="/wiki/Stevie_Wonder" title="Stevie Wonder">Stevie Wonder</a>, and "Lord, Don't Move the Mountain" by <a href="/wiki/Mahalia_Jackson" title="Mahalia Jackson">Mahalia Jackson</a> and <a href="/wiki/Doris_Akers" title="Doris Akers">Doris Akers</a>, sung by the <a href="/wiki/Glide_Memorial_Church" title="Glide Memorial Church">Glide Ensemble</a>.</p>
<p>The film debuted first at the <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North American</a> box office, earning $27 million during its opening weekend and beating out heavily promoted films such as <i><a href="/wiki/Eragon_(film)" title="Eragon (film)">Eragon</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Charlotte%27s_Web_(2006_film)" title="Charlotte's Web (2006 film)">Charlotte's Web</a></i>. It was Smith's sixth consecutive #1 opening and one of Smith's consecutive $100 million blockbusters. The film grossed $162,586,036 domestically in the US and Canada. In the hope Gardner's story would inspire the down-trodden citizens of <a href="/wiki/Chattanooga,_Tennessee" title="Chattanooga, Tennessee">Chattanooga, Tennessee</a> to achieve financial independence and to take greater responsibility for the welfare of their families, the mayor of Chattanooga organized a viewing of the film for the city's homeless.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> Gardner himself felt that it was imperative to share his story for the sake of its widespread social issues. "When I talk about alcoholism in the household, domestic violence, child abuse, illiteracy, and all of those issuesthose are universal issues; those are not just confined to <a href="/wiki/ZIP_code" title="ZIP code">ZIP codes</a>," he said.<sup id="cite_ref-CNN_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNN-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film was released on <a href="/wiki/DVD" title="DVD">DVD</a> on March 27, 2007 and as of November 2007, US <a href="/wiki/DVD_region_code" title="DVD region code">Region 1</a> DVD sales accounted for an additional $89,923,088 in revenue, slightly less than half of what was earned in its first week of release.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> About 5,570,577 units have been sold, bringing in $90,582,602 in revenue.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film was received generally positively by critics, with Smith receiving widespread acclaim for his performance. Film review site <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> calculated a 67% overall approval based on 171 reviews. The site's critical consensus reads, "Will Smith's heartfelt performance elevates <i>The Pursuit of Happyness</i> above mere melodrama."<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In the <i><a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Chronicle" title="San Francisco Chronicle">San Francisco Chronicle</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Mick_LaSalle" title="Mick LaSalle">Mick LaSalle</a> observed, "The great surprise of the picture is that it's not corny . . . The beauty of the film is its honesty. In its outlines, it's nothing like the usual success story depicted on-screen, in which, after a reasonable interval of disappointment, success arrives wrapped in a ribbon and a bow. Instead, this success story follows the pattern most common in life it chronicles a series of soul-sickening failures and defeats, missed opportunities, sure things that didn't quite happen, all of which are accompanied by a concomitant accretion of barely perceptible victories that gradually amount to something. In other words, it all feels real."<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Manohla Dargis of <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> called the film "a <a href="/wiki/Fairy_tale" title="Fairy tale">fairy tale</a> in <a href="/wiki/Realism_(arts)" title="Realism (arts)">realist</a> <a href="/wiki/Drag_(clothing)" title="Drag (clothing)">drag</a> . . . the kind of entertainment that goes down smoothly until it gets stuck in your <a href="/wiki/Crop_(anatomy)" title="Crop (anatomy)">craw</a> . . . It's the same old bootstraps story, an American dream artfully told, skillfully sold. To that calculated end, the film making is seamless, unadorned, transparent, the better to serve Mr. Smith's warm expressiveness . . . How you respond to this man's moving story may depend on whether you find Mr. Smith's and his son's performances so overwhelmingly winning that you buy the idea that poverty is a function of bad luck and bad choices, and success the result of heroic toil and dreams."<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Peter_Travers" title="Peter Travers">Peter Travers</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone" title="Rolling Stone">Rolling Stone</a></i> awarded the film three out of a possible four stars and commented, "Smith is on the march toward Oscar . . . [His] role needs gravity, smarts, charm, humor and a soul that's not synthetic. Smith brings it. He's the real deal."<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In <i><a href="/wiki/Variety_(magazine)" title="Variety (magazine)">Variety</a></i>, Brian Lowry said the film "is more inspirational than creatively inspiredimbued with the kind of uplifting, afterschool-special qualities that can trigger a major toothache . . . Smith's heartfelt performance is easy to admire. But the movie's painfully earnest tone should skew its appeal to the portion of the audience that, admittedly, has catapulted many cloying TV movies into hits . . . In the final accounting, [it] winds up being a little like the determined salesman Mr. Gardner himself: easy to root for, certainly, but not that much fun to spend time with."<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Kevin Crust of the <i><a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times" title="Los Angeles Times">Los Angeles Times</a></i> stated, "Dramatically it lacks the layering of a <i><a href="/wiki/Kramer_vs._Kramer" title="Kramer vs. Kramer">Kramer vs. Kramer</a></i>, which it superficially resembles . . . Though the subject matter is serious, the film itself is rather slight, and it relies on the actor to give it any energy. Even in a more modest register, Smith is a very appealing leading man, and he makes Gardner's plight compelling . . . <i>The Pursuit of Happyness</i> is an unexceptional film with exceptional performances . . . There are worse ways to spend the holidays, and, at the least, it will likely make you appreciate your own circumstances."<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In the <i><a href="/wiki/St._Petersburg_Times" title="St. Petersburg Times" class="mw-redirect">St. Petersburg Times</a></i>, Steve Persall graded the film B- and added, "[It] is the obligatory feel-good drama of the holiday season and takes that responsibility a bit too seriously . . . the film lays so many obstacles and solutions before its resilient hero that the volume of sentimentality and coincidence makes it feel suspect . . . Neither Conrad's script nor Muccino's redundant direction shows [what] lifted the real-life Chris above better educated and more experienced candidates, but it comes through in the earnest performances of the two Smiths. Father Will seldom comes across this mature on screen; at the finale, he achieves a measure of Oscar-worthy emotion. Little Jaden is a chip off the old block, uncommonly at ease before the cameras. Their real-life bond is an inestimable asset to the on-screen characters' relationship, although Conrad never really tests it with any conflict."<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/National_Review_Online" title="National Review Online" class="mw-redirect">National Review Online</a> has named the film #7 in its list of 'The Best Conservative Movies'. <a href="/wiki/Linda_Chavez" title="Linda Chavez">Linda Chavez</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Center_for_Equal_Opportunity" title="Center for Equal Opportunity">Center for Equal Opportunity</a> wrote, "this film provides the perfect antidote to Wall Street and other Hollywood diatribes depicting the world of finance as filled with nothing but greed."<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Kind Hearts and Coronets</i></h1>
<p><i><b>Kind Hearts and Coronets</b></i> is a British <a href="/wiki/Black_comedy" title="Black comedy">black comedy</a> film of 1949 starring <a href="/wiki/Dennis_Price" title="Dennis Price">Dennis Price</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joan_Greenwood" title="Joan Greenwood">Joan Greenwood</a>, <a href="/wiki/Valerie_Hobson" title="Valerie Hobson">Valerie Hobson</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Alec_Guinness" title="Alec Guinness">Alec Guinness</a>, who famously plays eight distinct characters. The plot is loosely based on the novel <i>Israel Rank: The Autobiography of a Criminal</i> (1907) by <a href="/wiki/Roy_Horniman" title="Roy Horniman">Roy Horniman</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Heffer_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Heffer-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> with the screenplay written by <a href="/wiki/Robert_Hamer" title="Robert Hamer">Robert Hamer</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Dighton" title="John Dighton">John Dighton</a> and the film directed by Hamer. The title refers to a line in <a href="/wiki/Alfred,_Lord_Tennyson" title="Alfred, Lord Tennyson">Tennyson</a>'s poem <i><a href="/wiki/Lady_Clara_Vere_de_Vere" title="Lady Clara Vere de Vere">Lady Clara Vere de Vere</a></i>: "Kind hearts are more than <a href="/wiki/Coronet" title="Coronet">coronets</a>, and simple faith than <a href="/wiki/Normans" title="Normans">Norman</a> blood."<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Kind Hearts and Coronets</i> is listed in <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i> magazine's top 100<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> and also in the <a href="/wiki/BFI_Top_100_British_films" title="BFI Top 100 British films">BFI Top 100 British films</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> In 2011 the film was <a href="/wiki/Film_preservation" title="Film preservation">digitally restored</a> and re-released in selected British cinemas.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>In <a href="/wiki/Edwardian_period" title="Edwardian period" class="mw-redirect">Edwardian</a> <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a>, Louis D'Ascoyne Mazzini (Dennis Price) awaits his <a href="/wiki/Hanging" title="Hanging">hanging</a> the next morning. A <a href="/wiki/Flashback_(narrative)" title="Flashback (narrative)">flashback</a> of the events leading to his sentence ensues, narrated by Louis as he writes his memoirs.</p>
<p>After his mother, a daughter of the seventh Duke of Chalfont, elopes with an Italian opera singer named Mazzini (also played by Price), she is disowned by the aristocratic D'Ascoyne family for marrying beneath her station. The couple are poor but happy, until Mazzini dies upon seeing Louis, his newborn son, for the first time. Louis' mother teaches him her family's pedigree. Louis's only childhood friends are Sibella (<a href="/wiki/Joan_Greenwood" title="Joan Greenwood">Joan Greenwood</a>) and her brother, a local doctor's children.</p>
<p>When Louis leaves school, his mother writes to her kinsman Lord Ascoyne D'Ascoyne, a <a href="/wiki/Private_bank" title="Private bank">private banker</a>, for assistance in launching her son's career, but receives only another snub. Louis is forced to work as an assistant in a draper's shop. When Louis's mother dies, her last request, to be interred in the family <a href="/wiki/Burial_vault_(tomb)" title="Burial vault (tomb)">vault</a>, also goes unanswered.</p>
<p>Sibella ridicules Louis's proposal and instead marries Lionel Holland (<a href="/wiki/John_Penrose_(actor)" title="John Penrose (actor)">John Penrose</a>), a former schoolmate with a rich father. After Louis quarrels with customer Ascoyne D'Ascoyne, the banker's only child, Ascoyne has Louis dismissed from his job. Louis then resolves to kill him and the other seven people (all played by Alec Guinness) ahead of him in succession to the dukedom.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>Note 1<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>After arranging a fatal boating accident for Ascoyne D'Ascoyne, Louis writes a letter of condolence to his victim's father, Lord Ascoyne D'Ascoyne, who relents and employs him as a clerk. Gradually becoming a man of means, Louis rents a bachelor flat in St James's and commences an affair with Sibella.</p>
<p>He next targets Henry D'Ascoyne, a keen amateur photographer. He is also charmed by Henry's wife, Edith (<a href="/wiki/Valerie_Hobson" title="Valerie Hobson">Valerie Hobson</a>). After fatally substituting petrol for paraffin in the lamp of Henry's <a href="/wiki/Darkroom" title="Darkroom">darkroom</a>, Louis attends the funeral and views for the first time the remaining D'Ascoynes.</p>
<p>He later approaches the Reverend Lord Henry D'Ascoyne, posing as a retired colonial bishop, and poisons his <a href="/wiki/Port_(wine)" title="Port (wine)" class="mw-redirect">port</a>.</p>
<p>From the window of his flat, he shoots down the <a href="/wiki/Balloon_(aeronautics)" title="Balloon (aeronautics)">balloon</a> from which the <a href="/wiki/Suffragette" title="Suffragette">suffragette</a> Lady Agatha D'Ascoyne is dropping leaflets over London, remarking: "I shot an arrow in the air. She fell to earth in <a href="/wiki/Berkeley_Square" title="Berkeley Square">Berkeley Square</a>" (parodying <a href="/wiki/Henry_Wadsworth_Longfellow" title="Henry Wadsworth Longfellow">Henry Wadsworth Longfellow</a>'s poem <i>The Arrow and the Song</i>).</p>
<p>General Lord Rufus D'Ascoyne receives a jar of <a href="/wiki/Caviar" title="Caviar">caviar</a>, which explodes when he opens it.</p>
<p>Admiral Lord Horatio D'Ascoyne presents a difficulty, as he rarely sets foot on land, but he conveniently insists on <a href="/wiki/Captain_goes_down_with_the_ship" title="Captain goes down with the ship" class="mw-redirect">going down with his ship</a> after causing a collision at sea. This episode is loosely based on the death of <a href="/wiki/George_Tryon" title="George Tryon">Vice-Admiral Sir George Tryon</a> in 1893.</p>
<p>Edith agrees to marry Louis. They notify Ethelred, the childless, widowed eighth duke, who invites them to spend a few days at the family seat, Chalfont Castle. Ethelred casually informs Louis that he intends to marry again to produce an heir. To forestall this, Louis stages a shooting "accident", but before murdering the duke he reveals his motive.</p>
<p>Lord Ascoyne D'Ascoyne dies from the shock of learning that he has acceded to the dukedom, thus sparing Louis a murder he would have been reluctant to commit. Louis becomes the tenth duke and is welcomed by his new tenants, but his triumph is short-lived: a <a href="/wiki/Scotland_Yard" title="Scotland Yard">Scotland Yard</a> detective arrests him for murder.</p>
<p>Lionel had been found dead following Louis's rejection of his drunken plea for help to avoid bankruptcy. When Louis is charged with his murder, he elects to be <a href="/wiki/Privilege_of_peerage#Trial_by_peers" title="Privilege of peerage">tried by his peers</a> in the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Lords" title="House of Lords">House of Lords</a>. During the trial, Louis and Edith are married. Sibella, in love with him and having an inkling of Louis' crimes, falsely testifies that Lionel was about to seek a divorce, naming Louis as <a href="/wiki/Co-respondent" title="Co-respondent">co-respondent</a>. Ironically, Louis is convicted of a death that he had not even contemplated.</p>
<p>Louis is visited in prison by Sibella, who observes that the discovery of Lionel's suicide note and the sudden death of Edith would free Louis and enable them to marry, a tacit proposal to which he agrees. Moments before the hanging, news of the discovery of the suicide note reaches the prison governor.</p>
<p>Outside the prison, Louis finds both Edith and Sibella waiting for him. Pondering his dilemma, he quotes from <i><a href="/wiki/The_Beggar%27s_Opera" title="The Beggar's Opera">The Beggar's Opera</a></i>: "How happy could I be with either, Were t'other dear charmer away!" When a reporter approaches to tell him that <i><a href="/wiki/Tit-Bits" title="Tit-Bits">Tit-Bits</a></i> magazine wishes to publish his memoirs, Louis suddenly remembers the detailed written confession he left in his cell.</p>
<p>To satisfy the <a href="/wiki/Hays_Office_Production_Code" title="Hays Office Production Code" class="mw-redirect">Hays Office Production Code</a>, the film was <a href="/wiki/Censorship" title="Censorship">censored</a> for the American market.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> Ten seconds were added to the ending, showing Louis's memoirs being discovered before he can retrieve them. The dialogue between Louis and Sibella was altered to play down their adultery; derogatory lines aimed at the Reverend Henry D'Ascoyne were deleted; and in the nursery rhyme "<a href="/wiki/Eeny,_meeny,_miny,_moe" title="Eeny, meeny, miny, moe">Eeny, meeny, miny, moe</a>", <i>sailor</i> replaced the word <i><a href="/wiki/Nigger" title="Nigger">nigger</a></i> (restored to the original dialogue, in the 2011 Criterion Collection DVD set). The American version is six minutes shorter than the British original.</p>
<p>Guinness was originally offered only four D'Ascoyne parts, recollecting: "I read [the screenplay] on a beach in France, collapsed with laughter on the first page, and didn't even bother to get to the end of the script. I went straight back to the hotel and sent a telegram saying, 'Why four parts? Why not eight!?'"<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The exterior location used for Chalfont, the family home of the D'Ascoynes, is <a href="/wiki/Leeds_Castle" title="Leeds Castle">Leeds Castle</a> in <a href="/wiki/Kent" title="Kent">Kent</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup> The interior was filmed at Ealing Studios.</p>
<p>The village scenes were filmed in the Kent village of <a href="/wiki/Harrietsham" title="Harrietsham">Harrietsham</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Bosley_Crowther" title="Bosley Crowther">Bosley Crowther</a>, critic for the <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">New York Times</a></i>, calls it a "delicious little satire on Edwardian manners and morals" in which "the sly and adroit Mr. Guinness plays eight Edwardian fuddy-duds with such devastating wit and variety that he naturally dominates the film."<sup id="cite_ref-NYT_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-11"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> Praise is also given to Price ("as able as Mr. Guinness in his single but most demanding role"), as well as Greenwood and Hobson ("provocative as women in his life").<sup id="cite_ref-NYT_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-11"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Roger_Ebert" title="Roger Ebert">Roger Ebert</a> lists <i>Kind Hearts and Coronets</i> among his "Great Movies",<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup> stating "Price is impeccable as the murderer: Elegant, well-spoken, a student of demeanor", and notes that "murder, Louis demonstrates, ... can be most agreeably entertaining".<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Reviewer <a href="/wiki/Simon_Heffer" title="Simon Heffer">Simon Heffer</a> notes the plot of the original <a href="/wiki/Roy_Horniman" title="Roy Horniman">Roy Horniman</a> novel was darker (e.g., the murder of a child) and differed in several respects. A major difference was that the main character was the half-Jewish (as opposed to half-Italian) Israel Rank, and Heffer noted that "...his ruthless using of people (notably women) and his greedy pursuit of position all seem to conform to the stereotype that the <a href="/wiki/Anti-Semitism" title="Anti-Semitism" class="mw-redirect">anti-semite</a> has of the Jew."<sup id="cite_ref-Heffer_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Heffer-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The death of Admiral Horatio D'Ascoyne was inspired by a true event: the collision between <a href="/wiki/HMS_Victoria_(1887)" title="HMS Victoria (1887)">HMS <i>Victoria</i></a> and <a href="/wiki/HMS_Camperdown_(1885)" title="HMS Camperdown (1885)">HMS <i>Camperdown</i></a> off <a href="/wiki/Tripoli,_Lebanon" title="Tripoli, Lebanon">Tripoli</a> in 1893 because of an order given by Vice-Admiral Sir George Tryon. Sir George chose to go down with his ship, saying "It was all my fault."<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup> The <i>Victoria</i> was sunk, losing over 300 men (including the admiral).</p>
<p>The film has been adapted for radio, including a version produced on <a href="/wiki/BBC_Radio_4" title="BBC Radio 4">BBC Radio 4</a> featuring <a href="/wiki/Robert_Powell" title="Robert Powell">Robert Powell</a> as the entire D'Ascoyne clan, including Louis, and <a href="/wiki/Timothy_Bateson" title="Timothy Bateson">Timothy Bateson</a> as the hangman (first broadcast in 1990),<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup> and another for <a href="/wiki/BBC7" title="BBC7" class="mw-redirect">BBC7</a> featuring <a href="/wiki/Michael_Kitchen" title="Michael Kitchen">Michael Kitchen</a> as Mazzini and <a href="/wiki/Harry_Enfield" title="Harry Enfield">Harry Enfield</a> as the D'Ascoyne family.</p>
<p>On 19 May 2012, <a href="/wiki/BBC_Radio_4" title="BBC Radio 4">BBC Radio 4</a> broadcast a sequel to the film called <i>Kind Hearts and Coronets  Like Father, Like Daughter</i>. In it, Unity Holland (played by Natalie Walter), the daughter of Louis and Sibella, is written out of the title by Lady Edith D'Ascoyne. Unity then murders the entire D'Ascoyne family, with all seven members played by <a href="/wiki/Alistair_McGowan" title="Alistair McGowan">Alistair McGowan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In 2013, a musical version entitled <i><a href="/wiki/A_Gentleman%27s_Guide_to_Love_and_Murder" title="A Gentleman's Guide to Love and Murder">A Gentleman's Guide to Love and Murder</a></i> opened at the <a href="/wiki/Walter_Kerr_Theater" title="Walter Kerr Theater" class="mw-redirect">Walter Kerr Theater</a> on Broadway to critical acclaim. The show has all the victims played by the same actor, in the original company <a href="/wiki/Jefferson_Mays" title="Jefferson Mays">Jefferson Mays</a>. Though the plot remains essentially the same, most of the names are changed - half-Italian Louis Mazzini becomes half-Castilian Montague Navarro, the D'Ascoynes become the D'Ysquiths, and Henry's wife Edith beomes Henry's sister Phoebe. Although the musical was developed as a faithful adaptation of the film, a rights issue prompted the removal of any material originating in the film, and the musical is officially based on the same Roy Horniman novel the film takes its basis from.. The musical won four <a href="/wiki/Tony_Award" title="Tony Award">Tony Awards</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Tony_Award_for_Best_Musical" title="Tony Award for Best Musical">Best Musical</a>.</p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Criterion_Collection" title="Criterion Collection" class="mw-redirect">Criterion Collection</a> released a two DVD disc set (Disc One: The Film, and Disc Two: The Supplements); Disc One featured the standard 'UK' version of the film, and as a bonus feature Disc One also included the final scene with the American ending. Disc Two includes a 75-minutes BBC TV Omnibus documentary "Made in Ealing", plus a 68-minute talk-show appearance with Alec Guinness on the BBC TV Parkinson Show.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup> UK distributor <a href="/wiki/Optimum_Releasing" title="Optimum Releasing" class="mw-redirect">Optimum Releasing</a> released a digitally restored version for both DVD and <a href="/wiki/Blu-ray" title="Blu-ray">Blu-ray</a> on 5 September 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>The Mechanic</i> (2011 film)</h1>
<p><i><b>The Mechanic</b></i> is a 2011 American action thriller film starring <a href="/wiki/Jason_Statham" title="Jason Statham">Jason Statham</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ben_Foster" title="Ben Foster">Ben Foster</a>. Directed by <a href="/wiki/Simon_West" title="Simon West">Simon West</a>, it is a remake of the <a href="/wiki/The_Mechanic_(1972_film)" title="The Mechanic (1972 film)">1972 film of the same name</a>, directed by <a href="/wiki/Michael_Winner" title="Michael Winner">Michael Winner</a>, starring <a href="/wiki/Charles_Bronson" title="Charles Bronson">Charles Bronson</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jan-Michael_Vincent" title="Jan-Michael Vincent">Jan-Michael Vincent</a>.
