Statham stars as Arthur Bishop, a professional assassin who specializes in making his hits look like accidents, suicides or the acts of petty criminals.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> It was released in the United States and Canada on <span class="nowrap">January 28</span>, 2011. <a href="/wiki/Mechanic:_Resurrection" title="Mechanic: Resurrection">A sequel</a> is due for release in 2016.</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>Arthur Bishop works as a "<a href="/wiki/Hitman" title="Hitman" class="mw-redirect">mechanic</a>". He sneaks into the lavish home of a Colombian Drug Cartel leader and discreetly drowns him in his own pool. Upon returning to his home in Louisiana, he later meets with his friend and mentor, Harry McKenna, who pays Bishop for his work.</p>
<p>Later, Bishop finds that his new assignment is to kill Harry. Bishop's employer confirms by phone that the contract is correct, whereupon Bishop requests a face-to-face meeting. Dean tells Bishop about a failed mission in <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">South Africa</a>, in which assassins of Bishop's agency were killed. Dean relates that only two people knew about the missionhimself and Harryand that Harry had been paid for the contract details. Bishop reluctantly kills Harry with his own gun and makes it look like a <a href="/wiki/Carjacking" title="Carjacking">carjacking</a>. At Harry's funeral, Bishop meets Harry's reckless son Steve, who swears vengeance anyway he can. Bishop stops Steve from trying to bait and kill a would-be carjacker and decides to train him as a mechanic. He adopts a <a href="/wiki/Chihuahua_(dog)" title="Chihuahua (dog)">chihuahua</a> and instructs Steve to take the dog with him to a coffee shop each day at the same time. As Steve settles in to his routine, Bishop escalates his training by taking him to observe a contract kill.</p>
<p>Bishop later gives Steve a contract of his own. The target is a mechanic for another agency named Burke, who frequents the same coffee shop as Steve. Burke's only weaknesses are that he is interested in young men and small dogs. Burke makes his move on Steve and invites him out for drinks. Bishop instructs Steve to slip a large dose of <a href="/wiki/Flunitrazepam" title="Flunitrazepam">Rohypnol</a> into Burke's drink to cause an <a href="/wiki/Drug_overdose" title="Drug overdose">overdose</a>. Steve ignores the instructions and instead goes with Burke to his apartment. Burke begins to undress, and Steve attempts to <a href="/wiki/Strangle" title="Strangle" class="mw-redirect">strangle</a> him with a belt as Bishop had done with an earlier assignment. Steve manages to kill Burke after much effort and a lengthy fight. Dean expresses his disapproval of Bishop's use of Steve for the Burke contract, but Bishop replies that he was given that contract through Harry and not Dean.</p>
<p>Bishop is given a contract to kill Andrew Vaughn, the leader of a <a href="/wiki/Cult" title="Cult">cult-like church</a>. Steve and Bishop plan to inject Vaughn with <a href="/wiki/Adrenaline" title="Adrenaline" class="mw-redirect">adrenaline</a> to simulate a <a href="/wiki/Heart_attack" title="Heart attack" class="mw-redirect">heart attack</a>, for which the paramedics would administer a fatal dose of <a href="/wiki/Epinephrine" title="Epinephrine">epinephrine</a>. A doctor arrives and sets Vaughn up with an <a href="/wiki/Intravenous_therapy" title="Intravenous therapy">IV</a> of <a href="/wiki/Ketamine" title="Ketamine">ketamine</a>, which would inhibit the epinephrine's effects. They improvise and suffocate him in his hotel room, but are discovered and forced into a shootout with the guards. They slip out while the building is being evacuated and fly home separately.</p>
<p>At the airport, Bishop sees a supposed victim of the mission that Harry allegedly sold out. Bishop realizes that Dean had tricked him into killing Harry, and that Dean engineered the failed mission to cover up his own shady dealings. Later, Bishop is ambushed by a hit squad. After killing them, he discovers that Dean was behind the hit. Bishop goes home to call Steve, only to find that Steve has also been ambushed at Bishop's house. Bishop directs Steve to a hidden gun, which Steve uses to kill his ambushers. Bishop has Steve gather supplies for their new mission while he plots how to get to Dean. In the process, Steve finds his father's gun and realizes that Bishop killed Harry.</p>
<p>Bishop and Steve kill Dean in an ambush. On the way back, Bishop notices Steve carrying Harry's gun. When they stop for gas, Steve floods the ground with fuel while pretending to fill the truck. He walks to a safe distance and shoots the gas, blowing up Bishop's truck with Bishop still inside. Steve returns to Bishop's house and performs two actions that Bishop told him not to do: playing a record on the <a href="/wiki/Phonograph" title="Phonograph">turntable</a>, and taking the 1966 <a href="/wiki/Jaguar_E-Type" title="Jaguar E-Type">Jaguar E-Type</a> Bishop had been working on. As he is driving away, Steve notices a note on the passenger seat: "Steve, if you're reading this, then you're dead!" Moments later, the car explodes, killing him. At the same time, Bishop's house also explodes. Back at the gas station, a security video reveals that Bishop had escaped from the truck, seconds before the explosion. Bishop gets into a spare truck he had by the beach and drives away.</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Irwin_Winkler" title="Irwin Winkler">Irwin Winkler</a> and <a href="/wiki/Robert_Chartoff" title="Robert Chartoff">Robert Chartoff</a>, producers of the 1972 original <i>Mechanic</i>, sought to make an update. Pre-rights to the remake were sold in February 2009 at the <a href="/wiki/Berlin_Film_Festival" title="Berlin Film Festival" class="mw-redirect">Berlin Film Festival</a>. (<i>Variety</i> reported that the screenplay was written by Karl Gajdusek.) Director Simon West and <a href="/wiki/Jason_Statham" title="Jason Statham">Jason Statham</a> were announced as part of the project three months later.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ben_Foster" title="Ben Foster">Ben Foster</a> and <a href="/wiki/Donald_Sutherland" title="Donald Sutherland">Donald Sutherland</a> were cast alongside Statham in October 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> Filming began in <a href="/wiki/New_Orleans" title="New Orleans">New Orleans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Louisiana" title="Louisiana">Louisiana</a> on <span class="nowrap">October 14</span> and lasted for nine weeks.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> Filming locations included <a href="/wiki/St._Tammany_Parish,_Louisiana" title="St. Tammany Parish, Louisiana">St. Tammany Parish</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_New_Orleans" title="World Trade Center New Orleans">World Trade Center</a> in downtown New Orleans<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> and the Algiers Seafood Market.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The soundtrack music is by Mark Isham, with two exceptions:</p>
<p>All songs written and composed by <a href="/wiki/Mark_Isham" title="Mark Isham">Mark Isham</a>.</p>
<p><i>The Mechanic</i> was released in the United States and Canada on <span class="nowrap">January 28</span>, 2011. Millennium Films sold U.S. distribution rights to <a href="/wiki/CBS_Films" title="CBS Films">CBS Films</a> for the release. It was expected to perform well with male audiences, with its release a week before <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLV" title="Super Bowl XLV">Super Bowl XLV</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><span id="Box_office"></span> The film grossed <span class="nowrap">$11.4 million</span> on its opening weekend in the U.S. and Canada. To date it has grossed a total of <span class="nowrap">$29.1 million</span> in those countries and <span class="nowrap">$16.7 million</span> in other territories, for a worldwide total after a recount of over $51 million.<sup id="cite_ref-bo-mojo_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bo-mojo-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><span id="Reception"></span><span id="Critics"></span></p>
<p>Review aggregator <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> gives <i>The Mechanic</i> a score of 53% based on reviews from 156 critics, and reports a rating average of 5.6 out of 10.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup> At <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>, which assigns a weighted average score out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, the film received an average score of 49% based on 35 reviews.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Roger_Ebert" title="Roger Ebert">Roger Ebert</a> awarded the film two out of four stars and said, "Audiences have been drilled to accept noise and movement as entertainment. It is done so well one almost forgets to ask why it has been done at all."<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>On 1 June 2011, the <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a> website confirmed that the TV advertisement for this film had been banned from television by the Advertising Watchdog.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The TV commercial was broadcast during the teen show <i><a href="/wiki/Glee_(TV_series)" title="Glee (TV series)">Glee</a></i> and received 13 viewer complaints.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2014)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The advert reportedly showed "a man's head exploding" and showed a "stream of violent imagery" according to the <a href="/wiki/Advertising_Standards_Authority_(United_Kingdom)" title="Advertising Standards Authority (United Kingdom)">Advertising Standards Authority</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2014)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Dennis_Gansel" title="Dennis Gansel">Dennis Gansel</a> will direct a sequel, with <a href="/wiki/Jason_Statham" title="Jason Statham">Jason Statham</a> returning as Arthur Bishop.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Lord of War</i></h1>
<p><i><b>Lord of War</b></i> is a 2005 <a href="/wiki/Crime_film" title="Crime film">crime</a> <a href="/wiki/War_film" title="War film">war film</a><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> written, produced and directed by <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Niccol" title="Andrew Niccol">Andrew Niccol</a> and co-produced by and starring <a href="/wiki/Nicolas_Cage" title="Nicolas Cage">Nicolas Cage</a>. It was released in the United States on September 16, 2005, with the <a href="/wiki/DVD" title="DVD">DVD</a> following on January 17, 2006 and the <a href="/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc" title="Blu-ray Disc" class="mw-redirect">Blu-ray Disc</a> on July 27, 2006. Cage plays an illegal <a href="/wiki/Arms_dealer" title="Arms dealer" class="mw-redirect">arms dealer</a>, inspired by the stories of several real-life arms dealers and smugglers.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> The film was officially endorsed by the human rights group <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a> for highlighting the <a href="/wiki/Arms_trafficking" title="Arms trafficking">arms trafficking</a> by the international <a href="/wiki/Arms_industry" title="Arms industry">arms industry</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>The film begins with a <a href="/wiki/Voice-over" title="Voice-over">voice-over</a> introduction by Yuri Orlov (Nicolas Cage), a <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian-American" title="Ukrainian-American" class="mw-redirect">Ukrainian-American</a> <a href="/wiki/Arms_trafficking" title="Arms trafficking">gunrunner</a>: Over 550 million firearms worldwide means one firearm per twelve people on the planet; he wonders how to arm the other eleven. Opening credits are set to the <a href="/wiki/Buffalo_Springfield" title="Buffalo Springfield">Buffalo Springfield</a> song "<a href="/wiki/For_What_It%27s_Worth_(Buffalo_Springfield_song)" title="For What It's Worth (Buffalo Springfield song)">For What It's Worth</a>", and depict the life of a <a href="/wiki/7.62%C3%9739mm" title="7.6239mm">7.6239mm</a> cartridge from construction in a <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> weapons factory, to being shipped across the world to an African warzone, loaded into the magazine of an <a href="/wiki/AK-47" title="AK-47">AK-47</a>, and fired into the head of a child soldier.</p>
<p>In the early 1980s, Yuri is visiting a <a href="/wiki/Brighton_Beach" title="Brighton Beach">Brighton Beach</a> restaurant, where a <a href="/wiki/Russian_Mafia" title="Russian Mafia" class="mw-redirect">Russian mobster</a> kills two would-be assassins. He is inspired to go into the arms trade, comparing the constant need for weapons to the similar human need for food. At his father's synagogue, he contacts an Israeli to obtain an illegal <a href="/wiki/Uzi" title="Uzi">Uzi</a>. After completing the first sale, Yuri convinces his brother Vitaly (<a href="/wiki/Jared_Leto" title="Jared Leto">Jared Leto</a>) to become his partner, and they leave their jobs at the family restaurant behind.</p>
<p>Yuri's first big break comes in the <a href="/wiki/1982_Lebanon_War" title="1982 Lebanon War">1982 Lebanon War</a>, when he sells guns to all sides of the conflict, despite witnessing war crimes and atrocities. As Yuri becomes more successful in the war's aftermath, his business comes to the attention of <a href="/wiki/Interpol" title="Interpol">Interpol</a>, and in particular idealistic agent Jack Valentine (<a href="/wiki/Ethan_Hawke" title="Ethan Hawke">Ethan Hawke</a>). Valentine is after glory rather than money, making it impossible for Yuri to bribe him as he does other government agents within Interpol and elsewhere in 1989.</p>
<p>During a sale in Colombia, a <a href="/wiki/Drug_lord" title="Drug lord">drug lord</a> pays with six kilos of <a href="/wiki/Cocaine" title="Cocaine">cocaine</a> instead of cash, and shoots Yuri with one of his own pistols when the two argue. Yuri relents, later finding the sale of the cocaine paid better than money would have. After sampling their profits, Vitaly becomes heavily addicted and absconds with an entire kilogram, prompting a lengthy search before he is discovered in a remote village. After several months, Yuri checks Vitaly into <a href="/wiki/Drug_rehabilitation" title="Drug rehabilitation">rehab</a>, and continues alone. He lures childhood crush Ava Fontaine (<a href="/wiki/Bridget_Moynahan" title="Bridget Moynahan">Bridget Moynahan</a>) to a false photo shoot and subsequently marries her. They later have a son, Nikolai (Nicky).</p>
<p>Yuri's second big break is the <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">dissolution of the Soviet Union</a>. After <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev" title="Mikhail Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a> resigns on Christmas Day 1991, Yuri flies to <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> and illegally buys tanks and weapons through his uncle, a former <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet</a> General. Expansion to Africa leads to Andre Baptiste Sr. (<a href="/wiki/Eamonn_Walker" title="Eamonn Walker">Eamonn Walker</a>), a ruthless dictator waging a never-ending civil war in <a href="/wiki/Liberia" title="Liberia">Liberia</a>. During one flight into Africa, Yuri's cargo plane is intercepted and forced to land by a fighter jet commandeered by Jack Valentine and Interpol. He escapes arrest by landing outside the nearby city, and by simply handing out the cargo to locals, he ensures no weapons are on the plane by the time Valentine arrives. Surveillance of Yuri and his activities continues at his home in the United States, however. Unable to charge Yuri, Valentine tells Ava he is an <a href="/wiki/Arms_trafficking" title="Arms trafficking">arms dealer</a>, prompting her to confront him and demand he stop his illegal business. For a time, Yuri agrees, but Andre Baptiste Sr. offers him even more money and soon he goes back.</p>
<p>Yuri soon goes to complete a sale in Africa in 2001, where a militia force allied with Andre Baptiste Sr. is visibly preparing to destroy a refugee camp. When Vitaly sees the militia hack an escaping woman and child to death with a <a href="/wiki/Machete" title="Machete">machete</a>, he pleads with Yuri to walk away. Yuri refuses; if he backs out, the militia will simply kill the Orlov brothers along with the refugees. Stricken with guilt, Vitaly steals a pair of grenades, destroying one of the weapons trucks and killing Baptiste Jr. Before he can reach the second truck, he is gunned down by RUF soldiers. Before expiring, Vitaly attempts to arm the remaining grenade but is prevented by Yuri, who surrenders it to the soldiers. Yuri reluctantly accepts half of the original diamond payment for the remaining weapons.</p>
<p>At home, Ava has discovered Yuri's cache of his arms dealing activities. She leaves with their son while Yuri's parents disown him after learning the circumstances surrounding the death of Vitaly and the true extent of Yuri's activities. When the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Customs" title="U.S. Customs" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Customs</a> finds a bullet in Vitaly's corpse, Valentine arrests Yuri, who predicts correctly that a knock at the door will signal his release as a "necessary evil" who distributes weapons so major governments can deny involvement. Despite his losses, Yuri returns to arms dealing. Yuri remarks that it's what he does best, and that arms dealers are most likely to inherit the world one day "because everyone else is too busy killing each other." His final advice to the viewer is, "Never go to war, especially with yourself."</p>
<p>An onscreen postscript states that private dealers conduct less business than the five largest arms exporters the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>, and <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> who are the five permanent members of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a>.</p>
<p>Plot details on the illegal arms market, particularly regarding purchases for <a href="/wiki/West_Africa" title="West Africa">West Africa</a> in early 1990s, are closely based on real stories and people originating from the former <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>.</p>
<p>The conflicts portrayed in the film are all real conflicts in real countries, particularly those in <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sudan" title="Sudan">Sudan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liberia" title="Liberia">Liberia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Leone" title="Sierra Leone">Sierra Leone</a>. Conversely, the image of <a href="/wiki/Interpol" title="Interpol">Interpol</a> as an acting <a href="/wiki/Security_agency" title="Security agency">security agency</a> is entirely fictional.</p>
<p>Some of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian language</a> dialogues in the film (mostly those by <a href="/wiki/Yevgeni_Lazarev" title="Yevgeni Lazarev">Eugene Lazarev</a> as Gen. Orlov) contain very obscene <a href="/wiki/Mat_(Russian_profanity)" title="Mat (Russian profanity)">Russian mat</a> wording, translated by far softer expressions in the original English <a href="/wiki/Subtitles" title="Subtitles" class="mw-redirect">subtitles</a>. It is unclear whether these pieces were part of the script, or Lazarev's <a href="/wiki/Improvisation" title="Improvisation">improvisation</a>.</p>
<p>A scene in the film featured 50 tanks, which were provided by a Czech source. The tanks were only available until December of the year of filming, as the dealer needed them to sell in Libya.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup> The production team rented 3000 real SA <a href="/wiki/Vz._58" title="Vz. 58">Vz. 58</a> rifles to stand in for AK 47s because they were cheaper than prop guns.<sup id="cite_ref-NZ_Herald_10345429_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NZ_Herald_10345429-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Lord of War</i> received fairly positive reviews from critics; the film received a 61% rating on <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a>; the consensus states: "While <i>Lord of War</i> is an intelligent examination of the gun trade, it is too scattershot in its plotting to connect."<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup> The film also received a special mention for excellence in filmmaking from the <a href="/wiki/National_Board_of_Review" title="National Board of Review">National Board of Review</a>.</p>
<p>It received a 62/100 score from <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film grossed $9,390,144 on its opening weekend, ranking #3 at the North American box office behind <i><a href="/wiki/Just_Like_Heaven_(film)" title="Just Like Heaven (film)" class="mw-redirect">Just Like Heaven</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Exorcism_of_Emily_Rose" title="The Exorcism of Emily Rose">The Exorcism of Emily Rose</a></i>. After the film's 7 weeks of release it grossed a total of $24,149,632 on the domestic market in the US, and $48,467,436 overseas, for a worldwide total of $72,617,068.<sup id="cite_ref-bom_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bom-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The UK DVD release of <i>Lord of War</i> includes, prior to the film, an advert for <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a>, showing the <a href="/wiki/AK-47" title="AK-47">AK-47</a> being sold on a <a href="/wiki/Shopping_channel" title="Shopping channel">shopping channel</a> of the style popular on <a href="/wiki/Cable_network" title="Cable network" class="mw-redirect">cable networks</a>. The American DVD release includes a bonus feature that shows the various weapons used in the film, allowing viewers to click on each weapon to get statistics about their physical dimensions and histories. The DVD bonus section also contains a <a href="/wiki/Public_service_announcement" title="Public service announcement">public service announcement</a> from Nicolas Cage that addresses the issue of illicit arms sales.</p>
<//body><//html><html><body><h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>Atonement</i> (film)</h1>
<p>United Kingdom</p>
<p><i><b>Atonement</b></i> is a 2007 British <a href="/wiki/Romance_film" title="Romance film">romantic</a> <a href="/wiki/Drama_film" title="Drama film" class="mw-redirect">drama</a> <a href="/wiki/War_film" title="War film">war film</a> directed by <a href="/wiki/Joe_Wright" title="Joe Wright">Joe Wright</a> and based on <a href="/wiki/Ian_McEwan" title="Ian McEwan">Ian McEwan</a>'s 2001 <a href="/wiki/Atonement_(novel)" title="Atonement (novel)">novel of the same name</a>. The film stars <a href="/wiki/James_McAvoy" title="James McAvoy">James McAvoy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Keira_Knightley" title="Keira Knightley">Keira Knightley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saoirse_Ronan" title="Saoirse Ronan">Saoirse Ronan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romola_Garai" title="Romola Garai">Romola Garai</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vanessa_Redgrave" title="Vanessa Redgrave">Vanessa Redgrave</a>, chronicles a crime and its consequences over the course of six decades, beginning in the 1930s. It was produced by <a href="/wiki/Working_Title_Films" title="Working Title Films">Working Title Films</a> and filmed in England. Distributed in most of the world by <a href="/wiki/Universal_Studios" title="Universal Studios">Universal Studios</a>, it was released in the United Kingdom and Ireland on 7 September 2007 and in North America on 7 December 2007.</p>
<p><i>Atonement</i> opened both the 2007 <a href="/wiki/Vancouver_International_Film_Festival" title="Vancouver International Film Festival">Vancouver International Film Festival</a> and the <a href="/wiki/64th_Venice_International_Film_Festival" title="64th Venice International Film Festival">64th Venice International Film Festival</a>, making Wright, at the age of 35, the youngest director ever to open the latter event. A commercial success, the film earned a worldwide gross of approximately $129 million against a budget of $30 million. Critics gave the drama positive reviews, praising its acting performances, its <a href="/wiki/Cinematography" title="Cinematography">cinematography</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dario_Marianelli" title="Dario Marianelli">Dario Marianelli</a>'s score.</p>
<p><i>Atonement</i> won an <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award" title="Academy Award" class="mw-redirect">Oscar</a> for <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Score" title="Academy Award for Best Original Score">Best Original Score</a> at the <a href="/wiki/80th_Academy_Awards" title="80th Academy Awards">80th Academy Awards</a>, and was nominated for six others, including <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Best Picture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Adapted_Screenplay" title="Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay">Best Adapted Screenplay</a> and <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actress" title="Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress">Best Supporting Actress</a> for Ronan.<sup id="cite_ref-NomineesOscars2007_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NomineesOscars2007-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> It also garnered fourteen nominations at the <a href="/wiki/61st_British_Academy_Film_Awards" title="61st British Academy Film Awards">61st British Academy Film Awards</a>, winning both <a href="/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Film" title="BAFTA Award for Best Film">Best Film</a> and <a href="/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Production_Design" title="BAFTA Award for Best Production Design">Production Design</a>, and won the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Motion_Picture_%E2%80%93_Drama" title="Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture  Drama">Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture  Drama</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-WinnersBAFTA2007_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WinnersBAFTA2007-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>In 1935, Briony Tallis is a 13-year-old girl from a wealthy English family and has just finished writing a play. Briony attempts to stage the play with her three visiting cousins, twin boys and their teenage sister, Lola; however, they get bored and decide to go swimming. Briony stays behind and witnesses a significant moment of <a href="/wiki/Sexual_tension" title="Sexual tension">sexual tension</a> between her older sister, Cecilia, and Robbie Turner, a servant's son (a man that Briony has a childish infatuation with). Robbie returns home and writes several drafts of letters to Cecilia, including one that is explicitly sexual and erotically charged. Initially written for the sake of humour, he does not intend to send it and sets it aside. On his way to join the Tallis family for dinner, Robbie asks Briony to deliver his letter, only to later realise that he has mistakenly given her the prurient draft. Briony secretly reads the letter and is simultaneously disgusted and jealous. She tells Lola of its contents and they call Robbie a sex maniac while debating whether to turn him into the police. That afternoon, Lola and her younger brothers meet a friend of the Tallis family, a wealthy chocolate manufacturer named Paul Marshall. Though he is much older than her, he excites Lola by flirting with her and treating her like an adult.</p>
<p>That evening, Cecilia confronts Robbie about the letter which she has since read. They meet in the library where they make love and tenderly confess their love for one another. During the act, Briony watches through the partially open door and her confused emotions about Robbie become heightened. At dinner it is revealed that Lola's twin brothers have run away; a search party is sent out and Briony goes off alone into the woods looking for them. She eventually stumbles upon a man running away from apparently raping Lola. Lola claims that she does not know the identity of her attacker, but then claims it was Robbie after Briony suggests that it must have been the sex maniac who attacked her. In a fit of pique, the still-hurt Briony tells everyone (including the police) that she saw Robbie commit the act. She shows Robbie's shocking letter to her mother and the police. Everyone believes Briony's story except for Cecilia and Robbie's mother; Robbie is arrested and sent to prison.</p>
<p>Four years later, Robbie is released from prison on condition that he join the <a href="/wiki/British_Army" title="British Army">army</a>. He is assigned to A Company, 1st Battalion, <a href="/wiki/Royal_Sussex_Regiment" title="Royal Sussex Regiment">Royal Sussex Regiment</a> and sent to France, where he is separated from his unit and attempts to return to them at <a href="/wiki/Dunkirk" title="Dunkirk">Dunkirk</a> on foot. He is then shown reuniting with Cecilia (who has not spoken with her family since the incident) in London six months earlier, where they renew their love before he is shipped off to the French front. Briony, now 18, has joined Cecilia's old nursing corps at St. Thomas's in London because she wants to be of some practical use to society after giving up an offer she received from Cambridge. Her attempts at contacting her sister go unanswered as Cecilia cannot forgive her for Robbie's unjust imprisonment. Robbie, gravely ill and wounded, finally arrives at the beaches of Dunkirk where he waits to be <a href="/wiki/Dunkirk_evacuation" title="Dunkirk evacuation">evacuated</a>.</p>
<p>Sometime later, Brionyat last fully understanding the consequences of her false accusationvisits the now-married Cecilia and Robbie to apologise to them directly. However, her apologies are rather weak and ineffectual; Cecilia coldly replies that she will never forgive her, while Robbie, in a rage that almost becomes physical, confronts Briony and demands that she immediately tell her family and the authorities the truth. Briony admits she knew all along that the real rapist was Paul Marshall, but that Lola cannot testify against him in a court of law because they have recently been married.</p>
<p>Decades later, an elderly Briony (now a published author) gives an interview about her latest book, a semi-autobiographical novel called Atonement. She reveals that she is dying of <a href="/wiki/Vascular_dementia" title="Vascular dementia">vascular dementia</a> and states that this last book is one she has been working on for most of her adult life. Briony confesses that the book's ending (in which she apologises to a married Cecilia and Robbie) is fictional: Cecilia and Robbie were never married and never saw each other again once he left for war. In reality, Robbie died at Dunkirk of <a href="/wiki/Sepsis" title="Sepsis">septicemia</a> while awaiting evacuation and Cecilia died a few months later as one of the flood victims in the <a href="/wiki/Balham_station#Second_World_War" title="Balham station">Balham tube station</a> bombing during <a href="/wiki/The_Blitz" title="The Blitz">The Blitz</a>. Briony hopes that by reuniting them in fiction she can give them the happy ending they always deserved. The last scene of the movie shows a happy Cecilia and Robbie together once again in what could either be afterlife or a figment of Briony's imagination.</p>
<p>The film was produced by <a href="/wiki/Working_Title_Films" title="Working Title Films">Working Title Films</a> and filmed throughout the summer of 2006 in Great Britain.<sup id="cite_ref-CastCrew2_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CastCrew2-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>These mainly were:</p>
<p>The other places across London were <a href="/wiki/Great_Scotland_Yard" title="Great Scotland Yard">Great Scotland Yard</a> and Bethnal Green Town Hall, the latter being used for a 1939 tea-house scene, as well as the church of <a href="/wiki/St_John%27s,_Smith_Square" title="St John's, Smith Square">St John's, Smith Square</a>, <a href="/wiki/City_of_Westminster" title="City of Westminster">Westminster</a> for Lola's wedding. Re-enactment of the 1940 <a href="/wiki/Balham_station" title="Balham station">Balham station</a> disaster took place in the former <a href="/wiki/Piccadilly_line" title="Piccadilly line">Piccadilly line</a> station of <a href="/wiki/Aldwych_tube_station" title="Aldwych tube station">Aldwych</a>, closed since the 1990s.</p>
<p>War scenes (in the French countryside) were filmed in <a href="/wiki/Coates,_Cambridgeshire" title="Coates, Cambridgeshire">Coates</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gedney_Drove_End" title="Gedney Drove End" class="mw-redirect">Gedney Drove End</a>, Lincolnshire; <a href="/wiki/Walpole_St_Andrew" title="Walpole St Andrew" class="mw-redirect">Walpole St Andrew</a> and <a href="/wiki/Denver,_Norfolk" title="Denver, Norfolk">Denver, Norfolk</a>; and in <a href="/wiki/Manea,_Cambridgeshire" title="Manea, Cambridgeshire">Manea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pymoor,_Cambridgeshire" title="Pymoor, Cambridgeshire" class="mw-redirect">Pymoor, Cambridgeshire</a>.</p>
<p>Much of the St Thomas's hospital ward interior was filmed at <a href="/wiki/Park_Place,_Berkshire" title="Park Place, Berkshire">Park Place, Berkshire</a> and exterior at <a href="/wiki/University_College_London" title="University College London">University College London</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-WildAbout_6-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WildAbout-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>All the exteriors and interiors of the Tallis family home were at the house mentioned selected from an old <i><a href="/wiki/Country_Life_(magazine)" title="Country Life (magazine)">Country Life</a></i> edition to tie in with the period and pool fountain of the novel.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup> This mansion was built in 1889 commissioned by the glove manufacturer John Derby Allcroft. It remains an undivided family home.</p>
<p>The third portion of <i>Atonement</i> was entirely filmed at the <a href="/wiki/BBC_Television_Centre" title="BBC Television Centre">BBC Television Centre</a>, London. The beach with cliffs first shown on the postcard and later seen towards the end of the film was <a href="/wiki/Cuckmere_Haven" title="Cuckmere Haven">Cuckmere Haven</a> <a href="/wiki/Seven_Sisters,_Sussex" title="Seven Sisters, Sussex">Seven Sisters, Sussex</a> (near to <a href="/wiki/Roedean_School" title="Roedean School">Roedean School</a>, which Cecilia was said to have attended).</p>
<p>The film opened the 2007 <a href="/wiki/64th_Venice_International_Film_Festival" title="64th Venice International Film Festival">Venice International Film Festival</a>, making Wright, at 35, the youngest director ever to be so honoured.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup> The film also opened the 2007 <a href="/wiki/Vancouver_International_Film_Festival" title="Vancouver International Film Festival">Vancouver International Film Festival</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>Atonement</i> was released in the United Kingdom and Ireland on 7 September 2007,<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup> and in North America on 7 December 2007. Worldwide distribution was managed by <a href="/wiki/Universal_Studios" title="Universal Studios">Universal Studios</a>, with minor releases through other divisions.<sup id="cite_ref-CastCrew2_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CastCrew2-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film grossed $129,266,061 worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-BoxOfficeMojo_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoxOfficeMojo-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> The film was released in the United Kingdom and Ireland on 7 September 2007, and grossed 11,557,134. It was also given a <a href="/wiki/Limited_release" title="Limited release">limited release</a> in North America on 7 December, and grossed $784,145 during its opening weekend, posting a per-cinema average of $24,504 in 32 cinemas.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2011)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<p>The film received positive reviews from film critics. The review site <a href="/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" title="Rotten Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> records that 83% of 196 critics gave the film positive reviews, with a consensus that "<i>Atonement</i> features strong performances, brilliant cinematography and a unique score. Featuring deft performances from James McAvoy and Keira Knightley, it's a successful adaptation of Ian McEwan's novel."<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup> On other review sites, <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">Metacritic</a> records an average score of 85%, based on 36 reviews.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In Britain, the film was listed as #3 on <i><a href="/wiki/Empire_(magazine)" title="Empire (magazine)" class="mw-redirect">Empire</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s Top 25 Films of 2007. The Australian edition of <i>Empire</i> gave it a five-star review, praising Wright's direction in the second half of the film, where he demonstrates "storytelling and technical flair to match his ability with actors".<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>Time</i> magazine's <a href="/wiki/Richard_Corliss" title="Richard Corliss">Richard Corliss</a> named the film one of the Top 10 Movies of 2007, ranking it at #4. Corliss praised the film as "first beguiling, then devastating", and singled out <a href="/wiki/Saoirse_Ronan" title="Saoirse Ronan">Saoirse Ronan</a> as "terrific as the confused 12-year-old."<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The American critic <a href="/wiki/Roger_Ebert" title="Roger Ebert">Roger Ebert</a> gave it a four-star review, dubbing it "one of the year's best films, a certain best picture nominee."<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup> In the film review television program, <i><a href="/wiki/At_the_Movies_with_Ebert_%26_Roeper" title="At the Movies with Ebert &amp; Roeper" class="mw-redirect">At the Movies with Ebert &amp; Roeper</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Richard_Roeper" title="Richard Roeper">Richard Roeper</a> gave the film "thumbs up" adding that Knightley gave "one of her best performances". As for the film, he commented that: "<i>Atonement</i> has hints of greatness but it falls just short of Oscar contention."<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2011)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<p>A censored and dubbed version of <i>Atonement</i> was shown to an extremely limited audience in North Korea at the <a href="/wiki/Pyongyang_International_Film_Festival" title="Pyongyang International Film Festival">Pyongyang International Film Festival</a> in 2008. The <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times" title="Los Angeles Times">Los Angeles Times</a> reported that "Screenings of two British films, <i>Atonement</i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Elizabeth:_The_Golden_Age" title="Elizabeth: The Golden Age">Elizabeth: The Golden Age</a></i>, were so crowded that guards had to bar the doors to prevent gate-crashers."<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film appeared on many critics' top ten lists of the best films of 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The film has received numerous awards and nominations, including seven <a href="/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award" title="Golden Globe Award">Golden Globe</a> nominations, more than any other film nominated at the <a href="/wiki/65th_Golden_Globe_Awards" title="65th Golden Globe Awards">65th Golden Globe Awards</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup> and winning two of the nominated Golden Globes, including Best Motion Picture Drama. The film also received 14 <a href="/wiki/BAFTA_Award" title="BAFTA Award" class="mw-redirect">BAFTA</a> nominations for the <a href="/wiki/61st_British_Academy_Film_Awards" title="61st British Academy Film Awards">61st British Academy Film Awards</a> including Best Film, Best British Film and Best Director, seven <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award" title="Academy Award" class="mw-redirect">Academy Award</a> nominations, including <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Best Picture</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Evening_Standard_British_Film_Awards" title="Evening Standard British Film Awards">Evening Standard British Film Award</a> for Technical Achievement in Cinematography, Production Design and Costume Design, earned by <a href="/wiki/Seamus_McGarvey" title="Seamus McGarvey">Seamus McGarvey</a>, Sarah Greenwood and <a href="/wiki/Jacqueline_Durran" title="Jacqueline Durran">Jacqueline Durran</a>, respectively. <i>Atonement</i> also ranks 442nd on <i>Empire</i> magazine's 2008 list of the 500 greatest movies of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Atonement</i> has been named among the Top 10 Films of 2007 by the Austin Film Critics Association, the <a href="/wiki/Dallas-Fort_Worth_Film_Critics_Association" title="Dallas-Fort Worth Film Critics Association" class="mw-redirect">Dallas-Fort Worth Film Critics Association</a>, the <a href="/wiki/National_Board_of_Review" title="National Board of Review">National Board of Review</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_Film_Critics_Online" title="New York Film Critics Online">New York Film Critics Online</a></i>, the Oklahoma Film Critics Circle, and the Southeastern Film Critics Association.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34"><span>[</span>34<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35"><span>[</span>35<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span>[</span>38<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Southeastern_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Southeastern-39"><span>[</span>39<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><i>Atonement</i> was released on <a href="/wiki/DVD" title="DVD">DVD</a> on 4 February 2008 in <a href="/wiki/DVD_region_codes" title="DVD region codes" class="mw-redirect">region 2</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/HD_DVD" title="HD DVD">HD DVD</a> edition followed on 11 March 2008. The North American DVD and <a href="/wiki/HD_DVD" title="HD DVD">HD DVD</a>/DVD combo editions (USA/Canada) were released on 18 March 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span>[</span>40<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span>[</span>41<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc" title="Blu-ray Disc" class="mw-redirect">Blu-ray</a> was released on 26 January 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span>[</span>42<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
